                 July 7, 1980, Monday, Late City Final Edition

NUMBER OF ALIEN ARRESTS FALLS AS BORDER PATROL IS SRETCHED THIN

BYLINE: By JOHN M. CREWDSON, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 12, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1457 words

DATELINE: HOUSTON, July 6


Despite fears that Mexico's worst harvest in three decades is propelling record
numbers of aliens northward in search of work, immigration officers have been
apprehending fewer illegal entrants this year than last year.

But officials of the Immigration and Naturalization Service say that the lower
figures on captures are no indication that the predicted influx is not under
way. Rather, they say, the data reflect the fact that the nation's border
defenses have been stretched thinner than at any time in recent years.

The service's personnel and operating funds have been seriously strained in
recent months by the unanticipated need to register tens of thousands of Iranian
students and to process more than a hundred thousand Cuban refugees.

Further, the service has been ordered to restrict some searching for illegal
aliens as a way of helping the Census Bureau overcome its problems in counting
them. And a more mundate concern, the big increases in gasoline prices, has also
had a serious impact on its operations.

Numbers of Arrests

In the first four months of this year, the latest period for which figures are
available, 302,300 aliens, most of them from Mexico, were arrested after
entering the United States illegally. That figure is 25,000 fewer than were
captured in the same period last year, and fewer even than in the same period in
1978. Illegal immigration from Mexico increases sharply in February and begins
to decline again in October, as aliens return to their families for the
Christmas holidays.

Because of the unusual demands placed on the immigration service, officials
said, it was impossible to say whether the anticipated sharp increase in illegal
immigration was taking place. The lower number of apprehensions, they said,
might simply have resulted from fewer officers patrolling the border in recent
months.

The capture data are the only actual numbers the Government has that reflect,
however imprecisely, the scale of illegal migration across the border.

''Had we had operations as usual, we might have been able to establish some kind
of a trend,'' said Herb Walsh, the chief of the United States Border Patrol's
Tucson sector, which is responsible for a 265-mile stretch of border. But Mr.
Walsh said he had noted that ''the bulk of the people we're apprehending here
are coming from the interior of Mexico and not from the border states.''

Other Nations Feed the Flow

Mr. Walsh added that an increasing number of aliens flowing across the border
were what the Border Patrol calls ''OTM's,'' for ''other than Mexican.'' These
tend to come from the ''troubled triangle'' - the countries of Nicaragua,
Guatemala and El Salvador, all of which have undergone recent political upheaval
- and generally enter the country with the aid of one of the burgeoning number
of illicit organizations engaged in the criminal smuggling of aliens, he said.

Today, officials in Arizona reported that at least 13 in a group of Salvadorans
brought across the border by smugglers had perished in 110-degree heat after
they were abandoned without water in the Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument,
near Ajo, Ariz., a favorite crossing point for illegal aliens.

The disastrous harvest, the result of an unusually dry fall and an early frost,
hit hardest at small subsistence farmers in central and northwest Mexico whose
croplands lacked irrigation.

Wayne Cornelius, a professor of political science at the University of
California's San Diego campus and a leading expert on Mexican migration, has
called the drought ''a classic short-term subsistence crisis'' and warned that
the affected farmers, who in normal times would probably not become illegal
immigrants, were ''not going to sit in their villages and starve.''

Mr. Cornelius said last January that many of the anticipated new arrivals were
likely to seek out jobs in urban service industries, such as hotels and
restaurants, rather than try for one of a declining number of agricultural jobs
in the South and West.

New Requirement of Warrant

Because of the census, however, the immigration service has been restricted
since April in its efforts to search for illegal aliens at homes and places of
business. The new requirement that the service obtain a warrant for such
searches was extended earlier this week until July 30, to the further dismay of
many Border Patrol officers.

''It's policy, but it hurts,'' said a senior Border Patrol official in El Paso.
Mr. Walsh asserted that the policy had ''created a sanctuary for the illegal
alien once he penetrates the border.'' It often is impossible to obtain
traditional search warrants for raids of homes and businesses, he said,
''because so much of our information comes in anonymously.''

Foremost among the other difficulties that have beset the immigration service
over the past six months are two special undertakings for which no extra funds
were budgeted.

Immigration officials said that checking the student status of some 50,000
Iranians had tied up investigators in Texas, California and other parts of the
country for months. ''While the investigators were working on the Iranian
project,'' one said, ''they weren't out arresting people.''

The second major drain on the service's resources, officials said, came when
scores of Border Patrol agents from Texas and Arizona were reassigned to Florida
in April, May and June to help process the Cubans.

The Border Patrol's strength in the Southwest was reduced by about one-fifth,
and its budget was depleted to the point where patrol vehicles were going
unrepaired and the utility bills unpaid.  ''There's no question that all this
has strained our resources,'' said Verne Jervis, a spokesman for the immigration
service in Washington.

In addition, the rising price of gasoline was not anticipated in the service's
budget. Along some parts of the border, gasoline was limited to three gallons
for each vehicle over an eight-hour shift.  ''If you have less fuel to transport
people and to transport officers to their areas, you're just not going to make
as many apprehensions,'' Mr. Jervis said. ''When the sheriff calls and says, 'I
have a dozen people here,' we can't come and pick them up.''

El Paso, which, after San Ysidro, Calif., is the second busiest international
port of entry in the world, lost 50 of its 350 Border Patrol officers to Florida
during the Cuban influx, and officials at El Paso said that another 20 officers
had been taken from patrol duty to replace immigration inspectors who had also
been detailed to Florida.

With little gasoline, the shortage of personnel and the restrictions on searches
of businesses, an El Paso officer said, ''we were forced to re-evaluate our
priorities.''

Largely out of desperation, the El Paso sector adopted a ''high profile
deterrent strategy'' of placing its remaining officers in more or less
stationary positions along the north bank of the Rio Grande in hopes that
potential border crossers would be dissuaded by a show of force.

But Mr. Jervis said there were serious questions about how effective the high
profile strategy had been.  The Border Patrol believes that it has long been
denied the manpower and machinery, such as rough-terrain vehicles and
helicopters, it needs to perform with any success its mission of halting illegal
immigration.

But there is a growing conviction in Washington, reflected in the Carter
Administration's budget for the 1981 fiscal year, which begins next Oct. 1, that
the addition of more border guards is not the solution to the problem of illegal
immigration.

The Administration is not prepared to commit more resources to defending the
border, officials said, until it sees the results of a White House-directed
management study of the agency that is now under way.

The immigration service's budget of $347 million for the fiscal year 1981,
contains an increase of less than 4 percent. Given an inflation rate hovering in
the double-digit range, the increase amounts to a substantial decrease in real
terms.

A recent survey of senior Border Patrol officers found an overwhelming opinion
that the 2,000-mile-long border with Mexico could be virtually sealed with the
addition of another 3,500 border patrolmen. The patrol's uniformed strength
nationwide is 2,081 officers, down from 2,213 at this time last year, of which
95 percent are stationed along the Mexican border.

''Give them a million men,'' one immigration official said the other day, ''and
they'd want a million-five.' Among other considerations, the official said,
addition of more officers might simply mean that the same aliens would be
apprehended more frequently before they finally evaded detection and
successfully entered the United States.

PANEL FINDS FLAWS IN IMMIGRATION LAW

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 27, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 994 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13


The United States Commission on Civil Rights, in a report to be issued next
week, says that immigration laws, as written by Congress and enforced by the
Justice Department, are riddled with discrimination that deprives many aliens of
their constitutional rights.

''The current Immigration and Nationality Act still contains discriminatory
provisions,'' says the 158-page report. ''The current practices and procedures
for the enforcement of that statute result in the denial of rights to American
citizens and to documented and undocumented aliens.''

The commission, an independent, bipartisan body, said that raids conducted by
Federal agents in pursuit of illegal aliens sometimes resulted in
''unconstitutional searches and seizures''; that some local police departments,
in attempting to enforce the immigration laws, had violated the constitutional
rights of American citizens and permanent resident aliens; and that,
''notwithstanding the consequences of the penalty of deportation, aliens subject
to deportation hearings receive less due process protection than defendants in
criminal proceedings.''

Three of the five commissioners who participated in the development of the
report said they opposed the creation of a compulsory national identification
card, the use of compulsory work permits or the enactment of a statute to
penalize employers who hire illegal aliens. A separate Federal commission is
considering such proposals, including the issuance of identity cards to all
citizens and aliens authorized to work in the United States.

Warning on Penalizing Employers

However, the Commission on Civil Rights said, ''A national identity card would
provide a tool that could be used to violate the right to privacy of the
individual.''

Moreover, a majority of the commissioners, including the chairman, Arthur S.
Flemming, warned that a law penalizing employers who hire illegal aliens ''would
have the undesired effect of causing employers to discriminate against easily
identifiable minority groups whose members, although legally in the United
States, might be mistaken for undocumented aliens.''

Two members of the commission issued separate dissenting statements on this
question. In support of an employer sanctions law, one commissioner, Frankie M.
Freeman, said that the Federal Government should make it ''more difficult for
persons entering illegally to secure employment'' by developing an
identification system ''which will minimize or effectively prevent
discrimination against persons legally here.''

Another commissioner, Stephen Horn, president of California State University at
Long Beach, said that he supported an employer sanctions law if it was
accompanied by the creation of a ''secure and counterfeit-proof social security
card'' which would be used by employers to prevent the inadvertent employment of
illegal aliens.

The chairman of the Select Commission on Immigration and Refugee Policy, the
Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, president of the University of Notre Dame, has
endorsed the idea of a worker identification system and employer sanctions.
Father Hesburgh is a former chairman of the Civil Rights Commission.

Panel's Recommendations

To remedy the problems arising from ''discriminatory'' immigration laws, the
commission made these recommendations:

- Congress should amend the Immigration and Nationality Act to eliminate
limitations on the number of immigrants who may come to the United States from
each foreign country. Instead, the commission said, immigrants should be
admitted on a first-come, first-served basis, in accordance with the six
preference categories listed in current law.

- The Immigration and Naturalization Service, a part of the Justice Department,
should immediately cease all ''area control operations'' - that is, neighborhood
raids in search of illegal aliens - ''to prevent the continued violation of the
constitutional and civil rights of individuals.''

- Congress should create a border management agency within the Treasury
Department and transfer the enforcement functions of the immigration service to
the new agency. The immigration service would remain responsible for and could
concentrate all its resources on helping people who wish to come to the United
States, become naturalized citizens or bring close relatives to this country.

- Congress should amend the immigration law to establish an immigration court
that is independent of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, in order to
remove the inference that deportation proceedings are unfair to aliens. Lawyers
have often said that the immigration judges who preside over deportation
hearings are subject to undue influence exerted by the immigration service.

- Congress should protect the legal rights of aliens by requiring that the
Government notify them of their right to counsel ''at all crucial stages of the
deportation process.''

- Congress should authorize the Secretary of State to create a board of visa
appeals to hear appeals of visa denials in which the actions of consular
officers are alleged to be ''arbitrary, capricious and an abuse of discretion or
otherwise not in accordance with law.''

Report Is Due Monday

The report, to be issued on Monday, is titled ''The Tarnished Golden Door: Civil
Rights Issues in Immigration.'' The title is an allusion to a poem by Emma
Lazarus, ''The New Colossus,'' which contains these lines: ''Give me your tired,
your poor, your huddled masses yearning to breathe free ... I lift my lamp
beside the golden door!''

Copies of the report are available from the Civil Rights Commission at 1121
Vermont Avenue N.W., Washington, D.C. 20425.

               December 5, 1980, Friday, Late City Final Edition

LEGALIZED STATUS FOR MOST ALIENS IN U.S. PROPOSED

BYLINE: By JOHN M. CREWDSON, Speci al to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 20, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1323 words

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 4


The staff of a Federal select commission on immigration policy has recommended
that virtually all illegal aliens now in the United States eventually be made
eligible for citizenship. At the same time, the staff recommended issuing work
permits to all Americans and laws forbidding the employment of anyone lacking
one.

In a 400-page report, the commission's staff said that issuing permits and other
stiff measures that it recommended could all but eliminate illegal immigration
in 10 years. The consideration of such permits has evoked concern among civil
libertarians, who say they fear that the documents might, in time, become a
national identity card.

The 16-member panel, which was established by Congress and is known officially
as the Select Commission on Immigration and Refugee Policy, will meet Saturday
in Warrenton, Va., to vote on the recommendations. Nina Solarz, a commission
spokesman, said that while all the recommendations might not be approved ''in
every detail,'' she believed that the commissioners agreed with most of them.

She expressed surprise that the staff report, which she said was being kept
''under lock and key'' until Saturday's meeting, had been made public
prematurely. The report, the result of 18 months of study and public hearings,
was made available here by the San Diego-based Committee on Chicano Rights,
which would not say how it had been obtained.

'Guest Worker' Plan Opposed

In its report, the commission's staff also recommended against an expanded
''guest worker'' program that would allow foreign nationals to fill agricultural
or other vacant jobs on a temporary basis, an idea that has gained currency
among businessmen and conservative legislators in recent years. Labor unions
have generally opposed the concept, but President-elect Ronald Reagan said in
his election campaign that he generally favored this approach to allow Mexican
laborers to work in the United States.

Nearly all of the major recommendations would require new legislation, and it is
unclear how Republican control of the Senate in the next Congress will affect
the reception the report gets there. In addition, the Reagan Administration will
have an opportunity to amend the commission's findings in January before they
are delivered to the House and Senate.

In Washington, Loren A. Smith, a senior member of the Reagan transition staff,
said that he was planning to attend the immigration commission meeting this
weekend. He would not comment on the substance of the recommendations, but said
the Reagan administration would consider them seriously.

The report contains some 50 recommendations, touching on nearly every aspect of
immigration and refugee policy. These are among the major ones:

- A strengthening of efforts to enforce existing immigration laws, including
additional funds for the United States Border Patrol, more immigration
inspectors at ports of entry, more airplanes and helicopters for patrolling the
border and replacement of the aging sensors that are designed to detect illegal
entrants.

- An upgrading of the operations of the Immigration and Naturalization Service,
which the report said had acquired an image as ''an inbred, mismanaged and, at
times, corrupt agency,'' by improving the training of its employees,
establishing a code of ethics and vigorously investigating allegations of
''malfeasance'' and corruption.

- The appointment, with the consent of the Senate, of the commissioner of
immigration for a term of seven years, something the report said might help
reduce the ''managerial weakness'' of the immigration service.

- The establishment of a Federal interagency body to handle ''mass asylum
emergencies,'' such as the arrival last spring of tens of thousands of Cuban and
Haitian refugees in Florida.

The commission has estimated that there are 3.5 million to 6 million illegal
aliens in the United States, most of them employed taxpayers who receive
''minimal welfare benefits'' and who in some instances enable low-paying
businesses, such as garment manufacturers, to successfully compete with foreign
firms.

To continue such individuals in their curre nt illegal status, the report said,
would simply perpetuate as a ''f ugitive underclass'' those who, in many cases,
were making a posit ive contribution to the American economy.

Roundup Called Destructive

The only alternative to giving them legal status, the report said, was to
attempt to round up all illegal aliens and expel them in a mass deportation that
would be ''destructive'' to the civil liberties of Americans and, in the end,
probably unsuccessful as well.

The report acknowledged that legalization might encourage further unlawful
immigration and might convince some aliens who would otherwise have returned
home to remain here. It nonetheless proposed the granting of permanent resident
status to aliens who had resided in the United States for two or three years
before the enabling legislation was passed.

Those aliens not eligible under this criteria would be given ''conditional
entrant status'' leading to permanent residence after five years, provided that
they had been employed in the United States for four of the five years. After
another five years, a permanent resident alien could petition to become a
naturalized citizen.

The proposal is similar to the so-called amnesty program sent to Congress by the
Carter Administration more than three years ago that failed to win approval.

In rejecting the concept of a guest worker program similar to the exchange of
workers among Common Market countries, the report noted the concern of the State
Department that, ''based on past history,'' such a program ''has much potential
for complicating or even damaging our relationships with Mexico.''

About 30,000 foreign agricultural workers are now admitted to the United States
each year, most of them residents of the British West Indies.

Under what the staff report termed an ''employer responsibility program,''
prospective employees would be required to demonstrate their eligibility to work
in this country before being hired, with the responsibility for ascertaining
that eligibility falling to the employer.

Citizens and resident aliens found eligible for employment, it said, would be
issued cards by a Government agency. The cards would include name, date of
birth, sex, a photograph and ''an identifying number unique to that
individual.''

Job applicants would be required to show the cards to employers, who would
report their names and numbers to Washington. Employers who failed to make such
reports would be liable for administrative citations, fines of up to $1,000 for
each ineligible worker employed and, after repeated violations, criminal
prosecutions and jail sentences. Aliens found working without permission would
be ''promptly deported.'' There is now no Federal statute that prohibits the
employment of illegal aliens.

Many Americans, the report said, might resent carrying such a card ''as both an
intrusion on their freedom and as an irritant,'' and it acknowledged that the
document could eventually turn into a national identity card ''despite initial
legislative prohibition.''

But the staff estimated that the system, which might cost as much as $230
million a year to administer, could reduce illegal immigration in this country
by 30 percent in the first year of operation and by 95 percent in the 10th or
11th year.

               December 28, 1980, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

MAJOR IMMIGRATION PROBLEMS

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 20, Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 346 words


John M. Crewdson, a New York Times correspondent based in Houston, has examined
the problems of immigration into the United States for the past year. These are
his central findings:

- For years, corruption, mismanagement, negligence and rock-bottom morale in the
Immigration and Naturalization Service have all but handcuffed that agency,
according to past and present immigration officers, Justice Department lawyers
and others familiar with it. In recent months, as these problems have come to
public attention, the agency has strengthened its internal investigations unit
and has begun to reorganize its auditing, purchasing and other crucial aspects
of its operations.

- Feelings of frustration and helplessness among immigration officers have led
to civil rights abuses and violence against aliens. In the past, the service
seemed eager to keep its agents' misdeeds hidden and, when it could not, was
reluctant to administer more than token punishments. Reforms this year led to
the first convictions of Border Patrol agents charged with abusing illegal
aliens.

- Thousands of illegal aliens each year find themselves being forced to work off
debts to employers or otherwise held illegally in servitude. Dozens of
immigration officials, migrant aid lawyers, social workers and others said that
they believed the practice, while not yet common, was growing.

- Illegal aliens are increasingly bypassing farms and ranches for better-paying
jobs in construction, manufacturing and service industries in the cities. There
also is increasing evidence that many employers prefer foreign workers, not
simply because they work for less money, but because they are among the most
reliable and enthusiastic of employees.

- After a decade in which the United States has absorbed more new residents,
legal and illegal, than in any decade in its history, there are signs of growing
public disenchantment with the current situation and indications that Congress
may move toward reform.

               October 20, 1980, Monday, Late City Final Edition

SLAVERY IN TEXAS:ILLEGAL ALIENS,SEAFOOD AND COVOTES

BYLINE: By JOHN M. CREWDSON, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 17, Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 943 words

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Oct. 18


One late September afternoon, Ramiro Avila Ocegueda, a chauffeur for the Mexican
consul in Brownsville, Tex., telephoned the Immigration and Naturalization
Service office there.  His brother Francisco, Mr. Avila Ocegueda told the
investigator who took the call, had been smuggled into the United States and was
being held against his will by the owner of an oyster processing plant at Smith
Point, Tex., on Galveston Bay.

Kenneth Lynch, an immigration investigator from Houston, was dispatched to Smith
Point, where, according to an affidavit he later filed in Federal court here, he
saw eight men ''who, from their dress and mannerisms, appeared to be illegal
aliens working on the premises of Jeri's Seafood Inc.''

The immigration service investigation, the affidavit said, determined that there
were at least 14 illegal aliens, including Francisco Avila Ocegueda, employed at
Jeri's, 10 of them from Mexico and four from El Salvador. They had been brought
to Smith Point from Houston by a coyote, or smuggler of aliens, who charged the
owner of Jeri's, Benjamin Harrison Nelson, $100 for each worker, the affidavit
said. Mr. Nelson allegedly forced some of the workers to shuck oysters until the
smuggling fees were repaid, with the result that they left with only a few
dollars for several days' work, according to the affidavit.

Francisco Avila Ocegueda, the affidavit said, ''had left once but had been
brought back by a man carrying a carbine.'' Edelmino Tomez Leal, another worker,
told the immigration service that he had been forced by Mr. Nelson to work for
15 days in September to repay the $100 fee, taking with him only $10 in wages
when he was allowed to leave.

Father and Son Charged

Mr. Nelson and his son Walter were arrested earlier this month and charged by
Federal agents with peonage, the first anti-slavery case in Texas in recent
memory and the first filed by the Government since the immigration service began
a renewed search for such crimes a few weeks ago. Immigration agents also
removed 11 of Mr. Nelson's workers, all illegal aliens.

Mr. Nelson, reached by telephone at his processing plant, was eager to talk
about the economics of oyster shucking and the circumstances that had led to his
arrest.

His plant was capable, Mr. Nelson said, of processing 200,000 oysters a day ''if
I got the help.'' But it was becoming increasingly difficult to find workers
willing to perform the tedious task of opening oysters ''day in, day out, in
wet, damp, humid conditions.'' A good shucker, he said, could make $7 an hour.
''That's not bad, but it's all manual.''

''I would rather have American citizens working for me,'' Mr.  Nelson said,
''but oyster opening is something people don't want to get into,'' especially in
a bleak locale like Smith Point, where ''we don't have no beer joints.''

He continued: ''I had seven families of Vietnamese working for me, but when they
got to the point where they had made enough money that they could go out and
better their way of life, they went on. That's the American way, and I'm happy
for them. But right now I could probably use 25 openers, and I got four.''

Mr. Nelson said he had ''gone all through Louisiana'' looking for openers and
had even offered to provide jobs for some of the recent Cuban refugees, but with
no success. So when the coyotes came by and asked, '' 'Do you need any help, do
you have any openings?' I'd say, 'Yes, sir, I have openings,' '' Mr. Nelson
said. ''I don't care where you're from if you want to work.''

'These People Need Jobs'

The Mexicans and Salvadorans, he said, are good workers. ''These boys that come
in here have got to work and want to work, if people would give them the right
to work. If they took all the illegal aliens out of the United States right now,
I believe our economy would go bankrupt. These people got families and need
jobs. You ever been to Mexico? Have you been to the border and looked at the
people sitting right there, starving to death?''

Asked about the Government's allegations that he had paid the smugglers $100 for
each worker, Mr. Nelson replied, ''These people are not like you and me, able to
catch a bus. When they come across the border, some coyote picks them up. I'm
not going to say I didn't pay somebody to bring a man here. If I get to your
house and I say, 'I owe this man here $200 for taxi fare,' if you want me to
work bad enough, you'll find the $200.''

In essence, he said, he had lent the workers the money to repay the smugglers
and had expected the workers to repay him. ''If I was to borrow $100 from you,
you'd want your money back,'' he said.  ''Wouldn't this be the legitimate and
honest way of conducting business?''

Mr. Nelson declined to discuss the charge that he had forced some of his workers
to work off the debt against their will, or that his son, Walter, had brought
Francisco Avila Ocegueda back to his job at gunpoint. ''That's something I don't
want to get into,'' he said. But he added, ''I've had a lot of these people come
here to me and say, 'Sir, my family is sick, I've got to go and I owe you money.
And they've left, owing me money.' ''

Nor was he alone, Mr. Nelson said, in his inability to find workers. ''My
brother's got a restaurant over here, and he's closing it because he can't get
no help.'' But Mr. Nelson nevertheless hopes to stay open, ''one way or
another.''

''I got a business,'' he said.

              November 13, 1980, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

FLORIDA GROWER ACCUSED IN ALIEN SMUGGLING RING

BYLINE: By JOHN M. CREWDSON

SECTION: Section A; Page 20, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1142 words

DATELINE: PHOENIX, Nov. 12


A Federal grand jury here has charged a Florida tomato grower, his son and five
other persons with having operated what immigration agents described as one of
the largest alien smuggling rings ever uncovered in this country.

According to a 20-count indictment returned today, the farmer, Raul Saldivar,
and his son, Raul Jr., a labor contractor, arranged over a three-year period
beginning in March 1977 for the clandestine transportation of thousands of farm
workers, most of them Mexican citizens, from Arizona to south-central Florida.

Michael D. Hawkins, the United States Attorney here, said that, if the
information given to the grand jury was accurate, the case was characterized by
''treatment of undocumented workers as bad as I have ever seen.''

In a prepared statement accompanying the indictment, Mr. Hawkins referred to a
civil lawsuit brought against the Saldivars by seven former workers who charged
the two with holding them under ''subhuman conditions'' at a tomato farm in
Bonita Springs, Fla., while paying them only a few dollars a week.

Charged With Transporting Aliens

The Saldivars were charged today with conspiring to transport illegal aliens, a
felony. Immigration agents familiar with the 18-month investigation that led to
today's indictment had previously said that the Saldivars might also be charged
with peonage, forcing an individual to work off a real or imagined debt. But Mr.
Hawkins said today that he had not invoked the peonage statute because of
Justice Department policy ''that it be used sparingly in these kinds of
incidents.''

One immigration agent described the elder Mr. Saldivar as ''the biggest''
importer of illegal alien workers to Florida. He said the ring, working through
recruiters, five of whom were also indicted today, had smuggled 3,000 to 4,000
workers a year from Arizona to Florida.

Some of the workers were used to harvest the Saldivars' crops, the agent said,
while others were provided, for a fee, to other farmers as field hands. At
times, the agent said, as many as 500 workers were quartered in a 60-acre labor
camp adjacent to the Saldivar farm.

Witnesses before the grand jury included several of the Mexican workers who had
previously given depositions in the civil suit mentioned by Mr. Hawkins. The
workers said in the depositions that it was not until after they reached Florida
that they were told they would have to work off a debt of $450 for their
transportation from Arizona - $100 more than first-class air fare between
Phoenix and Tampa - before they could leave the farm. All seven said that they
eventually fled.

Jackson L. Boughner, the Saldivars' attorney, dismissed the allegations in the
civil lawsuit as unwarranted. He said the seven plaintiffs were being
manipulated by Florida Rural Legal Assistance in an effort ''to unionize
Florida.''

All of the workers at the Saldivars' labor camp, he said, ''could leave any time
they wanted to,'' whether or not their transportation fees had been fully
repaid. He also said that the Saldivars had ''never asked anyone to transport
workers interstate'' to their farm.

Esteban Guerrero, a plaintiff, said in a deposition that he left Arizona for
Florida to earn some money to send home to his family in Mexico. But when he
arrived in Bonita Springs, he discovered that all of his earnings, except for $5
a week, would go for food and to repay his transportation debt to the Saldivars.

Carmen Zuniga, a worker who testified in support of the plaintiffs, said he was
told that ''the least one would earn here was $70 per day'' and that it would
cost him only $20 to go there. But for his first six-day week, he said, he was
paid only $170, of which he kept $20.

Neither Santos Martinez nor Miguel Ramos was told in advance that he would be
required to work off the cost of passage, they said. The first week, according
to the depositions, Mr. Ramos earned $190 and got back $5, and Mr. Martinez
earned $166 and got nothing. It all went, he said, ''to the payment of the man
who brought us from over there'' in Arizona.

Like many of those who have testified in the civil case, as well as before the
grand jury, Maximiliano Aguilar was picking lemons in Arizona when a stranger
approached him and offered better work in Florida. Only after he and the others
arrived at the Saldivar farm, he said, did they learn ''that we couldn't put a
foot out of the place.''

It is not illegal for a grower to charge workers for their transportation to his
farm. But forcing a laborer to work off such a debt is criminal peonage under
Federal law. Migrant farmworkers also must be given a written statement, in
advance, of terms and conditions of their employment, including any deductions
to be made.  Federal law also makes it illegal for a registered labor contractor
to transport or employ illegal aliens.

In a recent interview, Felipe Flores, a plaintiff in the civil case, said that
Raul Saldivar Jr. had made it clear to him and the other workers that ''until we
paid the $450 we could not get out.'' Meliton Zuniga said in a deposition that
once when he and a companion were on their way to visit someone, Raul Saldivar
sighted them and ''told us that we could even lose our lives if he caught us
around there again.''

Mr. Flores said a foreman had told him ''that if he saw somebody who would try
to take us out of the camp, that he could kill that person.'' Lupe Sanchez, an
official of the Arizona Farmworkers Union, said that, when he visited the
Saldivar camp to see conditions there for himself, ''they told me they would
kill me.''

Harsh Treatment Alleged

''He treated us like dogs,'' said Remijo Saldana of Raul Saldivar Jr., who he
said paid him $20 for four weeks' work. ''They did not want us to rest while we
were working,'' added Pedro de Santiago, who said that ''we had to work
continuously.''

When the water in the camp ran out, said Esteban Guerrero, the workers were
forced to drink either beer, which they bought from the Saldivars at 75 cents a
can, or what one worker described as the ''yellowish'' water from the canal.
There were no electric lights in the living quarters, said Juan Martinez, so the
workers spent some of their few precious dollars on a flashlight ''to make our
tortillas.''

Seven men lived in one room with only three beds, so they took turns sleeping on
the floor. There was no lavatory, so they relieved themselves in the woods.
''The snakes were the most dangerous of all,'' said Mr. Zuniga. ''They would
attack us at night while we were sleeping.''

The City;
4 Charged in Effort To Smuggle Aliens

SECTION: Section B; Page 3, Column 3; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 107 words


Four men have been indicted on Federal charges of violating immigration laws in
connection with the Feb. 2 seizure of a trailer truck carrying 84 aliens in the
South Bronx.

Those indicted were Jose Abreu, 24 years old, and Cesar Victorino, 35, -both
citizens of the Dominican Republic - and two Bronx men, Efraine Vega, 39, and
Roopnarine Singh, 22, a citizen of Guyana, who allegedly were driving the truck.

The four men, each of whom is being held in $200,000 bail, were accused of
violations involving transportation of 43 of the aliens cross-country and
harboring them.

               January 8, 1981, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

AROUND THE NATION;
Immigration Panel Modifies Opposition to Identity Cards

BYLINE: UPI

SECTION: Section A; Page 16, Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 165 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7


A Federal immigration commission today retracted its earlier outright opposition
to issuing identification cards for American workers, and said it favored the
idea when coupled with penalties for hiring illegal aliens.

A spokesman for the Select Commission on Immigration and Refugee Policy
announced earlier that the 16-member panel had rejected the identification card
proposal by a vote of 9 to 6, with one abstention.

Later, reacting to published reports of the announcement, Elaine Daniels, a
spokesman for the panel, ''clarified'' the vote. She said that the commissioners
voted, 8 to 7, in favor of the I.D. proposal when provisions to sanction
employers for hiring undocumented workers were included. One commissioner
abstained from voting.

The spokesman said the 9-to-6 vote simply favored the continued use of birth
certificates, drivers' licenses, immigration cards and other forms of
identification to keep track of illegal aliens.

                               The New York Times

                 May 11, 1981, Monday, Late City Final Edition

PLAN WOULD LET MEXICANS WORK AS U.S. GUESTS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 1177 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10


Despite opposition from organized labor and many Mexican Americans, the Reagan
Administration is considering the institution of a large guest-worker program as
a means of improving United States-Mexican relations and curbing illegal
migration.

Campaigning in Texas last September, Mr. Reagan called for a policy that would
permit hundreds of thousands of Mexicans to enter this country and work on a
temporary basis. In a television interview March 3, the President said he was
''very intrigued'' with a proposal to legalize the illegal migration from Mexico
by granting visas to those who wanted to go back and forth across the border
while holding jobs in this country. Mr. Reagan said he wanted to discuss the
idea with Mexico's President, Jose Lopez Portillo, who is scheduled to visit
Washington June 8 and 9.

The White House staff has developed a detailed proposal for a guest-worker
program. Although the President has not yet reviewed it or received advice from
his Cabinet, he is widely believed to favor such a program. ''On this
question,'' one official said Friday, ''there is a strong tidal force that stems
straight out of the Oval Office.''

A 'North American Accord'

White House officials said that a guest-worker program would facilitate natural,
mutually beneficial patterns of labor migration between Mexico and the United
States. President Reagan has repeatedly vowed to improve relations with Mexico
as part of what he calls a ''North American accord.''

Any proposal for a temporary worker program inevitably revives memories of the
''bracero'' program, which brought four million to five million Mexican
agricultural workers to the United States from 1942 to 1964. Most studies of
that program say that it stimulated illegal immigration, did little to end the
exploitation of Mexican workers and had an adverse effect on the wages and
working conditions of domestic agricultural workers.

Joseph Ghougassian, a senior policy adviser at the White House, has recommended
a temporary worker program as the best way to deal with ''the massive illegal
migration from Mexico.''

In a confidential memorandum to his superiors, Mr. Ghougassian said that the
bracero program, though defective in many respects, was ''nonetheless a workable
solution to the uncontrolled and mismanaged inflow of Mexican aliens.'' He noted
that the program had been discontinued in 1964 under ''pressure from Democrats
and labor unions.'' He said that ''a sound public relations program could deal
effectively with any initial opposition'' to another guest-worker program.

Documenting 'the Undocumented'

If the border cannot be sealed and if the influx of illegal aliens cannot be
curbed, Mr. Ghougassian wrote, then ''it is best to document the undocumented
entrants.''

President Reagan has expressed particular interest in the type of program
proposed by Gov. William Clements of Texas. That proposal would not tie Mexican
workers to specific employers, as the bracero program did. Instead, it would
permit Mexicans to move freely into industries where they were needed. In this
respect, it resembles the program favored by Senators Harrison Schmitt of New
Mexico and Barry Goldwater of Arizona, both Republicans.

A large guest-worker program would probably require Congressional approval,
whether it was established by treaty or by executive agreement between the
Presidents of Mexico and the United States.

Thomas O. Enders, President Reagan's nominee for Assistant Secretary of State
for inter-American affairs, discussed the possibility of a guest-worker program
when he visited Mexico City last Monday. He met with the Foreign Minister, Jorge
Castaneda, and the Labor Minister, Pedro Ojeda Paullada, to advise them of the
Reagan Administration's preliminary efforts to develop a new immigration policy.


Closer Consultation Sought

Reagan aides say they are determined to consult more closely with Mexico than
the Carter Administration did. In August 1977, when President Carter announced a
series of proposals on immigration, Mexican officials complained that they had
not been consulted.

In a meeting at the Justice Department on April 18 and in a meeting at the White
House Thursday, various special interests warned the Administration that there
would be intense opposition to a guestworker program.

''It would be politically naive in the extreme for the Administration to float
this program,'' said Msgr. George C. Higgins, a Roman Catholic priest who has
been working on labor issues here for 40 years. ''The Administration will find
absolutely universal opposition to a temporary worker program from every group
that has an interest in the subject from the point of view of the welfare of
workers.''

The National Committee for Full Employment, a coalition of church, civil-rights,
Hispanic-American and labor groups, said that ''it makes no sense to bring
additional workers to the United States when there are eight million
unemployed'' already.

Others in Opposition

Equally firm in their opposition were Thomas R. Donahue, secretarytreasurer of
the A.F.L.-C.I.O.; Arnoldo S. Torres, representing the League of United Latin
American Citizens, and Antonia Hernandez of the Mexican American Legal Defense
and Educational Fund. They said that guest workers were likely to become a
permanent subclass of employees, subject to exploitation.

Switzerland, Germany, France, Sweden and other European countries have had
guest-worker programs. The temporary workers tend to become permanent, according
to a Library of Congress study, because they develop social and economic ties to
the host countries.

In its final report last February, a Federal advisory panel, the Select
Commission on Immigration and Refugee Policy opposed any significant expansion
of the existing program under which 20,000 to 30,000 aliens enter the country as
temporary workers each year. The commission said that no industry should depend
on a constant supply of foreign workers.

The National Council of Agricultural Employers has been the main group
advocating expansion of the temporary worker program. Perry R.  Ellsworth,
executive vice president of the council, said that additional workers were
almost always needed to harvest certain crops.

The Government of Mexico has not taken an official position on the guest-worker
proposals. In a speech several years ago, the Mexican Ambassador here, Hugo B.
Margain, expressed his ''personal opinion'' that there should be a ''bilateral
temporary migration program similar to the one in existence from 1942 to 1964.''
Such a program, he said, would curtail the ''human rights abuses'' often
suffered by Mexicans working in this country.

               November 10, 1980, Monday, Late City Final Edition

ILLEGAL ALIENS ARE BYPASSING FARMS FOR HIGHER PAY OF JOBS IN THE CITIES

BYLINE: By JOHN M. CREWDSON, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 3309 words

DATELINE: CHICAGO


Illegal aliens are increasingly bypassing the nation's farms and ranches, their
usual sources of employment, for betterpaying jobs in construction,
manufacturing and service industries. In many cases they receive the same
salaries and benefits, such as employer-sponsored health care and union
membership, as the American workers they are sometimes displacing.

Figures compiled by the Immigration and Naturalization Service, which arrests
tens of thousands of illegal workers each year, show that for the last two years
fewer than half of those arrested were working in agricultural jobs and that
three out of five were earning more than the minimum wage. In Chicago, aliens
seized in recent months were found to have average earnings of more than $9,000
a year while working for plastics and electronics companies, foundries,
meat-packing plants, rubber products manufacturers, snack food and candy
producers and the like.

''There is a vigorous market for, and in some instances active recruitment of,
undocumented workers,'' said Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall, who expressed
concern over the displacement of American workers by illegal aliens. ''They make
desirable employees and normally have no difficulty in finding the work they
seek.''

The trend among aliens to settle in urban industrial areas of the North and East
seems certain to intensify the debate whether burgeoning illegal immigration
represents an economic windfall or a serious contributor to unemployment among
resident American workers, especially young people and members of minority
groups.

A Single, Crucial Decision

In effect, the debate is likely to come down to a single, crucial choice: Should
the United States in effect concede its lower-paid, less attractive jobs to
those immigrants who are eager to take them and legitimize their presence with a
''guest worker'' program along the lines of the existing worker exchanges
between member nations of the European Economic Community? Or should it enact
stringent laws that prohibit the employment of illegal aliens?

If the choice is the latter, experts agree, the enforcement capability of the
Immigration and Naturalization Service would have to be bolstered, because it
has conceded that it is now almost powerless because of new regulations and
severe shortages of money and manpower.

Some economists argue that the country is faced with what they call a
''voluntary withdrawal'' of American workers from jobs that offer low wages and
difficult working conditions and that the resulting vacuum can only be filled by
illegal aliens for whom such jobs are worthwhile. In the case of agriculture,
garment manufacturing and electronics, they say, illegal aliens offer employers
their only means of remaining in business, especially in the face of determined
foreign competition.

But there is also increasing evidence that foreign workers are preferred by a
wide range of employers, not simply because they work for less money than
Americans but also because, as business executives and immigration officials
contend, they are among the most reliable and enthusiastic of employees. And as
their reputation as ''superworkers'' spreads, the aliens are filling skilled and
semiskilled jobs that have previously been held by American citizens.

So sought after are the illegal workers, in fact, that some larger concerns,
such as construction companies and national hotel and restaurant chains, have
set up their own networks to recruit workers in Mexico and smuggle them into the
United States, a practice that the immigration service has recently begun
investigating.

Praise for Alien Workers

''They like to work,'' said the personnel manager of a Chicagoarea manufacturing
plant, who, like other business executives interviewed, asked that neither he
nor his company be identified.  ''They work hard and they show up on time, they
work overtime, they don't get into fights and they're relatively docile.''

''The citizen will gripe about working conditions,'' an immigration service
official said. ''The citizen will demand workmen's compensation, will demand
retirement. The alien is tickled to death to go in there and work 10 hours a
day. And he knows if he doesn't show up there's another alien standing in line
to take his job.''

By all accounts, the aliens are not only hardworking but also willing to endure
considerable deprivation in return for the privilege, to live a dozen to a room,
to sleep in shifts on wall-towall mattresses - in short to do whatever they must
do to stretch the precious dollars they send home to relatives in Mexico.

''There's a lot of things they have to undergo to work here,'' one Chicago
employer said, with not a little admiration in his voice.  Mr. Marshall
maintained that the continuing influx of illegal aliens was an important
contributor to the nation's level of unemployment. And the Secretary argued
that, while the aliens work hard, they also work ''scared,'' leaving themselves
open to exploitation, such as denial of overtime pay.

Underpayments of Workers Found

A recent Labor Department effort to seek out violations of the wage and hour
laws found that 1,600 employers in industries with heavy concentrations of
illegal alien employees had underpaid their workers by nearly $5 million,
principally in uncompensated overtime.

But it is far from clear whether the alien workers, who often pay smugglers
hundreds of dollars to bring them across the border and drive them to northern
industrial centers, see themselves as the victims of exploitation. In a single
hour in an American factory, even an unskilled alien who can command no more
than the minimum wage can earn the equivalent of a day's pay back in Mexico.

While the illegal workers include increasing numbers from South America, the
Middle East, the Far East and the impoverished island nations of the Caribbean,
the great majority of those who come are Mexicans. According to immigration
officials, the Mexicans tend to cross the border with assistance from paid
smugglers, or ''coyotes,'' while those from other countries are more likely to
enter the United States legally with tourist or student visas and to stay on
after their visas expire.

No one knows for certain how many illegal aliens are in the United States or how
fast they are coming. Edwin P. Reubens, an economist with the City University of
New York, estimated that about four million illegal workers were now living
permanently in the United States and that, barring any change in immigration or
enforcement patterns, the number would reach 10 million by the end of this
decade.

'A Lot of Uncertainty'

But all such estimates are questionable. ''There's no definitive study being
done,'' said Vernon Briggs, a Cornell University economist, ''and in my
estimation there never will be one. There's a lot of uncertainty on both
sides.''

Lawrence Fuchs, the director of the Select Commission on Immigration and Refugee
Policy, put it more bluntly: ''You cannot count illegal aliens accurately, let
alone determine their impact.  All you ever get is the subsample you have
chosen.''

But Professor Briggs said that it was still his ''strong predilection'' that
significant numbers of American workers were being displaced by illegal aliens,
and Professor Fuchs, who is on leave from Brandeis University, said that he
expected the Select Commission to recommend, in its final report to Congress and
the President at the end of the year, the passage of a Federal law prohibiting
the employment of illegal aliens.

Though it is by no means a scientific one, the largest data sample available on
illegal alien workers is that compiled by the Immigration and Naturalization
Service from arrest reports, which includes this information:

- In 1978, 45.6 percent of the employed aliens apprehended were working in
agriculture and 54.4 percent in manufacturing, construction and service
industries. In the first 11 months of the Federal fiscal year that ended Sept.
31, the number of agricultural workers had dropped to 43 percent.

- Among the 351 alien workers arrested at factories and businesses in the
Chicago area in the past three months, the average annual income was $9,360,
nearly twice the Federal Government's povertylevel income.

- In August, the latest month for which figures were available, well over half
the employed illegal aliens arrested in New York City, Los Angeles and San
Francisco were working in manufacturing alone, and more than three-quarters were
earning more than the minimum wage.

''There's not a business or industry of any type here that does not have
undocumented workers,'' said Joseph Howerton, head of the Los Angeles office of
the immigration service. ''If we were to pick up every illegal alien in this
area, we would close down not just 90 percent of the restaurants and the car
washes, but many of the light industries.''

Said another immigration official: ''Years ago, we could walk into a factory and
find maybe two or three illegal aliens. Now, 60 or 70 percent of the workers in
the place are illegal.''

Several economists emphasize that it is not necessarily a matter of only a
finite number of jobs being divided among a growing number of workers. ''People
not only take jobs, they make jobs,'' said Julian Simon, a professor of
economics at the University of Illinois. Over the long run, he said, the
expenditure by illegal workers of their salaries generates demand for goods and
services, creating greater employment opportunities for everyone. In the short
run, however, some displacement is inevitable.

The question, however, is precisely who is being displaced. As the undocumented
workers continue their movement to the large industrial cities, the displacement
of some American workers is bound to increase, with the first effects being felt
by the young and members of minorities, groups most associated with
minimum-wage, entry-level jobs.

Those groups of Americans are also experiencing the highest rates of
unemployment in the nation. National figures for October, which were made public
Friday, showed unemployment at 18.4 percent for teen-agers, at 14.3 percent for
blacks and at 10.9 percent for Hispanic Americans, as against an overall rate of
7.6 percent. For black teen-agers, the rate was 39.3 percent.

''They're taking jobs from young people, those that are just starting out, from
blacks and from other aliens who have gone through the proper immigration
process in this country,'' said Ted Georgetti, the chief immigration
investigator in Chicago.

George Montoya, his counterpart in New York City, agreed. ''There are many black
teen-agers who would like to have some of the jobs these illegal aliens are
taking,'' he said.

Tips From Displaced Workers

Perhaps significantly, Hispanic Americans and blacks, angry at having lost their
jobs, have provided many of the tips that the Immigration and Naturalization
Service has received about companies that employ illegal workers. But as Edwin
Reubens noted, there are a number of options for American citizens and legal
resident aliens that may prompt them to refuse to accept jobs at the salaries at
or just above the minimum wage. ''They can either go on unemployment insurance
or welfare,'' he said, ''or to say it bluntly, they can go in for various forms
of crime.''

Most experts agree that there is little displacement of American workers by
illegal aliens in agriculture, where the work is arduous and the wages
relatively low.

Many of the Mexicans now moving into industry first came to the United States as
what Mr. Georgetti of the Chicago immigration office termed ''relatively
unsophisticated'' aliens eager to pick crops in the fields of Texas and
California. ''Once they acquire a veneer of sophistication,'' he said, ''once
they learn their way around, once they learn the language, it's only human
nature that they'll seek a better job.''

Unlike their opposite numbers in agriculture, who are likely to return home at
the end of a harvest season, those who move on to work in industry tend to stay
until they are apprehended. A random immigration service sampling of aliens
arrested in Los Angeles in the last three months showed that they averaged 2.4
years on the job and earned $5.25 an hour.

One had worked for three years as a mechanic earning $700 a week, another as an
upholsterer earning $12 an hour. A roofer earned $11.81 an hour, an electrician
$11, a plumber $500 a week, a butcher $6.50 an hour, a machinist $7. Few were
found working in the occupations usually associated with illegal aliens; there
was only a handful of gardeners, a few seamstresses, two agricultural workers,
one busboy and one maid.

Many of those who argue that illegal aliens are not displacing American workers
refer to a 1975 study that reported that about 2,000 menial jobs vacated by
illegal aliens in the San Diego area had not been filled by jobless Americans,
principally because most of the jobs paid less than the minimum wage. But in the
suburbs of Chicago, where both wages and unemployment are running considerably
higher than they were in San Diego five years ago, the Illinois Department of
Labor has had no trouble filling openings left after immigration service raids
on factories and businesses.

''Every time we get them, we fill them,'' said Walter Tupy, a state labor
official. ''We've seen situations where Immigration is coming in one door and
people are applying at the other,'' said Jim Marino, another official. ''How
they hear about it is beyond us.''

One morning last summer, Mr. Marino recalls, immigration service agents raided a
foundry in nearby Elgin, a predominantly white, bluecollar town with an
unemployment rate of about 10 percent. The agents arrested 69 illegal aliens
earning from $4.50 to 3 an hour.  In hours, hundreds of local residents had
applied for the jobs, and within three days, all of them were filled.

Employers Say Screening Difficult

For their part, employers maintain that they are not law enforcement officers
and should not be saddled with the responsibility for screening job applicants,
a task that many say is made virtually impossible by Federal equal opportunity
employment regulations that limit the kind of information they can seek.

''We can ask them if they have a legal right to be in the U.S.,'' said the
personnel manager of a Los Angeles company that manufactures baby furniture.
''But once they say yes, we're stuck.'' Under Federal law, he said, he could
only ask for proof of legal residence if the same request was made of all
employees, something he deemed distasteful and impractical as well. ''Anyway,''
he said, ''80 percent of the documents they have are forged.''

The proliferation of bogus documents, chiefly resident alien identity cards,
birth certificates and Social Security cards, is a major problem, according to
employers and immigration officials. Most Hispanic areas of larger cities have a
flourishing trade in such documents, immigration officials say. In Los Angeles,
a forged Social Security card can be purchased on the street for as little as
$25, a resident alien certificate, known as a ''green card,'' for $100.

The immigration service acknowledges that it has no way of guarding against the
use of the same alien registration number by more than one person, and because
of backlogs at the Social Security Administration it frequently takes nine
months to a year to identify a false Social Security number. But under a program
called ''Operation Cooperation,'' the immigration service will advise
subscribing employers whether job applicants are in the country legally. In
Chicago, 57 large employers have joined the program, though in many cases
reluctantly and only after raids by immigration agents had decimated their work
forces.

An Unspectactular Start

Neither the immigration service nor the employers would argue that the program
was working well, and each side blamed the other's lack of interest. ''We just
don't get many calls,'' said Mr. Howerton, the immigration service director in
Los Angeles. The personnel manager of a large Chicago confection company said
she had submitted 25 names to the immigration service for clearance in the last
month and had received responses on only three of them.

Despite being publicly opposed to continued illegal immigration, some labor
unions seem indifferent to the legal status of their members. Asked about the
level of labor union cooperation here, Mr.  Georgetti said, ''They're more
concerned with membership than with immigration status.'' The manager of a
unionized plastic bottle factory agreed. ''With the union, it doesn't make any
difference about their status,'' he said.

Until recently, the risk of a raid by immigration agents was something of a
deterrent to employers tempted by illegal labor. But in the last year,
enforcement of the immigration laws has fallen greatly.

In August 1979, more than 21,000 aliens were apprehended in raids on workplaces
across the country. Last August, the number was about 7,000. In Los Angeles,
investigators have raided only two factories so far this year. The two were Mode
O'Day, a garment manufacturer where eight aliens were arrested, and Strollee of
California, a maker of children's furniture which spends approximately $100 a
month to provide health care benefits for each of its employees. Sixty-nine
aliens were seized there. There have been only five such raids in Philadelphia
and none at all in New York City.

Many Reasons for Decline

There are several reasons for the dropoff, including the diversion of
immigration personnel to handle the expulsion of Iranian students from the
United States and the arrival of 125,000 Cuban refugees in Florida. But the
trend has occurred mainly because of a Justice Department regulation that
severely limited raids on homes and businesses so that census takers could more
accurately count illegal aliens residing in this country.

Before the regulation was imposed last April, Mr. Georgetti said, immigration
service investigators in Chicago were apprehending about 1,000 illegal aliens a
month, most of them at places where they worked. The number of apprehensions has
since dropped to one-tenth that number, although at any one time, he said, his
office has information on the whereabouts of some 46,000 aliens.

''Three years ago we had 40 or 50 investigators a day on the streets,'' said Mr.
Smith, the immigration investigations chief in Los Angeles. ''Now we're lucky if
we've got eight.'' He added that most of those were kept busy picking up illegal
aliens arrested by local police on other criminal charges.

''We have a very token enforcement,'' Mr. Smith said. ''We don't have the
capability. We are no longer a threat to any employer here.''

               November 30, 1980, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

JOBS FOR ILLEGAL ALIENS STIRS SAME OPPOSITION AS IN '77 GALLUP POLL

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 24, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 390 words


Americans are as opposed to the entry and employment of illegal aliens as they
were three years ago, according to the latest Gallup Poll. Its findings indicate
that Americans have neither softened nor hardened their views despite
controversy over illegal immigration from Mexico, Central and South America and
the arrival of refugees from Southeast Asia and Cuba.

Seventy-six percent of the public believe that it should ''be against the law to
employ a person who has come into the United States without proper papers,'' the
survey showed.

In October 1977, a similar poll showed that the 72 percent of the public felt
that way. Given a margin of error of plus or minus three percentage points,
which both surveys had, those two figures are substantially the same.

Seventy-seven percent of the whites interviewed and 67 percent of the nonwhites
favored such a law.

Educational Levels Vary

The employment curb was favored by 80 percent of those interviewed who had a
college education, 67 percent of those who had a high school education and 64
percent of those who not gone beyond grade school.

The difference in opinions between whites and nonwhites was marked on the issue
of amnesty. The survey asked, ''It has been proposed that illegal aliens who
have been in the United States for seven years be allowed to remain in the
United States. Do you favor or oppose this proposal?''

Thirty-six percent of the whites favored the proposal, as against 45 percent of
the nonwhites. On the national average, 37 percent favored it, 52 percent
opposed it and 11 percent had no opinion.

The survey also asked, ''Do you believe everyone in the United States should be
required to carry an identification card such as a Social Security card, or
not?''

On the national average, 62 percent favored the requirement, 33 percent opposed
it and 5 percent had no opinion.  Only 44 percent of those with a college
education said there should be such a law; 68 percent of those with a high
school education said there should be, and 75 percent of those who attended only
grade school favored it.

The poll, based on interviews made in person around the country, was conducted
Nov. 7 to 10.

                May 30, 1981, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

RISE IN IMMIGRATION URGED FROM MEXICO AND CANADA

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Page 7, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 936 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 29


A Cabinet-level advisory committee has decided to recommend that President
Reagan ask Congress to double the annual limit on legal immigration from Mexico
and Canada.

There is now a limit of 20,000 immigrants a year for natives of any foreign
country. The advisory panel, in a report scheduled for submission to the
President in the next few weeks, suggests increasing the limit to 40,000 each
for Mexico and Canada.

This proposal, according to the report, ''recognizes the unique relationship
with our neighbors'' and ''provides a means for reducing pressures for illegal
immigration from Mexico.''

The recommendation is one of many being made by the President's Task Force on
Immigration and Refugee Policy. Attorney General William French Smith is
chairman of the panel, which includes seven other Cabinet members. In a
memorandum last week to all members of the group, David D. Hiller, a special
assistant to the Attorney General, said that the proposals were ''the component
parts of a final draft report to the President.''

Border Patrol Rise Urged

In its final draft, the panel also recommends a ''moderate increase'' in the
enforcement budget of the Immigration and Naturalization Service to provide
additional Border Patrol agents, investigators and other personnel.

The report also gives additional details of these proposals, including penalties
for employers hiring illegal aliens; an experimental program to admit Mexicans
as ''guest workers,'' and an amnesty for about one million illegal aliens.

''Increased enforcement resources and employer sanctions,'' the report says,
''in combination with a pilot temporary worker program, will reduce
substantially illegal immigration by expanding the opportunity for Mexican
nationals to work lawfully in the United States and by prohibiting employers
from hiring Mexicans outside of that program.''

In recent years, Mexico has used its quota of 20,000 visas, while Canada has
used only 12,000 to 16,000 of its allotted share. Under the panel's proposal,
any visas unused by Canada could be used by Mexico. The likely effect, if
migration patterns continue unchanged, would be to make 40,000 additional
immigrant visas available to Mexicans.

The panel estimated that its proposals would cost $256 million to $286 million a
year. Much of the cost, it said, could be offset by increasing the fees charged
by the Government for providing various immigration benefits to aliens.

Delays in Issuing Report

The report was originally to have been submitted to the President in the first
week of May. Then officials said that May 25 was the target date. Mr. Smith, at
a breakfast meeting with reporters yesterday, said that the study would probably
not be submitted until after Mr. Reagan meets here with President Jose Lopez
Portillo of Mexico on June 8 and 9. A copy of the draft report was obtained by
The New York Times from an official of one of the Federal agencies that
contributed to the report.

The report makes these recommendations:

- Brothers and sisters of adult citizens should no longer receive preference in
the allocation of visas. About 65,000 visas a year go to aliens in this
category. The special treatment for brothers and sisters, according to the
report, causes an exponential growth in visa applications.

- Congress should ''enact legislation prohibiting employers of four or more
employees from knowingly and willfully hiring illegal aliens.'' Employers
violating the law should be subject to civil fines of $500 to $1,000 for each
illegal alien they hire. The Justice Department should seek injunctions to halt
a ''pattern or practice'' of violations.

- Job applicants should be required to show identification, including a new,
counterfeit-resistant Social Security card, to establish that they are eligible
to work in the United States. This requirement would apply to citizens and
aliens alike. For a person to make ''knowing and willful'' use of false
identification papers in obtaining a job would be illegal.

- President Reagan should ask Congress to establish an experimental ''guest
worker'' program with Mexico. In each of the next two years, 50,000 Mexicans a
year would be allowed to enter the United States to search for employment. The
Mexican workers would be allowed to bring their spouses and their children under
the age of 18. They would have access to public schools and health care but not
to welfare, food stamps or unemployment insurance.

- There should be an amnesty for illegal aliens who were present in the United
States before Jan. 1, 1980, and who have been ''continually resident'' in the
country for at least five years. The estimated 1.2 million aliens in this
category could apply for status as lawful permanent residents.

The panel said that there was a net influx of 500,000 illegal aliens each year
and that its recommendations, if accepted, might reduce the flow to 100,000 a
year.

The report emphasizes demographic projections much more than similar studies
have in the past. The panel predicted that with the recommendations of the
report in effect the population of the United States would grow from the current
226 million to 267 million in the year 2030. The panel said that its
recommendations were a ''middle course'' between a very restrictive and a very
liberal immigration policy.

Under these assumptions, the Hispanic portion of the population would rise from
its present level of 6.5 percent to 10.4 percent in 2030. If illegal immigration
continued at current levels, it was estimated, Hispanic-Americans would account
for 15 percent of the population in 2030.
