                October 5, 1981, Monday, Late City Final Edition

FOR HAITIANS: LITTLE CHOICE;
News Analysis

BYLINE: By REGINALD STUART, Speci al to the New York Times

SECTION: Section B; Page 11, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 873 words

DATELINE: PORT


AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 1 - It was damned if you do, damned if you don't. The
veiled ultimatum put to Haiti was: Stop the illegal migration of Haitians to
America or risk further economic distress by being bypassed by

American companies in search of places in the Caribbean to build factories or
grow crops where there is cheap nonunion labor. That was the crux of what
American officials said to the Government of Haiti and the pressure led this
week to an agreement to work together to halt the flow of Haitians seeking a
higher standard of living.

Gov. Bob Graham of Florida, whose state has become the haven in recent months
for most Haitians leaving their country illegally, repeatedly brandished the
economic stick in a two-day visit here that ended today. While here, he and his
party met with Jean-Claude Duvalier, President for life of this tiny Caribbean
nation of blacks.

In their meetings yesterday, which President Duvalier characterized as
''extremely positive,'' the Americans offered nothing solid beyond a commitment
by Governor Graham to send a trade mission here to explore what can be done to
help stimulate the sick economy, with particular attention to agriculture, which
employs 79 percent of all Haitians and is one of the strongest industries in
Florida.

Economic Problems

Governor Graham is a moderate Democrat who insists that Haitians are leaving
their country solely for economic reasons, a point with whic h not everyone
agrees. The Governor says much can be done throughthe private sector to help
Haiti; Republicans are pushing that platform hard these days in the United
States .

Haiti is an impoverished nation whose economy has long been heavily influenced
by the United States. About 70 percent of all exports are sold to the United
States and nearly 53 percent of all imports come from the United States,
according to American Government studies. There are many here who earn little
more than a dollar a day, if that much, and Government statistics put per capita
income at less than $200 a year. The nation of 5.74 million people is the oldest
republic in the Western Hemisphere after the United States but it is estimated
that less than 20 percent of the people are literate.

Governor Graham told President Duvalier that one way Haitian officials could
revive the confidence of the American investor would be ''to demonstrate that
Haiti is a law-abiding country.''

President Duvalier may be in the corner now, but the promises that Governor
Graham made, and, to a lesser extent, those made by the American Ambassador,
Ernest H. Preeg, make it likely that they be the next to be cornered.

Governor Graham may have begun to stop the expenditure of state dollars to care
for illegal Haitian refugees. But he has assumed a leadership role in a
difficult task, that of delivering the economic stimulus to the Haitian people
that other well-intentioned outsiders have been unable to muster in decades of
effort.

Wait-and-See Attitude

And Haitians who heard of his promises through the press and on the streets are
eager to see the results.  Through his chairmanship of Caribbean Central
American Action, a group focusing on this region, Governor Graham promises the
same kind of attention for a well-behaved Haiti that has been afforded such
places as Jamaica and Puerto Rico, where business projects have been
successfully begun.

At the American Embassy here, officials working in the financially pressed
Agency for International Development, welcome Governor Graham's approach, noting
that it complements the Reagan outline for dealing with Haiti in the future. Mr.
Reagan has frowned upon the idea of keeping the agency strong financially and
the Graham step may emerge as a blessing.

The activity around these developments will step up in a few days.  Patrolling
of the high seas by the Coast Guard in search of fleeing Haitians is to begin.
And the Florida trade mission is to arrive by November.

Possible Impact on Haitians

But it could be months before these developments have any effect upon the
thinking of Haitians who have had enough of poverty, unemployment and living
conditions that most Americans would find intolerable.

These Haitians will determine whether the long-desired and nowpromised changes
will be enough to keep them at home or whether fleeing at the risk of their
lives is preferable.

If unimpressed, they may continue to test the American principle that those who
seek a better life may look to America as a place to settle and work.

Despite American officials' assertion, migration of Haitians will not be purely
for economic reasons. When one asks Haitians to assess the new relationship
between the two Governments, one hears apologetic explanations about the risk of
even discussing such things. To Haitians, there is no line between economics and
politics. Governor Graham will need to learn that as he seeks to help their
nation to protect his own state.

VESSEL BEGINS VIGIL FOR ALIENS TODAY ,

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section 1; Page 8, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 454 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, Oct. 9


The Coast Guard cutter Hamilton tomorrow will begin intercepting boats suspected
of transporting il legal aliens, officials here announced today.

The patrol will put into effect a new policy of the Reagan Administration to
stem the flow of refugees, principally those fleeing the impoverished Caribbean
nation of Haiti, who enter the United States by boat.

Petty Officer Dan Walbschmidt, a Coast Guard spokesman, said the Hamilton was
sailing today from the Haitian capital of Port-au-Prince to refuel at the United
States Naval Base in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. She is to begin its patrol tomorrow
afternoon.

Mr. Walbschmidt said the timetable for the Hamilton's patrol was announced after
Coast Guard and United States Immigration and Naturalization Service officials
met with representatives of the Haitian Government.

The Administration's policy, announced Sept. 29, has been criticized as racist
by leaders of Miami's Haitian refugee community, who have said the policy is
intended to exclude the Caribbean refugees because they are black.

The Hamilton has been ordered to move to a patrol position in the Windward
Passage between Haiti and Cuba and to stop and board boats suspected of
transporting illegal aliens, Mr. Walbschmidt said.
Plan to Board Vessels

A boarding party from the cutter will question the people on board, determine
where they are going and, if they do not have visas to enter the United States,
tell them to return to their homeland.

The United States Justice Department has said that those refugees who persuade
immigration officials that they are fleeing persecution will be taken to Miami
for a formal political asylum hearing.

Mr. Walbschmidt said the cutter was equipped with various weapons but it was
unlikely they would have to be used. Only four vessels have been fired at by the
Coast Guard since 1973, he said, and ''no one was injured.''

The Boston-based, 378-foot cutter will be accompanied on the interdiction patrol
by a search plane and two helicopters. A doctor will be aboard the vessel, along
with two immigration officials and two interpreters who speak Haitian Creole,
the language of almost all the estimated 50,000 Haitians who have landed on
Florida shores since 1970.

Meanwhile, Richard Gullage, deputy district director of the immigration service,
said only 21 Haitians arrived in South Florida this week. He said the new
arrivals landed Wednesday. Mr. Gullage said there were 1,100 refugees, mostly
Haitians, at a processing center west of Miami.

              October 24, 1981, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

Letter: On Illegal Immigrants;
The Threat of Alien Entitlements

SECTION: Section 1; Page 22, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 409 words


To the Editor:

In your Oct. 13 editorial advocating ''The Education of Alien Children,'' you
present the issue before the Supreme Court as though it were whether the State
of Texas can afford to provide free public education to illegal aliens.
Unfortunately, the import of the case is much more far-reaching than that.

New York State and City, for example, currently forbid illegal immigrants from
receiving a number of public benefits and from participating in several public
welfare programs. If the arguments of the appellees are accepted by the Supreme
Court, Federal courts could require the state and city to provide illegal
immigrants with every benefit and welfare program given to citizens. Illegal
aliens could be entitled to food stamps, public housing, free higher education,
employ-ment (and unemployment compensation), the right to keep and bear arms,
drivers' licenses - and a host of other rights and programs.

Any distinction made by a state or city between citizens and foreigners
illegally in the United States could be considered unconstitutional
discrimination. As one amicus brief in the case states, ''Since the statutory
classification of undocumented aliens will inevitably burden racial and ethnic
minorities, it should be subjected to heightened judicial scrutiny ....''

In other words, the whole line of court decisions and laws which protect
American minorities against discrimination in public programs should guarantee
American benefits to anyone in the world who reaches our shores.

It is hard to believe that The Times would support such a conclusion. As the
Federation for American Immi-gration Reform said in its brief supporting the
State of Texas, ''No one wishes to deny these claimants an education for their
children. But lines must be drawn to secure respect for the law, because
otherwise the opportunity for the country to respond effectively to (illegal
immigrants) can be critically handicapped at precisely the moment when national
leadership needs the flexibility to fashion policies appropriate to the times
... At stake in this case is the power of the United States to control
immigration and therefore its borders, and, in a larger sense, its future. A
decision which would at once dilute this power and encourage lawless behavior is
at odds with the fundamental character of our government.'' ROGER CONNER
Executive Director, Federation for American Immigration Reform Washington, Oct.
15, 1981

Reagan Aid Defends Detention of Hatians

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 23, Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 228 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15


Attorney General William French Smith today defended the Reagan Administration's
detention of Haitian refugees, saying: ''Anytime a Haitian being detained wants
to walk out the front door, he can do it. As a matter of fact, we'd welcome it,
as long as he wants to go home.''

The Attorney General told a news conference that the policy of detaining
Haitians refugees of stationing a Coast Guard cutter off the Haitian coast to
turn back other would-be refugees was ''working remarkably well.''

He said that 47 Haitians were caught entering the country last month, as opposed
to 1,021 in November 1980.  The Attorney General also disputed critics who have
charged that the Administration was singling out Haitians for exclusion because
they are black.

''We're treating them exactly as we're treating illegal immigrants everywhere
else,'' Mr. Smith said ''It's often overlooked that on the southwest border, we
detain illegals and always have.''

The Attorney General said that the Administration refused to consider Haitians
as political refugees ''except in very rare cases.''

He also rejected criticism of conditions in the centers where some 2,700
Haitians are being kept while their attorneys try to persuade judges to treat
them as political refugees.

               December 18, 1981, Friday, Late City Final Edition

A Haitian Freeze

SECTION: Section A; Page 34, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 406 words


A Christmas plum to Attorney General William French Smith. His Justice
Department has not abandoned the idea of sending illegal immigrants who have
fled Haiti to detention at icy Fort Drum, N.Y.  But now it says it won't do so,
at least not during the dead of winter.

To hold poor, desperate people from the tropics in a camp near the Canadian
border, where the temperature yesterday morning was 12 degrees, would be
callous. ''Siberia,'' some people say. So we're all for Mr. Smith's conclusion,
even though we don't exactly follow his logic.

The Attorney General observes that 1,021 illegal Haitian migrants were caught
entering the country in November 1980, while in November of this year the number
was only 47. That, he says, shows that the Administration's policy of
intercepting and detaining Haitians is ''working remarkably well.'' And it means
existing detention camps in Florida and elsewhere can handle all the Haitian
illegals; the Fort Drum plan can be deferred.

But the numbers can also be read another way -not as a sign that the fear of
freezing deters migration but that illegal Haitian entrants are struggling much
harder to avoid capture. If they were caught in November 1980, nothing awful
happened. They were allowed to stay, even work, pending a hearing on whether
they were legitimately entitled to refugee status. Now everyone who is caught is
put in a detention camp.

There is another set of relevant new numbers. They show that in fiscal 1981 503
Haitians applied for asylum, as refugees. Compare that with 36,296 Cubans, 7,138
Iranians, 4,111 Nicaraguans, 1,670 Poles, 992 Ethiopians. All told, 63,202
foreigners asked for asylum.

Why make such a fuss over only a few hundred black Haitians, especially when
doing so is sure to engender accusations of racism?  There are two answers. One
is technical: most of the Haitians got here illegally and, when caught, are
detained for fear of encouraging more illegals. Most of the asylum applicants
from other countries came in legally, as students or visitors, but overstayed.
That is a lesser transgression than sneaking in; they need not be detained.

Pending remedial action by Congress, there is another, less technical answer:
make less of a fuss over the Haitians. The interim decision on Fort Drum is a
welcome step in that direction.

               October 12, 1980, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

DO ALIENS FILL NEED OR CROWD JOD FIELD;
DALLAS

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME

SECTION: Section 12; Special Section Page 45; Page 45, Column 1; Carreers
Supplement Desk

LENGTH: 1133 words


WHEN 29-year old Dock Green lost his job on the management-training squad at a
fried-chicken franchise here, the first telephone call he made was to the United
States Immigration and Naturalization Service.

''I realized I was in trouble right from the start when I saw that I was the
only one there who spoke English. Everyone else spoke only Spanish,'' Mr. Green
said. ''I kept complaining to my boss that all these people were illegal aliens,
and he didn't want to do anything about it.

''I have nothing against those people, but every day we had people coming in
asking about jobs, and it's a pitiful shame to have people who are born and
raised here be out of work, and have these illegal aliens taking their job. To
me, the law means what it says, and if those people are illegal, then the law
should be obeyed.''

Mr. Green is not alone in his frustration. Illegal aliens are playing an
increasingly visible role in the job market, a role subjected to rising
criticism at a time of relatively high unemployment of Americans.

But Hispanic leaders and many academics insist the impact of those workers is
essentially benign. They say Mexican workers who cross the 1,300-mile border
into the United States do the menial jobs Americans don't want, are essential
for the harvesting of crops, and use very few municipal services while filling
the lowest niches in the job market.

Ruben Bonilla, president of the 100,000-member League of United Latin-American
Citizens, said undocumented workers, in addition to playing a positive role in
the economy, actually increase tax revenues by paying for Social Security
service they seldom use. He said any crackdown on Mexican immigration would have
a much more harmful effect than any displacement of Americans from available
jobs that goes on now.

''If we close the border, I feel that Mexico would literally burst at the
seams,'' he said. ''When you look at Mexico's 30 percent inflation and crippling
unemployment, it's clear these people have nowhere else to go. If they couldn't
leave, I think social conditions in Mexico could become so bad there would be
the loss of the democratic republic in Mexico as we know it. I don't think
America would want a Socialist or Communistic nation any closer than Cuba.''

Most experts would agree with Mr. Bonilla that Mexicans and other aliens fill
manual tasks that are the least desirable in the job market. But many of those
same experts also would agree with Mr.  Green that there is no shortage of
Americans competing for many of those jobs.

Proposals to deal with the flood of illegal aliens in the job market have ranged
from tighter border patrols, to sanctions against employers who hire illegal
aliens, to temporary work visas that would allow a limited number of aliens to
work here legally. Even those calling for one policy or another concede there is
no way to be sure how many illegal aliens are in the work force or what their
effects have been.

''I don't have any hard data and I don't know anyone who does,'' said Dr. Vernon
Briggs, a labor economist at Cornell University, who has studied illegal
immigration since the mid-1960's. ''But it can't be in the best interests of
this country to have a whole population of people who are without rights, people
who can't vote, people who have to live in constant fear of detection. It's
becoming a problem we can't ignore any longer even if we wanted to.''

Estimates on the number of illegal aliens vary from 6 million to 12 million, but
despite the lack of hard figures, some trends are clear. The vast majority live
and work in three states, California, Texas and Florida, and two cities, New
York and Chicago. Most of them come here for one reason: to work.

Most illegal aliens work in agriculture, restaurants, or hotels.  Mexico, which
sends an estimated 500,000 illegal aliens into this country every year, is the
biggest source. Other aliens come from Cuba, Haiti, the Dominican Republic, Hong
Kong, the Philippines and dozens of other nations, but experts estimate 60
percent of illegal aliens in the country are Mexican.

Dr. Briggs, who became interested in illegal aliens after trying to help
organize farm workers in south Texas in the 1960's, said his research shows
illegal aliens compete with Americans for jobs in all industries in which they
are represented, at the same time depressing wages and blunting moves toward
unionization or improvement of working conditions.

''The studies that have been done show the employment patterns of illegal aliens
in the Southwest are very similar to those of other Chicanos in terms of
geography and occupation. We've built this whole phantom labor source into the
labor market and someone must show what they do if not compete with the
available labor force.''

One matter that is not in question is the conditions under which illegal aliens
live. Francisco Barba, a San Francisco lawyer who has defended hundreds of
illegal aliens, told the Select Commission on Immigration and Refugee Policy, a
group created almost two years ago to study immigration policies, that
''immigration labor today is America's neo-slavery institution.'' Federal
investigators in recent years have documented hundreds of cases of abuse of
illegal aliens. A Federal Department of Labor strike force investigating
treatment of illegal aliens in Houston, Dallas and Fort Worth this year
uncovered $1.2 million in underpayments owed 4,470 employees, most of them
illegal Mexican aliens. Officials said the investigation involved only a tiny
percentage of illegal aliens in the area.

In 1977, President Carter asked Congress to pass legislation allowing the
Government to fine employers who knowingly hire illegal aliens. The legislation,
and others like it, was rejected, but another bill calling for employer
sanctions is pending before the Senate Judiciary Committee and may be considered
by the entire Senate later this year.

Supporters say sanctions are the most effective way to keep aliens out of the
labor market. Some opponents say sanctions would make employers do the job of
the Immigration and Naturalization Service.  Others say aliens are essential in
some industries -primarily farm work - where there is not an adequate supply of
Americans who will do the work. And Hispanic leaders say sanctions would prompt
employers to discriminate against all Hispanics.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Peter Applebome contributes regularly to The Times from Dallas.

                January 1, 1982, Friday, Late City Final Edition

FLASH FIRES OF RUMOR KEEP HAITIAN CAMP ON EDGE

BYLINE: By GREGORY JAYNES, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Page 7, Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 1118 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, Dec. 31


A snake, sometimes merely a searing bite from a deer fly, can spark a stampede
in a cattle holding pen. Something unfamiliar brought into a henhouse - a pipe
elbow or a hank of rope are enough to do the trick - will spook chickens into
riot. The flashpoint is even lower at a detention facility for illegal aliens
here: a rumor is enough to drive people wild.

The Krome Avenue Detention Facility, named for the nearest thoroughfare, which
years and years ago was named for a nearby farmer, has no more amenities than a
place for cows or domestic fowl. Its administrators, the United States
Immigration and Naturalization Service, are not proud of it. Seeking shelter as
well as a place for processing the waves of Cubans that hit here in 1980, the
Federal authorities settled on Krome, a closed missile base on the eastern edge
of the Everglades. It was to be a temporary expedient.

It is still in use. The Cuban crush diminished, but the flood of Haitian
refugees continued well into this year. Krome, a hangar an d atent holding camp
with an ''emergency'' capacity of 859 people, by midsummer was housing 1,500. To
relieve the overcrowding, the service was ' 'sponsoring out'' 50 Haitians a day
to relatives or volunteer org anizations. Miami, inundated by 125,000 Cubans the
year before, seein g approaching Haitian boats on the seascape every day,
screamed to t he Federal Government for relief.
'In a Detention Posture'

The resulting threat of Coast Guard interdiction on the high seas, the threat of
a permanent detention facility somewhere in the coldest part of this country and
the end of ''sponsoring out'' have stopped the tide of Haitians. As the year
ends, the naturalization service is in what it calls a ''detention posture.''
And a Haitian named Milus, the father of 10 children, is in his seventh month at
Krome.

''We get up and we eat,'' he said through a translator the other day. ''Then
they put us in the yard. The sun boils us. At midday they send us to eat again.
Then after we eat they send us inside. Then we lay on our beds. I have a Bible
but I cannot read. Some words I understand.''

Milus continued: ''I hold it and I look at it and sometimes I find a little word
that I understand and it stops me from going mad. There is a policeman at the
door and you cannot go out. You have no freedom. Later you can go out and if you
can find some water you can bathe. When I was in Haiti I thought I could work
much more here and support my children. Everywhere in Haiti they speak of
Miami.''

'I Will Carry Your Garbage'

Finally: ''If they would release me, even if there is no work outside, I will
find work. In Haiti you put your head upset down trying to find ways to get
money for your family. Can I clean your car? I will carry your garbage.
Anything.''

Milus (the naturalization service will not permit the use of the detainees' full
names) is one of 650 men still being held at Krome while civil liberties groups'
suits for Haitian rights inch their way through the courts. There are 50 Haitian
women now at the camp. Some detainees have been there as long as 10 months. One
of these, Lucian, believes that rumors drive the people madder than the long
days without a thing to do.

''All the time there are rumors in the yard,'' Lucian said. ''All the time. I
warn the people they talk too much. They listen to stupidities. They have crazy
things they say. People are losing their minds. Prison does that. It makes them
think and say crazy things. It is so crazy you cannot remember. You cannot hold
on to crazy things said to you.''

Start of Hunger Strike

False word of the death of a detainee can burn through the camp like a dynamite
fuse. It happened Nov. 6, putting Krome on edge for days. When someone falls ill
the suspicion is nearly always that he was poisoned. Anyone transferred is
always transferred to a hell much worse than Krome. On Christmas Eve, according
to the detainees, the message with no known origin was, ''Don't eat and they'll
let you out.''

A hunger strike began. On Sunday, 300 demonstrators f rom Miami's Haitian
community, having heard the detainees were fainting from hunger -and this, too,
a rumor - stormed the gate at Krome. Stones and bottles were thrown at guards.
The guards retaliated with tear gas. The demonstrators set small fires in the
sawgrass outside the camp. In the bald yard inside, 150 Haitian me n made a
break. Lucian says it was because the people in the yard sa w the smoke, heard
the commotion and bolted.

They scaled the 10-foot chain link fence at the back of the yard, grabbing the
strands of barbed wire on top and leaving behind little shreds of flesh.

Milus said the guards rushed back to stop the escapes with tear gas. ''A lot of
them were afraid because they had never been gassed before,'' he said, adding
that he had been through disturbances and tear gas at Krome before. ''The gas is
terrible because our eyes burn and our mouths burn and we can't breathe.''

''They don't have gas on La Gonave,'' he said, referring to the island in the
bay of Port-au-Prince from whence he came.
He Believes They Are in Montana

Milus said the gas stopped him from making it over the fence. A hundred men made
it. Milus does not know that. He and the others in the yard think they were
caught outside and taken to a prison in Montana, where they are freezing today.
(For a time, the service considered establishing a detention facility in
Glasgow, Montana, but the idea was abandoned.)

The Haitian said everyone was locked inside Sunday night. He said that on Monday
the immigration officials told them to stop the hunger strike and there would
not be any trouble. So they started eating, he said, giving an esentially
accurate account.

Now they are all back standing in the bright sun. A man named Escanej is telli
ng the latest story. He borrowed $800 from a money lender named Samson in
Port-au-Prince to pay for having himself smuggled to M iami on a plane. He was
supposed to pay it back at $300 a month for a year, such was the interest. But
he was picked up immediately, and has not made a single payment to his cousin,
who wassupposed to t urn the payments over to Samson. His cousin, the father of
six childr en, has since been found beaten to death in a cemetery. Tongues cluck
, and the story flies across the monotonous morning.

               January 19, 1982, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

2 EXILE COMMUNITIES PROTEST IN MIAMI

BYLINE: By GREGORY JAYNES, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 18, Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 1107 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, Jan. 18


Protest has at times seemed the lifeblood of Miami's Latin community, which now
makes up 58 percent of the city's population, but until this weekend no protest
had been marked by violence, nor, according to participants in a Saturday night
demonstration, had there been such a sense of personal loss.

About 3,000 Cubans turned out to protest the deportation of a Cuban stowaway
last week, the first time in the years of local Cuban gains that the United
States has shipped a Cuban refugee to Havana.  At the same time, another
volatile and growing ethnic presence in Miami, the 20,000-strong Haitian
community, was on the streets because it, too, had suffered a loss: A tiny,
locally launched attempt to overthrow the Haitian Government had failed
miserably, and most of its participants were under Federal arrest.

Failed to Prove His Case

In the Cuban case, the State Department found last week that Andres Rodriguez
Hernandez, a 20-year-old Cuban discovered aboard a Panamanian freighter in
Miami, had failed to prove a ''well-founded fear of persecution,'' the criterion
under which political asylum is granted or denied under present immigration
policy. Mr. Hernandez was deported to Havana Friday. He was the first Cuban sent
back since Fidel Castro took power in 1959.

The deportation had two effects locally. It defused a legal argument by Haitian
advocates that the United States was discriminating against refugees from
nations that are friendly, such as Haiti, while going to great lengths to
accommodate refugees from unfriendly nations, such as Cuba. The other effect was
to put the flame to a fuse in the Cuban community, which saw the decision as
barring friends and relatives who might try to flee here.

About 3,000 demonstrators began the protest on Calle Ocho, or Eighth Street,
Saturday night. At the end, stones, bottles and tear gas canisters were flying,
34 persons were arrested and charges of police brutality were made. At a special
meeting of the five-member Miami City Commission Sunday, the police said the
violence began after the protesters, who did not have a permit for a
demonstration, were told to disperse. Participants said the demonstration had
been peaceful until police officers moved against them with tear gas.

They Vote to Write Reagan

The commission, of which three members are Hispanic, voted to write the White
House condemning the deportation of the Cuban and to ask the Justice Department
to investigate to see whether the police used undue force. The city's only black
commissioner, Miller Dawkins, explained to the protesters that the Federal
Government ''cannot allow the Cubans to stay while it sends all the Haitians
back.'' ''That is why they sent this man back,'' he said.

A local columnist, Roberto Fabricio, observ ed in his weekly column in The Miami
Herald this morning: ''Cubans ha ve grown accustomed to seeing Miami and the
rest of the United State s as the lifeboat they have traditionally climbed
aboard. The deport ation of Rodriguez Hernandez is symbolic of the end of an
era. B itterness bordering on despair is a mild description of the resultin g
feeling.''

Among Haitians, who number 20,000, the feeling was not dissimilar, according to
leaders. A hapless coup attempt ended last week and 25 of the invaders, picked
up from a sinking boat, were brought back to Miami Sunday by the Coast Guard.

He Had Leaflets Dropped

For months, Bernard Sansaricq, a Haitian and an operator of a Shell service
station in Broward County, north of Miami, had been talking about the invasion.
In October, Mr. Sansaricq has acknowledged, he had a plane fly over
Port-au-Prince, the Haitian capital, dropping leaflets denouncing President
Jean-Claude Duvalier and announcing a coming invasion.

Earlier this month rumors flew that t he invasion was imminent, and Mr.
Sansaricq , who came to this country after participating in an abortive atte mpt
to overthrow the Haitian regime in 1963, went to theisland of Sou th Caicos, 90
miles north of Haiti, to prepare for the strike. On Su nday, Jan. 10, the
37-year-old revolutionary left the island in a 3 5-foot boat with 24 followers.
The day before, at least nine other Sa nsaricq followers went by seaplane to the
island of Tortuga, off Haiti's northwest coast, where they were captured.

On Tuesday, Jan. 12, the Haitian Government announced that three of the nine had
''succumbed to their wounds.'' Last Wednesday, the Sansaricq vessel, a sloop
called the Caicos Cloud, was intercepted by the Coast Guard cutter Gallatin,
which had picked up radio distress calls. The vessel was leaking and her engine
was stalled. A Coast Guard spokesman said they had been ''floating around
seasick for a couple of days.''

Two Others Also Charged

Sunday Mr. Sansaricq was brought back to Miami charged with violating the United
States Neutrality Act for leading an expedition against another nation.
Conviction carries a maximum penalty of three years in prison and a $3,000 fine.
Two of his followers were also charged with violating the Neutrality Act, and
the others were being held as material witnesses.

About 200 Haitians demonstrated outside the Coast Guard base here Sunday,
shouting words of praise for Mr. Sansaricq. As he was brought in for an initial
appearance before a magistrate this morning, another throng of Haitian
supporters gathered. Some participants at these and other demonstrations said
many of Miami's Haitians had worked themselves into a state of unrealistic
optimism, to the point that they believed success was at hand.

Mr. Sansaricq was ordered released on a personal bond of $400,000, and Milo
Gousse, a 37-year-old geography instructor in Montreal, and Phillipe Carre, a
32-year-old employee of a security system in Montreal, were ordered released on
$100,000 signature bonds, pending trial.
----

Murder Count Dropped in '80 Riots

MIAMI, Jan. 18 (AP) - The state dropped murder charges today against William
Paul Hembree, the only white accused of killing a black in the race riots here
in May 1980.

Defense attorneys said they convinced the state that it was a case of mistaken
identity. Assistant State Attorney Leonard Glick, who was to prosecute Mr.
Hembree in the killing of 38-year-old Lugene Brown, said, ''We cannot in good
faith proceed to trial.''

Mr. Hembree, 35, remained in the Dade County Jail on charges of parole
violation. He was arrested last August after the police were told that he had
boasted of shooting a black man in Liberty City on May 18, 1980.

               February 3, 1981, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

OFFICE IN BRONX SEIZE 84 PERSONS AS ILLEGAL ALIENS

BYLINE: By PETER KIHSS

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 6; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 747 words


Eighty-four suspected illegal aliens, many of them crowded into a
tractor-trailer truck, were seized in the South Bronx yesterday after shots were
fired without warning at two police officers responding to a report that
''suspicious persons'' were getting out of the truck.

Fifty-one of those arrested, including 14 women, were still in the truck, in
which all 84 had allegedly traveled for nearly three days.  Henry S. Dogin,
district director of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, said two men -
identified as Roopnarine Singh, a resident alien from Guyana, and Efrain Vega, a
United States citizen from Puerto Rico - were arrested on charges of unlawful
transportation of illegal aliens in the United States.

Said to Be From Mexico

Mr. Dogin said the 83 Dominicans and one Guatemalan seized in the roundup were
reported to have entered El Paso from Mexico late last Friday or early Saturday
and to have packed into the trailer for the trip to New York.

It was 6:30 A.M. yesterday when two police radio cars were directed to check a
report that seven ''suspicious persons'' were getting out of a trailer.

Officers James McCormack and Frank Califano of the Alexander Avenue station
found a trailer at East 156th Street and Cauldwell Avenue, in the Melrose
section of the Bronx, that was parked outside an egg factory on legitimate
business.

Another Truck Is Halted

Officer Califano then spotted another trailer truck down Cauldwell Avenue and
closer to Westchester Avenue. The two officers halted the vehicle as it started
to leave. Officer McCormack said the driver asserted that he had lettuce from
California in the trailer that he was taking to the Hunts Point Market.

Asked to open the truck, the driver said his brother had the keys, and pointed
toward a fourth-floor apartment at 647 Cauldwell Avenue.  The officers started
upstairs and got to the third floor.

''A female, about 35, saw us, and ran into an apartment and slammed the door,''
Officer McCormack said. ''Then shots came from the fourth floor, five of them,
five holes in the wall.''

''Me and Frank,'' he said, ''ran downstairs to get ourselves together. The
driver ran up to the fourth floor.'' About 20 officers responded to a radio call
for reinforcements.  Officers McCormack and Califano, who had both been wearing
their bulletproof vests, went up to the fourth floor.

23 People in One Apartment

''A lady opened the door,'' Officer McCormack said. ''We couldn't see anybody
inside. 'Mind if we take a look?' we asked. The bedroom was jammed. People were
sitting on the floor and in chairs. There were seven in the bedroom, a total of
23 people in the apartment.''

One was the driver, he said.  In a second-floor apartment, the police found 11
more persons.  There were six women among the group in the apartments, Mr. Dogin
of the Immigration Service said.

Officer McCormack said a search found more than $10,000 in cash hidden in the
fourth-floor gas oven-broiler, with the money in denominations of $50 and $100.
He said there was a report that a driver could ''clear $500'' for each person
transported in such an operation.

According to the office of District Attorney Mario Merola of the Bronx,
investigators found a .25-caliber automatic revolver in a closet in the
fourth-floor apartment but could not immediately determine who was the owner of
the weapon or whether it had been fired.

51 Found Huddled in Trailer

Members of the police emergency service unit cut the padlocks on the
tractor-trailer and found 51 people huddled inside. Officer McCormack said that
apparently seven persons at a time were unloaded into the apartment building.

An assistant United States attorney, Robert J. Costello, who ordered the arrest
of Mr. Singh and Mr. Vega as drivers of the tractor-trailer, said the interior
of the vehicle was filthy and pockmarked with foodstuffs and garbage.

The aliens were to be held at the immigration detention center at the former
Brooklyn Navy Yard, pending a hearing before a Federal immigration judge.

Mr. Dogin said the roundup was believed to be ''the largest seizure in smuggling
in the New York district, certainly in the last seven years.''

              February 4, 1981, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

ILLEGAL ALIENS TERM 2,000 MILES IN LOCKED TRUCK 'HELL'

BYLINE: By PETER KIHSS

SECTION: Section B; Page 4, Column 4; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 707 words


It was ''like a hell'' on the nonstop 2,000-mile trip for 85 men and women
locked into a truck for nearly three days on a trip from El Paso to New York,
Manuel Roberto Mejia said yesterday. Mr. Mejia, who was one of the people in the
truck, spoke Spanish, using the word ''infierno'' to describe conditions on the
long ride.

At the end, all 85 were rounded up by New York police officers Monday morning
and turned over to Immigration and Naturalization Service officials for hearings
and likely deportation as aliens entering the United States illegally.

Mr. Mejia, a 24-year-old university student majoring in history in the Dominican
Republic for the last two years, and five of his companions agreed to interviews
yesterday while in custody at the immigration processing center at 136 Flushing
Avenue, Brooklyn. They said none of the six could speak English.

''We came to the United States,'' Mr. Mejia said, clad in blue detention
fatigues, ''because the economic situation for Dominicans is too precarious. It
is very difficult.''

Minimum Wage $100 a Month

''It is almost impossible to buy necessities - the minimum wage is 125 pesos a
month,'' he went on. Prospero Ayala said this meant about $100 in American
money.

''Unemployment in the country is too great, calculated that we have one million
persons unemployed in a country so small,'' Mr.  Mejia said. He added that the
Government had just announced that it was going to lay off 30,000 public
employees.

Mr. Ayala, 33, said he was a diesel mechanic and married to an American woman
from Puerto Rico, Jovita Rodriguez Ayala, now in Chicago. Ever since they were
married in Santo Domingo in May 1975, he said he had been trying to get a visa
to come to the United States.

He got to Mexico on his own two months ago, he said, having sold an old car for
$700, and made his way from one place to another - Mexico City, Monterey,
Chihuahua - until he learned of the group heading for New York.

In Washington, the Immigration Service said the quota for the Dominican Republic
allowed a maximum of 20,000 immigrants a year, not counting parents, spouses and
children of United States citizens who also should be able to enter. In 1979, it
reported only 17,519 legal entrants from the island.

Papers Sought Were Unavailable

Mr. Ayala said he was continually asked by the United States consulate for
papers he could not get, for instance, ''a baptismal certificate - my family is
Evangelical.''

Manuel Medina, 28, said he graduated from the University of Santo Domingo with a
master's degree in social work in 1978, but had never been able to get a job in
his profession. He left his daughter, 8, and son, 4, and their mother in Santo
Domingo to come here for ''whatever work I could get.''

Mr. Medina said that visa applicants had to show property, for example, ''an
account of $5,000 on deposit in a bank for one year.'' Mr. Ayala, who comes from
Bani, said he had met a Dominican who said he could arrange for a trip to New
York by way of Mexico for 500 pesos, with $500 or $1,000 more to be paid after
getting jobs, which they would have to find. Usually they borrowed the initial
payment.

Plane Taken to Mexico

The people from the truck said they were flown in a commercial plane to Mexico
City last Wednesday, and taken by bus to ''the desert outside Ciudad Juarez.''
Last Friday, all 85 walked across the border. That night, they were crammed into
a tractor-trailer.

Men and women jammed together. They had food and soda, but no place to dispose
of refuse. They had to relieve themselves in plastic containers.

Two men, Roopnarine Singh, a Guayana native, and Efraine Vega, were held in
$200,000 bail Monday night by United States Magistrate Leonard Bernikow as
having illegally transported the aliens in the United States. Assistant United
States Attorney Robert J. Costello said the penalty of five years and $2,000
fine for each case, if convicted, could confront them each with 425 years in
prison and $175,000 fines.

PLAN ON ILLEGAL ALIENS TO BE DISCLOSED SOON BY THE ADMINISTRATION

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 31, Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 293 words

DATELINE: TARPON SPRINGS, Fla., June 27


The Reagan Administration will soon announce a program to deal with thousands of
illegal immigrants in Florida and the Southwest, Attorney General William French
Smith said today.

''We have lost control of our own borders,'' Mr. Smith said in a speech to the
annual meeting of the Florida Bar Association. ''We have lost control of not
only the number, but also the type of persons who enter the country.''

Mr. Smith made the announcement in a news conference before the speech. He said
that the Administration wanted to ''streamline and speed up'' the process of
deporting illegal aliens but he would not specify any possible changes in
immigration laws.

''We do intend in the next few days,'' he said, ''to announce a program which
will deal with the Cuban-Haitian situation in Florida.'' He said the proposals
would be a product of a cabinetlevel study group he heads.

In his speech, the Attorney General said that there were three million to six
million illegal aliens in the United States and that the number was growing by
about 500,000 a year.

Mr. Smith said the study group had considered various options, such as stopping
and turning back boats loaded with Haitians or dealing more harshly with people
who traffic in illegal aliens.

''As of right now, our hands are tied to a certain extent by a temporary
restraining order issued by the courts,'' the Attorney General said.

The order Mr. Smith referred to was issued by a Federal judge in Miami earlier
this month after lawyers representing Haitians complained that their clients
could not understand deportation proceedings and were being denied due process.

              October 28, 1981, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

AUTOPSIES CALLED 'HARD EVIDENCE' THAT SMUGGLERS ASSISTED HAITIANS

BYLINE: By GREGORY JAYNES, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 1504 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, Oct. 27


A medical examiner said today that the bodies of 33 drowning victims amounted to
''good, hard evidence'' that many of the thousands of illegal Haitian immigrants
who have made it to these shores have been helped by smugglers.

Dr. Ronald Wright of Broward County performed autopsies on the Haitians who
drowned yesterday morning when their homemade boat capsized within sight of the
expensive condominiums of Hillsboro Beach, a resort town 10 miles north of Fort
Lauderdale.

The medical examiner said his examinations showed that those who died had
consumed large, cooked meals less than two hours before they drowned. The meal
could not have been cooked aboard the overcrowded 30-foot boat and the food was
fresh, so Dr. Wright concluded that it must have been served on a ''mother
ship'' or freighter operated by smugglers.

U.S. Prosecution Seen Possible

He said he also thought that by pinpointing the time of consumption he might
have established that the Haitians were dropped off in choppy waters that lie
within the jurisdiction of the United States, and the State of Florida, and thus
that the smugglers could be prosecuted if caught.

Top officials of the Immigration and Naturalization Service said privately that
they believed the medical examiner's findings and that they tended to put stock
in his conclusions.

However, at a news conference this morning at the Federal detention facility for
illegal aliens, two of the 30 survivors of yesterday's accident said they had
made the trip from Haiti unassisted and that their last meal consisted only of
beans, consumed two or three days before their boat capsized.

Reliance on Smugglers Stressed

Dr. Wright, as well as civil libertarians who have worked in the Haitians'
behalf, contend that the Haitians' reliance on the smugglers - to bring them
back again if they are deported; to bring their families here if they are
allowed to remain - is the largest reason for the conflicting accounts.

Leonard E. Rowland, assistant district director for the immigration service,
said: ''The individuals who explained it are saying what they had to eat or
didn't have to eat. The medical examiner has other information. I'm sure you can
draw your own conclusion.''

There are no figures, and no very good estimates, on how many Haitians come here
under their own power and how many are smuggled.  On Sunday night another vessel
- a sinking 30-foot boat with 57 Haitians -was intercepted 123 miles northwest
of Port-au-Prince. The intercepted craft was bound for the United States,
according to the Haitians, who were taken back to Port-au-Prince aboard the
Coast Guard cutter Chase.

The interception suggests that many of the 44,000 Haitians who have come here in
the last few years have made it on their own. But Haitians in Haiti have told
American journalists they have sold all their possessions to pay from $1,000 to
$2,000 for passage on a smuggler's ship to America.

A Coast Guard spokesman in Washington, John Sproat, said that news reports of
''mother ships'' sounded ''plausible.'' He said that the Coast Guard, and the
Haitian Government, had been concerned that Haitians were being forced to pay
''exorbitant'' prices and to serve as indentured servants by the smugglers.

''I like to call them vermin,'' Dr. Wright, the medical examiner, said of the
smugglers.

Death Toll Raised

In the autopsies, he said, he found two fetuses he thinks could have survived
outside the womb, and so he has increased the death count to 35. He also found
that ''not more than an hour or two before they died they had a very heavy,
cooked meal.'' He found chicken, rice, pork, potatoes and celery.

If the survivors' stories that they sailed for nine days unassisted from the
Bahamas were true, he said, the meat would have spoiled and he could have
detected it.

Further, Dr. Wright contends that the rickety boat that capsized could not have
traveled 12 miles in two hours, and that since he has fixed the time of the meal
consumption at less than two hours before they drowned, it would be right to
assume the meal was eaten on board a freighter that was in the territorial
jurisdiction of the United States and the State of Florida.

''I'm quite excited here about the prospect of prosecuting for third degree
murder,'' he said, ''and I hope we can find the people who did this.''

No Search Being Conducted

The trouble is that no one is looking for the people smugglers. A spokesman for
the Coast Guard in Miami, Chief Petty Officer Mario Toscano, said the Coast
Guard was not searching. ''I can say that if there was such a mother ship,'' he
said, ''that ship would probably be miles and miles away by now.'' Law
enforcement authorities in Broward County, where the drownings occurred, said
they were not looking for the ship, and state law enforcement authorities said
the same.

However, they and Federal authorities are looking for names. So far, the
survivors have said there was no mother ship. They have, though, said that a
captain, named Charles Joseph, and three mates swam to shore from the small boat
an hour before it capsized, admonishing the Haitians to stay put while they went
to arrange transportation to the beach. They did not come back, nor have they
been found.

At the news conference this morning,the two survivors, Frank Jean, 24 years old,
and Lucot Pierre, 20 - the only two who would talk at all, according to the
immigration service - said there was no mother ship, and that the last meal
anyone had was beans three days before the accident. The Haitians said through
an interpreter that they left Haiti Aug. 26 on the boat that eventually
capsized. They said they had spent about a month on uninhabited islands in the
Bahamas, catching crabs and licking rainfall water off leaves, and set sail for
this county Oct. 18.

Future Need for Smugglers

Dr. Wright thinks he knows the reasons for the contradictions between his
findings and the Haitians account. ''The service provided by the people who do
the people smuggling will be needed again,'' he said. From his experience with
earlier Haitian arrivals, he said, he knows that those deported will try to come
back, and those who are successful in staying will use their earnings to hire
the people smugglers to bring their families ''here to paradise, relatively
speaking.'' He said that reliance, coupled with superstitions that betraying the
smugglers might ''elicit supernatural retribution'' has in the past led the
Haitians to insist they sailed the 700 miles unassisted - even, in one instance,
when some came by plane, landed in Broward County, and one among them walked
into the propeller. ''I mean, when you talk to a bleeding man in the middle of
an airfield,'' said Dr. Wright, ''and he says he got here by boat, it's kind of
hard to believe.''

The best known smuggling case, and one of the rare ones successfully prosecuted
here, happened on Aug. 13, 1979. That night, in the water off South Palm Beach,
the spotlight of a police vessel fell on a 28-foot Chris Craft. The captain,
Jeffrey Hastings, eventually was convicted of forcing 18 Haitians into the water
at gunpoint, six of whom drowned. He was sentenced to 180 years in prison on six
counts of manslaughter.

''These vermin,'' Dr. Wright said of the smugglers, ''consider them to be some
sort of expendable cargo.''

N.A.A.C.P. Assails Reagan Order

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People called on the
Reagan Administration yesterday to end ''a barbaric assault on human freedom''
by rescinding the interdiction order against Haitian boats loaded with illegal
aliens bound for the United States.

At a news conference in the N.A.A.C.P.'s headquarters in New York City, the Rev.
Charles H. Smith, deputy executive director, also called for a Congressional
inquiry into the plight of the Haitian refugees and said his organization would
prepare a case for submission to the United Nations.

He said the association would seek to determine ''if there are violations of
international law taking place, as we believe there must be when the human
rights of a people are so brazenly ignored.''

Mr. Smith said a three-man association team, including himself, would leave
immediately for Miami on a fact-finding mission into the Haitian refugee
situation, including Monday's drownings.

But, the association official stressed, the ''first and immediate step should be
the rescission'' by the Reagan Administration ''of the interdiction order and a
reinterpretation of the status of Haitian refugees so that they are recognized
as political refugees.''

CAREY SEEKS AID ON ILLEGAL ALIENS

BYLINE: By GLENN FOWLER

SECTION: Section B; Page 3, Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 257 words


Governor Carey called upon President Carter yesterday to provide Federal funds
for essential services for the more than one million illegal aliens believed to
be living in New York State, as the President has promised for the recent flood
of Cuban and Haitian refugees.

''We're not talking about amnesty'' for the illegal aliens, Mr.  Carey said, but
about recognizing their presence and dealing with their needs. He noted, as he
and Mayor Koch have repeatedly contended in the past, that most undocumented
immigrants are not counted in the census, depriving the state and city of per
capita assistance under many Federal programs.

In an interview on the CBS-TV ''Newsmakers'' program and in remarks afterward,
the Governor said he had proposed to Mr. Carter that ''we have the same
treatment accorded to the economic refugees in New York'' as to the newer
immigrants.

He praised the Administration's announced intention to provide Federal funds to
help localities furnish health care, shelter, education and other essential
services to the Cuban and Haitian refugees, and to permit them to qualify for
citizenship in two years instead of the normal five years.

If such a program were applied to all illegal aliens, the Governor said, ''it
could take care of the major part of New York City's billion-dollar budget
gap.''

A spokesman for the Governor said that a formal request to Washington was being
prepared, asking that eligibility for Federal assistance for welfare and other
essential services be extended to all illegal aliens.

                 July 6, 1980, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

Identity Papers

SECTION: Section 4; Page 16, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 650 words


A recent law school graduate we know offers an entrancing short course in
American constitutional law. Regardless of the specific issue, she says, the
argument always ends up the same. One side says, ''That idea would lead straight
down the slippery slope.'' The other side says, ''No, it won't.'' There's a
moral here for an issue, involving both immigration and personal freedom, that
could hardly be more appropriate to a July Fourth weekend.

The issue is how to stem the tide of illegal immigrants crossing the border from
Mexico. The proposed solution is to give all Americans a forgery-resistant
Social Security card and require that it be shown to employers in order to get a
job. That would discourage illegal migrants. In this case, the slippery slopers
recognize the merit of controlling immigration. But they recoil from use of such
a card. It would, they fear, lead to national identity papers and police
statism. We're inclined to think, ''No, it won't.'' But what we're interested in
most of all is ways to traverse the mountain without losing balance.

Not even a new electronic fence has made it possible to control the flow of
illegal Mexican workers; for them, even exploitative wages in the Southwest are
high. The answer is not a fence but worker identification and it is now being
explored for the Government by a blue-ribbon commission on immigration. The
Social Security card would be convenient identification, but the present card is
a cinch to counterfeit. The answer to that is to make it forgery resistant. It
might include a photograph, or fingerprint, or signature. For maybe $5, a card
could be secure enough to defeat anyone outside the KGB.  What's wrong with
that? Nothing - except the slippery slope.

Some people think that the balance between spontaneity and social control in
America is already awry. Robert Ellis Smith, an authority on privacy, worries
about a ''European mentality of submitting to inspectors who tell you that 'Your
papers are in order.' '' John

Shattuck of the American Civil Liberties Union fears that worker identification
cards would be ''tantamount to a form of domestic passport.'' Such concerns are
made more acute by the knowledge that memories of

Watergate are fading; that Americans no longer seem so concerned about the
dangers of a police state; that they would rather be searched at airports than
hijacked in the air.

An improved Social Security card would not, of itself, present any new threat.
Less easily forgeable ones would not create any new information. Social Security
numbers are already used for bank accounts, and taxes, and medical benefits for
psychiatric treatment or venereal disease. Some slippery slope fears arise
because of the very reliability of the new card. The more reliable it is, the
more agencies will wish to use it. And using it for this non-Social Security
purpose might well make Congress more willing to let it then be used for others.
The F.B.I., for instance, might wish authority to ask people for their cards in
the course of trailing fugitives. In the wake of an assassination, say, or a
shocking terrorist episode, could Congress resist yielding such authority?

Such fears are rational. The question is, what should society do about them? It
is no more sensible to reject the identification idea because of potential
problems than to ban telephones because they can be tapped. The immigration
commission should proceed with its study of a worker-identification system. One
is needed. Meanwhile, let the rest of us address the larger questions. If
Congress pledges to permit this use for a new card and no other, can it be
trusted? If not, what about the idea of Prof. Alan Westin of Columbia for a
protective constitutional amendment? One way or another, it is possible to grope
toward protections against potential abuses. The slope may be slippery but
society does not have to slip.

                 July 25, 1980, Friday, Late City Final Edition

3 AGENTS OF BORDER PATROL CHARGED WITH BEATING 8

BYLINE: By JOHN M. CREWDSON

SECTION: Section A; Page 6, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 485 words

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, July 24


Three agents of the United States Border Patrol were charged by a Federal grand
jury here today with beating several illegal aliens and at least one American
citizen at the patrol's highway checkpoint 60 miles north of here.

The three agents are J. Gillespie Wood, a senior official, and Jose Martin
Barker and Lester M. Fullen.  At least eight persons, including a 15-year-old
boy who is an American citizen, and two undercover agents of the Immigration and
Naturalization Service were alleged to have been beaten by Mr. Wood and Mr.
Barker in an interrogation.

Both agents were charged with 17 counts of depriving people of their civil
rights and assaulting a Federal officer. Mr. Barker and Mr. Fullen, who
allegedly observed the beatings but did not participate, were also charged with
committing perjury before the grand jury that returned the 37-page indictment.

2 Undercover Agents Assigned

The multiple-count indictment disclosed that the immigration agency, after
receiving a number of allegations of beatings by border patrolmen at the
checkpoint in San Clemente, Calif., assigned two Hispanic agents three months
ago to pose as illegal aliens in an effort to gather evidence of the beatings.

The agents, dressed as Mexican workers, were put on a bus destined to pass
through the highway checkpoint, where they were taken off, arrested and
questioned by the three patrolmen indicted today.

The indictment alleges that Javier Dibene, one of the undercover agents, was
assaulted by Mr. Barker with a metal chair, and that Mr.  Dibene's partner, Juan
Espinal, had been beaten by Mr. Wood with a metal flashlight.

In a statement accompanying the release of the indictment, the Justice
Department said that ''at no time'' did the undercover agents ''attempt to
provoke an incident'' at the checkpoint, which is on heavily traveled Interstate
5.

Justice Department lawyers familiar with the investigation said it began after

Federal officials say illegal aliens have been victimized by hundreds of New
Jersey employers. Page B2.
the 15-year-old boy complained to the authorities that he had been beaten by
border patrolmen while passing through the checkpoint. The department's
statement said that after the beating, the boy had ''confessed'' being a Mexican
citizen and was returned to Mexico.

Today's indictment marks the second time that a group of border patrolmen have
been charged with violations of civil rights and other misdemeanors by the
United States Attorney's office here.

Last year four agents stationed in San Ysidro, Calif., across the border from
Tijuana, were charged with having beaten a number of Mexicans they apprehended
while trying to cross the border illegally.

Two of those agents, Jeffery Otherson and Bruce Brown, were convicted early this
year of misdemeanor violations of Federal civil rights statutes. The third
resigned and the fourth was acquitted.

                 July 27, 1980, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

BY TOM FERRELL AND MARGOT SLADE;
IDEAS AND TRENDS;
Can't Penalize the Young, Judge Says In Illegal Alien Case

SECTION: Section 4; Page 7, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1476 words


No one in Texas disputes the incalculable social cost of not educating the
children of illegal immigrants - social unrest among Hispanic Americans. Still,
Texas has refused the task, claiming that since undocumented workers are not
protected by constitutional guarantees, the state is not required to extend the
benefits of social services, including a public school education, to their
children. That argument did not persuade Federal District Court Judge Woodrow
Seals. Last week in Houston, he declared unconstitutional a 1975 Texas law that
effectively barred illegal aliens from attending public schools.

The law guarantees free public school education only to United States citizens
and legally admitted aliens. It allows school districts to charge tuition -
Houston has been charging $162 per month - to illegal immigrants who want to
enroll their children.

Judge Seals dismissed the state's plea that it lacks the financial resources to
educate between 20,000 and 100,000 illegal alien children, at what state
witnesses estimated could cost as much as $200 million a year. He discounted
arguments that bilingual programs were short on staff and funds, or that a
decision opening up the schools for free would set a precedent for extending
other state social services to illegal aliens. Citing the Constitution's
guarantees of due process and equal protection, Judge Seals ordered the state
not to exclude students from public school ''on account of their status under
United States immigration law,'' not to deny them participation in bilingual
programs, and not to charge tuition.  Attorneys for the state have asked for a
stay of the order and plan to appeal Judge Seals' decision.

Other states with large populations of illegal aliens, such as California and
Florida, admit the children to school.

Cable TV Gets Big Extension Cord

For several years, the Federal Communications Commission has been one of the
nation's most active deregulatory bodies. Last week, the commission, by a 4-3
vote, ended two regulations that have sharply limited the kinds and numbers of
programs that cable television systems could bring to their viewers.

The commission will no longer regulate the import of ''distant'' broadcasts into
the area served by a cable system. (Signals are defined as ''distant'' if they
come from more than 35 miles away from a large metropolitan market or more than
55 miles from a smaller market.) Nor will the commission any longer allow
broadcasters to have a cable signal blacked out if the cable program is also
available on local television stations, unless the two transmissions are
simultaneous. The deregulation will leave cable operators free, under the 1976
copyright law, to provide their customers with other people's programs. As
payment, they need only turn over a small percentage of their revenues to a
central fund administered by a copyright tribunal which has yet to determine
just how to reward the owners of the programs.

Reaction to the deregulation, which is already being challenged in the courts,
was divided along predictable lines; the National Association of Broadcasters
called the decision ''irresponsible,'' while Thomas Wheeler, president of the
National Cable Television Association, said cable, especially in nonmetropolitan
areas, could now ''offer their viewers what citizens in major markets have had
for years.''

According to Paul Kagan, an industry analyst and publisher of cable-television
newsletters, the ruling came as no surprise and much recent expansion of cable
systems has been taken in anticipation of it. In the New York metropolitan area,
according to Mr. Kagan's figures, about 750,000 households, or about 15 percent,
are now cable subscribers.

A.M.A. Delegates Heal Themselves

Accepting a second opinion, the American Medical Association last week discarded
its 23-year-old code of medical ethics - an object of dissaffection and
expensive lawsuits - and adopted a new code. It emphasizes patients' rights,
permits doctors to advertise their fees and sanctions referrals to
chiropractors.

The wounds of the old code have been festering for years.  Chiropractors charged
that its language prevented physicians from referring patients to or accepting
referrals from them, on grounds that they did not practice ''a method of healing
founded on a scientific basis.'' A Federal Trade Commission ruling, still under
appeal, found the ban on soliciting patients a restraint of competition among
doctors. The association has spent $1 million yearly defending itself.

Meanwhile, regular dues-paying membership has shrunk from 168,226 in 1970 to
151,376 last year, and as a percentage of the nation's physicians, from 50 to 33
percent. The decline reflects a number of new realities - a rise in membership
fees to the present high of $250 - particularly onerous to young, debt-burdened
doctors, competition from professional organizations for specialists that cater
directly to members' needs, and a sense among many doctors that the A.M.A. has
lost touch with changes in methods of practice, medical education and political
and social attitudes.

Also at the meeting in Chicago, members cut short procedural delays and
proclaimed that physicians should not participate in the execution of prisoners.
Four states now authorize executions by lethal injection.

Copenhagen Hears Politics as Usual

The United Nations conference on women has prompted the realization among many
of the more than 1,500 delegates meeting in Copenhagen that, worldwide, women
may have little in common except being female. Yet as the conference enters its
third week tomorrow, with political speeches and strategies evoking more passion
than programs for health care or illiteracy, one unifying effort has emerged
-''networking.'' Delegates to the conference, and to its unofficial cousin (the
''Forum''), meeting down the road at Copenhagen University, have begun
organizing an international web of contacts that may transcend political and
cultural differences.

Last week, however, it was sexually undifferentiated political disagreements, as
usual. A predominantly Arab conference committee adopted a strong resolution
calling for the Palestine Liberation Organization to be given a central role in
helping Palestinian women in Israeli-occupied territories. United States
delegates are working to block its consideration.

Natalia Malakhovskaya, one of three Russian feminist writers expelled from the
Soviet Union last weekend, arrived in Copenhagen in time to attend the
conference. With no official government accreditation, she was not be allowed to
speak. So she held a news conference outside and reported that ''women in the
Soviet Union work at least four times harder than men.''

Splicing Genes, Producing Insulin

For 60 years, insulin - a hormone essential to the body's metabolism of sugar -
has been used in the treatment of diabetics.  All that insulin has been
extracted from the pancreases of animals, usually pigs or cows. Last week, the
first tests in humans began of insulin manufactured by bacteria genetically
altered by so-called gene splicing techniques to produce human insulin. The
tests are being carried on at Guy's Hospital in London, using insulin provided
by Eli Lilly & Co., the American pharmaceutical firm.

Animal insulin, though similar enough to work fairly well, is not identical to
human insulin. Bacterially produced insulin is chemically identical, according
to Lilly, and one of the purposes of the test is to see whether the new insulin
is identical in its effects. In addition, a minority of diabetic patients
develop allergic reactions to animal insulin, just as they might with any other
alien protein.

The supply of animal insulin is determined by the supply of meat animals, and
does not respond to the demands of diabetics, who are an increasing portion of
the population. If biologically manufactured insulin passes testing in humans,
it could help avert a shortage of insulin that some authorities anticipate in
the mid-1980's.

               August 2, 1980, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

Paying the Price for Alien Children

SECTION: Section 1; Page 20, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 402 words


Picture a ramshackle apartment in which a semi-literate immigrant child
struggles to master the three R's from worn and borrowed books. No, not New
York's Lower East Side in 1890 but the city of Dallas in 1980. How come? The
Mexican-born children of illegal aliens have been kept out of school in 17
districts of Texas through prohibitive tuition charges. No other state
discriminates in this fashion. Now a Federal judge, properly, has stopped the
practice in Texas, too.

The number of alien children kept out of Texas schools is estimated at between
40,000 and 110,000. The state's excuse for excluding them was financial
necessity. Besides, Texans asked, why should they pay for immigrant children
whose presence is the result of lax Federal immigration enforcement?

Federal Judge Woodrow Seals has answered these contentions forcefully. Texas, he
ruled, can well afford the added burden of educating these children. And in any
case, the state cannot deprive alien children of the equal protection of the
law. It may be proper to discourage illegal immigration by denying welfare and
medical benefits to adults. But, he argued, children cannot be victimized for
decisions over which they have no control.

The judge might, in addition, have invoked some highly practical arguments. The
porous border with Mexico serves the economic interests of the border states and
their businesses as much as it serves the diplomatic interests of the United
States. Illegal aliens are anything but freeloaders. A 1978 report by a House
committee showed that the typical illegal alien worker in San Diego County paid
17 percent of his wages in taxes, a much larger share than was paid by citizens
earning the minimum wage.

The Federal Government does indeed owe some states and cities more support.
Washington is at least partly responsible for illegal immigrants, as it is for
urban concentrations of welfare recipients.  But communities that benefit from
immigrant labor should not also profit from its social neglect. Besides, as
Bishop John McCarthy testified in the Texas case, ''Whether it be right now in
the form of modest increases ... in public school operating cost, or ... in
terms of social cost ... fifteen years from now, we will pay this bill.''

AROUND THE NATION;
Texan Indicted on Charges Of Holding Alien in Peonage

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 12, Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 158 words

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Nov. 6


A Federal grand jury has indicted a seafood company owner on charges involving
holding an illegal Mexican alien against his will at an oyster processing plant.

Benjamin Harrison Nelson, 41 years old, owner of a concern on Galveston Bay, was
indicted yesterday on two peonage charges, two counts of kidnapping with intent
to hold a slave and aiding in the transportation of an illegal alien, the
authorities said.

Mr. Nelson could be sentenced to a maximum of 25 years in prison and fined
$22,000.  The indictments came after a chauffeur for the Mexican consul in the
border town of Brownsville called the United States Immigration and
Naturalization Service and said that his brother had been smuggled to Houston
and then to the community of Smith Point, where he was being held against his
will.

The chauffeur, in an affidavit filed with immigration officials, said his
brother had left the plant once but had been taken back at gunpoint.

               December 14, 1980, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

THE NATION IN SUMMARY;
by Micahel Wright and Caroline Rand Herron;
Immigration Panel Suggests Answers

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4, Column 2; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 417 words


If the immigration proposals tentatively adopted by a Federal commision last
weekend seem familiar, it is perhaps because they resemble some key changes
recommended by President Carter, and yawned at by Congress, three years ago.
Similarly, any difference in the situation - unresolved questions about illegal
aliens, inconsistencies in the law, poor morale in the field - is mostly a
difference of degree. Things were bad then; they are evidently worse now.

Among other things, the Select Commission on Immigration and Refugee Policy said
Congress should grant amnesty to illegal aliens already in the United States if
they ask for it; that could number one million of the three to six million
aliens thought to be here. It also said that employers who hired illegal aliens
in the future should be hit with civil or criminal penalties, and that the basic
quota for legal immigration should be increased slightly.

But the panel voted, 7 to 5, against issuing identification cards to all bona
fide American workers. Because illegal aliens are difficult to spot - and
because forged documents are easy to obtain - employer sanctions would be
meaningless without work identification cards, argued Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh,
chairman of the commission and president of the University of Notre Dame.
However, Patricia Roberts Harris, the Secretary of Health and Human Services and
one of four Cabinet officers on the panel, said she was ''unalterably opposed''
to cards because of the potential for ''wrongful use'' by the Government.

It's not clear what the Reagan administration will prefer, although during a
campaign stopover in Texas, the President-designate supported issuing ''guest
worker permits'' to Mexicans hired to harvest crops. In the past, such proposals
have been strongly opposed by labor and Hispanic leaders.

The mood of the new, more conservative Congress is another question mark. The
House of Representatives in 1972 and 1973 approved penalties for businesses with
illegal aliens on their payrolls, but the legislation died in the Senate. More
recently, pleas by officials of the Immigration and Naturalization Service for
money and officers haven't gotten the agency much more than sympathetic nods.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Michael Wright and Caroli ne Rand Herron
