               October 27, 1980, Monday, Late City Final Edition

IMMIGRATION SERVICE KEEPS LIST OF 'PROSCRIBED' GROUPS IN NATION

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 19, Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 710 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26


Although President Richard M. Nixon abolished the Attorney General's list of
subversive organizations six years ago, the Immigration and Naturalization
Service still maintains a list of ''proscribed'' and ''questionable''
organizations, immigration officials have disclosed.

Aliens who are members of any of the organizations on the list are subject to
special investigations and may be barred or expelled from the United States, the
officials said.

The existence of the list was disclosed incidentally in papers that the Justice
Department filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan in preparation for the
trial of a lawsuit brought by the Socialist Workers Party. Immigration officials
here provided further details about the list of ''organizations proscribed,
questionable and cleared.''

The list, an 89-page appendix to the immigration service investigator's
handbook, classifies 668 political organizations in seven categories: avowed
Communist groups, explicitly proscribed by the Immigration and Nationality Act
of 1952; groups held to be proscribed on the basis of classified information;
groups that appear to be legal; groups still under study; ''questionable''
organizations about which other Government agencies have supplied ''derogatory
information,'' and ''Communist-front'' and ''Communist-infiltrated''
organizations.

Basis for Listing Groups

There are 384 proscribed organizations in the first two categories. Groups are
labeled as ''Communist-front'' and ''Communist-infiltrated'' on the basis of
petitions filed with the old Subversive Activities Control Board, which passed
out of existence in 1973, a year before President Nixon abolished the Attorney
General's list of subversive organizations.

The handbook says that the immigration service took ''no position'' on how the
control board's decisions might affect an alien's status under the immigration
law.

The basic immigration law already automatically bars 33 classes of aliens,
including those who write, publish or distribute materials espousing the
''doctrins of world Communism or the establishment in the United States of a
totalitarian dictatorship.''

The Socialist Workers Party is not proscribed and membership ''does not in and
of itself constitute grounds for deportation,'' a senior immigration official
said. But the handbook says that an alien who belongs to the party should be
''questioned closely to determine his personal attachment to the principles of
the Constitution and his disposition to the good order and happiness'' in the
nation.

Move to Halt 'Blacklisting'

Margaret Winter, an attorney for the Socialist Workers Party, said that the
group had filed suit seven years ago to ''stop this type of blacklisting.''

''The Government said in 1974 that they were not going to use the Attorney
General's list any more,'' she said, ''and in 1976 they said they had terminated
the investigation of the party. Now we find that the Government is still using a
list against us and other legal organizations.''

Justice Department officials, including several who work on internal security
cases, said that they had not been aware of the immigration service's list.

Glenn A. Bertness, Assistant Commissioner of the immigration service, said it
was extremely rare for an alien to be deported for membership in one of the
listed groups. The alien, he said, can usually obtain a hearing before an
immigration judge and can argue that his membership was not ''meaningful'' or
active.

Proscribed groups on the immigration service list include the Communist Party of
the United States of America, the Federation of Greek Maritime Unions, the
Jewish Aid Society of Montreal and the W.E.B. DuBois Clubs of America.

The Socialist Workers Party suit, which seeks $40 million in damages from the
Government for alleged disruption of the party's activities, is tentatively
scheduled for trial next Jan. 5 in Federal district court in Manhattan. The
party, which is Marxist, says that it has no close political ties to China or
the Soviet Union.

               November 23, 1980, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

YOUNG SALVADORANS COMPLAIN OF JAILINGS IN MEXICO

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 23, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 617 words

DATELINE: TIJUANA, Mexico


Central Americans fleeing here from political violence in their homelands have
charged that they are being illegally jailed and extorted by Mexican immigration
officials and the police.

In most cases the refugees are young university students, often victims of
right-wing terrorist groups in their native countries, who arrive at the Tijuana
airport with valid visitor visas. Several of those currently held in the Tijuana
jail said their visas had been confiscated because immigration officials had
alleged that the refugees intended to cross illegally into the United States.

The jailed Central Americans, most of whom are from El Salvador, said they had
been forced to pay immigration officials in Mexico City $20 or $40 to continue
their trips. The immigration officials here demanded $150 and jailed the
refugees regardless of the fee payment, the detainees said.

Twenty-eight of the imprisoned Central Americans staged a hunger strike recently
to protest their confinement. Most were sent to Mexico City for deportation just
hours after the strike began.

Jose Perez Canchola, a lawyer and director of a Tijuana civil rights group that
is pressing for better treatment of the refugees, said the jailings were
unlawful. He explained that the immigration authorities argued that if a Central
American visa holder had insufficient cash or had no friends or relatives in the
area, immigration officials ruled that they would likely enter the United States
illegally and thus are deportable.

''There is nothing in the law that allows them to do this,'' said Mr. Perez
Canchola. ''No other foreigners are subject to these requirements,'' he said.
''It allows all sorts of arbitrariness.''

The situation has drawn criticism from the Mexican national press.  In an
apparent response to the charges of abuse, Roman Cardenas was dismissed on
Monday as Tijuana's immigration chief.

Neither Mr. Cardenas nor his successor, Primitivo Lomeli, has been available for
comment. The assistant chief, Alberto Corona, said he was not authorized to
speak to reporters about the matter.

According to Mr. Perez Canchola, Central Americans have been imprisoned here for
up to seven weeks while the police have attempted to extort money from them.
''They are told that if they can come up with several hundred dollars they can
get out,'' said Mr. Perez Canchola. ''What happens is that even if they pay,
they keep squeezing them for more. In the end they have no more money and they
just deported.''

Sometimes, he said, local attorneys call relatives in the United States and
offer to gain the release of the prisoners for $1,000 to $1,500.

Isabel Gomez, a Salvadoran mother of two, interviewed in her filthy dank cell at
the Tijuana jail, said that since being imprisoned two weeks ago, attorneys had
called her husband, an illegal alien living in California.

''They say they can get me out for $1,500,'' she said. ''He makes very little
money, and it was hard for him to get the $1,000 to have my children and me
brought here. Where will he get that kind of money again?''

In another part of the jail, several young Salvadoran university students
complained bitterly about ''illegal and inhumane treatment.''

''The Mexican Consul gives us visas, but he doesn't tell us they are only good
to go to jail,'' said Francisco Contreras.  ''We are running for our lives,''
said Mr. Contreras. ''That is important to understand. We are not here to get a
better job. If we stay in El Salvador, we die.''

               December 7, 1980, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

1,774 PEOPLE WITHOUT A COUNTRY: CUBAN REFUGEES SIT IN U.S. JAILS

BYLINE: By PAUL L. MONTGOMERY, Spec ial to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 1, Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 1401 words

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Dec. 5


In the cell blocks for Cuban refugees at the United States Penitentiary here,
the gray steel bunks are jammed end to end. Some inmates have draped sheets from
the bed above to create shadowy white havens in what has been their American
home for as long as seven months.

The 800 men in the pentitentiary here are among the 1,774 refugees from the
Cuban boatlift who were selected on arrival as criminals and are still
incarcerated in 17 institutions around the country. All but 37 are men; most
were imprisoned on the basis of their own admissions to immigration officers
that they had committed crimes ranging from murder to petty thievery. Almost
half have yet to receive a hearing on their status.

Of all the snarls in public services created by the surge of 125,000 Cuban
refugees into the country this year, the situation of these 1,774 is one of the
most tangled.

Since Cuba refuses to take them back, and since immigration law and public fear
prevent their admission to this country, most appear to be stuck where they are.
Acknowledging the problem, the Government is planning to convert the 1,500-bed
Atlanta penitentiary - known since its cons truct ion in 1902 as the place where
Federal prisoners serve ''hard time'' - into an all-Cuban facility next year.

Even the severest critics of immigration policy agree that there are some among
the 1,774 who should not be freed, though denial of due process in their cases
causes concern among civil libertarians.  However, many basically blameless
refugees appear to have been thrust into the same category as convicted
murderers and rapists by inadequate screening, faulty translation, bureaucratic
mix-ups and sheer bad luck.

When the boatlift began from Mariel, Cuba, on April 21, the Cuban authorities
announced that they were sending the United States ''escoria'' - ''scum.'' An
easy way to get a safe-conduct to the boats at Mariel was to show evidence of a
jail term for criminal or anti-government behavior.

Alberto Delgado Quesada, an Atlanta inmate, is 27 years old, polite and well
spoken. He was a bulldozer operator in Havana. Mr. Delgado says, however, that
he has never been in jail. To get the safeconduct, he says, he took over the
record of a friend who had been jailed for six months for stealing three pairs
of underpants from the factory where he worked to give to a girl friend.

Upon arrival in Key West, Fla., and in the processing centers afterward, each
refugee was asked whether he had ever been in jail.  Since the Immigration
Department has no access to Cuba's criminal records, officers had to take each
refugee at his word.

Mr. Delgado, fearing an inconsistency in his records, he says, ''confessed'' to
the theft of the underpants and the six-month sentence. He has been in the
Atlanta penitentiary since May 28.

Mr. Delgado, whose explanation of these circumstances was accepted by the
immigration court, is one of about 50 Atlanta inmates, only some of whom had
hearings, who have been cleared for release if sponsors can be found. But
finding sponsors has proved to be one of the most difficult problems in the
resettlement program.

While many sponsors stepped forward last spring, particularly in the Cuban
communities in Miami and northern New Jersey, most have dropped out because they
are already taking care of refugees or because of bad experiences with some of
the refugees released. For the sponsors remaining, priority is given to the
6,700 refugees without serious criminal records who are still being held in the
resettlement camp at Fort Chaffee, Ark.

''I haven't lost hope, but it has been a long time,'' Mr. Delgado, who left a
wife and 4-year-old daughter in Havana, said in an interview last Wednesday, the
first press interview permitted at the penitentiary since the arrival of the
Cubans. ''It's so easy to get demoralized. Most people have a set term when they
go to prison. Here there is no limit; the months keep passing.''

Crimes of 'Moral Turpitude'

Under immigration law, applications for admission to the United States can be
denied if the applicant has been accused of a crime of ''moral turpitude'' in
his country of origin. Crimes against persons, theft, embezzlement and
prostitution are in that category.

According to the immigration authorities, nearly 24,000 of this year's Cuban
refugees admitted to criminal records. Those incarcerated were generally those
who had been convicted of crimes that would be felonies in the United States.
Since they have theoretically not yet entered the country, the imprisoned
refugees are not considered by the courts to have such constitutionally
guaranteed rights as due process or equal protection under the law.

Each refugee is entitled to what is called an exclusion hearing before an
Immigration and Naturalization Serv ice judge and can be represented by counsel.
However, in such proc eedings the applicant has the burden of proving he is
worthy of ent ering the country ratherthan the Government's having the burden of
pr oving he is not. For example, the applicant cannot confront and qu estion an
immigration officer who may have misunderstood what he sa id on arrival.

Some Categories Elicited

The Government says it has no breakdown of the categories of crimes supposedly
committed by the 1,774. Defense lawyers in Atlanta said that interviews with 312
prisoners at the penitentiary had shown these categories of crime:

Homicide, 11; rape, 6; child molesting, 5; assault, ll; arson, 2; thefts, 148,
of which 40 involved thefts of food and 32 thefts of clothing; homosexual
prostitution, 4; sexual deviation, 18; marijuana smoking, 7. The rest were
categorized by the lawyers as political crimes, including keeping unbalanced
books, killing a cow without government permission, being a troublemaker,
dealing in the black market, using a father's identification card to attend a
carnival, deserting from the army and attempting to escape from Cuba.

So far, 1,0 25 of the 1,774 in detention have had hearings. Of these, 947 we re
ordered excluded, 32 were granted admission, and 46 decisions are pending.
However, about half of those ordered excluded have appealed their cases to a
higher immigration court, and the Government ha s appealed the cases of some of
those granted admission.

Once an applicant is deemed not admissible to the country after the exclusion
hearing, the law says he must be returned to the country from which he came. The
State Department says it tried five times from June to September to have the
Cuban Government accept the undesirables. The reply in each case, the department
said, was that the Cubans had forfeited their right to live in Cuba.

'My County Is a Bad Country'

Prisoners interviewed at the penitentiary said the long wait in jail without
word of their fate had produced tensions and a number of suicide attempts. In
September one of the Cubans was stabbed to death by another in a fight. Those
interviewed said that the longtime criminals among them ruled the rest, pushing
first into the food lines and attempting to rape the younger men.

''I never have experienced anything like this, and my country is a bad
country,'' said Luis Perez Ramirez.  William Noonan, the executive assistant to
the warden at the penitentiary, said it was standard Federal practice not to
segregate inmates by the severity of their crimes. ''In our prison system, it's
not what they did but how they behave when they get here that counts,'' he said.

He said that 550 of the Cubans were in the cell blocks - eight to a
20-by-10-foot space designed for four prisoners - and that 99 were in segregated
cells because of misbehavior or for their own protection and about 150 model
prisoners were in an open dormitory in the basement.

In the cell blocks, many of the Cubans were asleep on their bunks at
mid-afternoon one day this week. One stood with his face pressed to the bars.
''Help, help,'' he cried in English to a passerby.

NEWS ANALYSIS;
IMMIGRATION, OLD AND NEW;
News Analysis

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 33, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1013 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10


The proposals endorsed this week by the Select Commission on Immigration and
Refugee Policy resemble those unsuccessfully pushed by President Carter in 1977,
and there is no obvious indication that the latest recommendations will have any
better chance of gaining Congressional approval.

Mr. Carter, like the commission, urged Congress to legalize the status of
illegal aliens already in this country and to establish civil and criminal
penalties for employers who hire illegal aliens in the future. Like the
commission, he opposed any new form of worker identification.

The 16-member commission was created by Congress the year after Mr.Carter made
his proposals. Its chairman, the Rev. Theodore M.  Hesburgh, president of the
University of Notr e Dame, predicted that its recommendations would fare better
than th e President's because ''we've done more research'' and thinking abo ut
the apparently intractable problems of immigration. The pane l's voluminous
study hasmade a permanent contribution to public debat e; its final report, due
March 1, will be the most authoritative G overnment study of the issue.

No Clear Mandate Given

At best, however, the commission has only laid the groundwork for action. For
any comprehensive revision of immigration law and policy, the prospects are
rather bleak. No clear overall mandate emerged from the commission. And though
it did not disclose all of its votes, it was apparently divided into two or
three factions of roughly equal strength on several key issues.

In the past, proposals to revise the immigration laws have probably taken too
little account of public sentiment. A recent Gallup Poll found strong support
for a law prohibiting employment of illegal aliens, favor for identification
cards for everyone in the United States and opposition to an amnesty for illegal
aliens.

The commission heard witnesses around the country testify to their outrage about
illegal immigration, but then it recommended a moderate increase in the basic
quota for legal immigration, on the theory there would ultimately be a net
decrease in the flow of immigrants if illegal immigration could be sharply
curtailed.

''We seem to be expanding like mad,'' Father Hesburgh said of the proposals. But
he asserted that if all of the proposed figures were taken into account, the
number of immigrants entering the country would be far below the number of legal
and illegal entries today.
'Then We're in Trouble'

And what, he was asked, if the Government legitimized the status of about 1.5
million aliens, then found that its enforcement program was not working well
enough to prevent the illicit entry of still more aliens? ''Then,'' he said,
''we're in trouble.''

For that reason, another member of the commission, Senator Alan K.  Simpson,
Republican of Wyoming, said he wanted to be sure that enforcement was effective
before he would allow any increase in legal immigration.

The Hesburgh and Simpson logic is that the United States cannot legalize the
illegal aliens without more aggressive enforcement of the law; cannot
effectively enforce the law without imposing sanctions on employers, and cannot
adopt sanctions without a new means of identification for all citizens and
aliens authorized to work in this country.

But the commission would not accept a new form of identification; some members
saw in it a potential for abuse of civil liberties. So the logical coherence of
the package begins to fall apart. Without a foolproof means of identification,
Father Hesburgh said, employer sanctions are meaningless, ''like kissing your
sister.''

An Emotional Issue

Legislation to penalize employers for intentionally hiring illegal aliens was
twice passed by the House of Representatives, in 1972 and 1973, but died when
the Senate did not act. It is unclear whether Republican control of the S enate
and the White House will revive support for t he idea. The sanctions could be
seen as a form of Government in tervention, which Republicans often preach
against.

Immigration is, for many, an emotional issue, and anyone proposing restrictions
is vulnerable to charges of racial discrimination. Even Father Hesburgh's career
as a civil rights advocate does little to comfort Hispanic groups alarmed at the
idea of employer sanctions.

''Sanctions will be used by employers as a license to deny employment to
qualified Hispanics,'' said the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational
Fund. And Eleanor Holmes Norton, chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity
Commission, has expressed a similar concern and opposes enactment of employer
sanctions for that reason.

A Sign of More Understanding

The Immigration and Naturalization Service lacks the resources it needs to
enforce current laws, so without a huge infusion of money and manpower, it could
probably not enforce stringent new laws in the workplace and on the Mexican
border. In recent years, neither Congress nor the Administration has placed the
agency high on its list of budget priorities.

Eight members of Congress served on the immigration commission, and that bodes
well for the panel's report, if only because some additional lawmakers now
understand the complexity of the issue.  They, at least, will be prepared when
public frustration, heightened by this year's experience with Cuban and Haitian
refugees, forces Congress to ct.

President Truman established a similar comm ission in 1952, just after Congress,
over his veto, passed a restr ictionist immigration statute. The Truman panel
had no immediate ef fect, but its viewpoint gradually gained acceptance, leading
to aboli tion in 1965 of the quota system based on national origins. Simil arly,
the Hesburgh commission may lay the basis for changes a de cade from now.

NEW RESETTLEMENT EFFORT AIMED AT CUBAN REF UGEES IN MIAMI JAILS

BYLINE: UPI

SECTION: Section A; Page 24, Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 403 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, Dec. 11


Immigration officers interviewed Cuban refugees at Dade County's crowded jails
today in the Federal Government's first attempt to help South Florida cope with
what local officials called a refugee crime wave.

The immigration service agreed yesterday to begin taking homeless refugees into
custody and to move them to camps, including one in Brooklyn, N.Y., where
efforts will be made to find them homes, jobs and sponsors around the country.
Other camps are in Texas and California.

A city official said the agreement was a good first step that could relieve
tensions caused by the presence of an estimated 2,000 refugees who have been
abandoned by their sponsors and are living in city parks or on the streets.

Assistant City Manager Cesar Odio said the action should have been taken ''a
long time ago.''

30 or 40 Arrests a Day

Mr. Odio said the city police had been arresting 30 or 40 refugees a day on
charges of vagrancy and other misdemeanors. ''They have been back on the streets
the next day,'' he said. ''Now they have someplace to go.''

Ray Morris, district director of the Immigration and Naturalization Service,
said immigration officials were identifying those refugees who had been arrested
for such misdemeanors as vagrancy and who had no homes, jobs and sponsors. Only
those people will be eligible for resettlement.

Refugees charged with felonies will be left in jail to face prosecution, he
said.  Mr. Odio said local misdemeanor charges against the eligible refugees
would be dropped.

Officials Requested Action

A spokesman for the immigration service in Washington said the action was taken
at the request of Florida's Congressional delegation and local authorities in
Miami.

Immigration Commissioner David Crosland 3d, in Washington, directed Miami
immigration officials to determine which arrested refugees were eligible for the
resettlement program. The Government will revoke the special status under which
those refugees have been living in this country, a move that will allow them to
be taken into custody.

The camps at Brooklyn, El Paso and Port Isabel, Tex., and El Centro, Calif.,
have room for a total of 500 refugees, Mr. Morris said.

''As we find sponsors for those we can take others,'' he said.

              December 25, 1980, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

COURT OPPOSES CONGRESSIONAL VETO AS INTRUSION ON EXECUTIVE BRANCH

BYLINE: By STUART TAYLOR JR., Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1, Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 885 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24


In a decision that President Carter today called ''profoundly significant,'' a
Federal appeals court has cast doubt on the constitutionality of hundreds of
laws providing for Congressional vetoes of executive branch actions. The
President said he would issue an executive order instructing Government
departments and agencies to ignore such vetoes.

Mr. Carter said he would consult with Attorney General Benjamin R.  Civiletti to
determine whether an early Supreme Court decision should be sought to confirm
the finality of the decision made Monday by the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco.

The appeals court ruled that the House of Representatives had violated the
constitutional separation of powers when it sought to force the Immigration and
Naturalization Service to deport an immigrant from Kenya. The House had acted
under a law that allows the House or Senate to override some decisions of the
executive branch to suspend deportation of illegal aliens.

Separation of Powers

The appeals court said that the Congressional veto provision in the immigration
law violated the constitutional doctrine of separation of powers ''because it is
a prohibited legislative intrusion upon the executive and judicial branches.''

Although the court did not declare un-
constitutional all laws that provide for Congressional vetoes of executive
branch actions, a Justice Department lawyer said that the reasoning in the
court's 45-page opinion ''confirms the view previously taken by the Attorney
General that legislative veto provisions are generally unconstitutional.''

Larry L. Simms, a Deputy Assistant Attorney General, said, ''We would like to
get a decision from the Supreme Court in an appropriate case because it would be
more definitive.'' He said it had not been decided whether to seek Supreme Court
review, however. Mr. Simms said there was precedent for the Government to take
the unusual step of seeking Supreme Court review even though it was the winning
party in the court below.

Ruling Is a Precedent

The appeals court decision is the first ruling ever against a legislative veto
provision, according to Mr. Simms. Every President since Franklin Delano
Roosevelt has opposed legislative veto provisions generally as unconstitutional.

The Court of Claims upheld a one-House veto in a 1975 decision in a suit
involving judicial salaries, but that decision was based on narrow grounds and
was not reviewed by the Supreme Court.

Congress, increasingly determined to assert greater control over regulatory
actions by Federal agencies, has written more than 150 Congressional veto
provisions into various laws during the Carter Administration, prompting an
ongoing battle with the White House and the Justice Department.

These provisions generally provide that either House of Congress, or in some
cases both Houses acting together, can nullify rules or other actions by
particular executive branch departments or agencies.

Congressional advocates of such provisions have said they are necessary to
ensure that the executive branch carries out the laws the way Congress intended
them to be carried out. President Carter and Mr. Civiletti have criticized them
as usurpations of power that upset the constitutional balance among the three
branches of government and infringe on the constitutional duty of the executive
branch to ''take care that the laws be faithfully executed.''

Victory for Student

The appeals court decision was a victory not only for the Carter Administration
but also for Jagdish Rai Chadha of Kenya, who entered the United States as a
student in 1966. After his visa expired, he obtained a suspension of deportation
from the Government, in part because of a finding that his East Indian heritage
would have made it difficult to return to Kenya.

The House of Representatives passed a resolution vetoing his suspension of
deportation along with those of several other aliens under an immigration law
that provided for such a one-House veto. The Immigration and Naturalization
Service ordered his deportation. But when Mr. Chadha appealed to the court, the
Justice Department, representing the agency, conceded that the order and the
Congressional actions on which it was based were unconstitutional and sought to
use the case to test its position that congressional vetoes are generally
unconstitutional.

The three-judge appeals court panel, in a complex opinion written by Judge
Anthony M. Kennedy, stressed that the use of the Congressional veto in
immigration cases interfered with ''a central function of the judiciary,'' that
of ensuring fairness and uniformity in dealing with aliens who seek suspension
of deportation. The opinion said the use of the Congressional veto also
''trespasses upon central functions of the executive'' to enforce the laws. The
court also found that the one-House veto provision bypassed ''the internal check
of bicameralism'' inherent in the constitutional requirement that legislation be
passed by both House and Senate.

FT. DRUM MADE A DETENTION SITE FOR ILLEGAL ALIENS

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 422 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10


The White House announced today that the Fort Drum Army base in upstate New York
would become an interim detention center for Haitians, Cubans and other aliens
who had entered the United States illegally.

About 2,700 illegal Haitian immigrants are currently being housed in 17
locations around the country, most of them in Florida.  They will be joined at
Fort Drum, which is just outside Watertown, near the Canadian border, by 460
Cubans from Fort Chaffee in Arkansas. Renovations on the buildings at the Army
base are expected to take two months.

Representative David Martin, a Republican whose district includes Fort Drum,
said he disagreed with the Reagan Administration's decision.

Site 'Met Key Criteria'

After meeting with President Reagan and Secretary of Defense Caspar W.
Weinberger, however, Mr. Martin said he had been assured that Fort Drum would
continue to play ''a major role'' in future defense plans.

A team of Federal officials from the Departments of Health and Human Services,
Justice, and Defense recently completed a nationwide search for a temporary site
while a permanent facility was built. The White House said that all three of the
departments agreed that Fort Drum ''was the one site that met the key criteria,
including capacity, availability and minimal impact on defense operations.''

The White House announcement took New York State officials by surprise. Barbara
B. Blum, Commissioner of the New York State Department of Social Services, said:

''The Governor's office has heard nothing. We are astonished, and, at the very
least, we feel there should have been consultation. We know the state itself
will ultimately bear responsibility for the refugees and the needs of the
Watertown community that borders Fort Drum.''

Other Sites Considered

Representative Samuel S. Stratton, an upstate Democrat who is a member of the
Armed Services Committee, said: ''It was not a very smart idea. It's going to be
cold up there.''

Fort Drum was one of half a dozen locations on the Justice Department list of
potential sites. Other military installations mentioned in the past included
bases at Lakehurst, N.J.; McAlester, Okla., and Sandwich, Chicopee and Ayer,
Mass.

The Administration has already moved to cut off the access of Haitian refugees
to lawyers and judges by having the Coast Guard intercept their boats.

Around the Nation;
Suspect Admits Conspiracy In Smuggling of Aliens

BYLINE: UPI

DATELINE: ROCK ISLAND, Ill., June 6


Alfonse Interial, whom the authorities called the leader of an alien-smuggling
operation, pleaded guilty yesterday.

He was among 17 persons indicted April 27 by a Federal grand jury in Illinois
for transporting illegal aliens from Mexico and Guatemala into Illinois, Texas,
Florida, New Jersey, Oklahoma and Michigan.

count of income tax evasion and one of transporting illegal aliens.

2 CLEARED ON 2 COUNTS OF SMUGGLING ALIENS; NO VERDICT ON 6 ITEMS

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 20, Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 357 words

DATELINE: PHOENIX, June 16


Raul Saldivar and his son, Raul Jr., two Bonita Springs, Fla., farmers accused
of smuggling Mexican aliens through Arizona, were found not guilty here today of
two counts of transporting illegal aliens, but the Federal jury was unable to
reach a verdict on six related counts.

The jury returned guilty verdicts against two other defendants, Federico
Villalon of Phoenix and Rafael Pedro Gonzalez, a Mexican national, for
participation in alien smuggling. Both Mr. Villalon and Mr. Gonzalez were
accused of being ''coyotes,'' or drivers of the illegal aliens.

Judge Valdemar Cordova of Federal District Court declared a mistrial on the six
undecided charges, four against the elder Saldivar and two against the son. The
United States Attorney's Office said that it would again prosecute the six
charges, and Judge Cordova took under advisement a motion from the defense
attorney, Claude Tison, for a transfer of the case to a Federal court in
Florida.

Union Helped Prepare Case

The jury deliberated for nearly three days after the three-week trial. Each
count carried a possible sentence of five years in prison or a $2,000 fine or
both. In the course of the trial, three other defendants were dropped from the
case.

The Government case was prepared over more than a year with the assistance of
members of the Arizona Farm Workers Union, according to Don Devereux, a member
of the group.

In a 20-count grand jury indictment handed up in November, the Saldivars were
accused of arranging the shipment of undocumented workers from Mexico to their
Florida farm. They were accused of advancing a $450 fee for workers'
transportation and then withholding wages until the fee was repaid.

Mr. Tison said that the Government charges were false and that the case was
based on the testimony of witnesses who sought immunity for their own illegal
presence in the country.

Mr. Devereux said in an interview that the case was significant because it
''never would have been started under the Reagan Administration'' and because he
believed it marked ''the end of prosecution of growers in Florida by the U.S.
Attorney'' for illegal smuggling.

               October 11, 1981, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

TEXAS SEEKS NEW PLAN FOR MEXICAN OFFENDERS

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section 1; Part 2; Page 64, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 723 words

DATELINE: EL PASO, Tex., Oct. 10


To Texas officials, the problem of Mexican youths who cross the border and
commit crimes in El Paso seemed to have an easy solution: Ship them back to a
detention center in Ciudad Juarez.

But that solution has become an international issue that some say may have to be
resolved by Congress with a treaty between the United States and Mexico.

More than two years ago, El Paso officials reached an oral agreement with
juvenile authorities in Ciudad Juarez that called for sending youths caught
committing crimes in El Paso back across the border to spend up to three months
in the detention center.

''It was working beautifully,'' said District Judge Woodrow Bean 2d. ''The crime
rate here went down last year. Those juveniles over in Juarez knew that if they
were caught over here, they were going to be taken to the detention center, so
they didn't come over here.''

Question of Legality

Juvenile authorities on both sides of the border said they were pleased with the
arrangement. But in December, Margaret Ingle, a Juvenile Probation Department
employee, refused to take a group of youths to Juarez, saying it was illegal for
El Paso County officers to take prisoners into a foreign country.

She was dismissed, but complained. The county Juvenile Board, by a vote of 4 to
3, ruled April 23 that the process indeed violated a clause in the Texas
Constitution that prohibits ''banishing'' convicted criminals from the state.
The board reinstated the employee and ordered the probation department to find
another solution.

Under the procedure, young illegal aliens who were arrested were sent to the El
Paso County probation department for screening. Those with Texas criminal
records were taken to court and, if convicted, placed in the state juvenile
center in Brownwood.

First offenders were placed in state vehicles and taken to the Juarez detention
center, said Xavier Banales, head of the probation department.

Jailed Without a Hearing

''I felt bad about that, too,'' said Judge Edward Marquez, a member of the
Juvenile Board who voted to end the policy. ''Those kids were being locked up
without any kind of a hearing.''

Since the shuttle across the border was halted, Mr. Banales said, his agency has
either tried to prosecute the youths or turned them over to the Immigration and
Naturalization Service.

But to prosecute the department must contact a youth's parents.  That can be
difficult in Juarez, a city of 900,000 that has relatively few telephones, Mr.
Banales said.

Lee Holder, assistant immigration director for investigations, said the
teen-agers were either taken to court for deportation hearings or released at
the bridge over the Rio Grande in what his agency calls ''voluntary departure.''


More Referrals, Faster Returns

Since the policy was changed, Mr. Banales said, ''we're beginning to see two
things - an increase in the number of referrals and quicker returns by the
youngsters.''

Judge Bean said the trend had proved a prediction he made when he was outvoted
at the Juvenile Board meeting.  ''I predicted right away that the crime rate
would probably double in El Paso, especially after those kids start realizing
that they're just going to take them to the bridge and kick them out,' ' he
said.

Statistics appear to bear him out. For the first 28 days of September, 56
Mexican youths were referred to the probation department, the highest monthly
total since last October. By contrast, in April, the last month under the
agreement, 25 Mexican juveniles were arrested in El Paso.

Most Arrests for Burglaries

According to Mr. Banales, 60 to 70 percent of the young illegal aliens are
picked up on suspicion of business burglaries.  The judges on the Juvenile Board
have now t urned to Congress, sincethe Constitution limits agreements with forei
gn countries to the Federal Government.

Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, and 14 colleagues from border states
have asked the State Department to begin talks with Mexico.

                July 19, 1980, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

THE SPARSE WATCH ON AMERICA'S BORDERS 4/bl;
by Hamilton Fish Jr.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 16, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 433 words


To the Editor:

The smuggling of aliens which prompted your July 7 article on our undermanned
Border Patrol is the vilest and most frustrating aspect of illegal migration.

he U.S. Border Patrol is charged with maintaining the integrity of our borders
between points of entry. Numbering only 350 at any given time on our 2,000-mile
border with Mexico, it is no match for the smugglers, who are well-organized on
both sides of the border.

Illegal border crossings increase annually; in 1979, apprehensions exceeded one
million. While it is more humane to turn aliens back at the border than to
apprehend them in the interior of the country, reassigning personnel while
failing to increase levels makes the mission of the Border Patrol virtually
impossible. More officers are needed, particularly since South Florida is now an
area of vulnerability.

The President's policy statement of August 1977 calling for improved border
control has been followed up by reductions in patrol strength. Personnel on duty
in May 1980 was 214 below levels authorized by the Congress in fiscal 1978.

Congressional concern was expressed on July 1, when the House adopted, 337 to
72, my amendment to provide for 311 additional Border Patrol positions in
Justice Department appropriations for fiscal year 1981.

As long as Mexico and other Central American countries experience rapid
population growth, poverty and high unemployment, pressures on our border will
continue. Cooperative arrangements with Mexico to develop labor-intensive
industry and agriculture would help.  Likewise, the magnet effect of the U.S.
economy could be reduced by economic disincentives.

All aspects of this complex phenomenon, including the status of aliens already
here illegally, are being explored by the Select Commission on Immigration and
Refugee Policy. Its recommendations, due in March of 1981, will certainly
include more effective control of our borders.

Recognizing the magnitude and importance of the problem, recruitment and
training of Border Patrol personnel should not be delayed.  (Rep.) HAMILTON FISH
JR.  Washington, July 11, 1980

The writer is ranking member on the House Subcommittee on Immigration, Refugees
and International Law and a member of the Select Commission on Immigration and
Refugee Policy.

               August 21, 1980, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

TEEN-AGERS JOIN IN THE BUSINESS OF SMUGGLING ALIENS

BYLINE: By JOHN M. CREWDSON, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section B; Page 11, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1307 words

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO


In the apparent belief that they will not be prosecuted, children and young
teen-agers are being used by large alien-smuggling rings operating along the
Mexican border to guide groups of illegal aliens into the United States and to
drive them in cars and trucks to their destinations in the north.

The Justice Department is responding to the smugglers' latest ploy by arresting,
prosecuting, convicting and, in some instances, imprisoning those as young as 16
who are found to have been involved in the booming business of smuggling illegal
aliens for profit.

There is no shortage of youngsters willing to risk such involvement. They can be
seen by the thousands each day in Mexico's teeming border cities, where nearly
half the labor force is idle and where a payment of $100 for driving a single
load of aliens to Dallas or San Francisco is as much as a month's wages.

Immigration officers say that children as young as 10 are now being used by the
smuggling rings for the less dangerous, and also less remunerative, jobs of
guiding groups of illegal aliens across the border on foot.

Less Leniency Now

Those so young are not being prosecuted. They are simply returned across the
border to Mexico, often to reappear a few days later, officials say, with
another load of illegal aliens. But the older youths being hired to drive the
aliens north, chiefly boys and girls ranging in age from 15 to 17, are sometimes
meeting with a less happy fate.

''The transporters of illegal aliens are apparently telling these kids, 'You'll
get a couple of nights in jail and the feds will bounce you back across the
border,' '' said Jerry Collins, an official of the United States Parole
Commission, which has just begun a study of the problem. But such leniency from
the Justice Department cannot be relied on, as Jose Luis Ramirez now knows.

Last Monday Jose Luis, a resident of Tijuana who turned 17 in June, was
sentenced to six months in prison after his conviction in a Federal court here
of transporting illegal aliens, a felony.  According to his lawyer, Craig
Weimerman of the Federal Public Defenders' office, Jose is typical of the youths
who become involved with smuggling.

''He's pretty much been living off the streets since he was 14,'' Mr. Weimerman
said. ''He hangs around Tijuana, somebody offers him some bucks to drive into
the United States, so he does it. It's his way of surviving.''

Prosecution Is Not Widespread

Although the prosecution of juveniles like Jose appears to be on the increase,
it is by no means widespread. John Cleary, who heads the Federal Public
Defenders' office here, estimates that his staff has represented about 35 young
defendants in similar felony smuggling cases in the last year, ''an increase
compared to a couple of years ago.''

Because records in juveniles proceedings are often sealed, the precise number of
such prosecutions nationwide could not be obtained. Other lawyers in Mr.
Cleary's office, a Government agency that provides legal counsel for indigents
accused of Federal crimes, said they represented a considerably larger number of
juvenile smugglers, perhaps 75 a year, who were tried on misdemeanor charges,
given mandatory sentences of probation and returned to Mexico.

Like most defense attorneys involved with such cases, Mr. Cleary questions the
value of the prosecutions, either to society or the young defendants. ''They
always hit the lieutenants and the sergeants,'' he said. ''It's a manifestation
of our frustration with the alien problem -we tend to take it out on the ones we
can get our hands on.''

The border guides and drivers, like Jose Luis, are not even sergeants. They are
the privates of the smuggling trade. Most of them know nothing about the
organization that has employed them, probably not even the real name of the
person who gave them the job.  For this reason, Mr. Cleary believes, ''it's
foolish to initiate such prosecutions against children.''

Law Makes No Distinction

Peter K. Nunez, the principal Assistant United States Attorney here, disagrees.
''Why not?'' he asked in a recent interview. ''If we catch a 16-year-old who is
violating a law and it's a serious case, then we'll prosecute.''

The Federal immigration statutes, Mr. Nunez said, made no distinction between
juveniles and adults. ''If Congress does@ n't want us prosecuting juvenile
aliens, they ought to say so,'' he added.

Although it is up to individual United States Attorneys' offices to decide
whether to pursue a particular case, some critics of the Justice Department
blame pressure from the Border Patrol for the prosecutions of juvenile
smugglers.

''Their standard response is, 'We have to prosecute or we'd be overrun with
juveniles','' said Bernie Velasco, a Federal defender in Tucson. ''But the
reason they do it is the Border Patrol. They're out there beating the bushes,
and they catch people and they want to prosecute them. It's the tail wagging the
dog.''

Repeat Offenders Cited

Some Border Patrol officers believe, however, that such prosecutions are not
extensive enough. Robert L. Barber, who heads the patrol's antismuggling unit in
El Paso, said his intelligence officers had been unable to crack an organization
in that area that was providing teen-age drivers to smuggling groups ''on a
moment's notice.''

The drivers his agents apprehended were simply returned to Mexico without
prosecution, Mr. Barber said, adding that he would like to see some of the
repeat offenders tried in court, particularly ''one young lady I know of who
keeps turning up - she's about 16.''

One element that concerns critics of the juvenile prosecutions is the wide
disparities in sentences meted out to young defendants. Mr.  Velasco told of two
17-year-old Mexican youths discovered recently in southern Arizona driving
vehicles containing illegal aliens. Both youths, he said, were convicted, but
one was given probation and returned home while the other was sentenced to jail
until his 21st birthday.

What prosecutors describe as ''aggravating circumstances'' that warrant
prosecutions are often seen by defense lawyers as less than malicious, as with
the case of 16-year-old Hector Campos Rodriguez, who was convicted here last
month of smuggling aliens, a felony.

Panicked at Highway Checkpoint

According to his lawyer, Eugene Iredale, Hector panicked when the car he was
driving was flagged down last July 12 at the Border Patrol's highway checkpoint
at San Clemente, Calif., on Interstate 5, a principal northbound route for
illegal alien traffic. Instead of stopping, Hector hit the accelerator, but the
Border Patrol caught him after a chase. Five illegal aliens were riding in the
car.

Although Hector has been tried and convicted, he is not in jail. On July 28, he
was sentenced to five years' probation and returned to Mexico. His only time
behind bars was the three weeks he spent at the Metropolitan Correctional Center
here, awaiting trial and sentencing.

Jose Luis Ramirez is not so lucky. He has already served a month at the
correctional center, a Federal facility for adult offenders, in a third-floor
wing set aside for juveniles.

''It's very cramped up there,'' Mr. Weimerman said. ''There's not much room for
the kids. The law says they're supposed to be separated from adults, but they
rarely are. The problem with the Federal system is that they have no facilities
for juveniles.''

The probation officer who handled Jose Luis's case recommended that he serve
four years in jail. But the suggestion was rejected as excessive by the
presiding judge, who sentenced Jose to six months.

The youth will serve his time at one of the state juvenile detention centers or
private ''community-based facilities,'' like boys' ranches, with which the
Federal Government contracts for incarceration of its young prisoners.

With a conviction in Federal District Court in Tucson, Ariz. last week, the

when about 30 people, part of a band of about 40 aliens smuggled from El
Salvador through Mexico to the United States border, crossed by night with their
guides into a desert; two days later, 13 would be dead of dehydration.

Santos Flores Elias, a Salvadoran, was convicted of one count of conspiring to

Flores was part of a smaller detachment of the original 40 who safely crossed
the border south of Yuma but were later arrested.

The 13 deaths were mentioned only in passing during testimony identifying Mr.
Flores as an assistant to Carlos Rivera, said to be the organizer of the whole
affair. Mr. Rivera himself was one of the 13 who died in the desert. Two
survivors of the trek pleaded guilty week before last to one count each of
smuggling aliens.

AROUND THE NATION;
Salvadoran Is Sentenced In Alien Smuggling Case

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 16, Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 197 words

DATELINE: TUCSON, Ariz., Nov. 3


A 22-year-old Salvadoran was sentenced today to seven years in prison after his
conviction on charges of smuggling aliens in connection with an attempt to enter
the country last summer that ended in the deaths of 13 of his countrymen in the
Arizona desert.

Federal District Judge James A. Walsh sentenced Santos Flores Elias of San
Salvador to a five-year term for conspiracy plus concurrent two-year terms for
each of seven counts of smuggling aliens. Mr. Flores was found guilty in a jury
trial last month.

According to Arthur J. Hutton, Mr. Flores's attorney, the conviction will be
appealed on the ground that the trial should have been moved from Tucson because
of extensive pretrial news coverage of incident, and because some jurors knew of
the case before the trial began.

Prosecutors had charged that Mr. Flores helped the man they identified as the
ringleader of the smuggling attempt, Carlos Rivera, to bring a group of 40
Salvadoran refugees across the Mexican border into the 516-acre Organ Pipe
Cactus National Monument in Arizona.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: letter

                   Copyright 1981 The New York Times Company


                              185 of 474 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

              October 14, 1981, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

Two Pieces of I.D.

SECTION: Section A; Page 30, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 391 words


Will the person who knows the real Reagan position on identification cards
please stand up?

Is it Attorney General Smith? He has tenaciously opposed requiring employers to
ask for I.D. from job applicants even though that would, finally, permit
effective Federal action against illegal immigration. He does not object out of
a civil libertarian concern about police statism but because he thinks such
cards could be too easily forged.

Or is it Secretary of Agriculture Block? To combat fraud, his department will
now require plastic photo identification cards from the 2.84 million people who
pick up food stamps for their families in 17 cities. The value of spending $8
million for cards to discourage fraudulent use of stamps is obvious. The typical
food stamp family receives benefits worth $1,068 a year.

Common sense, if not consistency, points toward the position of the Secretary of
Agriculture.  The Reagan Administration says, commendably, that it wants the
United States to get control of its own borders. And Attorney General Smith
ac-knowledges that there can be no effective enforcement unless employers who
hire illegal immigrants are made liable to punishment.

But the only way that will work is if they know the people they are hiring are
illegal. That means requiring job applicants to show identification - like a
Social Security card. That is already necessary, but the card is easy to
counterfeit. It could, like the food stamp card, be made much harder to forge.

Mr. Smith thinks even that would not be forgery-resistant enough: if it's not
possible to produce a counterfeit-proof $20 bill, an identity card could not be
safe. His logic eludes us. Sure, people are always trying to counterfeit $20, or
$100, bills. But the Secretary of the Treasury does not therefore order his
department to stop printing them.

It is easy to see the overriding value of currency to society. It is easy to see
the value of holding down fraud in the food stamp program. What is hard to see
is why the Attorney General is so reluctant to acknowledge the value of
enforcing the immigration policy this Administration professes to desire.

                 June 8, 1981, Monday, Late City Final Edition

DEPORTATION OF HAITIANS FROM MIAMI CENTER ON RISE

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section B; Page 9, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 909 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, June 7


There is resigned stillness these days at the Immigration and Naturalization
Service's Krome Avenue Detention Center, which is home to some 800 refugees,
mostly Haitians.

A week and a half ago, all male Haitians were locked in the new concrete
two-story men's dormitory to keep them from escaping. Then, on Thursday and
Friday, a total of 25, the largest group of Haitians to have been deported since
early 1979, were put on planes back to Port-au-Prince after closed hearings at
the immigration service's downtown Miami headquaters.

The remaining male refugees were allowed out for meals and, as of Thursday, for
a 10-minute exercise period.  A month ago the immigration service added 25
guards to its 30-man force, put in a third 12-foot-high fence topped with barbed
wire, and assigned a patrol car to the camp.

Camp 'Like a Sieve'

Krome was ''like a sieve,'' in the words of one immigration service official,
who said inmates would take off to the local convenience store to supplement
their meager diets or to add new T-shirts to the minimal wardrobes issued them.
Others would disappear to Miami's rapidly growing ''Little Haiti'' about 35
miles to the east.

The 15-acre camp of scrubland on the eastern edge of the Everglades has been
split down the middle with a fence to keep the men and the women separate. They
even eat at different times.

The immigration service had been allowing five voluntary agencies to resettle
Haitian refugees pending their claims for political asylum. Then the service
decided not to release anyone who had arrived on a plane with forged visas after
Feb. 23. Of the 161 in this category, called the ''Boeing People,'' only 46 were
still at Krome when the security crackdown began. ''Boat people'' were not
allowed to leave if they arrived after May 20,

The Krome Avenue site, formerly used to store Nike missiles, was taken over by
the immigration service last summer to house Cubans who came from Mariel. But as
the influx of Cubans slowed to a trickle and the refugees were resettled, the
population of the plant shifted. Now the immigration service is bracing itself
for the seasonal influx of Haitians who take advantage of the summer-calm
Caribbean seas to make the crossing.

One-Quarter Detained

Only about one-quarter of the Haitian arrivals are caught before they have a
chance to disappear into Miami's Haitian community, according to United States
Representative Daniel Mica, a Democrat from West Palm Beach; those who are are
caught go to the Krome Avenue Detention Center.

Thus on Thursday and Friday, for example, while some of the Haitians were being
sent back to Port-au-Prince, 18 were sent to the center after they were arrested
while applying for work authorization papers. The immigration service will not
have an exact count of the number of refugees at the center until tomorrow.

Life for most Haitians is not easy, as it has not been for Samedy Philippe
Franklin. He is a slim, 23-year-old tailor from Cap-Haitien, one of the poorest
areas in a desperately poor country. In a good month he made about $35; some
months he made nothing. His relatives paid his $250 boat fare hoping that he
would find employment in this country and then help them. He left a wife and a
child behind.

On the overcrowded boat he lost his most valuable possession - addresses of
relatives in Miami who could help him. He has written back to Haiti for a copy
of the list but does not know how long he must wait to get an answer.

Complaints About Food

He and others have complained about the food. Sometimes it was rotten, Mr.
Franklin said, and other times there was not enough.  William Alexander, the
immigration service official in charge of Krome, conceded that they were having
trouble with both the quality and the quantity of the food served last month but
said there had been no recent complaints.

Dr. Richard Morgan, head of the Dade County Health Department, said that
conditions at Krome had improved greatly with the open of the new men's
building. He said he was worried, however, that the expected influx of new
refugees would force camp officials to use the tents again.

Getting in touch with the outside world is the Haitians' biggest problem. There
is only one phone in the compound to which the refugees have ready access. It is
this phone that refugees depend on to contact their relatives in Florida as well
as lawyers to represent them at their immigration service hearings. Those who
appear without a lawyer almost certainly will be found ''excludable,'' according
the Steven D. Forester, a lawyer with the Haitian Refugee Center.

Agencies Sharing One Phone

The five voluntary agencies that have been charged with relocating the Haitians
also have to share one phone, which increases the difficulties of getting in
touch with relatives and sponsors.

Along with the Federal Government's Office of Refugee Resettlement, the
volunteer agencies have been working six-day weeks to relocate as many refugees
as possible. ''These are good, hard-working people,'' said Tania Mary Dina,
Miami director of the U.S. Catholic Conference. ''They deserve a chance.''

              September 13, 1981, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

UNTOLD STORY OF COAST IMMIGRATION CENTER UNFOLDS

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section 1; Part 2; Page 84, Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 804 words

DATELINE: ANGEL ISLAND STATE PARK, Calif., Sept. 12


Paul Chow vividly recalls his father's admonition of ''Angel Island. Shhh!'' ''I
heard that so much, it's almost like one word,'' he says.  From 1910 to 1940,
about 175,000 Chinese came to the United States. Most, including the elder Chow,
awaited entry to Gam Saan, the Golden Mountain, as they called California, at
the Federal Immigration Station on Angel Island.

Like the better-known Ellis Island in New York Harbor, which was the first stop
for European immigrants to the United States, Angel Island was entry point for
Asian immigrants.

But many recall their stay on the island with only bitterness.  They were locked
up like criminals. They slept stacked on steel bunks six high. If thet rebelled
they were put into a bare, windowless closet.

For decades this shabby chapter in American history lay virtually unexamined.
Humiliated Chinese-Americans -nearly all of those who entered at Angel Island
were Chinese - would not speak of it.

False Papers Used for Entry

Many had entered with false papers and were called ''paper sons'' because their
forged documents made them sons of merchants, teachers and United States
citizens. Those were the privileged, exempted under the Chinese Exclusion Act of
1882, the first Federal law to deny entry to a specific ethnic group.

Now the unpleasant story is being told, led by Mr. Chow, whose Angel Island
Immigration Station Historical Advisory Committee wants a museum created in the
decaying barracks last used in 1940.

Felicia Lowe, a Chinese-American filmmaker from San Francisco, is interviewing
former detainees for a television documentary.  Mr. Chow, a transportation
engineer with the state, stood in what was the men's dormitory on the island,
whose hilly paths and secluded coves in the middle of San Francisco Bay now draw
cyclists, hikers and boaters.
Poems Written on the Walls

On the peeling walls of the dormitory are poems in Chinese, written by
immigrants to express outrage and anguish. One of them, by an anonymous author,
reads:

''There are tens of thousands of poems composed on these walls; They are all
cries of complaint and sadness. The day I am rid of this prison and attain
success, I must remember that this chapter once existed.''

The immigrants called this place ''The Island.'' The name ''Angel'' seems to
mock memories such as those of Howard Tom.  Mr. Tom was 14 years old when he
arrived on the island in 1922. His father was a naturalized American citizen who
had returned to China to get his wife, Howard and a baby son.

His family was ''separated within two hours,'' Mr. Tom said, adding, ''We didn't
have a chance to say goodbye.'' He recalled lying on his bunk in the locked
dormitory, daydreaming of friends in China.

Questions From Official

Through an interpreter, an immigration official questioned him and his parents
separately, seeking to determine if they were really a family.

''How far from your house to your neighbor's?'' they each were asked.  ''The
three of us all gave the wrong answer,'' Mr. Tom said. ''I stretched my hand out
to represent so many feet. I didn't tell the interpreter how many feet each arm
length represented.''

The family was detained for two weeks before being released after a Chinese
minister in San Francisco vouched for them.  ''After 40 some odd years,'' Mr.
Tom said , he visited the island aspart of a spe cial tour. ''I was really
upset.'' There are s ome Chinese who say the period is too painful to
relive.Genny Lim, wh o wrote a history of the era, says a ''prominent, older''
Chine se-American woman was horrified by the idea of tourists visiting the
island, calling it ''exploitation.''

Other detainees recount suicides not mentioned in official records. They said
that modest Chinese women, shocked by the lack of privacy in the toilets, would
cover their heads with bags.

Ranger Gets Scholar's Interest

The history of the island began to unfold in 1970, when Alan Weiss, then a
ranger on the island, noticed characters carved on the walls and showed them to
superiors.

''No one was interested,'' Mr. Weiss said on a recent tour with Mr. Chow's
group. So he invited a scholar who determined that they were poems written by
Chinese immigrants. Enthusiastic Asian-American college students then began to
pry loose the island's history.

Restoration work is going slowly. A state grant of $322,000 is exhausted, and
Mr. Chow estimated that $1 million more was needed.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Illustrations: photo of Paul and Hing Gai Chow

               December 25, 1981, Friday, Late City Final Edition

HAITIANS AT 2 DETENTION SITES REFUSING TO EAT AND TO TALK

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Page 8, Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 658 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, Dec. 24


Haitians being held at a Federal detention facility here and at a Federal prison
in Lexington, Ky., stopped eating and stopped talking to their keepers today.

Beverly McFarland, a spokesman for the United States Immigration and
Naturalization Service in Miami, said that 727 of the 730 Haitians at the Krome
Avenue detention facility here refused breakfast and lunch. ''It's a passive
resistance,'' she said. ''They don't say anything, not a word. They have not
given any reason.''

At the Federal prison in Lexington, the warden, Robert Elsea, reported that ''a
few'' of the 186 Haitians being held there refused breakfast and that 20 percent
to 30 percent of the Haitians there turned out for lunch. ''Some are saying
they're not eating because they are in jail,'' he said. ''It's kind of hard to
read between the lines. They are very passive.''

There were no reports of hunger strikes at detention facilities elsewhere in the
country. In all, about 2,500 Haitians are being detained in this country and
another 700 are being held at Fort Allen in Puerto Rico, under an agreement with
the government there.

Backlog of Court Cases

The United States contends the Haitians are illegal aliens who tried to enter
the country without proper documents. Attorneys for the Haitians have filed
class-action suits, contending that they are political refugees and should be
granted asylum. The backlog of court cases has resulted in long periods of
incarceration, with occasional riots and breakouts.

The immigration agency in Miami had to add 12 Border Patrol guards to its
26-member security detail after repeated escapes in late November. At the time,
immigration officials cited Christmas as the reason for growing tensions at the
Krome Avenue facility. Nearly all of the Haitians are Roman Catholic, and the
immigration service said that as those in detention began to realize they would
not be free by the holiday, they became restive.

This morning the Haitians at Krome refused cleaning duties, chores that in the
past were performed with relish as the only relief from the monotony of being
held at a former missile base with no recreational facilities. The Haitian
community in Miami has held demonstrations all week demanding those being
detained be released before Christmas. Haitian leaders here also sent a petition
to the White House, comparing the Haitians detained at Krome with the American
hostages in Iran.

At Fort Allen, P.R., where 200 Haitians staged a stone-throwing riot last
weekend, injuring three guards, Don Hasson, a spokesman for the immigration
service, said the situation today was ''normal'' and ''relatively quiet.''

He said those being detained had not refused meals. One-hundred Border Patrol
guards have been added to the security complement at Fort Allen, said Mr.
Hasson, who declined to give the size of the normal security unit.

Archbishop Appeals for Release

MIAMI, Dec. 24 (AP) - The Roman Catholic Archbishop of Miami appealed to
President Reagan today for the ''humane'' release of the Haitians at the Krome
Avenue Center.

Archbishop Edward McCarthy said in a telegram to the President: ''As we witness
the cruel suppression of human rights in Poland, we must show the world that we,
the people of the United States, still stand for freedom, liberty and justice.
Your release of these Haitian detainees who have come to these shores seeking
freedom, liberty and justice will speak louder than any words.''

The Archbishop also said mass for 677 Haitians at the detention center and said
he sympathized with their frustration. He called their hunger strike ''a very
human reaction to the very inhuman conditions'' of the detention site.

He held a separate service for about 70 Haitian women who are segregated from
the men for what immigration officials call ''security reasons.''
