MOON CHURCH FOLLOWER AGREES TO LEAVE U.S.

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 22, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 653 words

DATELINE: AKRON, Ohio, Dec. 17


A 20-year-old Australian woman, who came to the United States for a vacation but
spent the last 14 months in the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church, agreed
today to leave the country voluntarily rather than face deportation as an
illegal alien.

Her parents, who had flown here to try to bring their daughter home, at one
point had her committed to a mental institution to remove her from the church's
influence.

The woman, Angela Hamersley, a former reservations clerk for Qantas Airlines,
was arrested today in Akron by officials of the United States Immigration and
Naturalization Service.

Miss Hamersley arrived in this country in October 1980 for a vacation but did
not return to Australia. Her visitation papers expired in April.

Say She Was Brainwashed

Her parents, John and Julie Hamersley, first flew here from Perth, Australia, a
month after her arrival. They later hired an Arizona ''deprogrammer'' to try to
reclaim their daughter. Although Miss Hamersley told her parents she had joined
the religious group of her own free will, they said they believed she had been
brainwashed.

An Australian consul also journeyed to Akron from Chicago to assist in getting
Miss Hamersley's cooperation to leave the country.  ''I am very happy,'' Mr.
Hamersley said after his daughter agreed not to fight deportation. He said
Thursday's session with Government officials and lawyers was ''the first time
we've seen her behave like a normal person'' since she joined the Moon church.

For the Hamersleys, the ordeal began in October 1980, when their daughter, then
18 years old, phoned them from San Francisco saying that she had canceled her
flight home and was staying in the United States.

'Nice Set of Friends'

''She said just that she had met this nice girl who had a nice set of friends
and that she had invited her to stay with them,'' Mrs.  Hamersley said.

Mr. Hamersley, a pharmacist, said he was ''shocked'' at his daughter's decision
because ''she was an extraordinarily sensible and level-headed girl.''

The Hamersleys said they learned the truth about their daughter's whereabouts
after distant relatives in this country helped them check the address their
daughter had given where she could be reached and found it was a warehouse
leased by the Mr. Moon's Unification Church.

As soon as they could get passports, they journeyed to San Francisco and told
Unification Church officials they wanted to see their daughter.

Slept on Floor of Hut

The Hamersleys said they found their daughter was living in a wood hut with
about a dozen other young girls and was sleeping on the floor. After several
visits, the Hamersleys were unable to persuade her to return with them.

Miss Hamersley then moved to New York with the Unification Church and then to
Akron, where she lived in the church commune and worked for the church at a
store in a shopping center.

The Hamersleys returned to the United States several days ago, this time aided
by a deprogrammer and some lawyers.  They succeeded in getting a court order to
have her temporarily committed to a mental hospital, where she was held for
several days.  The Hamersleys had told the court their daughter suffered from
hypoglycemia, a disorder involving low levels of blood sugar, and that her
sudden gain of about 25 pounds jeopardized her health.

By the time the mental hospital was ready to release her Thursday, immigration
officials had been alerted and were prepared to arrest her.

Peter Reilly, the Australian consul from Chicago, said foreign travelers in the
United States were often targets of religious cults. ''It is becoming an
increasing problem, the difficulties that Australians have encountered with
cults,'' he said.

Six Poles Jump Ship In Alaska

BYLINE: UPI

SECTION: Section 1; Page 11, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 210 words

DATELINE: ANCHORAGE, Dec. 25


Six Polish sailors who jumped from their fishing vessel into a tugboat in Kodiak
Harbor on Christmas Eve spent Christmas with families of Polish descent on their
first full day in America.

A Roman Catholic church helped place the sailors with Polishspeaking families in
the Anchorage area until the Federal authorities can determine whether to grant
the men asylum.

Peter Gordon, an inspector with the Immigration and Naturalization Service, said
that the State Department would have the final word on whether the sailors would
be eligible for asylum, but added, ''There's no thought of sending them any
place at this time, certainly not back to Poland.''

that had been dispatched by the Coast Guard to ferry two crewmen suffering from
abdominal bleeding to Kodiak, where an ambulance was waiting. While the ailing
sailors were being lowered into the tug, the six jumped aboard the tug and asked
for asylum.

Coast Guard escorts flew the six to Anchorage, where they were handed over to
immigration officials, who allowed the men to be placed with Anchorage families.

CAMP DISTURBANCE STAGED BY HAITIANS

MIAMI, Dec. 27 (AP) - Chanting ''liberte, liberte,'' more than 200 Haitian
immigrants broke through security lines and stormed the fences of a Federal
immigration camp here today in an apparent attempt to free 700 detained
countrymen.

Using clubs and tear gas, immigration security guards and Metro Dade police beat
back what one officer described as a ''mob-type'' rush while about 300 other
demonstrators shouted support for the charge.

''The plan seemed to be to help break out the interned entrants,'' said Beverly
McFarland, a spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service. ''They
stormed past the security line and were climbing the fences to get in.''

As the demonstrators fled the tear gas, several began setting fires in the
surrounding Everglades underbrush, said police Sgt. Joe Wiche. Twelve acres of
the Everglades burned, and more than 10 fire units were required to bring the
fires under control.

About 30 Haitian detainees escaped in the confusion, but 20 returned voluntarily
or were recaptured, said Miss McFarland.  She said no injuries were reported,
but Vera Weisz, an attorney for the Haitian Refugee Center, said the police had
used unnecessary force in subduing the crowd.

The Haitians inside the compound apparently were not involved in the
demonstration. Many of the 742 aliens at the camp have been detained for several
months awaiting immigration hearings or deportation.

Most of the male detainees have been boycotting meals since Christmas Eve. The
51 Haitian women in the camp are accepting food.  Miss McFarland said the
Haitians had never given a reason for their food boycott, but others said the
refugees were protesting their confinement.

The Haitians contend they are political refugees, while Federal immigration
authorities say the Haitians are coming to this country for economic reasons and
should not be granted asylum.

----

Cuban Refugees Protest Arrests

FORT CHAFFEE, Ark. Dec. 27 (AP) - Two small groups of angry Cuban refugees
carrying rocks gathered at the Fort Chaffee resettlement center today to protest
the arrests of two refugees that they thought had been mistreated.

Capt. Adrian Droke of the Federal Protective Service said that 25 Cubans formed
one group and that 15 others gathered about half a block away. He said the
refugees did not throw the rocks. The demonstration followed a scuffle between
police and two unidentified refugees, Captain Droke said.

The Cubans at Fort Chaffee are the last prisoners of the thousands who arrived
in the Freedom Flotilla boatlift.

SOVIET JEWS POSE U.S.-ISRAEL PUZZLE

BYLINE: Reuters

SECTION: Section A; Page 15, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 675 words

DATELINE: VIENNA, Dec. 27


With the number of Jews allowed to leave the Soviet Union dropping sharply, a
dispute has erupted between United States and Israeli organizations helping to
settle the emigrants.

The Israelis accuse the Americans of provoking a new hard line from the Soviet
authorities by enticing the emigrants away from Israel, the destination that is
listed on their exit visas.

The Americans defend what they describe as the principle of free choice of
destination, and assert that the decline in the number of Jews leaving the
Soviet Union is linked solely to tensions in East-West relations.

The American and Israeli groups, which have jointly handled more than a
quarter-million Soviet Jewish emigrants in the last decade, agree on predictions
that the departures will become a trickle in the next few years. The number of
emigrants is expected to fall below 10,000 this year for the first time since
the exodus started in 1969.

'Broad Hints of Dissatisfaction'

The rift between the groups became evident when the Jewish Agency, which
oversees immigration to Israel, decided last August to change its assistance
program after receiving what it said were ''broad hints of dissatisfaction''
from Moscow at the high rate of emigrants settling in countries other than
Israel.

Until then, the agency had referred all emigrants arriving in Vienna who chose
not to go to Israel to two United States Jewish organizations, Hias and the
Joint Distribution Committee.

Under its new procedures, the agency directs such emigrants to the two American
groups only if they have immediate relatives, such as parents, children or
spouses, in the United States.

In the month that the new policy was put into effect, the rate of departures to
Israel rose from 20 to 30 percent of the total, according to Barbuch Minkovitz,
the agency's director in Vienna. Mr.  Minkovitz accused Hias of breaking an
agreement on the issue shortly afterward.

'They Cannot Force People'

But Dr. Merryll Rosenberg, the society's director in Vienna, said: ''We don't
want to be accused of stealing people. But people who did not want to go to
Israel were literally evicted onto the street, so we helped them. They cannot
force people to go to Israel.''

Mr. Minkovitz denied that his agency was forcing Soviet Jews to go to Israel.
''We don't want to force anybody,'' he said. ''But we don't want to be forced to
help those who harm our interests.''

He said the Soviet Union ''has made it known on several occasions that it will
let fewer Jews out if more go to the United States.'' Eighty percent of the Jews
leaving the Soviet Union have gone to the United States this year, he said,
''and look what happens - last month we had fewer than 400 arriving here for the
first time in 10 years.''

''To get a visa for Israel, and then decide in Vienna, when all pressure is
gone, to go to America, is cheating the Soviet authorities,'' he said. ''This
slowly closes the door, and could liquidate Soviet Jewish emigration
altogether.''

At Least 200,000 Jews Seek Visas

Mr. Minkovitz estimated that 200,000 to 400,000 of the two to three million Jews
in the Soviet Union want to emigrate and have received the invitations from
relatives in Israel that they need to apply for visas.

The Jewish agency also objects to the United States granting refugee status to
Soviet Jewish emigrants.  ''As a lawyer, I simply cannot understand how someone
with a visa for a free country can be considered a refugee,'' Mr. Minkovitz
said.  He said Israel had repeatedly asked the Soviet Union to put Jewish
emigrants aboard direct flights to Tel Aviv, rather than use neutral Austria for
transit, but without success.

He said he had asked thousands of emigrants whether they would have left the
Soviet Union if they had known that they could go only to Israel, and none had
said no.

DISPLACED TRIBE IN PAKISTAN SEEKS HOME IN ALASKA

BYLINE: By MICHAEL T. KAUFMAN, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 15, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 587 words

DATELINE: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Oct. 5


A small group of Kirghiz tribesmen who were forced out of the Soviet Union in
the 1930's and out of China in the 1950's have fled Afghanistan to refugee camps
in Pakistan where their elders are planning another migration - this time to
Alaska.

Philip Covington, the United States Consul here, said that the tribe's leader,
Rahman Qul, had been in contact with Senator Mike Gravel, Democrat of Alaska,
about the possibility of taking the 978 surviving members of the tribe to an
Alaskan island. The consul said the idea had been brought to the attention of
the Immigration and Naturalization Service and that Mr. Qul was pursuing his
case through the appropriate agencies.

The main body of the Kirghiz people form a republic in the Soviet Union. There
is also an autonomous Kirghiz district in China, across the border.

The tribal leader is living at a camp in Gilgit, 240 miles north of here, and
could not be reached. However, Andre Singer, a film maker who made a documentary
about the tribe several years ago, visited Mr. Qul recently and quoted him as
saying that his people sought resettlement in a familiar cold climate.

The Kirghiz originally herded their yaks in the 15,000-foot-high valleys of the
Pamirs, which stretches from northeast Afghanistan into Soviet Tadzhikistan and
China's Xinjiang Autonomous Region. In the Stalinist period a group of the
Kirghiz, including Mr. Qul's people, battled army and police units and were
ultimately driven out of the Soviet Union.

Reason to Leave Afghanistan

In 1950 the Chinese closed their borders to the Mongol nomads. Mr.  Qul told the
American consular officials and Mr. Singer that after the 1978 coup that brought
the first of three pro-Soviet leaders to power in Afghanistan, he sensed that
the tribe was threatened because of its historic opposition to Communism and its
clashes with Soviet patrols.

The group then set off for Pakistan in a caravan that included 1,136 tribesmen,
10,000 sheep, 200 yaks, 17 camels and 16 horses. In Pakistan the people were
scattered in several camps, and most of the animals had to be sold. The people
suffered in the relatively warm weather of the much lower valleys near Gilgit,
which are 6,000 to 8,000 feet above sea level. Over 150 tribesmen have died in
the last two years, Mr. Singer said.

Mr. Qul saw in Alaska an end to his tribe's problems. Some years ago he was told
about Alaska by a United Nations wildlife specialist. Mr. Qul has told consular
officials his people would find the frozen expanses hospitable.

He has written to scholars in the United States, including Louis Dupree, an
anthropologist whom he knew when Mr. Dupree lived in Afghanistan. He asked Mr.
Dupree to help obtain visas for his people. Mr. Dupree got in touch with Senator
Gravel, who before his defeat in the primary election in August was said to have
responded enthusiastically.

----

Officials Report No Action

Special to the New York Times

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 - Verne Jervis, a spokesman for the Immigration and
Naturalization Service, said the agency had not received a formal request to
help the Kirghiz tribesmen from Senator Gravel or the State Department.

A State Department official said the tribal leaders had not applied for visas or
begun the paper work to immigrate.  Heida Boucher, administrative assistant to
Senator Gravel, said the Senator was interested but had not done anything since
losing the primary.

Louis Dupree, reached in Princeton, N.J., said he still wanted to help the
tribe.

ILLEGAL FLOW OF HAITIAN IMMIGRANTS INTO FLORIDA IS REPORTED TO INCREASE

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section B; Page 17, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 445 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, Oct. 29


While the flow of Cuban refugees into the United States has slowed to a trickle,
officials say the number of Haitians who enter the country illegally has
increased to an average of about 200 a day.

About 1,500 Haitians have arrived in southern Florida since last week, when the
Government of the Bahamas ordered the 25,000 Haitians living there to come
forward for deportation to Haiti.

The United States Immigration and Naturalization Service believes that a large
percentage of the current wave of Haitian immigrants are coming from the
Bahamas, the agency's district director, Raymond A.  Morris, said today.
Processing of the immigrants has not been completed, however, ''so we don't
really know at this time,'' Mr.  Morris added.

''When the Bahamian Government puts pressure on the Haitians to leave, we can
expect an influx here,'' he said. He said that only about seven Cubans arrived
in the United States in the previous week.

Face Prosecution in Bahamas

A Bahamian Government spokesman, Bill Kalis, said the Ministry of Home Affairs
announced Oct. 22 that Haitians in that country would be given a 12-week period
to agree to leave. Haitian residents who do not come forward will face
prosecution, Mr. Kalis said.

Most of the illegal entries to the United States have been by boat, but 41 of
the 330 Haitians who arrived Monday and yesterday came aboard commercial
airplane flights from the Bahamas. Maria Linares, spokesman for the State
Department's Cuban and Haitian Task Force here, said the refugees turned
themselves over to immigration officials and were taken to the Krome Avenue
processing center west of Miami.

By last night the processing center held more refugees than at the peak of the
''freedom flotilla'' boatlift from Cuba. There were 1,278 Haitian refugees at
the center today, 278 more than the facility held at the height of the Cuban
influx.

Justice William J. Brennan Jr. of the United States Supreme Court last week
temporarily blocked the Government's plans to transfer refugees from the
processing camp to Fort Allen in Puerto Rico.  Justice Brennan told the Carter
administration Friday to postpone the transfer until it hears from the full
Supreme Court. The Puerto Rican Government has filed suit to block the plan.

More than 125,000 Cubans have arrived in the country since the Cuban boatlift
began in April. As many as 40,000 Haitians have sought refuge in the United
States in recent years, and most of them have settled in southern Florida, along
with the majority of the Cubans.

Increasing Role for Immigration Seen in U.S. Population Growth

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 42, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 158 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8


A private study group has predicted that immigration will play an increasing
role in United States population growth in coming years.

Currently, according to the report from the Population Reference Bureau,
immigration accounts for nearly half of the nation's population increase. The
country receives about 700,000 legal immigrants annually, plus illegal arrivals
estimated at between 100,000 and 500,000, said the report, made public Thursday.

If combined legal and illegal immigration proceeded at a total of about one
million a year, the report by Leon F. Bouvier said, and if there was no change
in current low fertility rates, the population would reach more than 310 million
in 50 years.

Because the current fertility rate of 1.8 is not sufficient to replace people
who die, immigration would eventually become the sole source of increase, the
report says.

               November 14, 1980, Friday, Late City Final Edition

JERSEY'S CUBANS LOOK TO U.S. FOR HELP IN AIDING REFUGEES

BYLINE: By ALFONSO A. NARVAEZ, Spec ial to the New York Times

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1242 words

DATELINE: WEST NEW YORK, N.J., Nov. 13


Last spring tens of thousands of Cuban refugees survived a perilous flight from
their country in small boats and, with the help of an earlier surge of
immigrants, many of them settled here and in neighboring Union City.

But, unlike the earlier wave of Cubans who poured into the United States in the
early and middle 1960's - most of them from Cuba's prerevolution middle-class,
well-educated and eager to do well in a new country - many of the new immigrants
are poor, lacking education and job skills.

Now, the very people who had welcomed the new immigrants say that hospitality
has turned into a burden and that the Federal Government must step in.

Jobs and Housing Scarce

''We did our part,'' said Gaston Rodrigues, a businessman in Union City who,
along with four colleagues, raised $150,000 to aid Cuban refugees who fled to
Peru and the United States. ''When the need was there, we went all out. A lot of
us saw our businesses begin to go down because we were devoting so much time to
the refugees. We did what we could.''

The new arrivals - about 21,000 of them -have moved to areas already suffering
from high unemployment and overburdened government services. Jobs are scarce,
housing is expensive or nonexistent, and the refugee children have swollen
already overcrowded classrooms.  Some of the refugees are suspected of
contributing to a rising crime rate.

West New York and Union City are second only to the Miami area in their numbers
of Cubans and Cuban-American residents.  Some were drawn to the United States by
glowing tales of prosperity from relatives in Miami and New Jersey. Others,
according to social workers assisting in resettlement, did not want to leave
Cuba but were expelled.

Some Cuban-American businessmen in Union City say that crime has increased along
Bergenline Avenue, the heart of the business district.

Sponsorships Break Down

The police say burglaries and robberies have increased with the latest influx of
Cubans and social agencies say they have been overwhelmed.

''Many of those arrested seem to be without homes,'' said Edward C. Megill, the
deputy first assistant prosecutor in Hudson County. ''It appears that many of
the sponsorships have broken down and these men are out on the streets and don't
know where to turn.''

Michael Leggiero, the executive director of the North Hudson Community Action
Corp, which has assisted more than 5,000 refugees in the last six months, said,
''We're getting 60 to 75 people a day looking for jobs, for food stamps or for
emergency aid.''

Housing is also in such short supply that some refugees have been found sleeping
in cars and hallways. More than 900 refugee families have applied for welfare
assistance and for food stamps at the county level and hundreds of other cases
are being handled by the municipalities themselves.

Schools Hard Pressed

Meanwhile, school officials in West New York and Union City say they must
receive promised Federal money if they are to cope with an influx of refugee
children that has forced them to put as many as 50 students in a classroom.

More than 1,100 refugee children were enrol led in the two school systems in
September, long after budgets for the school year had beenadopted. Officials
were hard pressed to find teachers and classroom space for them.

''I had 51 students in my bilingual mathematics class when school started,''
said Juan Rivello, a teacher at Memorial High School here. ''I was able to move
some of them into another class when a new teacher was hired but I still have 29
here. I have 38 others in a science class. That's just too many. We usually have
no more than 25 students in a class.''

In a bilingual history class with 41 students, Daniel Valdes reviewed
Spanish-language material on Columbus's first trip to the New World. The
students waved their arms vigorously to get the teacher's attention and
animatedly answered his questions in Spanish.
'Weak in the Basics'

Mr. Valdes said most of the students in the class were re fugee children, of
which there are 476 in the West New York system. The high school c ontains 150
of them.

''They're weak in the basics and they do not have much discipline,''he said.
''From what I have seen on television programs dealing with the school system in
Cuba I expected them to be more regimented but they tell me that in Cuba their
teachers were often absent and they could cut classes whenever they wanted.''

In Union City, 667 youngsters came into the school system. Robert Menendez,
secretary to the Board of Education, said bilingual classes had grown from 25
students to 36 or 37.

On Oct. 10, President Carter signed a bill designating up to $200 million over
three years to aid communities hard hit by an influx of refugees from Cuba,
Haiti and Indochina.

The money is to provide up to $1,200 for each student enrolled in an
overburdened school system, and additional reimbursement for social service
costs. Officials say they have not been told when the money is to arrive.

Fourteen Arrived in October

Meanwhile, refugees are still arriving from reception centers in other parts of
the country. Last month, 14 Cubans, who had spent more than four months in
Arkansas and Wisconsin, were brought to Paterson under the auspices of Catholic
Family and Community Services. Officials hope to find jobs, housing and sponsors
for them.

The men, who range in age from 19 to 50 years, were among the approximately
4,000 hard-to-place men and women still at Fort Chaffee, Ark.

The Rev. Robert J. Vitillo, executive director of the of the program, said most
of the men were unskilled, uneducated and had little work experience in Cuba.
But he added that they were eager to learn and to get jobs.

Despite their months at the reception centers, the men had nothing but kind
words and gratitude for their treatment in this country.  They placed the blame
for riots at the camps - including one at Fort Chaffee in which four buildings
were burned down - on former convicts expelled by the Castro Government.
A Welder Gets Ahead

Some refugee leaders point out that despite problems encountered by a few,
thousands have been absorbed peacefully by the two New Jersey communities, where
the earlier immigrants donated food and clothing and spending money and made
space in their homes for them.

One who got help and fit in smoothly is Vicente Ramsay, who came to Union City
in May.  Mr. Ramsay, a 46-year-old welder, left his wife and three children in
Havana. Members of the Cuba-Peru Crusade gave him clothing, some expense money
and were able to find him a job, all within a week of his arrival in Union City.

Since then, Mr. Ramsay has received a modest raise, and he now earns $6.25 an
hour at his job at a marine terminal. He has also bought some new clothes,
rented an apartment and he is looking forward to having his wife and children
join him.

''It's lonely,'' he said, ''but it's worth it. Here I have freedom. Nobody is
spying on me or telling me what to do.''

THE NEW AMERICANS, YOUNG AND OLD

BYLINE: By NATHAN GLAZER; Nathan Glazer, professor of education and sociology at
Harvard, is the author of ''Beyond the Melting Pot'' (with Daniel P. Moynihan),
''American Judaism'' and ''Affirmative Discrimination.''

SECTION: Section 7; Page 7, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1224 words


AMERICAN MOSAIC The Immigrant Experience in the Words of Those Who Lived It.  By
Joan Morrison and Charlotte Fox Zabusky.  457 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $19.95.

ONE approaches with some trepidation the numerous books that are made these days
out of tape recordings: They are so long, and it takes so much time to get to
the point, if there is a point. But ''American Mosaic'' is something of a
triumph of this new form. It is consistently fascinating and consistently rich
in significant details about the great and complex story of immigration to the
United States and adaptation to American life.

The authors interviewed 140 immigrants from perhaps 50 countries.  The earliest
came as far back as 1895, the latest in 1979. Some of their stories take up
seven or eight pages, others are represented by a short passage. Sophie
Zurowski, a 109-year-old woman who immigrated from Poland in 1895 and was
interviewed in a nursing home in Gary, Ind., briefly tells us: ''My husband
worked in the steel mill all his life. ... None of my boys ever went to work in
the steel mill.  The one that got to be a druggist, when he was going to
collegehe went over there to make a little money, and he said, 'Daddy, I don't
know ho w you can stand that place!' My husband said, 'Well, I could stand i t.
If you want to make a living, you have to stand it.' ''

But one doesn't have to go to a nursing home to reach back to the immigrants of
the 19th century. One finds Joseph Baccardo, an Italian immigrant who came in
1898, still working as a barber in the shop he opened in a small town in
Pennsylvania in 1902; Gunnar Johanson, an immigrant from Iceland in his 90's,
still working his 200-acre North Dakota farm; and Pauline Newman, who came from
Lithuania in 1901 and is today, at the age of 86, the authors tell us, the
educational director of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

Is there a thesis? One of the virtues of ''American Mosaic'' is that just about
every thesis that has been proposed about American immigration can find some
support in these accounts. Life was hard, terribly hard ... and yet the son who
was shocked by the steel mill his father worked in is now a druggist. But in
this new form of oral history no point need be insisted upon. And one has no
sense that the immigrants in the book were selected according to a thesis. They
include the successful and the unsuccessful, those who met prejudice and those
who found complete acceptance, the rebels and revolutionaries and the
conservative and quiescent.

That one can reach back into the experiences of immigrants who came here in the
1890's - and that these experiences are still so vivid and are recounted by
people who are still at work - is astonishing.  Here are the people Willa Cather
and Ole Rolvaag wrote about. These are their ''true stories,'' and they are
still here. It is perhaps for this reason that I found the first of the three
sections into which this book is divided, ''The Last of the Old: The Traditional
Immigrants,'' the most interesting. Their stories make an epic: These are the
people who left the Europe in which they struggled to gain their livelihood from
worn-out fields, who can even remember life under a feudal order, and who came
to a country in which hard work assured them livelihood and sometimes more.

One is surprised at how often, along with their accounts of a kind of hard labor
we can no longer imagine, the immigrants paused to tell us what good times they
had. Here is Pauline Newman, after describing her 14-hour working days as a
child in the notorious Triangle Shirtwaist Factory: ''But despite that, we had
good times. In the summer we'd go to Cent ral Park and stay out and watch the
moon arise; go to the Palisades and spend the day ...  and remember, in that
time you could go and h ear Caruso for twentyfive cents.'' No wonder that, a few
pag es after telling of all the changes the union and time have brought, she
muses: ''Only now, I'm a little discouraged sometimes when I see the workers
spending their free hours watching television - trash.  We fought so hard for
those hours and they waste them. We used to r ead Tolstoy, Dickens, Shelley, by
candlelight, and they watch the ' Hollywood Squares.' Well, they're free to do
what they want. That 's what we fought for.''

Or here is Anna Ohlson, from Norway, after describing her incredibly hard life
on a Dakota farm at the turn of the century: ''But, you know, it was fun.''
Still, one has to remember, as Oscar Handlin properly and soberly reminds us in
his introduction, ''The interviews are not records of what actually happened,
but retrospective accounts of a deep human experience, as recalled by those who
lived through it.''

A proper caution: these are the survivors, after all, as we are so frequently
reminded in these narratives, of difficult voyages, of accidents in mine and
factory, of disease and epidemic. So many of the stories focus, at one point or
another, on a sister or a brother, a father or a mother who died very young.
Death was as ever present as work. And yet, as Pauline Newman and Anna Ohlson
remind us, there were good times and fun, vividly remembered, of a kind that
seems to have been integrally related to the hard lives they lived, and perhaps
therefore of a kind we can no longer experience.

The following two sections of the book are much darker in coloring. Part two,
''The Wartime Influx: Heroes, Victims, Survivors,'' is dominated, despite its
subtitle, by the terrible stories of the survivors of the Holocaust - and by the
morally ambiguous accounts of those among whom they suffered and died, many of
whom also became immigrants. Here too are the war brides, and those who were
famous or became famous - Alexandra Danilova, Edward Teller, Eugene Wigner,
Denise Levertov, W. Mich ael Blumenthal. This is still a pr edominantly European
immigration, but the immigrants nowcome from mor e varied backgrounds and
countries and have more varied stories. Only the background of Fascism, Nazism,
Communism and war iscommon. The e pic and innocent qualities of the earlier
immigrant accounts have disappeared.

In the final section of the book, ''Immigration: A Continuing Process,'' the
canvas broadens. The immigrants now come from countries that did not exist
before World War II, from Latin America and the West Indies, from Africa and
Asia, as well as from Europe.  They come for all the old economic reasons, as
well as for newer reasons. So many of them have suffered from the ferocious
racial, religious and political persecution that make the experience of the
pre-World War I years (except for the genocide of the Armenians) mild in
retrospect. If it is hard to find a thesis in the first two sections of
''American Mosaic,'' it is even harder in this final section.

Yet one assumes there was art and intention as well as a sense of chronology at
work in placing at the end of the book the stories of recent Jewish immigrants
from the Soviet Union, the story of Vio Thi Tam, a Vietnamese who survived the
awful ordeal of the boat people, and finally the story of a young married couple
from South Africa, Ali and Johanna Patel - he an Indian, she an Afrikaner - who
came here to escape the apartheid laws. America, we are being told, is still, at
least -whatever else it is not - the land of refuge.

ABROAD AT HOME;
HYPOCRISY WINS AGAIN

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

SECTION: Section A; Page 23, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 871 words

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 3


Last Oct. 2 Jeane Kirkpatrick, United States Ambassador to the United Nations,
spoke in the U.N. General Assembly about what she called the ''savagery'' of the
Marxist regime in Ethiopia. In graphic terms she denounced assaults on human
rights that have occurred since Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam took over in the
revolution of 1974.

''It is estimated that some 30,000 persons in Ethiopia were summarily executed
for political reasons between 1974 and 1978,'' Mrs. Kirkpatrick said, crediting
Amnesty International as the source of the figure.

''Twelve-year-old children were among those immersed in hot oil, sexually
tortured or flung out of windows and left to die in the street.''

The outrages were continuing, Ambassador Kirkpatrick charged.  ''There are at
least 300 to 400 arrests every week in Addis Ababa alone,'' she said. ''Many of
those arrested simply disappear and are presumed executed....''

Powerful words. But at about the same time Mrs. Kirkpatrick spoke them, Reagan
Administration officials were preparing action to send the 20,000 or 30,000
Ethiopian refugees in this country back to Ethiopia.

The action was taken by the Justice Department's Immigration and Naturalization
Service. In the Boston area, a letter signed by the District Director, Paul E.
McKinnon, went individually to Ethiopian refugees on Oct. 30. I have a copy and
it says:

''Dear -----: ''This is to inform you that because of the stabilization of
conditions in Ethiopia, your voluntary departure status in the United States is
being revoked.

''You are being granted until Nov. 30, 1981, to depart the United States
voluntarily. You should notify this office on or before Nov.  19, 1981, of the
travel arrangements you have made. If you fail to depart as directed above,
consideration will be given to the institution of deportation proceedings.''

According to one arm of the Reagan Administration, then, conditions in Ethiopia
are ''savage.'' According to another, they are ''stabilized'' - so amiable, in
fact, that we give refugees from the Mengistu regime a mont h to go voluntarily
or face deportation to Ethiopia.

The letter added that a refugee could seek relief under a provision of law
helping aliens who would face death or imprisonment at home for political
reasons. But the legal burden of proof is heavy in such cases, and authorities
have indicated that few of the Ethiopian refugees would be able to meet it.

It is always hard for an individual, except a politically prominent one, to
prove that he will be tortured or killed or persecuted by a tyrannical regime.
But there is every reason in common sense for the Ethiopian refugees here to
expect trouble if they return home now.  They are Westernized, highly educated,
many of them children of officials in the Haile Selassie Government overthrown
by Col.  Mengistu.

There is a particular political callousness in the move against these refugees.
In the Haile Selassie days the United States regarded Ethiopia as one of its
best friends in Africa. Since the revolution the U.S. has stopped aid and shown
sympathy for Ethiopia's traditional enemy, Somalia, even when Somalia tried to
seize Ethiopian territory by force.

Some think American antagonism to the Mengistu regime has made matters worse.
U.S. refusal to deliver arms that had been paid for when Somalia attacked
certainly encouraged Ethiopia to turn to the Soviet Union and to invite Cuban
troops in. B ut whatever the wisdom of our political attitude toward Col.
Mengist u, it is utterly inconsistent with the decison to expel the Et hiopian
refugees.

The episode can be seen as one more example of lack of coordination in the
Reagan Administration's foreign policy, this time one that not only embarrasses
us but has immediate human consequences. But it signifies something more, I
think.

This is an Administration that bristles with talk about the cruelties of
Communism. When it comes to invective about the Soviet Union and its friends,
few can beat Jeane Kirkpatrick or Alexander Haig, or for that matter Ronald
Reagan. But the same Administration has shown itself in many ways insensitive to
human suffering.

Again and again the Reagan people have tried to undo American efforts to
alleviate the cruelties of right-wing tyrannies. It fiercely resisted
Congressional moves to continue human-rights conditions on aid to such murderous
Governments as those of Guatemala and Argentina. It has said nothing audible
about the Turkish military Government's demand for the death penalty in a
pending prosecution of 52 trade union leaders.

But the two-faced treatment of Ethiopia and Ethiopian refugees is an especially
glaring case. It adds a cynical note to the message broadcast to the world by
President Reagan on New Year's Day: ''Our hearts go out to those who suffer
oppression.''

               January 11, 1982, Monday, Late City Final Edition

VISA DISPUTE IMPERILS U.S. MEXICO TIES

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 3, Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 767 words

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 10


A decision by the Reagan Administration to cancel the temporary immigrant visas
of tens of thousands of Mexicans living in the United States has provoked loud
protests in Mexico and is threatening the first storm in relations since
President Reagan took office.

The Government has recalled its Ambassador to Washington, Hugo B.  Mar gain, who
will brief President Jose Lopez Portillo and Foreign Minister Jorg e Castaneda
de la Rosa on the controversy this week.  Mexican labor groups have also
asserted that the Immigration and Naturalizatio n Service is planning ''mass
deportations'' of Mexicans in the United States.

So far, however, both the Reagan and Lopez Portillo administrations have been
careful not to let the problem grow into a major crisis.  ''The issue, as
presented publicly, has been blown out of all proportion to the real facts,''
the American Ambassador, John Gavin, insisted last week. The Mexican Government
said it had been assured there would not be ''massive deportations or
roundups.''

Court Decision Is Root

Yet despite the evident political good will existing between the two
administrations, Washington's freedom to be flexible is limited by legal
constraints. If the law is applied strictly, relations will unavoidably be
strained.

The issue has its roots in a decision by a United States district court in
Chicago accepting the argument of a Mexican national, Refugio Silva, who
maintained that the United States Government's practice of deducting the number
of immigrant visas granted to Cuban refugees from the Western Hemisph ere quota
di scriminated against applicants from other countries.

The court ordered that a similar number of visas - 144,999 - be issued to
citizens of the Americas in addition to the 120,000-person annual quota and the
single country limit of 20,000 a year. This was to take place between Nov. 9,
1979, and Nov. 9, 1981.

Around 200,000 Mexicans were eligible to apply for the new visas and, once they
had become ''Silva class applicants,'' they were allowed to stay and work in the
United States and receive welfare benefits. Of these, however, only 115,271
Mexicans eventually received permanent resident status.
Judge Ends Injunction

On Dec. 24, a district court judge took note that the required number of
additional visas had been issued and he lifted the injunction imposed on the
Immigration and Naturalization Service, which effectively protected the ''Silva
class applicants'' against arrest and deportation.

Soon afterwards, letters started being mailed to those applicants who had not
benefited from the Silva program asking them to go to the offices of the
Immigration Service to discuss their status.  Immediately, protests began to be
heard from Hispanic leaders in the United States and labor groups in Mexico

Until Ambassador Margain was received by a State Department official last
Wednesday, however, the Mexican Government had received no information from the
United States on the subject. ''This is an internal matter of the United States,
but we would have expected to have been warned as a courtesy,'' a Mexican
Foreign Ministry official noted.

Estimates of the number of Mexicans affected vary from 70,000 to 100,000 and,
according to the Mexican Foreign Ministry, Ambassador Margain was told that as
many as 50 percent of those may still be granted immigrant visas through
ordinary channels as a result of having wives, children or other close relatives
who are now United States citizens. ''As for the other 50 percent, each case
will be studied individually,'' the ministry statement said.

Confrontations 'Can Be Avoided'

Faced by a wave of alarmist reports in the Mexican press suggesting an imminent
offensive against ''Silva class applicants'' and other illegal immigrants,
Ambassador Gavin issued a statement last Thursday stressing that ''they are not
being rounded up an herded to the border.''

''Unfortunately, many people speak out on this sensitive and emotional issue
before they know the facts,'' Mr. Gavin said.  ''Others, some of them in the
United States, frequently take advantage of confusion to inflame passions for
their own purposes. If we speak to each other calmly, based on a knowledge of
the facts, these confrontations can be avoided.''

Notes on People;
A New Citizen Marks 100th Birthday

BYLINE: By Albin Krebs and Robert McG. Thomas Jr.

SECTION: Section B; Page 14, Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 168 words


A follow-up: Last July 22, Gabriel Isahar Isaharov, a 99-year-old immigrant from
the Soviet Union who had been in this country only three years, was granted
citizenship by a Federal judge even though Mr. Isaharov was unable to speak or
write English.

The exception was made for Mr. Isaharov, who said through an interpreter that he
had dreamed of coming to this country for 65 years, because of his advanced age.

That was a happy day for Mr. Isaharov, and so was yesterday, when he celebrated
his 100th birthday at the Queens Jewish Center.  ''I plan to live longer,'' said
Mr. Isaharov, noting that his father, a native of the province of Uzbekistan,
ate yogurt, drank a glass of wine daily, and lived to be 118.

Asked about his plans, Mr. Isaharov, a widower, said he would like to visit his
five children and 70 grandchildren and greatgrandchildren in the Soviet Union.

''I'd also like to marry again,'' he said.

Briefing

BYLINE: By Francis X. Clines and Bernard Weinraub

SECTION: Section B; Page 8, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 905 words


T HE wrenching plight of children of the Orient fathered by American servicemen
is scheduled to reach Congress in the next few weeks, and Representative Stewart
B. McKinney, who has been championing their cause, is faintly optimistic that
the House will finally approve his bill.

Mr. McKinney, Republican of Connecticut, is sponsoring a measure that would
change the ''not-preferential'' status of the children and allow them to apply
to enter the United States under the Immigration and Nationality Act's ''first
preference'' status for unmarried children of American citizens.  The change
would also require the applicants to have American sponsors, but that would not
be very difficult since a range of groups, such as The Pearl S. Buck Foundation
and Save the Children, are actively involved.

''These children will not be coming here to find fathers,'' said Mr. McKinney,
whose earlier bill concerning the children died in the House. ''Many of these
kids are abandoned.''

The Congressman said that both the Carter and Reagan Administrations had been
chilly to his proposal to assist the children, of whom there may be as many as
80,000 in Vietnam, Korea, Thailand, Laos and the Philippines. Officials of the
Reagan Administration have expressed worry about fraud and abuse, Mr.  McKinney
said, and have proposed that any immigration effort should wait until each child
received a blood test, a notion he called ''ludicrous.''

Mr. McKinney said that the measure would not open the doors to mass immigration,
but ''would simply place the Amerasian in his or her proper reference
classification, based on their legitimate claim as a child of a U.S. citizen.''

With 155 co-sponsors in the House, and with a Senate bill supported by such
Republican conservatives as Jeremiah Denton of Alabama and Paul Laxalt of
Nevada, Mr. McKinney is hopeful that his measure will triumph.

''I don't think you can see the pictures and hear the stories of these kids and
not become involved,'' he said.

I N this day of tight Federal budgets and a war on waste in the Pentagon, the
Defense Department's chief spokesman, Henry E. Catto Jr., was asked the other
morning to justify an annual subsidy to the National Rifle Association to
promote target practice. Caught unaware, Mr. Catto asked how much was involved.
Told it was $440,000, he said, almost with a straight face: ''You can't call tha
t a cheap shot, can you?''

A S if the State Department didn't have enough worries, along comes The Crisis
in the American Embassy in Bangkok.  For the last few years, the former American
Ambassador, Morton I.  Abramowitz, maintained a somewhat informal diplomatic
atmosphere.  Most of the senior staff called the Ambassador ''Mort.'' His door
was inevitably open to anyone who wanted to chat. Unlike most ambassadors, Mr.
Abramowitz would dial the telephone himself and invite American journalists over
for a movie or a quick lunch. Around the embassy, many of the men wore
short-sleeved shirts, open at the neck, because of the pulsing heat.

Mr. Abramowitz departed last year; he is now scheduled to take over the American
Embassy in Indonesia. His replacement, John Gunther Dean, promptly made it plain
that the informal days were over.

Mr. Dean, a former Ambassador to Cambodia, Denmark and Lebanon, prefers to be
called ''Sir,'' or ''Mr. Ambassador.'' An embassy officer who showed up
Saturday, his day off, to clean up his desk, was admonished by Mr. Dean because
of his casual appearance.

Mr. Dean even has a young political aide pouring tea now, whenever the
Ambassador has a guest in his office. Mr. Dean prefers his tea hot.

J O-ANN GASPER, a self-described ''pro-family leader'' who edited a publication
called, ''The Right Woman,'' and who opposes Federal assistance to battered
wives and abused children, has just been appointed Deputy Assistant Secretary
for Social Services Policy at the Department of Health and Human Services.

''People for the American Way,'' a Washington-based organization seeking to
counter the influence of Moral Majority, takes note in its current bulletin of a
column that Mrs. Gasper wrote in the March, 1980, issue of the Conservative
Digest, whose publisher is Richard A. Viguerie, the direct-mail expert for many
New Right organizations.

In the column titled, ''Beating Up on the Family,'' Mrs. Gasper wrote that the
concept of domestic violence was so vague that it can mean ''any form of
'belittling' or 'teasing' or 'failure to provide warmth' (whatever that may be -
I guess if you don't set the electric blanket high enough in the winter).''
Francis X. Clines Bernard Weinraub

               January 22, 1982, Friday, Late City Final Edition

2 I.R.A. LEADERS ARRESTED WHILE TRYING TO ENTER U.S. ILLEGALLY

BYLINE: By LES LEDBETTER

SECTION: Section A; Page 3, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 600 words


Two leaders of the Irish Republican Army - in what appeared to be a coordinated
effort to reach New York City in time for a fundraising dinner tonight - were
arrested in separate incidents last night as each was trying to cross into the
United States illegally from Canada, the Immigration and Naturalization Service
said.

One of the arrested I.R.A. leaders, Owen Carron, is a recently elected member of
the British Parliament who last summer was refused a visa to enter the United
States because of his support for violence in Northern Ireland.

Mr. Carron, an unemployed high school teacher who has been identified as a
hard-line republican, was elected to Parliament in August to replace Robert
Sands, the I.R.A. official who won the seat in April while on a fatal hunger
strike in Maze Prison outside Belfast.

The other I.R.A. official who was arrested was identified by the Immigration
Service as Danny Morrison, the I.R.A.'s director of public relations.

Irish Panel Denounces Arrests

The arrests were denounced early this morning by the Irish Northern Aid
Committee as ''censorship'' by the United States State Department ''at the
request of the British'' to prevent Mr. Carron and Mr. Morrison from speaking at
a testimonial dinner in New York City this evening.

A statement issued by the committee said, ''The State Department has apparently
decided at the request of the British that free speech does not apply to those
who oppose the British presence in the north of Ireland.''

The committee said that while it ''no advance knowledge'' of the attempts at
illegal entry into the United States, ''it is obvious that both m en intended to
speak'' at the dinn er and ''to confront'' a loyalist group currently in this
country.  The spokesman for the group would not elaborate.

Antismuggling experts in the Immigration Service had been aware ofthe presence
of the two I.R.A. officials in Canada, according to officials of the Federal
agency, and it was expected that they would make attempts to reach New York City
before the dinner.

Mr. Carron, believed to be 29 years old, was arrested along with a Canadian man
shortly before 9 P.M. as they tried to cross into the United States at Niagara
Falls, said Benedict Ferro, district director for the Buffalo office of the
Immigration Service.

At about the same time, Mr. Morrison, was arrested along with a Canadian
national as they tried to enter the United States across the Peace Bridge in
Buffalo, Mr. Ferro said.

Mr. Carron falsely told immigration officers in Niagra Falls that he had landed
immigrant status in Canada, permitting him to enter without a visa, according to
Mr. Ferro. Mr. Morrison presented officers in Buffalo with a Canadian
citizenship certificate that was not his, he said.

'We Knew They Would Try'

Alerted by members of the service's antismuggling squad, the border officers
were waiting for the two Irishmen and arrested them and their companions.

''We had the information for days and knew they would try,'' Mr.  Ferro
explained in a telephone interview.  All four men were arrested on criminal and
administrative charges in connection with giving false information and attempted
smuggling, according to Mr. Ferro. He said they would be held in upstate jails
while it was determined whether to try them on the charges or initiate
deportation proceedings.

POLICE AIDE ON COAST SAYS SPIES MAY POSE AS JEWISH EMIGR ES

SECTION: Section 1; Page 8, Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 192 words

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 22


Daryl Gates, the Los Angeles police chief, said today that intelligence reports
indicated the Soviet Union was sending ''dangerous criminals'' to this country,
posing as Jewish emigres and that they might attempt to disrupt the 1984 Summer
Olympic Games here.

In a report distributed to business leaders and news executives, Mr. Gates noted
that the annual quota for immigration of Soviet Jews was recently increased to
50,000 a year and said that investigators had determined that some immigrants
entering this country under the quota were not Jewish.

''Many knowledgeable people,'' he said, ''are of the opinion that the Soviets
are selecting dangerous criminals and sending them to the United States as
refugees via the Jewish immigraion quota. The Soviets realize they can aggravate
our already serious crime problem in this manner. Intelligence agents and spies
are infiltrating in the same way.''

Mr. Gates later said at a news conference that the report was speculation but
that he ''saw nothing in here so out of line it shouldn't have been stated.''

2 I.R.A. SUPPORTERS RRMAIN IN CUSTODY

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Page 3, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 630 words

DATELINE: BUFFALO, Jan. 22


Two prominent Irish republican activists remained in c ustody here today after
trying to enter the United States illega lly from Canada in separate cars.

The men, Owen Carron, a Member of the British Parliament, and Danny Morrison,
identified as public relations director of Sinn Fein, the political arm of the
Irish Republican Army, were arrested Thursday night. Mr. Carron was seized at
the Whirlpool Bridge in Niagara Falls, which carries traffic from Niagara Falls,
Ontario; Mr. Morrison, at the Peace Bridge in Buffalo, which carries traffic
from Fort Erie, Ontario.

According to Benedict J. Ferro, district director of the United States
Immigration and Naturalization Service in Buffalo, Mr. Carron and Mr. Morrison
were on their way to a dinner tonight in Astoria, Queens, sponsored by the Irish
Northern Aid Committee.

Both were charged with making false statements to Immigration and Naturalization
Service officials. The charge is punishable by up to five years in prison.

Two Canadians Also Seized

Officials said Mr. Carron had identified himself at the bridge as having
landed-immigrant status in Canada and showed a driver's license that was not
his. Mr. Morrison, officials said, had reportedly showed border authorities a
Canadian citizenship certificate that belonged to someone else.

In addition, two people who were said to have been driving the two activists
across the border were charged with attempted smuggling, according to Roger P.
Williams, interim United States Attorney here.  They could receive as much as
two years in prison if convicted.

They were identified as Patrick Morrell, reported to be an Irish native who is a
naturalized Canadian citizen living in Niagara Falls, Ontario, who was driving
Mr. Carron, and Helen McDonald Quigley, an Australian citizen, who is a resident
of Hamilton, Ontario.

All four were brought before Magistrate Edmund F. Maxwell, who set a preliminary
hearing for 2 P.M. Tuesday and set $10,000 recognizance bond for each of the
four. They were then turned over to the Immigration and Naturalization Service.
No date was set for a civil hearing on their status, according to the
immigration agency.  Normally, this hearing is held after the criminal charges
are disposed of.

2 Claim to Be Political Prisoners

Immigration agency officials declined to say where the four would be held.  Both
Mr. Carron and Mr. Morrison claimed to be political prisoners when they appeared
without lawyers before Magistrate Maxwell.  Mr. Ferro said the immigration
agency was waiting for the two to try to enter the country. He said the American
border authorities had been watching a pattern of Irish republican activists
traveling in Canada during an 18-month investigation.

''This investigation made us aware they would be coming,'' he said, adding that
a special immigration agency squad was waiting at the border crossing when the
attempts were made.

---- 'Publicity Stunt,' Paisley Says

LONDON, Jan. 22 (AP) - The Rev. Ian Paisley, the militant Northern Ireland
Protestant leader, said today that the arrest of two Roman Catholic Irish
nationalists in the United States was ''all a publicity stunt.''

''It doesn't suprise me at all,'' Mr. Paisley said without elaboration.  Mr.
Paisley made the remarks to reporters upon returning from a weeklong visit to
Canada to publicize the Protestant position in Northern Ireland and combat Irish
Republican Army sentiment.

Mr. Paisley said his trip to Canada was an ''outstanding success.'' ''What I had
to say was carried on more than 800 radio and television networks,'' said the
55-year-old Protestant leader, who is a Member of the British and European
Parliaments.

                                 NEW YORK TIMES

                January 4, 1981, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

ISRAELI EMIGRATION INSPIRES ANGER AND FEAR

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4, Column 3; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1090 words

DATELINE: JERUSALEM


With ''descents'' rising and ''ascents'' declining, each to record levels, 1980
was a bitter year for Israel. The mystical character of the words Zionists use
to describe, respectively, emigration of a Jew from Israel or his immigration to
the Jewish state shows the high degree of emotion contained in demographic
statistics in this country and explains the bitterness.

Definitive emigration statistics are unavailable in Israel, as is the case in
all open societies that do not require from their citizens an accounting of
their intentions every time they leave.  But immigration authorities keep track
of the total number of Israelis who depart and who return; emigration estimates
are based on the difference between them. The difference last year was about
30,000.

The previous record year was 1974 when, following the 1973 war, 25,000 more
Israelis left than returned. When a resident has been gone for four years, the
Central Bureau of Statistics lists him as an emigrant. The record total was
again in 1974, 16,400. Last year is likely, four years hence, to surpass that
record.

The bottom year of 1974 was followed by a contraction of emigration; the
difference between departures and returns was down to 7,000 in 1979. Thus, last
year's 30,000 total was not only a record but also marked a dramatic reversal in
the trend of outflow.

Perhaps even more dramatic than the rise in departures was the decline in new
immigrants. Last year's total of about 21,000 represents a drop of more than 40
percent from 1979. Even more frightening to Israel, last month was the first
month in the 12 years in which fewer than 1,000 Jews made their ''aliyah'' or
ascent.

Not all of the drop is due to a lack of desire among Diaspora Jews to come here.
The Soviet Union, through the 1970's the principal source of immigration, has
reduced the outflow of Jews by more than half. In 1979, 51,317 Jews left; the
total for the first 11 months of last year was 20,583. The percentage of Soviet
emigres who chose to come to Israel remained steady at about 35 percent.

''It's nothing short of a disaster,'' said a senior official of the Jewish
Agency, the semi-official body responsible for attracting and settling
immigrants.

Although both the rate of arrival and of departure cause great concern, the
principal focus recently has been on Israelis who leave. One reason was the
leaking of an internal report by a Jewish Agency official on Israelis in the
United States. The document put the cumulative total at as high as 500,000, or
roughly one-sixth of Israel's Jewish population.

The Central Bureau of Statistics rejects this estimate. Its records indicate
that about 350,000 Israelis have left the country for all destinations since its
founding in 1948. But whatever the statistics, emigration is clearly on the
increase, and therein lies the deeper reason for the anguished and angry debate.
In a country founded within recent memory and based on an act of faith that is
under increasing challenge from the non-Jewish world, departure from Israel,
particularly of Israeli-born Jews, not immigrants who have found the going too
tough, is a defection from an embattled cause. An Irishman or Italian who leaves
his country in hard times for a land of greater economic opportunity is not seen
as deserting or endangering the existence of Ireland or Italy. ''Yeridah,'' the
descent of a Jew from Israel, is viewed as all of that and more.

Resentment From Those Who Stay

''A person leaving the country denies his personal role in the rebuilding of the
Jewish state and contradicts the raison d'etre of the Jewish state,'' said the
Jewish Agency official, an academic who weighs and moderates his words. ''The
Diaspora is a disease, and we should have nothing to do with Israelis who join
it,'' said Geula Cohen, an ultranationalistic member of the Knesset, in an
inconclusive parliamentary debate last week. Former Prime Minister Yitzhak
Rabin, a man not given to verbal excess, once referred to yeridah, in
contemptuous Hebrew, as ''the dropping off of the weaklings.''

Israelis deeply regret the sharp decline in aliyah, and extremists like Mrs.
Cohen no doubt equate the failure of all of the world's Jews to gather in Israel
with disloyalty to Jewishness. But there is a vast difference in mainstream
Israeli perception between Jews who prefer to remain in the Diaspora - the
majority - and those who, in effect, take the active step of rejecting the
Jewish homeland.

A usually mild-mannered Israeli, forgiving of human failings and understanding
even of Israel's Arab enemies, surprised a friend with an unwonted note of steel
in his voice when he said, ''Let them go, those who don't want to say.'' And
jabbing the air with a clenched fist, he added, ''but don't make it easy for
them to come back.''

Israeli anger is keenest at the native-born citizens who leave. No figures are
available, because of the paucity of emigration data collected, but New Yorkers
know that Hebrew has become a frequently heard language and the sabra accent in
English has a familiar ring on Manhattan's West Side.

While the decline in new immigrants is conceded by Israeli officials to be at
least in part due to Israel's isolation and the decline in its international
standing, Israelis of all political stripes ascribe emigration entirely to
economic factors. Runaway inflation, which when last year's figures are
tabulated will show a rate of at least 135 percent, Government budget cuts that
affect employment opportunities and reduce Government investment and support for
the private sector, a serious housing problem and a decline in public confidence
that the economy can right itself are factors that enter into all decisions to
leave. A high proportion of emigres are middle class people for whom
opportunities for self-improvement in a richer economy - more university posts,
more and better equipped laboratories, more research grants - abound in the
United States.

Looking desperately for a silver lining, the Jewish Agency official said,
''Given the situation in which Israel has found itself for almost 33 years, one
often wonders why the rate of emigration isn't higher still.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

Bahamian Officials Order Vesco To Leave the Country by Jan. 20

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section B; Page 17, Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 199 words

DATELINE: NASSAU, the Bahamas, Jan. 7


Bahamian immigration officials who want to deport Robert L. Vesco have given the
45-year-old fugitive financier a new deadline of Jan. 20 to leave their country.
Mr. Vesco was served with a deportation order yesterday at his home here.

A previous order was served on Mr. Vesco's son, Anthony, last Wednesday when
officers found that the financier had left Nassau for an undisclosed
destination, reportedly a remote island in the Bahamas, to spend the New Year's
holiday with his family.

Mr. Vesco, who has applied for political asylum in the Bahamas, returned here
Sunday but was not available for comment. Last week, in a statement released to
reporters by his attorney, Mr. Vesco said he would fight Bahamian efforts to
deport him.

Mr. Vesco has been sought by the authorities in the United States since the
early 1970's. The United States contends that he looted Investors Overseas
Services of $224 million while he headed the investment company, and that he
tried to have charges in the case dropped by contributing $200,000 in 1972 to
President Nixon's reelection campaign.

               January 11, 1981, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

TROUBLE, TROUBLE

BYLINE: By LORE DICKSTEIN; Lori Dickstein is a freelance writer bases in New
York City.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 10, Column 3; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 915 words


LOVE By Susan Fromberg Schaeffer.  390 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $14.95.

ALES of immigrant family life - with their large historical scope, clashes of
cultures and generations, and personal stories of people displaced into a new
world - are rich, fertile ground for novelists.  The best books in this genre -
such as Henry Roth's ''Call It Sleep,'' and I.J. Singer's ''The Family
Carnovsky'' - achieve a literary brilliance that lasts long after the story
itself fades from memory. (The genre is not confined to the Jewish novel: Maxine
Hong Kingston's two memoirs ''The Woman Warrior'' and ''China Men'' attest to
that.) But these books are rare achievements. For the most part, the traditional
immigrant novel mines its historical and social material with little artistic
restraint, spewing forth large chunks of the past wrapped in sentimental,
sometimes bathetic, tales of woe that run on, generation after generation, for
hundreds of pages.

Susan Fromberg Schaeffer's fourth novel, ''Love,'' is the story of Esheal Luria,
a Russian-Jewish immigrant whose life is ''blessed with catastrophe.'' To begin
with, Esheal has a lot of trouble with women. While a small boy, he is abandoned
by his widowed mother, who runs off with her new husband. When he later rejoins
her in America, she foists him off on an aunt who raises him. Esheal falls in
love with an unavailable older woman, Sarah Romanoff, and then with one of her
daughters, Diana, who marries someone else. By default, Esheal ends up marrying
Diana's sister Lily, who has been rejected by another suitor. Although Esheal
becomes a successful, even wealthy druggist and is a decent person, he is
unappreciated and mocked by his wife and her family.

Esheal's adult life is a series of disasters: His mother dies two days after he
returns from his honeymoon. One of his children is born hydrocephalic and dies
of spinal meningitis in childhood. During a jealous (and groundless) rage,
Esheal pulls a gun on Lily and she leaves him, taking their two daughters with
her. Oy vey, you think, but there is more. Old grandparents die in melodramatic
ways - one is hit by a falling brick, another run over by a cart. Someone is
always running to the morgue to identify a body, or is hacking away with TB or
double pneumonia, or is bloated by kidney failure. Two people are disfigured by
burns. Relatives end up in prison. Money secreted away is stolen. Finally,
Esheal himself is killed in a holdup.

These kinds of troubles are the stuff of life to immigrant novels and one of the
elements that has made them (like soap operas) so appealing: Other people's
troubles, whether minor or catastrophic, are always gratifying to hear about -
they are not ours. But this novel is unremitting in its bleakness.  There is
little of the biting folk humor found in the early works of Bernard Malamud, or
even in Irving Howe's nonfictional ''World of Our Fathers.'' Where are the small
triumphs of life? There is not one truly happy person or event in the 390 pages
of this book.

Why this novel is entitled ''Love'' is puzzling; little love is found here. In
its place is an obsession with the past. Esheal's granddaughter Emily, the
ostensible author of ''Love,'' sees the lives of her family as a ''dance of the
genes'' in which she is ''only a new step in the continuing dance.'' Her dead
ancestors speak to her ''as living people who have refused to go until they have
made themselves understood.'' Their stories and voices seem to echo in the
author's mind, for ''Love'' picks up strands from her first novel, ''Falling,''
which also contains a pharmacist grandfather who jealously threatens his wife
and is killed in a holdup. Curiously, there is even a repetition of a minor
street-corner incident in both novels. In ''Falling'': ''He drew back the
coverlet and looked at Sarah. 'She looks just like the pharmacist down the
street,' he said. 'I should hope so!' said Belle; 'he's my husband!''' In
''Love'': ''She kept staring at the child, and she said, you know, it's the most
amazing thing, but the child looks exactly like the pharmacist on the corner,
and she said, that's a good thing, because the pharmacist on the corner is her
father.'' While the significance of this scene is unclear to the reader, it must
be of particular weight to the author. It has the resonant quality of a screen
memory, in which action and dialogue are perfectly recalled.

Mrs. Schaeffer has constructed this novel in large sections of flashback
interspersed with narratives written in the voices of the characters, a device
she has used in previous novels. Although many of these first-person accounts
sound very much like verbatim transcripts of tape-recorded interviews, they are
quite wonderful in the way they foretell and retell the story and they save the
novel from mediocrity. Only in these sections can one hear distinctly individual
voices, a quiet chuckle, an ironic comment. For example, here is Emily's mother
Lucy looking back on her life: ''I remember all those things, but now I don't
like to save the old things. They take you over, all those books, cards,
letters, and pictures. They keep accumulating and accumulating and it becomes a
chore to sort them out and they pile up until they overwhelm you and then you
get rid of them all.'' This passage comes at the end of the novel, where the
entire dramatis personae present themselves in a series of short sketches. It is
a stunning finale to an otherwise unimaginative novel.

REFUGEES AND IMMIGRANTS AID NEEDIEST IN GRATITUDE

BYLINE: By WALTER H. WAGGONER

SECTION: Section B; Page 2, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 445 words


Many immigrants and refugees who have found sanctuary in New York City are among
the contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

Hannah Herz of Kew Gardens, Queens, donated $20 to commemorate her arrival in
New York City on Dec. 20, 1937, with her parents, Alfred and Hedwig Herz. She
wrote that her parents, who died last year, had contributed annually ''in
gratitude for our safety and the freedom and good life we found in this
country.''

Felix Bing of Manhattan gave $50 ''in remembrance of the day I was liberated
from Bergen-Belsen concentration camp.'' An anonymous donor from Forest Hills,
Queens, gave $150 in memory of his mother, with whom he came to the United
States in 1940, ''refugees from Hitler and Germany.'' An anonymous gift of $40
came from a resident of Brooklyn who wrote that although he had once been an
impoverished refugee from Europe, ''through God's mercy we were never here in
need.''

Dr. and Mrs. Leon Tan of Brooklyn contributed $50 in ''appreciation for the
hospitality extended by the Americans to two strangers from the Orient.''
