                August 30, 1981, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

40 HAITIANS ARE HELD UPSTATE UNDER RIGID CONTROL

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 35, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 669 words

DATELINE: RAY BROOK, N.Y., Aug. 29


Forty Haitians, confined in the Federal prison here are subject to more
stringent controls than those imposed on the convicted inmates, according to the
prison warden. In addition, two of the Haitians have been held in solitary
confinement.

Homes for all the teen-age Haitians, as well as some of the older men, have been
found with families in Rochester but the Federal Immigration and Naturalization
Service has refused to release them, according to John S. Walker, a Baptist
minister and executive secretary of the Black Ministers of Rochester.

The warden of Ray Brook Prison, George Rodgers, said in an interview yesterday
that the Haitians did not have the ''freedom of movement'' of the inmates, most
of whom he said are convicted drug dealers and bank robbers.

The convicted felons are free to play softball, jog or just stroll around the 55
grassy acres when not confined to their rooms. The Haitians are restricted to
their dormitory and a fenced-in blacktop area where they play soccer, although
it is only half the size of a regular soccer field.

The Haitians at this prison in Essex County, near Lake Placid, are men between
the ages of 17 and 59. They were among several hundred transferred in mid-July
from a Federal detention camp near Miami, where they had been detained after
arriving in the country without visas. None have been charged with committing
crimes.

The policy of imprisoning aliens awaiting hearings on their asylum claims is a
discretionary one being applied so far only to Haitians, a spokesman for the
Justice Department said.

Two of the Haitians here were placed in solitary confinement - called
''adminstrative detention'' by prison officials - after one of them, Nicolas
Joseph, 44 years old, last week lay down in front of a truck bringing food. Mr.
Joseph was said to have told other Haitians that he did it to try to get
information about when he was going to be released.

Mr. Rodgers said he would not discuss the incident ''with the news media
present.'' Religious leaders and lawyers at Ray Brook said yesterday that they
had learned that Mr. Joseph had been hospitalized after fainting several times.
Mr. Rodgers would not allow anyone to talk with Mr. Joseph, who he said would be
returned to solitary after treatment.

A reporter visiting the prison yesterday was not allowed to listen as church
leaders talked to the Haitians about their legal rights and listened to their
concerns. He was allowed to talk with only one Haitian, using a government
interpreter.

John L. Niewieroski, the Immigration Service official in charge of the Haitians
at the prison, stood a few feet away during the interview with the other man who
had been placed in ''administrative detention,'' 29-year-old Bernavil Elisnord.

Mr. Elisnord was placed in solitary confinement, he said, because an interpreter
incorrectly told the prison guards that he was encouraging the Haitians to start
a hunger strike.

During his eight days in isolation, Mr. Elisnord said he was allowed outside of
his room only on two days for exercise periods of about 15 minutes, and twice to
shower.

Mr. Elisnord said that several of the Haitians here had wives, brothers and
cousins being detained in Federal facilities in West Virginia and Florida. He
added that the Haitians were upset because they have not received any mail or
visitors.

''What we all want here is to get out of here,'' Mr. Elisnord said. ''If they
could let us out temporarily or transfer us to another area so we could get a
lawyer.''

An Immigration Service lawyer has acknowledged that ''there are no attorneys in
the Buffalo District'' to provide free legal representation for the Haitians.
Because of that, immigration officials have been assisting them in filling out
their applications for asylum.

Eight More Cuban Refugees Are Freed From U.S. Prison

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 15, Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 143 words

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Sept. 10


Eight more Cuban refugees were released yesterday from the Federal penitentiary
here, bringing to 75 the number of detainees from freed in the last three weeks.

Leland Lagow of the Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service said the
eight left for Michigan and New York, where they have sponsors.

About 1,800 Cubans who came to the United States by sea in 1980 had been
detained here because of reports they had criminal records in Cuba.

Three weeks ago, Federal District Judge Marvin Shoob ordered 381 of the
detainees released, later changing the order to exclude 77 with records of
violent crime. He also ordered the Justice Department to review the cases of 226
more refugees.

In July, Judge Shoob expessed concern that many of those being held were
detained only because they lacked visas.

              September 15, 1981, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

ULSTER'S DEMOCRACY DIES HARD, TOO

SECTION: Section A; Page 30, Column 3; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 222 words


To the Editor:

As one of many Protestant Northern Irish immigrants who are now proud and
grateful citizens of the United States, I wish to voice our silent exasperation
with the naive view of American journalists who seem to believe the ''Protestant
die-hards'' are forcing British rule upon Northern Ireland.

Your Aug. 30 editorial pontificates: ''So long as Protestant diehards in the
North feel they have an unquestioned veto on any change in the province's
status, the I.R.A. will continue to find fanatic recruits.''

Surely, surely - despite all the banshees wailing in the offices of The Times -
somebody in New York must know that the majority of voters (both Catholic and
Protestant) in Northern Ireland continue to vote firmly and repeatedly - in
democratically-run elections - for union with Britain!

If this is ''the Protestant die-hards'' exercising their ''unquestioned veto,''
then ''double-speak'' has arrived, and we should reverse what ''die-hard
Republicans'' did with their ''unquestioned veto'' in our last election.

All of us immigrants from Northern Ireland - Protestant or Catholic - detest the
bitterness, violence and prejudice in our native land, but we treasure democracy
and resent its being called ''the unquestioned veto of die-hards.''
ERNEST W. O'NEILL, Excelsior, Minn., Sept. 1, 1981

              September 20, 1981, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

SECTION: Section 10; Page 26, Column 6; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 273 words


To the Editor:

Those lines at passport control, that rush for luggage carts and subsequent
lines for customs are not a very friendly welcome to foreign tourists. Passport
control seems to be the worst bottleneck, particularly since the foreigners'
ranks have been swelled by resident aliens who used to go through with U.S.
citizens until these were freed of passport control a few years ago and resident
aliens are now being treated as foreigners. Why? Surely returning to your
country of residence, where you live and pay taxes, puts people into a different
category from visitors or new immigrants? What about siphoning them off and
giving them a booth of their own to pass by?  What about doing what banks and
post offices do and having just one line, with the first person going to the
first officer who is free; waiting time in banks and post offices has been cut
down considerably since this system was started. What about providing seats?
Without being a wheelchair case, one can be very tired after a trans-Atlantic
flight and standing there with one's hand luggage with airconditioning that is
inadequate or nonexistent for up to 40 minutes is quite a strain.

When one emerges from passport control at Copenhagen Airport into the luggage
claim area, there is an airport official at the entrance renting out luggage
carts at 65 cents, which is a vast improvement over having to run back and forth
before finding one. The International Arrivals Building at Kennedy is the worst,
of course; conditions are better in the individual airline terminals but still
far from ideal and could surely be improved.
LU FENTON, New York

               October 1, 1981, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

ENGLISH, BY LAW

BYLINE: By S.I. Hayakawa

SECTION: Section A; Page 35, Column 2; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 738 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


One point that Americans often boast about to foreign guests is how our country
has assimilated different ethnic groups that at first glance seem
irreconcilable. Fleeing political repression and religious persecution, these
individuals have endured the most difficult of hardships to enjoy the freedom we
have to offer.

At one time, most immigrants' first task was to learn English. This is no longer
an accepted fact. Many public sc hools now use bilingual education as a method
to bring new citizens i nto the fold of Americansociety. Which is fine, provided
that the pro gram adheres to the original concept of bilingual education: the
use of the immigrant's native language as a transitory tool that wil l
accelerate the processof learning English.

However, many bilingual programs have veered from this mandate, and now use the
native language to teach subjects other than English.  This deviation from the
original concept results largely from the Carter Administration's efforts to
expand on the ''Lau'' guidelines, which came out of the 1974 Lau v. Nichols
decision by the Supreme Court. The plaintiffs argued that their Chinese-speaking
children were being denied equal access to education because they could not
understand courses taught in English. As a result of this decision, in which the
Court found for the plaintiffs, school districts were admonished to focus their
attention on the needs of non-Englishspeaking students. However, the former
Administration pushed to create a binding set of ''Lau'' regulations, which
would have resulted in school districts being forced into compliance under the
threat of withdrawal of funds. Although the regulations were not put into
effect, the problem caused by variants of bilingual education linger.

More and more young immigrants are having their entire curriculum taught to them
in their native language. The longer they are instructed in the native tongue,
the more difficult it becomes for them to learn English in their later years. By
allowing this to continue, we are delaying the immigrants' entrance into the
mainstream of society.

The use of bilingual ballots compounds this problem. Made possible by the 1975
amendments to the Voting Rights Act, bilingual ballots were intended to bring
more non-English-speaking people into our political system. Jurisdictions in 30
states are now required to provide bilingual ballots to their immigrant
citizens, and California's 39 affected counties must print ballots in Chinese,
Spanish and and American Indian.

This policy conflicts with the explicit requirements for naturalization as a
citizen, which state that an applicant must be able to ''read, write and speak
words in ordinary usage in the English language.'' Are we telling immigrants
that they must know English to become a citizen but that they don't need it once
naturalized? These crossed signals that we are sending to immigrants have made
our immigration and citizenship requirements vague and unclear.

We must make it clear to everyone that America does have an official language.
To that end, I have introduced a constitutional amendment that would make
English the official language of the country. The amendment contains provisions
that would eliminate the costly and conflicting problem of the bilingual ballot,
and return bilingual education programs to their original purpose. The amendment
would not scrap all bilingual programs, nor would it prohibit foreign-language
requirements in schools or colleges. I strongly believe in learning more than
one language, and feel our tendency toward monolingualism has put us at a
disadvantage in the international business community.

I have received an overwhelmingly favorable response to my amendment, and many
letters of approval have come from former immigrants who have told me how
important learning English was to them in settling here.

Our strength and creativity has always come from the diverse talents of ethnic
groups, and in no way does my amendment attempt to stifle these rich human
resources. What it attempts to do is prevent a growing split among ethnic groups
based on their native languages.  With each trying to become more powerful than
the other, the function of language could change from a means of communication
to a tool of cultural assertion. Such a struggle for supremacy could have
catastrophic consequences.
S.I. Hayakwa is Republican Senator from California.

IL PROGRESSO, 100, CHANGING FORMAT

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Part 2; Page 52, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 609 words

DATELINE: EMERSON, N.J.


Il Progresso, celebrating a century as a newspaper for Italian immigrants in the
New York metropolitan area, is changing course under new publishers in an effort
to attract later generations of readers interested in a Continental heritage.

The targets are the three million Italian Americans in the area, and even some
of the tens of millions across the country who have ''a remarkable interest in
things Italian'' but no longer speak the language, according to the daily's new
managing editor, Carlo Scarsini.

Mr. Scarsini has headed bureaus in Cairo, New York and Moscow for Ansa, Italy's
largest news service.

Tabloid Format Due

Plans call for the changeover to a tabloid format on Oct. 26 and an eight-page
section in English starting Nov. 15. One model on display in the modern building
in this Bergen County community shows, with magazine-like graphics and new
typeface, a section in English called The Progresso.  It is tucked into a
16-page Il Progresso.

The newspaper will continue to present world, national and local news, with
emphasis on news of special interest to Italians. It will also continue to
feature Dear Abby. And opera - ''one of the images in New York of Italian
tradition,'' Mr. Scarsini said - will still receive the play it has enjoyed for
years.

Il Progresso's circulation was about 300,000 in the 1920's, when Italian
immigration was high, and it briefly surpassed 500,000 in 1935. Assimilation and
the decline of spoken Italian among descendants have cut its readership to
60,000 and resulted in a $200,000 yearly loss.

Pure Italian for Readers

Unlike the pure Italian in Il Progresso, the relatively little Italian that is
spoken in this region is mostly ''Ameritalian,'' a mixture of Italian and
Sicilian dialects with ''New Yorkese,'' Mr.  Scarsini said.

Last year Piero Pirri Ardizzone, publisher of Il Giornale di Sicilia, and Carlo
Caracciolo, publisher of a major Italian news magazine, L'Espresso, purchased
the paper for $1 million from Generoso Pope. Mr. Pope had paid more than twice
that for Il Progresso in 1928. The new owners are investing $250,000 in new
electronic equipment.

Over the years the newspaper and the Pope family have been honored by the City
of New York and the Italian Government. Il Progresso has covered Italian
American social activities, as well as such subjects as assimilation and social
assistance.

The newspaper began in 1879 as a flyer in the Little Italy section of Manhattan,
defending an Italian immigrant who had been convicted and sentenced to death for
the murder of his wife, according to a history of the paper that appeared in its
recent centennial edition.

Identification With Italy

The article described the paper's early support of Mussolini, the collection
with another Italian American newspaper, Corriere d'America, of more than
$700,000 for Italy during its war with Ethiopia in the 1930's and its aid of
post-World War II Italy with food and other provisions.

Il Progresso still has fund drives, Mr. Scarsini said. This year it raised more
than $29,000 to help finance open-heart surgery in Boston for a 9-year-old boy
from Aquila, Italy. It also raised money for victims of the recent earthquake in
southern Italy.

''We want to satisfy interests and curiosities and evolve with the community,''
Mr. Scarsini said. For Il Progresso, he said, the beginning of its second
century marks ''the end of an era and the opening of a new one.''

EMIGRATION BECOMES A PROBLEM IN ARGENTINA

BYLINE: Reuters

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 5, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 555 words

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 24


In an alarming reversal of tradition, Argentian, once a haven for immigrants
from depressed areas of Europe, is experiencing large-scale emigration.

For the first time since independence 150 years ago, the number of people
leaving the country far exceeds the number entering.  After the First World War,
1.5 million poor southern Europeans, most of them Spaniards and Italians, came
to Argentina. They helped turned the country into one of the world's top farming
nations and sent their children to school. Today, their university-educated
grandchildren are knocking at the doors of foreign consulates. They represent a
cross section of Argentine society and include doctors, engineers, lawyers and
architects as well as bricklayers and plumbers.

Diplomatic sources estimate that two million of Argentina's 28 million people
are visiting consulates to inquire about emigrating.  Each morning, long lines
form outside the consulates of the United States, Canada, Australia, Spain and
France, the countries most popular with Argentines who want to leave, often
because these Argentines have relatives there. The Canadian Consulate interviews
about 250 would-be emigrants every day, the sources said.

The Reasons for Leaving

These Argentines have one thing in common: they see no prospects in a country
plagued by economic stagnation, inflation that was 78 percent in the first five
months of this year and growing unemployment.

The number of jobless in greater Buenos Aires, where half the country's
population is concentrated, is 5 percent. This rate may seem tolerable by some
standards abroad, but unemployment is a new phenomenon in underpopulated
Argentina.

The fact that would-be emigrants include many people in the professions has
prompted some publications to describe the exodus as a ''brain drain.''

Argentina probably has the highest number of unemployed doctors in the world, a
young physician who has applied to work in Australia said bitterly. The same can
be said about engineers, architects and biologists.

The Rate of Increase

In the last 20 years, two million Argentines have emigrated at an average rate
of 100,000 a year. Figures made public by consular officials indicate that the
rate is rising rapidly.

Compared with the previous year, applications at the Canadian Consulate from
September 1980 until this August were up 298 percent, and from January to August
of this year the increase was 409 percent.

Earlier waves of emigrants were almost exclusively professionals.  Now
bricklayers, shopkeepers and bus drivers line up outside the consulates.

Low pay and soaring prices - Buenos Aires is one of the most expensive capitals
in the world - mean that many Argentines have to hold two or three jobs to make
ends meet.

''I have lived in Buenos Aires all my life and I never thought I would want to
live elsewhere one day and start all over again,'' a 45-year-old bricklayer said
outside the Spanish Consulate.

Unemployed for six months, he felt he had a good chance of making a livelihood
in Spain, where he has relatives and no language problem.

               October 26, 1981, Monday, Late City Final Edition

TRIAL OF UKRAINIAN IMMIGRANT REVIVES BITTERNESS ON 2 SIDES

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 18, Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 695 words

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25


All last week, Jews sat on one side of a Federal courtroom here and
Ukrainian-Americans sat on the other as the second denaturalization trial in a
year involving charges of collaboration with Nazis revived ancient bitterness.

So far, testimony that a Philadelphia tailor, Serge Kowalchuk, 61 years old,
participated in the massacre of 5,000 Jews in his hometown in the Ukraine has
not spurred the open hostility and angry letters to the editor that the trial of
another Ukrainian immigrant, Wolodymyr Osidach, brought. Stripped of his
citizenship last March, Mr. Osidach died two months later, before any appeals
could be made or a deportation hearing could be held.

Both men were charged with illegally entering the United States after World War
II by not mentioning their roles in the Ukrainian national police force, which
was set up by the Nazis after Hitler's forces invaded the Soviet Union.

Among the spectators at the current trial are members of the Jewish Defense
League, who picketed with signs urging ''Deport Serge Kowalchuk Now'' when the
trial opened last Monday, and who sit in court wearing armbands with the slogan
''Jewish Justice.''

Fifth Case to Be Tried

Mr. Kowalchuk is the fifth immigrant to be tried in the past year by the Justice
Department's Office of Special Investigations. All but one of the defendants
have been Ukrainian. The other cases were in Cleveland, West Palm Beach, Fla.,
and Long Island.

Mr. Kowalchuk, who has lived in Philadelphia for 20 years, listened quietly last
week as witnesses described him as the commandant of the Ukrainian occupation
police in the town of Lyuboml, whose 5,000 Jewish residents were machine-gunned
and buried in mass graves in October 1942.

Mr. Kowalchuck says he was a civilian employee of the town government and that
witnesses have mistaken his identity in describing his role in the roundup of
Jews who were murdered.

Coming to Terms With Holocaust

''In the last half-dozen years, many Jews are coming to terms with the Holocaust
almost since the first time since World War II,'' said Murray Friedman, the
Middle Atlantic director of the American Jewish Committee.

He added that in many Jewish families, ''folk memories'' had left images of a
''hostile populace'' in the country of their origin that could be revived by
testimony on war crimes.

But the trials have stirred equally strong reactions in the Ukrainian-American
community of 40,000 here, which considers itself a powerless minority
stereotyped by unwarranted sensationalizing of a few court cases.

''Because of the way things like this are reported, the minute people see
'Ukrainian' they think we're all anti-Semitic, and that's certainly not true,''
said Alexandra Shwed, president of the Ukrainian Anti-Defamation League here.

'Community Is Intimidated'

''No one would say that among the Ukrainians there were no criminals, just as no
nation is criminal-free,'' said Dr. Peter Stercho, an economics professor at
Drexel University and president of the Philadelphia chapter of the Ukrainian
Congress Committee. ''But the Ukrainian community is intimidated. They feel
prejudged already.''

Allan A. Ryan Jr., director of the Justice Department's special unit, said he
had received protests from national Ukrainian-American organizations contending,
among other things, that videotapes of Soviet nationals used at the trial were
engineered by Moscow to stir animosity between Jews and Ukrainians.

Mr. Ryan said he believed that the tension last week was ''not nearly as high''
as at the Osidach trial, in part because of peacemaking efforts by leaders of
the two communities.

A joint statement was issued recognizing that both groups had suffered
persecution at the hands of the Nazis, and Jewish leaders, including Rabbi Mark
Tanenbaum of the American Jewish Committee, met with the new Metropolitan of the
Ukrainian Church in America, Stephan Sulyk, who is based in Philadelphia.

33 HAITIANS DROWN AS BOAT CAPSIZES OFF FLORIDA

BYLINE: By GREGORY JAYNES, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 689 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, Oct. 26


Thirty-three Haitians drowned this morning in choppy waters just north of here
after their jerry-built 30-foot boat capsized less than a mile from shore.
Thirty-four others from the overloaded vessel swam to shore and were taken, many
of them in tears, to a Federal detention facility for illegal aliens.

Immigration authorities said it was the worst such accident recorded since waves
of immigrants from the impoverished Caribbean country began heading for the
United States 10 years ago. Gov. Bob Graham of Florida called it ''a human
tragedy which has been waiting to happen,'' and said he would press the Federal
Government to work with Haiti to stop the flight to these shores.

Two months ago the Reagan Administration ordered the Coast Guard to interdict
Haitian boats loaded with illegal aliens on the high seas and return them to
Port-au-Prince, the Haitian capital. The first interdiction came last night, 123
miles northwest of Port-au-Prince, when the cutter Chase intercepted a leaky
30-foot boat filled with 57 passengers.

2d Boat Sinks After Transfer

That boat, too, sank in rough seas shortly after the Haitians were transferred
to the Chase. It was the first seizure of Haitians the Coast Guard had made
since it began patrolling the Windward Passage off Haiti's northwest coast on
Oct. 11.

In Miami, a Coast Guard spokesman said of the drownings, ''It's just such a
tragedy,'' adding, ''It's what we were hoping to avoid'' by intercepting
vessels.

The boat apparently struck a reef and split apart in a four-foot chop before
dawn today. As the lights began to go off from the expensive condominiums along
Highway A1A in Hillsboro Beach, a Broward County village 10 miles north of Fort
Lauderdale, the bodies began to wash ashore.

19 Men and 14 Women

By midday, rescue workers had recovered the bodies of 19 men and 14 women, one
of whom was pregnant. The surf had ripped the clothes off many of them.

(Autopsies indicated that the victims had been loaded into their small boat from
a mother ship about an hour before they died because they had eaten a variety of
refrigerated, ship-type meals, according to an Associate Press telephone
interview with Dr. Ronald K. Wright, the Broward County medical examiner.

(The Authorities have in the past expressed suspicion that some wooden sailboats
filled with refugees were dropped off by freighters not far from land. Police
Chief Ralph Dunn noted that refugee boats were usually waterproofed on the
inside with pitch, but said that this boat frame ws coated only with mud,
possibly indicating that it was not intended for a long journey.)

Sgt. Daniel Hynes of the Hillsboro police said that survivors had said that the
boat's captain, identified as Charles Joseph, and three mates had made it to
shore and fled.

Leonard E. Rowland, a spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service,
said the survivors had told the authorities that they left Haiti Aug. 26 and
spent a month ''bouncing around'' the Bahamas. Their last landfall was an
unidentified Bahama island on Oct. 18, according to Mr. Rowland.

Residents concerned about crime and low-paid workers fearful that job-hungry
immigrants could be a threat have been stridently vocal about stopping the tide,
but this morning the word from most quarters was sympathy.

''It is a human tragedy,'' Governor Graham emphasized, adding at one point that
''probably this has already happened and went undetected.''

The bodies were taken to the Broward County morgue. A spokesman for the Medical
Examiner's Office there said that autopsies would be performed and that attempts
would be made to identify them. ''Then,'' said the spokesman, ''the bodies will
have to be disposed of in some respectable and tasteful fashion.

56 Haitians Returned Home

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 26 (AP) - Fifty-six Haitians were returned here
today aboard the Coast Guard cutter Chase, which picked them up 75 miles
northwest of Cuba a few minutes before their boat capsized, the Coast Guard
said.

BODIES OF DROWNED HAITIANS TO GO BACK TO ISLAND

BYLINE: By GREGORY JAYNES, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 12, Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 1300 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, Oct. 29


The local Haitian community wants the 33 immigrants who drowned off Florida's
shore to be buried here, but the State Department and the Government of Haiti
have decided to bury them on the island they were trying to escape. The decision
has deeply upset the Haitians in Miami, and a coroner caught in the middle is
beside himself with rage.

Tonight, Anita Stockman of the State Department said that a Haitian airline is
to pick up the bodies at the morgue on Homestead Air Force Base and fly them
back to Haiti, although she was not sure when. She said that the department got
in touch with the Haitian Government after learning of the drownings and that it
was agreed that the dead would be returned to their families in Haiti for
burial.

The Broward County Medical Examiner, Ronald Wright, said in an interview today
that he was called yesterday by Howard Davis, the State Department desk officer
for Haitian affairs. ''He said to me,'' Dr. Wright said, ''that international
protocol was such that the State Department was required to notify the foreign
government when foreign nationals die within the United States.

''I said, 'Gee, that's amazing. How come I haven't heard from you guys before?'
He had no answer.''

Issue of Next of Kin Raised

Dr. Wright said that he had dealt with groups of 30 or more Haitian bodies in
the last two years, and ''nobody has ever been interested.  We haven't seen any
enthusiasm on the part of the State Department before. He said, 'We think that
they will want to take them back.' I said, 'Wait, some of them have next of kin
here.' He said, 'Well, that's just alleged.' ''

By 7:30 last night, Dr. Wright had a telegram from the State Department
directing him to surrender custody of the bodies to the Haitian consulate here.
By 8:30 P.M., word of the decision reached a poverty-ridden section of north
Miami known as Little Haiti. The area is on the southern rim of the black ghetto
known as Liberty City.

In Little Haiti, several hundred Haitians blocked a city street in protest. The
police let the demonstration proceed. There was no destruction.

Haitian Leaders Speculate

This morning in the Haitian community of about 20,000 people, leaders said that
they felt the decision to move the bodies was made to avoid calling national
attention to a funeral for illegal immigrants whom the Federal Government is at
present turning back on the high seas or holding in detention facilities around
the country.

Steve Forrester, an attorney who has been representing Haitians in deportation
hearings here, said that he thought ''the motive here is to prevent the natural
outpouring of emotion and grief and sympathy that would come from any kind of
community funeral.''

The State Department issued an announcement this morning which said, in part:
''The Haitian Government delivered a diplomatic message formally requesting
permission to repatriate the deceased Haitians at Haitian Government expense so
that the victims of this tragic event could be interred with dignity by their
next of kin at home. Under the circumstances this appears to be a generous
humanitarian request.''

Washington Officials Criticized

Dr. Wright, who said he was in touch with Mr. Davis today, said, ''As I view it,
the Federal Government engineered the removal of these bodies back to Haiti, and
when they recognized that that was sort of politically unacceptable, they
immediately began to backtrack and shirk their responsibility. They are
shouldering it back to local government.''

He added that Mr. Davis ''hung up on me the last time. At 2:55 P.M. I believe
he's sweating blood.'' Since Monday, when the Haitians' boat capsized off the
little resort village of Hillsboro Beach, Fla., the 33 bodies have been kept in
a 48-foot refrigerated truck that Dr. Wright rented. Thirty-four others
survived, including a captain and three mates who disappeared.

The other 30 in the Haitian group were taken to a Federal detention facility for
illegal aliens. They were interrogated there by representatives of several
Federal agencies trying to determine what happened or whether the group was
smuggled here aboard a freighter, then put out in dangerous waters. A Haitian
freighter was seized at Fort Pierce, Fla., last night, but law enforcement
authorities said today that the vessel appeared to have no connection with the
drownings.

Bodies to Be Flown to Haiti

Though the Broward County medical examiner said that he thought the decision to
return the bodies was about to be reversed, Haiti's Ambassador to the United
States, Georges Leger, said in an interview late in the day that he understood a
chartered Air Haiti plane would take the bodies back in 12 to 24 hours.

The Ambassador said: ''They left Haiti seeking improvements in their conditions.
They most probably were victimized by smugglers, and they died unnecessarily. So
we feel that the least our Government could do would be to return them home
where we want all our citizens to be. They are all welcome.''

He added, ''We felt we just could not morally leave them without giving them a
place where they could rest in peace.''

Refugee Center Director Objects

In Miami, where several of the dead have relatives, the mother of a pregnant
girl who drowned told representatives at the Haitian Refugee Center Inc., one of
the agencies working for Haitian rights, that she ''would prefer that they shoot
her rather than let the body go back to Haiti.'' The Rev. Gerard Jean-Juste, the
center director, said, ''The relatives have been here mourning, crying - shocked
that the Government is working with Haiti to steal the bodies.''

In Broward County, Dr. Wright said that with the aid of the survivors he had
identified all the bodies, but that relatives of only 20 percent had come
forward to claim them.

In Dade County, the medical examiner, Joseph H. Davis, said he could not recall
how many Haitian bodies he had examined in the last few years. He explained that
''the tragedy is that many do have relatives here.

''But the relatives themselves are illegal aliens and they are torn between the
desire to take the bodies and to protect themselves,'' he went on. ''We have a
Haitian working with us, and when we have a body come in, the word somehow gets
around and a funeral director comes and picks up the body.''

''Relatives don't have to come in,'' he added. ''So we get rid of a body and the
relative remains unidentified and the body is properly buried.''

18 Funeral Directors Volunteer

That apparently would have been the case in Saturday's scheduled mass burial.
Eighteen funeral directors had volunteered their services, and churches, refugee
agencies and Broward County officials planned to underwrite the cost of the
burials. ''You must realize we had a plan completely worked out here,'' said Dr.
Wright

The State Department, he said, ''screwed it all up.'' ''It is as far as I'm
concerned one of the biggest messes I've ever been involved in,'' he continued.
''And they want us to come back and pick up the pieces and damn it I am tired of
doing that sort of thing for the Federal Government.

''I can drive an 18-wheeler,'' he said, referring to the refrigerated truck
holding the bodies. ''If it were up to me alone, I would drive it right this
minute to Homestead Air Force Base and park it and let them for once try to
clean up one of the messes they've created.''

               November 2, 1981, Monday, Late City Final Edition

AUSTRALIA, UNDER NEW POLICY, IS SEEKING SKILLED AMERICANS

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 10, Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 479 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30


Australia, under a new immigration policy due to go into effect next April, is
actively seeking more Americans with business and technical skills.

Advertisements had already begun to appear in the American press, drawing
attention to opportunities in Australia, before the announcement in Canberra of
the new national policy. The Australian Embassy in Washington has been sending
out newsletters to prospective immigrants for the last nine months, according to
Wayne R. Slater, the embassy's Counselor for Immigration.

Australia's new policy will limit immigration to people who have at least one of
three requirements: close family ties in Australia, a skill that will benefit
the country or the experience and assests to start a ''viable business
venture.''

Problem of Unemployment

Australia has faced increasing unemployment among the unskilled, Mr. Slater
said, and the new policy in part reflects public pressure to limit the entry of
people in unskilled categories.

According to Mr. Slater, the immigration policy is in line with the Government's
plans to increase population in the country, which has 15 million people in a
territory the size of the United States.  In the last Australian fiscal year,
ending June 30, 3,236 North Americans - from Canada and the United States
-immigrated to Australia, a 29 percent increase over the previous year.

In the same year, 25,000 Asians entered Australia, most of them Indochinese
refugees. According to Mr. Slater, one in every 305 Australians is ethnically
Indochinese. Australians say that the new plan will not alter the country's
policy of helping refugees, nor will it be racially discriminatory.

''The pattern of immigration has changed over the years,'' Mr.  Slater said.
''In the 50's they came from Northern Europe. Then the source began to move
toward Southern Europe, the Middle East and, more recently, Asia.''

More Britons Immigrating

''Now we see a return to European migration,'' Mr. Slater said.  Last year
31,600 Britons, faced with a declining economy, went to Australia, an increase
of 93 percent over the previous year.

Mr. Slater said that there were about 32,000 American-born Australians, many of
them successful in business and one of them a member of the state parliament in
Tasmania.

''Americans first ask themselves, 'Is there another place to live?' '' Mr.
Slater said. ''Then they see in us a free and open society, no poverty, an easy
living style. They look at Australia as a place where they will probably get
individual rewards for their contributions. Many of them come for environmental
or social reasons.

''There is more similarity between Australians and Americans, I think,'' Mr.
Slater said, ''than between any other two groups.''

              November 12, 1981, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

ARGENTINES FLOCK ABROAD AS DREAMS OF RICHES DIE

BYLINE: By EDWARD SCHUMACHER, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 2, Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1107 words

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 11


It was the promised land in South America, and for more than a century
immigrants from Europe flowed here just as they did to the United States.

But because of economic turmoil and political uncertainty, Argentina is today
losing people, with emigration draining the country of skilled workers,
technicians and professionals.

American officials report that immigration inquiries have risen 50 percent in
recent months to more than 200 a week. Inquiries about Canada, a new mecca for
Argentines, have increased by five times in just a year to a similar level,
Canadian officials said. The Spanish, Italian, Australian and Brazilian
embassies report that immigration applications are up dramatically, too.

Many simply leave on tourist visas, hoping to find work and join - legally or
illegally - the more than two million Argentines already living abroad.

A Search for Security

Almost all those seeking to leave are of European stock, and the failed promise
for many is seen in a family like the Bossos. The father is a second-generation
Italian; the mother came from southern Italy 25 years ago to marry him.

Recently, the oldest son, 19-year old Jorge Oscar Bosso, a hair stylist in a
poular salon here, boarded a plane for Milan, Italy, hoping to find security for
his own family.

''I suffer as a young person,'' he said at a small going-away party in the
modest family home, ''because it is such a rich country going nowhere.''

Argentina's problems have been festering for 40 years. Only one elected
government has finished its term in that time and there have been more than 30
economic ministers and a continual flip-flop of policies.

Argentina Falls Behind

Argentina once surpassed Australia in income and development and until World War
II was roughly equal to Canada. Today, it is far behind both despite similar
resources and size.

The common refrain here, despite the stagnation, was ''there is food,''
especially the thick steaks, crunchy French bread and mixed salads that are a
staple in a country that is one of the world's leading exporters of meat and
grains.

The refrain has a caustic ring now. The balloon of an overheated economy burst
early this year. Inflation is running at more than 100 percent; the peso is
worth less than one-fourth what it was in dollars at the beginning of the year,
and unemployment has risen to between 600,000 and 1.5 million people, depending
on who is doing the figuring.

After almost six years of military rule, the Government of President Roberto
Eduardo Viola is shaky as rumors persist of plots within the military and
civilian politicians clamor ever more loudly for elections, raising the
likelihood of a confrontation.

Nation Called Neurotic

Argentines have emigrated before, but mostly during revolutions.  Emigration
experts here say the present exodus is different and the largest yet.

''Now they are emigrating for physical subsistence,'' said Alberto Bonis, a
sociologist. ''The country has become neurotic, frightened by reality and
fearing the ghost of unemployment.''

Colleen Cupples, the Canadian consul, said the people trying to leave
''represent the entire range of Argentine society, from the lowliest baker to
the person who owns his own business''.

They include people like Miguel Angel Barboza, a cabinetmaker who has been
trying to place ''work wanted'' advertisements in New York City newspapers so he
can take his wife and three sons there. After working all day here, he teaches
at a technical school two hours away at night, arriving home at 1 A.M.

''I have labored all my life and have not progressed,'' he said.

Technical Jobs Are Few

They also include people like Oscar Ricardo Pons, a 27-year-old unmarried
electrical engineer who last week obtained a Canadian residence visa. He works
in a management job here because there is a shortage of the sort of technical
jobs and advanced training he wants. ''All engineers want to build and
develop,'' he said.

Professionals are among the hardest hit. Ten percent of the registered doctors
are reportedly not practicing. Of 50,000 registered engineers, 10,000 are out of
the country and 8 percent of those remaining are unemployed, according to the
Center of Argentine Engineers.

The Committee to Stimulate Argentine University Graduates and Students Abroad, a
private body that works with the Government to attract its citizens back, says
almost half of the expatriates are trained technicians or university educated.

''Its a great hurt to the country,'' Moises Margulis, president of the
committee, said. ''We cannot offer the work to keep them here.'' Yet Argentina
has one-third the land mass of the United States and only a little more than
one-tenth the people. Forty percent of the population lives in metropolitan
Buenos Aires. The country's history is one of huge empty spaces going
undeveloped.

Where the Emigrants Go

Tierra del Fuego in the far south abounds with fish and offshore oil. Natural
gas underlies the vast semiarid plains of Patagonia.  The Andes mountains that
line the western border are filled with barely tapped minerals.

Where have the Argentines gone? According to the advisory committee, some
800,000, or more than one third of the those who have left. are in the United
States. Spain follows with 270,000 and Canada with 200,000.

The United States is particularly attractive to professionals, whose skills can
get them by tough United States immigration quotas.  Among the 10,000 Argentine
professionals who arrived at New York City airports from 1968 to 1978, according
to a study by the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service, were
almost 1,500 doctors, some 1,400 engineers, and 400 chemists, biologists,
geologists and physicists. The rest included professors, accountants, lawyers,
architects and the like.

Paris is a haven for many of the country's writers, painters, dancers and
musicians, many of whom have been very successful there.  Many of the elderly go
to Spain, where they enjoy a common language and through reciprocal agreements
can receive their government retirement benefits.

For Nina Bosso it was a sad time as she served wine and sandwiches to her son's
close friends four hours before he was to fly to Italy.  But she understood, she
said. ''He's young, and he has to go forward.''

Theater Piece Studies Children of Immigrants

SECTION: Section C; Page 19, Column 2; Cultural Desk

LENGTH: 175 words


Howard Da Silva, Pearl Lang, Rita Karin, Eve Merriam, Joseph Papp, Zvee Scooler
and the Klemzer ensemble, Kapelye and others will participate in a theatrical
exploration of the lives of the children of Jewish immigrants in a bilingual
performance called ''Children in a New Land.''

Sponsored by YIVO, the Institute for Jewish Research, the theater anthology will
use literary and theatrical genres in Yiddish and English from modernist poetry
to folk and theater music of the first third of this century.

The program will be presented twice. The first performance will be today at the
Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street. The second will be tomorrow at the
Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street. Both performances will begin at 8 P.M.

A benefit for the institute, the program was assembled and staged by Isaiah
Sheffer and will come at the end of a YIVO conference on ''Children of
Immigrants: Second Generation Jews in New York.'' Tickets are $10. For
information, call 582-4240.

A Plea to Stay in the United States

VIENNA TRAIN TAKES POLES TO NEW LIFE

BYLINE: By NINA DARNTON, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 3, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1019 words

DATELINE: WARSAW, Dec. 3


The Chopin Express leaves for Vienna every day at 5:56 P.M., and, the conductor
says, it is ''usually full in one direction - going.''

Poles do not need visas to travel to Austria and the train is the main form of
transportation there, carrying a large number of the 25,000 Poles who have
already asked for asylum in Austria this year and the other 25,000 thought to be
staying as tourists.

Since new liberal passport regulations went into effect eight months ago, many
people take the night train to Vienna, see what possibilities are available for
work and return only if they have to.

The train is particularly crowded on Mondays, the conductor said, adding,
''That's a good day to begin a new life.'' Warsaw officials, however, have
become alarmed at the growing rate of emigration as Poland's economic crisis
deepens, and the statecontrolled television ran a program here a few weeks ago
aimed at stopping the flow. It backfired.

Difficult Life Described

The program showed a refugee camp in Vienna. Although the members of the Polish
television crew were not allowed inside the camp, they stood at the entrance and
interviewed many of the residents as they went in and out.

Those interviewed spoke of how difficult life was for immigrants.  One woman
told the reporter that she had decided to return to Poland, complaining of
cramped sleeping quarters and boredom, of having nothing to do but drink beer
and eat sandwiches.

But after the program was shown, a Polish journalist said, many Polish shoppers
standing on lines for meat were talking about the report, about how people in
the Vienna camp had beer and meat and ate sandwiches and how ''life there
doesn't sound so bad.'' And Tuesday 360 Poles, a record, arrived in Vienna.

The people waiting the other day for The Chopin Express to pull into the
northern Warsaw station, however, were leaving not only because of economic
hardships. Many of the complaints were about the system itself, and most of
those interviewed said they were leaving now simply because it was the easiest
time to get a passport.

'I Don't Want Any Trouble'

The wind was chilling on the railway platform, and one 23-year-old car mechanic
stood with his back to it, hunched over for warmth. He said he was going for two
or three weeks to arrange for a good job and ''to make it and stay forever.''

''But if I don't,'' he said, ''if something goes wrong and I have to come back,
I don't want any trouble.'' He dreams of moving to Australia or New Zealand, he
said, because it is far away, ''a great democracy'' and ''a beautiful stable
country.'' He said he was ''leaving because of the political situation'' in
Poland and would come back only ''if the Government changes.''

There was no one to see him off. His mother is dead and his father works the
night shift in a factory and could not come. ''But he's glad I'm going,'' the
son said. ''He's too old to make it anywhere else. He's glad I have a chance.''

One man in his early 20's boarded the train with his wife as soon as it arrived,
and they sat in silence, holding hands in a secondclass compartment. She is 19,
and they had been married for six months.

Athlete Seeks to Leave

''I'm sorry, I don't want to talk,'' he said to a reporter. ''I am going far
away, and I hope my wife will join me later.'' In the corridor stood a man of 21
who said he was a broad jumper.  ''I want to go to the West because I am good,''
he said, ''and I want to be better.'' He said he did not want to waste his life
in Poland, where, because of ''the hard life, the politics, you can't excel in
anything.''

Noting that his parents, both 55, could not accompany him, he said, ''But when
you are young you have a chance, and now that I can get a passport I am taking
it.''

Most of the travelers held tourist visas, although dozens of those spoken to
said they were hoping to stay abroad. The Polish Government makes official
emigration difficult, so many emigrants find it easier to apply only for tourist
visas.

The West German Embassy issued 160 percent more three-month tourist visas for
the period from January to October this year than it did last year. In the
summer it issued about 2,000 visas a day.

Many Work Illegally

''We know,'' one diplomat said, ''that most of these so-called tourists work
illegally when they get there.'' Pointing out that the black market rate for the
West German mark ''is now 200 to 1,'' he said, ''If a Pole makes 2,000 marks in
one month, he can live in Poland for a year on his earnings.''

About twice as many Poles as last year have asked about emigration to the United
States, Canada and Australia or have applied for visas.  Those Poles who go to
Vienna and apply for refugee status wait to be accepted by other countries. But
many diplomats here asserted that the Austrians, out of humanitarian
considerations, were bending the definition of a refugee in order to accept the
Poles in that category.

''Strictly speaking,'' said one diplomat, ''a refugee is supposed to be someone
who has reason to believe that he will be persecuted for political or religious
reasons if he returns to his own country.  That is not the case in Poland
today.''

He said these were ''really economic refugees, and if we were to take people
because of economic reasons we would have all the starving people in Africa and
India to think of first.''

Diplomats report that many of those applying for visas are people with varying
degrees of technical expertise -auto mechanics, electronics engineers, computer
scientists, doctors.

This might represent a serious drain for Poland, and the Polish Government is
not unaware of the danger. The Government recently issued an appeal to Poles
already living abroad to return and help in the country's ''renewal.''

MEXICAN BORDER AGENTS WARNED OF ASSASSIN TEAMS

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 13, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 685 words

DATELINE: SAN YSIDRO, Calif., Dec. 10


The Immigration and Naturalization Service has told border agents to be on the
lookout for two assassination squads from Libya, including one headed by the
notorious international terrorist known as Carlos and dubbed ''the Jackal'' by
the British press.

A seven-page notice, posted in the employees' lunchroom at the nation's busiest
border-crossing point on the Mexican border south of San Diego, alerts agents to
watch for squads of terrorists reportedly dispatched by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi,
the Libyan leader, to assassinate President Reagan and other senior officials in
the Administration.

The document, dated Dec. 6, warns that two ''hit'' teams ''may attempt to enter
the United States illegally with the help of established smugglers familiar with
the U.S.-Mexican border.''

The notice says the hit squad reportedly headed by Carlos consists of three
Syrians and three Libyans. It also says a second group consists of two Iranians,
a Palestinian, a Lebanese and an East German.

The notice, issued by the Washington headquarters of the Immigration and
Naturalization Service, says that Carlos, a 32-yearold Venezuelan whose real
name is Illich Ramirez Sanchez, is believed to be traveling on a Lebanese
passport under an assumed name.

Similar Notice on Clipboard

A border control agent in Nogales, Ariz., said a similar notice had been put on
a clipboard available only to employees at the crossing there. The agent, who
declined to be identified, said the notice was posted either Wednesday or today.

It could not be immediately determined if the notice was posted at other
stations on the Mexican border or at any other entry points.  James O'Keefe,
district director of Immigration in San Diego, said today that the border
crossing was ''operating normally.'' He and inspectors at the border declined
further comment, referring questions to Washington.

Reporters were refused admission to the facility today, but no extraordinary
precautions could be observed at the entry point, where about 40 million
crossings into the United States are made every year.

In Washington, Vernon Jervis, spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization
Service, refused to discuss any aspect of the document.

''It's a matter that's extremely sensitive, involving national security,'' Mr.
Jervis said.  The notice includes a reproduction of a Royal Canadian Mounted
Police poster of Carlos that describes him as a heavyset man who is 5 feet 9
inches tall with thick brown, curly hair and ''skilled at changing appearance
and identity.''

Beginning in August 1970, when he underwent commando training in Jordan, Carlos
has devoted most of his energies to killing for the Palestinian cause. He is
wanted in connection with the slaying of Israeli athletes at the Olympic games
in Munich in 1972, the shooting of Edward Sieff, a British Zionist, in 1973, the
kidnapping of 11 oil ministers attending the OPEC conference in Vienna in 1975
and the assassination of Ramon Trabal, a Uruguayan military attache.

Members of Teams Named

The notice listed Hasan Al-Khayer, Ali Ahmed and Walid Abdul Rahman as Syrian
nationals who are members of the assassination team, and Omar or Umar Ayad and
Ali Saghayer as Libyan nationals. It also listed a man variously named Mohamed
or Milad Muhammad el-Hadi or Hadi, also known as Milad Muhammad Hadi or
Muhamammd Ibraham Al-Hadi on that team.

A second team included Ahmed Jooma, also known as Ahmad Juma or Abase Said or
Ahmed Husayn Juma, an Iranian, about 25; Luitz Schewesman, an East German, about
50; Ahmat Abass, or Ahmed Abbas or Mouses Abou Mahmoud, a Palestianian, about
35; Ibrahim El Haya, an Iranian, about 36 and also known as Ibrahim El-Haya,
Ibraham ElHaya, Ibrahim Al-Haya, Ibrahim Al Haya, Ali Ben Ali, Ali Ben-Ali; and
Ali Chafio, a Lebanese, about 35.

              December 15, 1981, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

A BIG WEEKEND FOR ANTELOPE WELLS, N.M., POP. 2

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 22, Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 647 words

DATELINE: ANTELOPE WELLS, N.M., Dec. 13


Normally, Antelope Wells, perhaps the most remote port of entry in the United
States, has two residents. Each has a trailer behind the customs station and is
employed by the Government to enforce trade and immigration regulations. The
number of people entering here averages fewer than three a day.

For the last two days, however, Antelope Wells has been alive with ranchers,
truck drivers, ranch hands, brokers, buyers and sellers, inspectors from the
United States Department of Agriculture, vaqueros, or cowboys, and, more than
likely, a few crooks.

They came to assure safe passage of 1,221 cattle from ranches in Chihuahua,
Mexico's largest cattle-raising state, to the United States.

Before sunrise, Mexican ranch hands, who camped out in bedrolls next to
all-night fires a hundred yards south of the border, started their day with
freshly brewed coffee.

Cattle Owner Flies In

The workers arrived throughout the night after a two-hour truck ride in the
Sierra de Medio mountains. The trucks brought cattle from the ranch of Hilario
Gabilondo. Mr. Gabilondo arrived at daybreak, landing his plane in a nearby
field after the five-minute flight from his ranch.

Mr. Gabilondo's cattle, from 7 to 10 months old, were held in corrals in Mexico,
then sent single file through wooden chutes leading to a concrete shed. There,
Douglas Woody, a veterinarian of the Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service,
Department of Agriculture, and his crew felt each calf. They were looking for
ticks, scabs, lumpjaw, ringworm, warts or abcesses and verifying that each
animal had been neutered.

The few who failed inspection were sprayed on the forehead with red paint and
sent back to the Gabilondo ranch. A numbered metal strip was stapled onto the
right ear of those who passed.

The entire procedure was carefully watched by Mr. Gabilondo, who is an adviser
on livestock affairs to Mexico's President, Jose Lopez Portillo. This year, he
said, Mexican ranchers will ship less than half of their 400,000-head quota for
export to the United States because cattle now command a better price in Mexico.
He said that the American cattle industry ''is in a down market. It runs in
nine-year cycles and, barring a depression, it will begin its upturn in a year
or two.''

After weighing, the cattle were corraled, then placed in a narrow vat to be
submerged in a milky tick dip. When dry, they were sent to corrals on the other
side of the line.

''Well, they're United States citizens now,'' Mr. Gabilondo observed as the last
of his 757 calves crossed. The cattle, averaging 430 pounds, would probably be
slaughtered in a couple of years when they weigh 1,000 pounds.

The 100,000-acre Gabilondo spread is divided among four family members to
conform with land-ownership laws, according to Jose Luis Gabilondo, the
rancher's 26-year-old son.

Even when the land was known as New Spain, cattle drives crossed the area,
according to the elder Mr. Gabilondo.  Shortly after their cattle crossed, the
two Gabilondos flew off.  Just after that came Scott R. Dean, a cattle broker
from the Paul Dean Cattle Company in El Paso and Brad Tate, a Lakeland, Kan.,
rancher who was purchasing the Gabilondo cattle.

Mr. Dean paid from 80 to 90 cents a pound for the herd of 325,928 pounds. The
Customs Service collected duty of one and one-half cents a pound.

After nightfall, another herd arrived from the Villanueva Ranch, 17 miles to the
east. The 464 animals, weighing 193,366 pounds, went through the same procedure
as the Gabilondo cattle. By mid-afternoon, Antelope Wells settled back into the
tempo it maintains the other 363 days a year.

IMMIGRATION SERVICE SAYS OVER 100 FLED FROM HAITIAN CAMP

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section B; Page 8, Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 571 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, Dec. 28


The Federal authorities barred all visitors from a Miami detention facility
holding Haitian refugees today and brought in additional security guards after a
stone-@ and bottle-throwing incident yesterday in which 110 men escaped from the
compound.

There were about 660 men in the camp before the escapes. They began a hunger
strike Christmas Eve, fasting for their freedom, according to leaders of Miami's
Haitian community. The 51 women at the facility joined the fast Sunday, the
authorities said.

Doctors at the camp reported this afternoon that the Haitians were ''still
extremely healthy at this point,'' said Beverly McFarland, a spokesman for the
Immigration and Naturalization Service. She said the medical staff was
''monitoring the situation very carefully,'' as the refugees continued to take
only water.

On Sunday afternoon, about 300 Miami-area Haitian residents stormed a gate at
the facility, called Krome North, hurling stones and bottles, according to Miss
McFarland, and immigration service guards responded with tear gas to disperse
the crowd.

First Incident With Outsiders

There have been similar incidents at Krome, Miss McFarland said, but this was
the first confrontation between guards and outsiders.  She said none of the
Haitians inside the camp took part in the disturbance, and that she knew of no
injuries. Those who escaped during the demonstration climbed over a rear fence
topped by barbed wire.

Miss McFarland said security personnel were searching the tall sawgrass in the
immediate area around the camp, which is in a remote section of Dade County
south of Miami near the Everglades. She said there were no plans to widen the
search.

The Dade County police arrived after most of the demonstrators had fled, and
they arrested one man on charges of arson and eight other persons for unlawful
assembly.

Miss McFarland said she did not know how many security guards were on duty when
the disturbance occurred or how many were added afterward, only that ''we called
in all available personnel.''

The immigration service said there was ''no identifiable leader'' of the
demonstration. The Rev. Gerard Jean-Juste, executive director of the Haitian
Refugee Center Inc., said the disturbance had not been planned, but that it
began after the demonstrators heard reports that some of the detainees had
fainted from hunger. The reports were denied by the immigration service.

Brief Disturbance at Ft. Chaffee

FORT CHAFFEE, Ark., Dec. 28 (AP) - A dispute among a small group of Cuban
refugees lead to a brief confrontation Sunday between refugees and Federal
officers at the resettlement center here, an official said today.

The disturbance ended in the arrests of three refugees, a woman, one of the men
in the dispute and another man who said he had mediated the argument.

''The heated argument, to the best of my knowledge, started over the affection
of a female refugee,'' said Gunther Wagner, deputy director of the Cuban-Haitian
Task Force at Fort Chaffee. He said no charges were filed.

Sunday night 15 to 25 refugees, protested the arrests, but the center was calm
today, the authorities said.  The 400 people held at Fort Chaffee are all that
remain to be resettled of the thousands of Cuban refugees who came to the United
States in April of last year.

                 June 6, 1980, Friday, Late City Final Edition

GRAND JURY TO REVIEW CASE OF FEDERAL AGENT KILLED WITH OWN GUN

SECTION: Section B; Page 3, Column 4; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 332 words


A 21-year-old Brooklyn man was charged yesterday with criminally negligent
homicide in the fatal shooting of an off-duty Immigration and Naturalization
Service officer. The police said they believed the shooting was a tragic
accident involving friends but that the case would be presented to a grand jury.

Investigators said the Federal officer, Joseph Aiello Jr., 26, of 1542 East 27th
Street, Brooklyn, had taken two friends from Brooklyn for a ride in his car
Wednesday night. They were identified as Charles Shand of 1110 Avenue O, who was
charged in the shooting, and Kenneth Rowletter, 17, of 1477 East 12th Street.

About 9:30 P.M., Mr. Aiello stopped the car at Ocean Avenue and Avenue P to
check a noise toward the rear of the automobile. He asked Mr. Rowletter, who was
sitting in the front, to hand him some tools from the glove compartment, the
police said. Mr. Shand saw that the compartment also contained a .38-caliber
revolver, which Mr. Aiello used on guard duty at the immigration detention
center at 136 Flushing Avenue in Brooklyn.

Gun Was Being Passed

At that point, Mr. Aiello was standing outside the car and Mr.  Shand was
sitting in the rear of the automobile. According to the police, Mr. Shand asked
Mr. Rowletter to pass him the gun. While Mr.  Shand was handling the gun, it
discharged, firing one bullet, which hit Mr. Aiello in the head, the police
said.

The Federal officer collapsed in the street, and was later pronounced dead at
Kings County Hospital. Police Officers Robert Chille and Angelo Grande, of the
Coney Island precinct, responded to an emergency call. Officer Chille said that
Mr. Shand had told them he did not realize the gun was loaded.

''My partner and I spoke to the parents of the deceased, and they don't believe
he knew it was loaded, either,'' Officer Chille said.  The charge of criminally
negligent homicide carries a maximum penalty of four years' imprisonment. A
grand jury will begin hearing evidence in the case today.

                 June 8, 1980, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

PENALTY UNLIKELY IN HOAX OF ALIENS

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

SECTION: Section 11; Connecticut; Page 1, Column 5; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1241 words


A MAN indicted last year on a charge of helping Poles enter the United States
illegally and obtain work and Social Security cards is likely to escape
prosecution on the ground of mental incompetence, according to Federal
prosecutors and psychiatric reports. The officials said the possible
incompetence was demonstrated in part by his repeated assertions that he was
working for the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Central Intelligence
Agency.

The man is Alexander Gorski, 43 years old, the proprietor of a travel agency in
Newington. He was indicted by a Federal grand jury in New Haven last August on
charges of conspiracy, making false statements to Federal agents, harboring and
shielding illegal aliens, inducing the illegal entry of aliens, and mail fraud.
Prosecutors said he had fraudulently obtained 90 Social Security cards and sold
them to aliens.

He has also been accused, in sworn depositions, of selling jobs to newly arrived
Poles, and pretending to be a lawyer and representing them before Immigration
and Naturalization Service proceedings, often inadequately, for large amounts of
money. The allegations go back to at least 1975.

Seven Federal agencies have investigated Mr. Gorski for two years, and two of
the agencies, the former Department of Health, Education and Welfare and the
immigration service, sent two investigators to Poland for three weeks last year
to seek information.

The superintendent of Fairfield Hills Hospital, a state mental institution in
Newtown, concluded after a Dec. 18 examination of Mr.  Gorski that ''there was
no impairment of intellect - when asked about the events leading to his present
plight he gave a poorly constructed story to indicate that he was acting in
behalf of the C.I.A. and F.B.I.''

The superintendent, Dr. Robert B. Miller, a psychiatrist, said Mr.  Gorski had
also asserted he was a ''double agent.'' He added that Mr. Gorski's ''insight
and judgment are within normal limits.''

But Mr. Gorski, who has been admitted to mental hospitals on several previous
occasions, was hospitalized again after that examination, following which Dr.
Miller said that ''Mr. Gorski's paranoid ideation is more florid.'' After the
later examination the doctor said: ''Mr. Gorski lacked substantial capacity by
reason of mental disease (schizophrenia, paranoid type) to advise counsel and to
participate in his own defense.''

As a result, the United States Attorney in Connecticut, Richard Blumenthal, has
recommended a ''pretrial diversion program, which would result in a status of,
in effect, conditional probation, with one of the conditions being that he cease
the practices that are the basis for the pending charges.'' Mr. Blumenthal would
not describe the other conditions.

According to court papers, Mr. Gorski is still under psychiatric care.  With two
psychiatrists finding Mr. Gorski unable to stand trial, and none dissenting, the
likely outcome, according to several sources, is that the prosecution and
defense will agree to a course of mental treatment for Mr. Gorski, and that the
court will sanction this course of action.

Investigators for several of the agencies, which include the Internal Revenue
Service, the Postal Service, the Secret Service, the F.B.I. and the Social
Security Administration, declined comment on the matter because it is still
before a Federal judge, T. F. Gilroy Daly.

The investigation has produced bitterness outside the Government.  ''This guy is
laughing at us,'' said Ryszard S. Mrotek, a Hartford lawyer of Polish origin who
has gathered evidence from aliens allegedly defrauded by Mr. Gorski and given it
to prosecutors. ''He always said he had friends in high places who would protect
him,'' Mr. Mrotek said.

He said Mr. Gorski had boasted to clients that he was immune from prosecution
because ''I have what is called in Polish, crazy papers.''

Mr. Mrotek is also angered because, although the indictment charges violations
of Federal law, it does not directly refer to charges that Mr. Gorski preyed on
aliens.

For example, the court file includes a deposition from Bronislawa M. Przewoznik,
taken from the 31-year-old woman before she returned to Poland. Mrs. Przewoznik
said that for $80 Mr. Gorski helped her get a Social Security card, and that for
$80 more he helped her get a $107-a-week job as a housemaid in an East Windsor
nursing home.

Investigators used such information to convince a grand jury it should charge
Mr. Gorski with several crimes and the owner of the nursing home, James D'Amore,
with harboring and shielding illegal aliens.

Mrs. Przewoznik, asked whether she knew that her visa did not allow her to work
in the United States, answered, typically of many aliens: ''I had a vague
understanding, but there is a general knowledge that everyone is working and
nothing actually happens to you if you happen to have employment. The general
understanding is that people are coming to United States to improve their living
conditions.''

As her visa approached expiration, however, Mrs. Przewoznik gave her passport to
Mr. Gorski, who she said offered for a fee to have the visa extended. He assured
her several times that this had been done.

Later, Mrs. Przewoznik's parents became ill, and she decided to return to see
them in Poland. She made plane reservations and asked Mr. Gorski for the
passport, according to the depositon.

She said that Mr. Gorski assured her everything would be taken care of, but in
fact he was not able to extend the visa, and Mrs.  Przewoznik, who went to the
Immigration and Naturalization Service to retrieve the passport, discovered she
was in the country illegally.

In similar cases, according to Mr. Mrotek, Mr. Gorski held passports for ransom
and sometimes, without the knowledge of the alien, submitted fabricated
applications for political asylum on their behalf.

According to John Weiss, chief investigator in the Hartford office of the
Immigration and Naturalization Service, the investigation was not a total loss
because ''it's expanded into quite a bit of other material.'' Others are under
investigation, he said.

Five Connecticut residents and a Baptist minister from Brooklyn, in New York
City, are under indictment charging peripheral involvement.  None of these,
however, could be characterized as major cases.

In addition to Mr. D'Amore, the nursing home owner, Walter Demusz, owner of an
East Hartford machine shop, was charged with offenses connected with employment
of illegal aliens, and Paul and Jack Ziskin, brothers who operate a West
Hartford drugstore, were accused of falsely notarizing documents.

Mr. Gorski's secretary, Bernice Novak Orenstein, was charged with making a false
statement concerning a translation of a document. The Baptist minister, the Rev.
Vincent Winniczeck, was indicted on a charge of allowing Mr. Gorski to meet
aliens in his church, the Polish American United Methodist Church of Greenpoint,
in New York City, and of acting as middleman in the sale of the Social Security
cards.

All these cases are moving toward trial.

60 Being Sent to Texas

BYLINE: UPI

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 11, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 121 words

DATELINE: FORT CHAFFEE, Ark., June 7


Sixty Cuban refugees suspected of instigating last weekend's rioting at Fort
Chaffee face confinement and hearings that could lead to their deportation,
Federal officials said today.

The 60 suspects, none of whom have been charged with any state or Federal
crimes, were scheduled to be taken from the Fort Chaffee stockade and flown to
an Immigration and Naturalization Service detention center at El Paso, Tex.,
between 8:30 and 9:30 P.M., central daylight time, today.

Nelia Petrick, a spokesman for the Federal Emergency Management Administration
at Fort Chaffee, said that the suspects' cases would be decided by an
immigration service judge on a case-by-case basis.

                June 10, 1980, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

INDIA SENDS MORE FORCES TO CONTROL VIOLENCE IN 2 NORTHEASTERN STATES

SECTION: Section A; Page 8, Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 454 words

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, June 9


Additional security forces were being flown to Tripura and Assam in northeastern
India to contain the spreading violence, an official report said today.

In Tripura, bordering Bangladesh, serious clashes have occurred since last
Thursday, when the local population began a protest against immigrants, mostly
Bengalis from Bangladesh.

According to official reports from Agartala, the state capital, at least 20
people were killed in the clashes. New Delhi today declared two districts of
Tripura as ''disturbed areas'' and ordered army and paramilitary forces into the
area.

The nearly yearlong agitation in Assam, which has now spread to Manipur and
Tripura, has blocked the flow of oil from the wells in northern Assam, disrupted
normal life and led to the clashes between ethnic groups.

The Assamese are demanding that the immigrants who have entered the state since
1951 be expelled. Mrs. Gandhi has refused to order any mass eviction but has
offered to evict those immigrants who have come since 1971, the year Bangladesh
was created from what was East Pakistan.

50 Killed in Clashes in Last Month

At least 50 people have been reported killed in Assam in the lash month in
clashes between Assamese and Bengalis in the interior districts in northern
Assam. Although the Indian Army and the border forces have intervened to quell
the disturbances, sporadic violence in the villages is still being reported.

Prime Minister Indira Ghandi said today that while she had ''no direct or
conclusive evidence'' to show that a foreign power was behind the protests, she
said the ''method in which the agitation is being conducted indicated the hand
of a foreign power.'' Mrs. Gandhi did not name the foreign power but she had
earlier hinted that the United States Central Intelligence Agency was involved.

Mrs. Gandhi told some editors who met with her today that she was trying to find
a peaceful solution to the crisis but opposition parties were exploiting the
situation.

American Reportedly Expelled

She cited Indian newspaper reports on the expulsion of an American from India
for alleged espionage in the northeast. The Indian Express reported on Saturday
that James H. Goodman had been asked to leave India last week. Mr. Goodman
reportedly went to Gauhati as a tourist and met various groups involved in the
