U.S. WILL LET SOME IRANIAN STUDENTS EXTEND STAYS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

SECTION: Section A; Page 7, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 560 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10


The Immigration and Naturalization Service said today that it would permit some
Iranian students enrolled in American colleges and universities to extend their
stays in the United States.

David W. Crosland, acting commissioner of the agency, sent out instructions to
all field offices granting, in effect, a reprieve to Iranian students who had
been admitted to this country for a limited period, with a precise departure
date stamped on their travel documents.

The students had complained that there was inequity in the distinction that the
Federal Government made between them and the majority of Iranian students, who
were admitted to the United States for the duration of their studies, with no
fixed departure date.

Verne Jervis, a spokesman for the immigration service, said that the new policy
would affect ''at most a few thousand'' students. But William P. Bray, assistant
director of the National Association for Foreign Student Affairs, said that it
could benefit up to one-third of the estimated 60,000 Iranian students.

Language Students Aided

Among those who will benefit, he said, are students enrolled in one-year or
two-year intensive English language training programs.''Had this order not come
out,'' said Mr. Bray, whose association represents 1,200 foreign student
advisers, ''up to 20,000 Iranian students could have been facing deportation
hearings in the next six months.''

Mr. Crosland's order, which was apparently cleared with the White House, the
State Department and other interested agencies, said: ''Iranian students whose
authorized period of stay has expired or will expire on a specific date can be
granted extensions to complete their current course of study or degree level, at
which point they will be required to leave. Those individuals who had already
been accepted to graduate schools, law schools, medical schools as of June 9
should be permitted to continue with those studies.''

In addition, he said that immigration officers should be ''strict in identifying
students eligible for these extensions'' and should resolve any doubts by
denying Iranian students an extended stay.

Carter Order After Seizure

On Nov. 10 last year, six days after Iranian militants seized the American
Embassy in Teheran, President Carter instructed Attorney General Benjamin R.
Civiletti to review the status of Iranian students in this country and to begin
deportation proceedings against those who had violated immigration laws. On
April 12 the immigration service announced that it would force students and
other Iranians to leave the United States when their travel documents expired
unless there were ''compelling humanitarian reasons,'' for them to remain here.

David Carliner, an immigration lawyer in private practice here, praised the new
policy as a ''welcome sign.'' Mr. Carliner, the author of an American Civil
Liberties Union handbook on the rights of aliens, had described the previous
policy toward Iranian students as ''an act of blind vengeance upon hapless
Iranians.''

In a letter to President Carter on April 25, the heads of six organizations
concerned with the international exchange of scholars said that the Iranians
studying here ''constitute an important influence toward moderation in Iranian
affairs and might eventually be an important force for reconciliation between
our two nations.''

EXCERPTS FROM MURPHY'S DENIAL

SECTION: Section B; Page 8, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 684 words


Following are excerpts from a statement issued yesterday by Representative John
M. Murphy about charges pending against him:

Following are excerpts from a statement issued yesterday by Representative John
M. Murphy about charges pending against him: The first major charge is that I
allegedly accepted a portion of a $50,000 bribe for providing a phony Arab sheik
with immigration help. The allegation is supposedly supported by the videotape
taken of myself, Mr. Criden an F.B.I. undercover agent and an informer working
for the F.B.I. in a Kennedy Airport motel room on Oct. 20, 1979.

The truth of the matter is I never promised to help in such immigration matters
nor did I introduce and get passed any such legislation.

The videotape of the Kennedy Airport meeting were reviewed by my lawyer, Michael
Tigar and myself on two occasions and they show the following:

At no time was the prospect of legislation even discussed by me.  The agent and
the informer asked for some assistance in getting someone into the country and I
told them to get a lawyer, that all they had to do was file the proper
immigration forms if they had a problem.

I in fact advised against an attempt to get the phony sheik into the United
States in view of this Administration's treatment of high ranking foreign
leaders who sought sanctuary here.

Howard Criden carried a briefcase out of that meeting. I was never shown or told
the contents of the briefcase and I subsequently did not receive any portion of
whatever was supposed to be in that briefcase. There was no explanation at all
of the contents of the briefcase.

When these tapes are made public it will be seen and it will be made very clear
that the references from the time that briefcase appeared until all of the
parties who were talking go off camera, that the briefcase only had to do with
Mr. Criden and nothing to do with Murphy.

There was no discussion in that meeting of any money being in the briefcase. The
discussion about it was simply that it was a briefcase that Mr. Criden was to
take with him.

That was not a discussion in which I had any role. Howard Criden took it
downstairs, got in a separate automobile and left. That has been my public
position and that is what the tapes will reveal. I have so testified under oath.

The second major charge in the indictment is that Congressman Thompson and I
both conspired to have the sheik invest large amounts of money in business deals
that would ''inure directly and indirectly'' to our benefit.

Specifically I was supposed to somehow be financially involved with Mr. Lawrence
Buser, the former president of American Export Lines who discussed with the
bogus Arab representatives the possible purchase of a Puerto Rican shipping
line.

The truth of the matter is contained in the videotape recorded meeting on the
10th of January, 1980 at the W Street townhouse at which I was present and Mr.
Criden, Mr. Buser, Mr. Weinberg and agent Amoroso or Devito as he called
himself, were present.

At that meeting the tapes show that I stated in no uncertain terms in response
to leading, suggestive questions by Agent Amoroso that not only would I not
participate in any business deal of the kind that was being discussed and that I
would not accept any favors or consideration of any kind in return for any
official action on my part but that I, in no uncertain terms, said it was wrong
for the suggestion even to be made.

The tapes further show the F.B.I. agents repeatedly attempted to get me to say
that I would be involved in a shipping enterprise. I once said unequivocally ''I
am not in this'' and when Mr. Weinberg persistently tried to enveigle my name
into the conversation Mr.  Buser said on several occasions ''he is not involved
in this.'' Seeing they had thus failed to involve me, Agent Amoroso asked me
into the library to try to get me to say something that would be incriminating.
I was annoyed at what - I now find - was a pathetic display of amateur seduction
and I actually lectured Amoroso on the ethics of what it means to hold and
responsibly discharge a public trust.

AROUND THE WORLD;
78 Indicted for Defiance Of Order Limiting Cubans

MIAMI, June 23 (AP) - Criminal indictments were filed in Federal District Court
here today against 78 persons who Federal prosecutors say brought Cuban
nationals to United States shores in defiance of a May 15 Presidential order.

Assistant United States Attorney William Norris said the indictments were ''the
first batch.'' The 78 persons are charged with knowingly bringing undocumented
aliens into the United States, conspiring to do so, or interfering with Coast
Guard vessels assigned to control the flotilla of small boats from Mariel, Cuba,
to Key West, Fla., that began in April.

If convicted, each could be fined a maximum of $2,000 and sentenced to five
years in prison.  In addition, the Immigration and Naturalization Service has
served nearly 2,000 boat captains with notices of intent to fine them $1,000 for
each illegal immigrant brought into this country, and 400 captains already have
received bills.

Pryor Undergoes Skin Graft On Burned Upper Torso

SHERMAN OAKS, Calif., June 23 (AP) - Richard Pryor, the comedian, underwent
surgery today to graft healthy skin over the critically burned upper half of his
body, a hospital spokesman said.

A hospital spokesman said that the doctors were pleased with the results.  The
extensive burns on Mr. Pryor's chest have inhibited normal breathing and
coughing that rid the lungs naturally of fluid buildup, thus causing the
pneumonia, Gary Swaye, assistant executive director for the hospital, explained.

Mr. Pryor, 39 years old, had been responding well to treatment after an accident
at his Northridge home June 9.

O'Hare Airport Computer Inoperative for Fourth Day

CHICAGO, June 23 (AP) - Air traffic controllers at the nation's busiest airport
had to keep track of airplanes without their trafficmonitoring computer for the
fourth straight day today. But no serious problems or delays were reported.

The computer at O'Hare International Airport has not been functioning since
Friday and is expected to remain out of service for another day or two..

Peter Salmon, deputy chief of the control tower at O'Hare, said that fair
weather enabled the airport to operate with no disruptions of service today.

A team of specialists from the Federal Aviation Administration's experimental
center in Atlantic City has been working since Friday to correct the problem.

Meanwhile, in Fremont, Calif., an Federal aviation official said today that the
primary computer aiding air traffic controllers for Northern California and
Nevada broke down last weekend for the fourth time this month. He said that no
aircraft were in danger.

Chinese Ship Is the First To Dock at California Port

LONG BEACH, Calif., June 23 (UPI) -A ship flying the red and gold colors of
China has become the first vessel from that nation to dock at a California port.

The Mei Gui Hai, a bulk freighter, had been riding at anchor for 10 days outside
the harbor before she came in last Saturday to be loaded with 15,000 tons of
feed grain for China.

The ship tied up at the Koppel Inc. grain pier and is to return to anchorage
until next Friday when she will make her official entry into the port and
continue loading her 36,000-ton cargo.

Chinese ships have called earlier at Portland, Seattle and Vancouver, according
to the Kerr Steamship Co., Inc., the United States agent for the China Overseas
Ocean Shipping Corporation, which operates the Mei Gui Hai.

JUDGE ORDERS RELEASE OF 31 BOATS SEIZED BY U.S. IN REFUGEE

FLOTILLAMIAMI, June 25 (UPI) - A Federal judge today ordered the Government to
release 31 shrimp boats seized for taking part in the Cuban refugee flotilla,
leaving officials in a quandary over how to proceed against the more than 900
other vessels that were seized.

Federal District Judge Sidney Aronovitz ruled that impounding of the commercial
fishing boats that ferried undocumented refugees across the Florida Straits had
caused the boat owners ''irreparable harm'' by leaving them without a means to
make a living.

United States Attorney Atlee Wampler immediately sought a suspension of the
order pending an appeal, and a hearing was set for tomorrow afternoon. The order
left officials of the Customs Service and Immigration and Naturalization Service
unsure of how to follow instructions from President Carter to punish
participants in the sealift.

More than 114,000 Cubans have been ferried to the United States.

'A Very Knotty Problem'

''It's a very knotty problem,'' said a spokesman in Mr. Wampler's office.
Meanwhile, the Immigration and Naturalization Service sent six Cuban refugees
with criminal records from El Paso, Tex., to a Federal prison in Washington
State today to await possible deportation.

A spokesman said the six would join other Cubans with criminal records who are
being held in the maximum security cells of McNeil Federal Prison Camp, on an
island near Tacoma.

The refugees had been sent to El Paso from Fort Chaffee, Ark., where they were
allegedly involved in violence.  The suit ruled on today by Judge Aronovitz was
the first filed by boat owners trying to get their vessels back. At least two
others have been filed in Federal District Court here.

Judge Aronovitz ordered the 19 owners of the 31 shrimp boats to bond their boats
out with liens to the Government, and he barred them from setting sail for
foreign countries.

While ordering the boat released, Judge Aronovitz refused to halt the
Government's efforts to fine boat owners or captains up to $1,000 for each
refugee brought in illegally.

18 Cubans Ordered Deported

TALLADEGA, Ala., June 25 (UPI) -Eighteen Cuban refugees held at a Federal prison
have confessed to crimes including murder, rape and child molestation and have
been served with deportation notices, officials said today.

They are among 396 Cuban men who were taken to the Federal Correctional
Institute at Talladega because they had prison records.  Myles Frechette, head
of the State Department's Cuban desk in Washington, said, ''We will turn them
back to Cuba.'' Butthe Cuban Government has indicated that it will not take
them.

U.S. IS GIVING NICARAGUAN REFUGEES A 3-MONTH EXTENSION FOR STAY HERE

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

SECTION: Section A; Page 17, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 360 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30


State Department and immigration officials said today that thousands of
Nicaraguans who sought refuge in the United States last year when President
Anastasio Somoza Debayle was ousted would be allowed to stay here until Sept.
28.

A State Department spokesman said that Warren M. Christopher, Deputy Secretary
of State, had recommended extending the deadline for the Nicaraguans' departure
by three months to give them ''an opportunity to put their affairs in order.''

The spokesman, Donald E. Mathes, said it was not expected that the Nicaraguans
would be allowed to settle here as a group the way that Cubans and Haitians have
been permitted to stay, under a policy announced by the Carter Administration 10
days ago.

The Nicaraguans, including civil servants who worked for General Somoza, will be
subject to deportation after Sept. 28, Mr. Mathes said, but they will not be
forced to leave if they have applications for asylum pending.

Applications will be reviewed individually under the Refugee Act of 1980, which
makes asylum available to foreign nationals who can demonstrate ''a well-founded
fear of persecution'' if they are forced to return to their homeland.

Finds No Legal Basis

Robert L. Boyer, a Miami lawyer who said he represented two groups of
Nicaraguans totaling 15,000 members, said the three-month extension was ''better
than nothing,'' but that there was no legal basis for treating the Nicaraguans
more harshly than the Cubans and Haitians. Accordingly, he said, he will file
suit in Federal court to prevent the immigration service from initiating
deportation proceedings against any Nicaraguans who came here since the
revolution last year.

Verne Jervis, a spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service, said
that 3,686 Nicaraguans had been granted ''extended voluntary departure'' status,
in effect a reprieve, expiring today.  They will be granted a further extension
to Sept. 28, as recommended by Mr. Christopher in a letter last Friday to the
Acting Commissioner of the immigration service, David W. Crosland, Mr.  Jervis
said.

Mr. Mathes said the exact number of people who had come to the United States.

MAN IN THE NEWS;
NEW U.S. IMMIGRATION CHIEF

BYLINE: By JOHN M. CREWDSON

SECTION: Section 1; Page 5, Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 642 words


Matias W. Garcia, the grandson of a Mexican immigrant, was nominated by
President Carter yesterday to be commissioner of the Immigration and
Naturalization Service. In a career in Texas politics, he has combined advocacy
for the rights of Hispanic Americans with an uncommon talent for getting and
holding the ear of the more conservative elements of the political
establishment.

Mr. Garcia is the second Mexican-American selected for the post.  The first was
Leonel P. Castillo, a fellow Texan who resigned last fall. Mr. Garcia is
expected to preside over a reorganization of some key elements of the service's
operations. After a meeting this year with Attorney General Benjamin R.
Civiletti, Mr. Garcia said he had concluded that ''a new policy and a new
direction have to be provided.''

The 52-year-old Mr. Garcia, whose nomination is subject to confirmation by the
Senate, emerged politically in Texas in the late 1960's when, in behalf of
Mexican-Americans, he challenged the equal opportunity employment program at
Kelly Air Force Base near San Antonio.

As a Texas State Representative for eight years, he focused the attention of the
Legislature, never a stronghold of Hispanic sentiment, on such issues as
bilingual education. Last year he entered into a battle with Bill Clayton, the
Speaker of the Texas House, because Mr. Clayton was not appointing
Mexican-American representatives as chairmen of committees.

Ties With Conservatives

Though his voting record is liberal, he has close ties with the moderate and
conservative wings of the Texas Democratic Party. Two years ago he supported the
unsuccessful race of the conservative Dolph Briscoe Jr. for the party's
gubernatorial nomination against John Hill, a moderate with populist-liberal
leanings.

In the Texas House, he usually begins his remarks with, ''I'll be brief.''
Usually he is not. He has a reputation in debates as an intense, perhaps
excitable advocate, like a trial lawyer hammering away at a jury. He is a trial
lawyer.

Outside the State Capitol he is said to be essentially mildmannered. With his
modishly styled hair, neat mustache and hornrimmed glasses, he could be taken
for a professor from the nearby University of Texas.

Matias William Garcia was born Nov. 7, 1927, in San Antonio, attended its public
schools and received a law degree in 1951 from St. Mary's University there. His
wife, Minnie, served on the site selection committee for the 1980 Democratic
National Convention and, with her husband, attended last year's White House
reception for Pope John Paul II and the state dinner for President Jose Lopez
Portillo of Mexico. The Garcias have two sons and two daughters.

Seeks Appointment to Bench

He hopes for an appointment to the Federal bench, but he has set that ambition
temporarily aside, just how long depending in large part on whether President
Carter is re-elected.

Mr. Garcia is chairman of his state's Mexican-American Democratic Organization
and of the Mexican-American caucus in the Legislature, posts that have made him
a chief spokesman on Hispanic issues. In December he was elected vice chairman
of the Hispanic American Democrats, a national organization in the Democratic
Party.

Because the Legislature meets for only 140 days every two years, Mr. Garcia has
had time to develop a lucrative legal practice in San Antonio and to involve
himself in statewide and national politics.

The agency he now heads, its employee morale low, struggling under mountains of
unsorted immigration records, needs improved administration. Mr. Garcia has
never managed anything larger than his San Antonio law office. But Henry
Cicneros, a San Antonio City Councilman, says of his friend: ''There is
unanimous respect for the man's professional talent. He can focus in on the
policy issues and leave the administration to others.''

                 July 13, 1980, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

CHINATOWN LEAPS THE WALL AND MOVES INTO LITTLE ITALY

BYLINE: By FRED FERRETTI

SECTION: Section 4; Page 6, Column 3; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1240 words


When formal funerals wind slowly through the narrow streets of Little Italy
these days, with the trumpets and drums of the Bacigalupo Funeral Home on
Mulberry Street mournfully playing ''Rock of Ages,'' more likely than not the
cars in procession are filled with Chinese. Perhaps nothing else is quite so
symbolic of what that patch of Lower Manhattan called Little Italy has become.

It may be Little Italy to city planners and to the few Italian-Americans for
whom it is still home, and the unbroken ranks of restaurants along Mulberry may
present a facade that is solidly Italian, but Little Italy is in fact rapidly
disappearing as New York's historic Italian enclave.

Many of the Italians have now moved to the suburbs or to that Italian-American
section of Brooklyn known as Bensonhurst. And the Chinese are rapidly buying the
houses that once housed German immigrants, then Irish and until recently,
Italians. With each purchase the borders of Chinatown expand.

The City Planning Commission and the Federal Bureau of the Census estimate the
population of Chinatown to be between 50,000 and 60,000, but the Planning
Commission concedes that there may be double that number, Most are immigrants;
many - it is impossible to say how many - are illegal immigrants.

The newcomers are not from Canton, the origin of the early Chinese arrivals, but
from the north, from Shanghai mostly, and from Taiwan.  It is these newcomers,
with fresh money, who have made the Chinatown-Little Italy area an investment
boomtown.

One realtor, John Zaccaro, estimated recently that within the 37 square blocks
of Little Italy - a rough square bounded by the Bowery to the east, Broadway to
the west, Bleecker Street to the north and south to Canal Street - the Chinese
own 70 percent of the buildings.

''It's a steady thing that's been going for at least 10 years,'' Mr. Zaccaro
said. ''My main business is with the Chinese. Thank God for them.'' Another real
estate man, Irving Raber, does not go so high in his estimate. He believes that
at least half of the buildings in the core of Little Italy, along Mott and
Elizabeth Streets, are owned by Chinese, but that Mulberry Street itself, the
heart of Little Italy, ''is still Italian.''

Anthony Bastiano, a member of Community Board 2 and a founder of the Little
Italy Restoration Association, says city figures that divide Little Italy's
population of 14,580 into 58 percent Italian, 40 percent Chinese (with the
remainder mostly Dominicans), are inflated ''so that the city will be able to
continue talking about Little Italy as a planning zone.'' In reality, says Mr.
Bastiano, the population is only 24 percent Italian and 72 percent Chinese, with
a small percentage of Hispanic residents.

Whatever the correct figures, the Chinese continue to move into Little Italy,
expanding north beyond Canal Street which used to be thought of as Chinatown's
northern limit. And they continue to buy buildings at a dizzying rate for
enormous prices with money that has lately come from Taiwan and Macao.

It is money in search of investments, much of it from Taiwan businessmen who are
worried that America's new and expanding business ties with the People's
Republic of China could reduce their own economic influence here. The relatively
new Golden Pacific National Bank on Canal Street is a reportedly a haven for
Taiwan funds. At least one building in Chinatown, the glass-faced square at Mott
and Chatham Square, reportedly was built with gambling proceeds from Macao's
casinos and dog tracks.

Says Mr. Bastiano, ''The attitude here was, the buyers would say, 'I'll buy
anything;' the seller would say, 'Whatever you offer, I'll take.' And it usually
was a lot more than the market value.''

The tales of prices paid for buildings that for the most part are not in prime
condition, for the few building sites that still exist, and for warehouses, can
be astounding:

* A parking lot at Hester and Mott Streets was resold with a Chinese buyer in
the middle for $1 million.

* Half-a-million dollars was paid for a Bowery and Canal Street site that is to
become a 600-seat movie theater and a restaurant.

* A building on Mulberry Street, a former pottery manufacturing plant, that was
offered for $200,000, bought in an inflated market for $300,000, sold a year ago
for $500,000 and resold a month after that for $600,000. The buyers and
speculators were all Chinese.

* Another building on Mulberry, that was bought for $480,000 was sold for
$780,000.  A common tactic has been for a Chinese buyer to purchase, say, a
factory building and then evict the tenants. The upper floors often become
garment factories with the Chinese workers becoming live-in tenants. Such
Chinese expansion has not been without friction.

Little Italy, particularly along Mulberry Street, and in private membership
clubs like the Ravenite Club and the In Crowd, and the unnamed and unmarked
store-front clubs along Hester Street, reacted strongly when the Chinese buyers
began snapping up buildings in the mid-1970's. Mr. Raber recalls, ''The Italians
were getting upset because the Chinese were buying tenements and making
warehouses out of them. Also they'd buy stores, paint the plate glass over and
deaden the block.''

He said Italian community organizers petitioned the City Planning Commission and
a neighborhood meeting was called ''about three years ago.'' Mr. Raber recalls
that the Chinese sat along one wall, the Italians along the opposite wall. He
said the Chinese were ''upset and kept asking, 'Do you want to build a Great
Wall and keep us out?' and the Italians were saying, 'No, we want to see
investment and improvement in the neighborhood.' ''

Implicit agreements were reached, Mr. Raber said, that the character of Little
Italy where possible would be maintained, particularly along Mulberry Street.
''One of the results has been,'' he says, ''that many Chinese-owned properties
along Mulberry have been sold back to Italians.'' Along Mott and Elizabeth,
however, the great majority of the buildings are owned by Chinese, according to
Mr. Raber. ''Mott Street, for example, is all Chinese except for Vincent's Clam
Bar,'' he says.

Instrumental in helping Little Italy to look much like it has looked for decades
has been the Lee Association, one of the so-called family associations of
Chinatown, whose president, Man Bun Lee, has a reputation of being a force for
moderation in his community. And so while change has come, the friction has
lessened.

A center for the elderly at 180 Mott Street now has two bottom floors devoted to
the needs of elderly Italians, while the rest of the building is tenanted by
Chinese.

Along Mott, the Chinese groceries co-exist nicely with the latticini. It is only
at the annual feast of San Gennaro that the Chinese are noticeably
uncomfortable. Mr. Zaccaro says, ''the big Italian thing here is still the
feast. For 10 days there is nothing else down here. It's something the Chinese
now realize they have to live with. And that's okay because they understand
business.''

Iranian May Be Ousted In Theft of One Grape

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 12, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 143 words

DATELINE: CHARLESTON, W.Va., July 23


Seyedashraf Mirhadi, an Iranian student, is accused of shoplifting for eating
one grape and his attorney says that he could be deported over it.

Robert A. Hallowell of the Immigration and Naturalization Service said today
that his agency would consider the case ''on its merits'' if Mr. Mirhadi was
convicted.

Mr. Mirhadi, a 20-year-old junior studying engineering at the West Virginia
Institute of Technology, was arrested June 13 at a Kroger store in Montgomery.
Yesterday in Montgomery Municipal Court, Judge Carl Harris took the case under
advisement, saying he would review a recent state Supreme Court decision
striking down part of the shoplifting statute.

The store manager, Larry Bowers, testified that he saw Mr. Mirhadi eating the
grape. James Humphrey, a police officer, said the student told him he ate a
grape to test their sweetness.

INQUIRIES INTO IMMIGRATION AIDES ROUSE ALIENS DEPORTATION FEARS

BYLINE: By JOHN M. CREWDSON

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1, Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 1403 words

DATELINE: FRESNO, Calif., July 24


One morning six weeks ago, three men with pistols under their coats appeared at
the door of John Atachian's jewelry shop in this central California city. Though
the men were not robbers, Mr. Atachian might be happier now if they had been.

They were Federal agents; one agent was from the Immigration and Naturalization
Service and the two others were from the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
Because of their visit Mr. Atachian, an Armenian who emigrated here from Lebanon
17 months ago, may lose something far more precious than his wares: his
treasured status as a resident alien.

Mr. Atachian, 34 years old, is one of 70 recent immigrants to the United States,
many of them Armenians, whose cases are being reopened by the immigration
service in an investigation of possible wrongdoing by officials in the service's
office here.

Harassment Is Charged

The Fresno investigation is being pursued with such vigor as to generate
complaints of harassment. Justice Department officials said that the immigration
service had a strengthened commitment to ferret out any wrongdoing in its ranks,
including the kind of physical brutality that Hispanic groups have charged for
years is routinely inflicted on illegal aliens by service personnel.

Earlier this year, after sharp criticism of its internal investigations unit by
the Justice Department and Congress, the immigration service began revamping the
unit, known as the Office of Professional Responsibility. It added more
investigators and brought in a new chief, Walter Connery, a former official of
the New York City Police Department.

One Justice Department lawyer said that since Mr. Connery took over the office
of responsibility had been ''quicker to respond'' to allegations of internal
wrongdoing and had kept the Justice Department, of which it is a part, better
informed about the progress of its investigations.

Inquiry 'Far From Over'

Charles Sava, the associate immigration service commissioner for enforcement,
has been temporarily reassigned from Washington to New York to assist in
investigating a burgeoning bribery case there.  Justice Department sources said
that a score or more of immigration officers had become targets of the Federal
inquiry, which one source described as ''far from over.''

Last week two immigration employees pleaded guilty to undisclosed charges -the
pleas are sealed because the two are cooperating with prosecutors, and
law-enforcement sources said that more pleas would be forthcoming soon. ''People
are being arrested and pleading guilty and cooperating,'' one source said.
''We're still gathering evidence.''

Earlier this week three Border Patrol agents stationed at San Clemente, Calif.,
were accused by a Federal grand jury in San Diego of beating illegal aliens, all
of them Mexicans, who had passed through the patrol's checkpoint on Interstate
Highway 5 there. At least four other agents of the Border Patrol, the
enforcement arm of the immigration service, have been notified that they are
targets of the grand jury's investigation.

Several other Federal investigations are under way around the country, including
one into the shooting death of a 6-year-old Mexican girl who was riding in a
truck that was being chased by the Border Patrol. A Justice Department source
said that ''a number'' of inquiries were looking into a charge that immigration
officers at San Isidro, Calif., south of San Diego, were issuing border crossing
cards to Mexican citizens ineligible to receive them.

For John Atachian and the other immigrants caught in the middle of the Fresno
investigation, however, all this means only that they may have to leave the
country and return home, in Mr. Atachian's case to Beirut, the once-lovely city
devastated by a civil war, where, he said, things are still ''very bad.''

''We were shocked,'' he said, recalling anew the surprise visit from the Federal
agents last month. ''We are aliens, and when we hear F.B.I., we panic. They
said, 'Your lawyer, did he tell you how much he is going to pay to immigration?'
I said no, he didn't tell me anything.''

Tactics Called Heavy Handed

Among those who figure in the Fresno inquiry are Charles Stephens, the chief of
the immigration office, and a number of local immigration lawyers and
''consultants,'' among them Steven Simonian, a Fresno lawyer who is of Armenian
descent. Judging by the questions investigators have been asking the aliens, the
immigration service suspects that bribes were paid to obtain residence for the
immigrants. But both Mr. Stephens and Mr. Simonian said that they were not
guilty of any wrongdoing and deplored what they described as the heavy-handed
tactics of the investigators working on the case.

The investigators, Mr. Simonian said, have been harassing his clients and
frightening them, asking such questions as how much Mr.  Simonian told them ''he
had to pay the immigration service to get your work done for you.'' Mr. Stephens
is equally angry over what he said was the unlawful attempt last month of the
investigators to enter the immigration office here after hours, presumably in
search of evidence.

In Washington, Verne Jervis, a spokesman for the immigration service, said:
''There is an investigation. It's not complete, and we will have no further
comment.''

Legal Fee Was $3,500

Mr. Atachian said that he had told the agents that Mr. Simonian, his attorney,
had charged him $3,500 to prepare his visa petition and that he had paid him
with a check. He said that the lawyer had mentioned nothing about using some of
the money to pay off officials to get the petition approved.

Like most of the other immigrants whose status is now in question, Mr. Atachian,
along with his wife and two young daughters, came here on a temporary visitor's
visa to see an old friend, a resident of Fresno's sizable Armenian community.

''My wife liked the country,'' Mr. Atachian said. They decided to consult a
laywer to see ''if we could stay as residents.'' He said that he had not known
Mr. Simonian but had picked his name out of the telephone book ''because he is
Armenian.'' He said that the lawyer had told him '' 'Yes, why not; we make your
application and give it to the immigration.' ''

Represented 20 Families

Mr. Simonian, a Fresno native who has been practicing immigration law here for
18 months, said that he had represented perhaps 20 Armenian families comprising
''40 or 50 people at most,'' and that all of his clients had been paid similar
visits by investigators.

He said that he suspected the investigations had focused on him primarily
because he and Mr. Stephens, the immigration chief here, were ''good friends''
who attended the same church.

He had often sought advice from Mr. Stephens on the handling of immigration
cases, he said, but had never paid him any money in return for his help. ''We
don't even exchange gifts at Christmas,'' he said. ''I don't make enough money
to bribe anybody.'' Mr. Simonian said that he had offered to submit to an
interview and a polygraph examination and to open his books to the Federal
Bureau of Investigation but that his offers had been refused.

Office Entered After Hours

Mr. Stephens said that he had not realized that the matter had reached the level
of a serious investigation until three weeks ago, when a Fresno immigration
agent working late was surprised by two Federal Bureau of Investigation agents
and an immigration investigator who had entered the office here after hours,
presumably in search of evidence.

Mr. Stephens, who has headed the immigration office here for five years, said
that he was outraged by such conduct and had filed a complaint with the United
States Attorney's office here charging unlawful entry. But, he said, he was
ordered by higher-ups to withdraw the complaint, and William Odencrantz, the
western regional counsel for the immigration service, said that the
investigators had been within their rights. ''There was no forceable entry,'' he
said.

Mr. Atachian, who operated a textile import business in Beirut, said that he was
afraid that he would be deported from the United States after investing nearly
all his money in his home and business here. ''As soon as immigration O.K.'d
petition,'' he said, ''I bought my car and house and furniture. All the money I
got I invest in this country. I have a very bad position now. All we want is to
stay in this country.''

DRAFT REGISTRATION POSES PROBLEMS FOR MEXICAN YOUTHS BORN IN U.S.

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Part 2; Page 31, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 652 words

DATELINE: CIUDAD JUAREZ, Mexico, July 26


The decision by the United States Government to require young men to register
with the Selective Service System for possible military service is creating
problems for young men born in the United States to Mexican parents.

Many prominent people in Juarez said they were concerned about the registration
of their sons who were born in 1960 and 1961 in the relative luxury of an El
Paso hospital, said Gaston de Bayona, director of international relations for
the Mayor of Juarez.

Mr. de Bayona mentioned a ''civic leader'' whose El Paso son was attending the
University of Texas at El Paso. The Mexican leader wanted his son to attend a
better university in the United States, but because of the renewal of draft
registration earlier this month he is not sure what his son should do.

In El Paso County, the city-county health unit reported that of 11,251 births
last year, 4,354 were to Mexico-born mothers of either American or Mexican
citizenship. Parents of American citizens can apply for legal resident alien
status in the United States after the child reaches 21 years of age, without
obtaining labor certificates from the Department of Labor, according to Henry V.
McGehee, a supervisory inspector with the Immigration and Naturalization
Service.

Some Hope to 'Lay Low'

American citizens in Juarez are reluctant to discuss the concerns they have
about registration with the Selective Service System. By ''laying low,'' some
hope to escape detection and retain their American citizenship by contending
that they were ignorant of the law, said Nelson Smith, an lawyer and president
of the El Paso Association of Immigration Practitioners.

But those who plan to register were open about it. Robert Caffery, a 19-year-old
El Paso resident whose mother is Mexican and father is American, said, ''I was
born in this country, so I'll defend this country if needed.''

Mr. Caffery said his El Paso friends with dual citizenship feel the same. ''It's
not a big deal like it was in the Vietnam crisis,'' he added.

Elea Aguirre, a 32-year-old mortgage banker who was born in El Paso to Mexican
parents, said that in Mexico ''the empathy was with the Vietnamese'' in the
Vietnam War.

Unable to Regain Citizenship

Mr. Smith said he had received a number of cases in which American citizens from
Mexico made no claim to American citizenship until after hostilities ceased in
the Vietnam War. Some who renounced their American citizenship have not been
able to regain it, he added.

Employees at El Paso's post offices have noticed a few Juarez residents who
registered with the Selective Service System this week.  Keith Powell of the
American Consulate in Juarez said 26 Americans registered for the armed forces
this week. But three 20-year-olds renounced their American citizenship this week
also, he said.

In Matamoros, the Mexican city opposite Brownsville, Tex., Wayne Griffith, a
consul, said that only two men registered this week for the draft.

Law Applies to All Aliens

''There are no group statistics on how many Americans live on the border,'' Mr.
Griffith added, ''because very few of them register with us.''

In addition to American citizens living in foreign countries, the registration
law applies to all legal and illegal aliens who live in the United States and
were born in 1960 and 1961.

Brayton Harris, assistant director of the Selective Service Service, said that,
starting next January, all men must register 30 days after their 18th birthday.

While officials do not know how many illegal residents live in El Paso, the
metropolitan area was the home of 5,214 legal resident aliens of various ages
and both sexes in 1978, according to the immigration agency.

U.S. OFFERS FREE TRIPS TO IRAN FOR PRISONERS AGREEING TO GO HOME

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 4, Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 326 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3


The United States Government has offered free flights home to the 192 Iranian
demonstrators imprisoned in New York State, immigration and State Department
officials said today.

The Iranians, who were transferred from the District of Columbia jail to prisons
in Manhattan and Otisville, N.Y., yesterday, face possible deportation for
refusing to identify themselves.

They were arrested here last Sunday for demonstrating without a permit. Although
those charges have been dropped, the authorities have continued to hold the
Iranians for refusing to reveal their names, a violation of regulations issued
last November shortly after the American hostages were seized in Teheran.

The group was transferred to the New York facilities after prison officials here
said they lacked sufficient space.

U.S.-Iranian Arrangements

Under arrangements worked out between immigration officials and representatives
of the Iranian interests section at the Algerian Embassy here, prisoners who
volunteer to return to Iran may do so at United States Government expense
without having to reveal their names.

The officials said, however, that those who wished to remain in the United
States must identify themselves or face deportation proceedings.

The rules issued last November require ''full and truthful disclosure of all
information requested'' by the Immigration and Naturalization Service. ''Willful
failure'' to comply is a ground for deportation.

A State Department spokesman said department officials had been in touch with
the Iranian interests section here on a continuing basis about a variety of
issues since the arrests. But he said he had no information on the Iranian
response to the United States proposal.

Asked about a report that Iran's United Nations Ambassador had been instructed
to visit the 20 women prisoners at the Metropolitan Correction Center in
Manhattan, the official said the department was unaware of a request for such a
visit.

                August 10, 1980, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

IRANIANS TESTING THE LIMITS OF U.S. JUSTICE

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

SECTION: Section 4; Page 3, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1092 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


An international political controversy spilled into the streets of the nation's
capital last week, raising fresh questions about the rights of aliens to express
unpopular views.

Just as supporters and opponents of the Shah clashed here three years ago, when
the Iranian monarch visited the White House, friends and foes of Ayatollah
Ruhollah Khomeini have recently been confronting each other in demonstrations
here. Nearly 200 Iranian students were arrested late last month at a
demonstration in support of the Ayatollah and spent 10 days in prison.

As soon as they were released, they returned to Washington to participate in yet
another demonstration, protesting, among other things, their treatment in
prison. Angry onlookers jeered and heckled the

Iranian demonstrators, who seemed eager to provoke just such a reaction. For its
part, Teheran saw a victory for Islam in the release of the protesters from
American prisons. ''After 10 days,'' Teheran radio said, ''the savage police of
Washington and the ruthless and cruel police of the U.S. Immigration Department
at last retreated in the face of the brave struggles of our beloved sisters and
brothers.''

The Iranian demonstrations and the treatment of the protesters by Federal
authorities raised several questions to which there were no simple answers. To
what extent are aliens protected by the Constitution? To what extent do they
enjoy First Amendment rights of free speech and assembly? Can immigration laws
be used as an instrument of foreign policy? Does the Immigration and
Naturalization Service consult with the State Department in deciding how to
enforce the law?

Justice Department officials insisted that the treatment of the Iranian
protesters was strictly in accordance with immigration laws and that the
political beliefs of the protestors were not a consideration. The State
Department insisted that it had not sought lenient treatment for the Iranian
prisoners in an effort to avoid harm to the American hostages. Consultations
between the two agencies were apparently informal and the details were kept
secret.

The District of Columbia police said that the 192 Khomeini supporters were
arrested after they pushed through a police line on July 27 and tried to disrupt
an anti-Khomeini rally. The Iranians, initially held in the city jail on
disorderly conduct charges, were transferred to Federal custody and taken to New
York for possible deportation proceedings because they refused to disclose their
names.

Under rules issued last November by the Justice Department, Iranian students
must make ''full and truthful disclosure of all information requested.''
Officials said the Iranians were violating this requirement until they
identified themselves.

It was announced, after rather hurried checks of the files, that all the Iranian
prisoners were ''in status'' - in compliance with the law and with the terms of
their visas. That finding surprised Justice Department officials (who maintain
that a fair percentage of any foreign student group usually has visa problems)
and suggested that the demonstrators had been carefully selected.

On the other hand, immigration officers who interviewed the Iranians said that
many had been released prematurely, that some were indeed ''out of status.'' The
Justice Department is conducting an internal investigation to determine what
actually happened.  Preliminary evidence suggests problems, at the very least,
in the way information was transmitted and decisions made within the immigration
service, a beleaguered agency in the best of times.

A Policy of Extremes?

The Iranian demonstrators, it seemed clear, were testing the limits of the First
Amendment. The Bill of Rights applies to ''people'' in the United States, not to
citizens alone, and civil libertarians have successfully asserted many claims on
behalf of aliens. But Federal courts have also upheld the power of Congress to
enact restrictions on classes of foreigners.

''Any policy toward aliens is vitally and intricately interwoven with
contemporaneous policies in regard to the conduct of foreign relations, the war
power and the maintenance of a republican form of government,'' the Supreme
Court of the United States said in a 1951 decision upholding the deportation of
three resident aliens who had once been members of the Communist Party. ''Such
matters are so exclusively entrusted to the political branches of government as
to be largely immune from judicial inquiry or interference.''

Just as Congress has ''plenary power'' over immigration matters, the executive
branch has substantial discretion in administering the law. At one extreme is
the tough Federal policy toward Iranians: Students already here were required to
report to the nearest immigration service offices last November. Visas issued to
Iranian citizens for future entry into the United States were invalidated in
April. At the other extreme is the generous policy toward Cuban refugees, who
have been welcomed with financial assistance for two decades. Somewhere in
between are the hapless Haitian refugees, who faced expulsion from the United
States until a Federal judge ordered the immigration service to reconsider their
asylum claims last month.

Congress has not enacted special punitive measures against Iranians, but
Representative Kent R. Hance, a Texas Democrat, has asked for hearings to
investigate ''possible subversive actions'' by Iranian students in this country.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation has some evidence to suggest that Iran sent
money to the United States to help Khomeini supporters foment civil
disturbances.

Harsh actions against the Iranians in this country might be politically popular,
but many diplomats, educators and specialists on Iranian affairs oppose such
measures. The American Foreign Service Association, the professional
organization of career diplomats, said the fact that aliens could express their
views here, in a nation of laws, ''stands in stark contrast to the violations of
law and of human dignity'' suffered by the hostages in Iran. Or, as a Justice
Department official said, ''We must not let the passions of the moment outweigh
good long-term practice and procedure.''

U.S SPENDING $16.8 MILLIONFOR REFUGEES IN FLORIDA

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 17, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 591 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, Aug. 13


Federal officials here announced plans today to spend $16.8 million for health
and educational services for Cuban and Haitian refugees in south Florida.

James J. Gigante, the new director of the Miami operations office of the State
Department's Cuban-Haitian Task Force, said today that he had arranged for
$150,000 in State Department funds to be made available immediately to the Dade
County Community Action Agency, which is trying to resettle the Haitians.

The announcements came a day after a coalition of resettlement agencies said
that it was so short of funds that it would not accept more Haitians from
Immigration and Naturalization Service holding areas until it could find homes
for 75 percent of the Haitians who are now living in a Miami Beach hotel.

Approximately 500 Haitians a week are now arriving in south Florida. The Rev.
Gerard Jean-Juste, director of the Haitian Refugee Center in Miami, said that
conditions for the 950 refugees at the Immigration and Naturalization Service's
Krome Avenue holding center were deplorable.

''It is overcrowded,'' the priest said. ''There is not enough shelter. There is
a sanitation problem. There is not enough fire protection. The grass is three
feet high; people dream of snakes every night. The place has 950 people. It was
made for 200.''

A second Immigration Service holding center, the Federal Correctional
Institution here, holds 150 refugees. After processing and medical examinations,
the refugees are supposed to be released by the immigration authorities to local
agencies for placement. Those who cannot be placed have been sent to the Metro
Hotel in Miami Beach, which now houses 230 Haitians.

The Dade County Community Action Agency is the lead agency of the Haitian
Coalition, a group of concerned public and private agencies.  The coalition has
been trying since April to place the refugees, using Federal and state money and
local funds from Dade County.

Yesterday, citing a desperate shortage of money for housing, food, staff
salaries and transportation, the coalition voted not to accept more Haitian
refugees from the immigration authorities until it substantially reduced the
backlog.

Isaac A. Withers, executive director of the Dade County Community Action Agency,
said that the coalition had been promised $500,000 in State Department funds in
a contract signed June 1 and had spent $132,000 in county funds in July alone.
To date, none of the State Department funds have arrived.

William G. Oliver, a Dade County Commissioner and member of the executive board
of the Haitian Coalition, said today that he felt Haitians, like Cubans, should
be resettled in other parts of the nation as well as Miami. ''Everybody can't
live in Dade County,'' he said angrily.

The State Department took over coordination of Federal efforts to coordinate
settlement of the Cubans and Haitians from the Federal Emergency Management
Agency. A State Department work group that arrived here in July departed Friday
amid complaints that it had not received enough money to carry out its work.

The funds announced today include $6.8 million to expand health and mental
health services for the refugees and $10 million for adult education programs to
teach English to an estimated 12,000 Cubans and 3,600 Haitians in an effort to
help them get jobs.

In the meantime, Father Jean-Juste has urged Federal officials to clarify the
legal status of the refugees, now designated under an executive order by
President Carter as ''entrants,'' with permission to stay for six months.

               August 16, 1980, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

IRANIAN DEMONSTRATORS AND DUE PROCESS

SECTION: Section 1; Page 20, Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 262 words


To the Editor:

The recent episode involving the mass arrest of nearly 200 pro-Khomeini
demonstrators and their subsequent 10-day detention raises fundamental questions
involving our nation's commitment to the constitutional guarantees of free
speech, assembly and due process of law.

A large group of people were subjected to special immigration inquiries merely
because of their participation in a political demonstration, and were detained
without any reasonable basis to believe they were in violation of immigration
laws.

Only last year, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously that an individual may not
be detained by the police merely because he refuses to provide identification.
That principle, basic to our concept of liberty, applies to I.N.S. officials as
well as to the police.

Indeed, a Federal court in New York held unconstitutional the I.N.S. practice of
mass detentions of large numbers of suspected aliens absent reasonable suspicion
that each and every person so detained is an alien illegally present in the
United States. The I.N.S. position vis-a-vis the Iranian demonstrators stands in
stark contradiction to these judicial precedents.

It is a measure of the strength of our society that we can tolerate the exercise
of free speech and assembly even by those whose motivations may be questioned
and with whom we may most vigorously disagree. Unfortunately, I.N.S. officials
who have sworn to uphold the law have instead violated it.
STEVEN R. SHAPIRO, ARTHUR N. EISENBERG, Staff Counsel, New York Civil Liberties
Union, New York, Aug. 8, 1980

                August 17, 1980, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

HOMOSEXUAL CUBANS GET SETTLEMENT AID

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 34, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 628 words

DATELINE: FORT CHAFFEE, Ark.


Homosexuals among the Cuban refugees here are being helped in gaining American
sponsors by two national homosexual organizations.

When reports indicated that a large portion of Cuban refugees were homosexuals,
the National Gay Rights Task Force began lobbying on their behalf, as did the
Metropolitan Community Church, an international homosexual church based in Los
Angeles.

''We became concerned when we got reports that the immigration people were
taking detailed sexual histories of these people,'' said Charles F. Brydon,
co-director of the National Gay Task Force. ''The immigration laws cite
homosexuality as a reason for being excluded from this country and we didn't
want that to happen to these people.''

Mr. Brydon said that his organization had been given assurances by officials of
the Carter Administration that a section of the Immigration and Naturalization
Act that permits exclusion of aliens on the basis of their sexual preference
would not be used to screen Cuban refugees.

Some Getting Priority

Because of the pressure by American homosexual groups, homosexual refugees have
frequently received American sponsorship before other refugees, Mr. Brydon said.

''While the general American public has been hesitant about the Cuban refugee,
the gay community has been very supportive,'' he said.  Some estimates on the
number of homosexuals among the Cuban refugees, both at Fort Chaffee and in
other camps around the country, have run as high as one quarter of the refugee
population.

A screening done here by the Metropolitan Community Church indicates, however,
that there are no more than 250 avowed homosexuals among the 5,000 Cuban
refugees in this Ozark camp.

'Still Hiding Our Feathers'

''There are a lot of us here, though some of us are, as we say in Spanish,
'tiene las plumas ocultas,' still hiding our feathers,'' said 24-year-hold
Wilfredo Marin Cardenas.

Mr. Marin stood behind the camp's rope barricade with another homosexual, Ramon
Alcuria, also 24, discussing what life in Cuba was like for homosexuals.
Although the official policy of the Cuban Government is that homosexuality is
not illegal, the general society frowns on it and homosexuals are regarded as
''escoria,'' or scum.  Homosexuals could lose their jobs or be excluded from
universities in Cuba.

And among the refugees here, homosexuals are often shunned or brutalized.

Declaration to Aid Escape

Ironically, in order to escape Cuba, many refugees declared themselves
homosexuals, which fueled reports in this country of large percentages in that
category. Even when the refugees reached this country, many were reluctant to
drop this ploy, according to Richard Tucker, director of Church World Services,
who is helping to find sponsors for the refugees. For this reason the
Metropolitan Community Church has been working with the camp officials to
determine just how large the homosexual community in the camps is.

''Most of the time, it was obvious,'' said one volunteer who worked for the
church at Fort Chaffee and who asked to remain anonymous.  ''The guy was
effeminate in looks and action. The strangest thing was that the straight
refugees were intimidating the gays in order to get out together because they
heard that we had had more sponsorship responses than the other church groups.''

In his three weeks of working at this camp, the volunteer said that he had
screened about 250 homosexuals and had ''20 to 40'' sponsorship offers a day. He
also said there were very few lesbians among the refugee population.

BRIBERY CONVICTIONS AT BROOKLYN TRIAL LEAVE SEVEN OTHERTT ABSCAM CASES

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 28, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 472 words


In addition to the trial that ended early yesterday in Federal District Court in
Brooklyn, indictments have been handed up in seven other cases as a result of
the Abscam investigation.

Some of the people accused in the other cases were among those convicted
yesterday. In that trial, the defendants were Representative Michael J. Myers,
Democrat of Pennsylvania; Mayor Angelo J. Errichetti of Camden, N.J., who is
also a New Jersey State Senator; Louis C. Johanson, a Philadelphia City
Councilman, and Howard L. Criden, a former law partner of Mr. Johanson.

Four men have been indicted in Brooklyn in an alleged conspiracy involving
immigration and other matters and payments totaling $100,000. They are
Representatives John M. Murphy, Democrat of Staten Island, and Frank Thompson
Jr., Democrat of Trenton; Mr. Criden, and Joseph R. Silvestri, a New Jersey
business consultant and real estate man.

Another indictment in Brooklyn, involving an alleged $50,000 bribe in connection
with an immigration bill, names Representative Raymond F. Lederer, Democrat of
Pennsylvania, and Mayor Errichetti, Mr.  Johanson and Mr. Criden. Mr. Johanson
and Mr. Criden have been severed from the other two defendants in this case.

Immigration Scheme Alleged

A third indictment in Brooklyn names Alexander A. Alexandro Jr., an investigator
with the Immigration and Naturalization Service, and Alfred Carpentier, a Long
Island businessman. They are accused of immigration bribery scheme.

In Washington, an indictment also charging an immigration bribery plot names
Representative John W. Jenrette Jr., Democrat of South Carolina, and John R.
Stowe, a former South Carolina businessman.

A second indictment in the capital involves allegations of a similar scheme. It
names Representative Richard Kelly, Republican of Florida; Stanley Weisz, an
accountant from Long Island, and Eugene R. Ciuzio, a Florida businessman.

In Philadelphia, four men have been indicted in an alleged bribery scheme to
provide favorable treatment for a spurious hotelconstruction project. They are
George X. Schwartz, president of the Philadelphia City Council; Mr. Criden, and
two City Councilmen - Mr. Johanson and Harry Jannotti. This case has been
scheduled for Sept. 8 and would be the second trial to arise from the inquiry.

Finally, in San Diego, an indictment has been brought against Joseph B. Meltzer,
a real estate man and one-time Government informer, and his wife, Hilda. They
are accused of swindling West Coast businessmen of more than $140,000 by using
inside information about the Abscam inquiry that Mr. Meltzer allegedly gained as
an informer participating in an early stage of the investigation.

U.S. Promises Quicker Decisions On Entry of Cubans Now in Peru

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 3, Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 162 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1


The Carter Administration has agreed to expedite decisions on whether Cubans in
Peru will be allowed to immigrate to the United States.

The promise came Saturday after 168 Cuban men, women and children stormed a Los
Angeles-bound plane in Lima and held 15 hostages for 23 hours in an unsuccessful
attempt to reach the United States. The State Department said almost all the
Cubans involved in the incident had originally been declared ineligible for
admission to the United States and had been resettled in Peru.

''Those among them who consider themselves eligible to enter the United States
through normal immigration procedures are, of course, free to apply for such
visas, and the United States has agreed to review those applications on an
expedited basis,'' a department statement said.

Asked if taking part in the hostage incident would count against Cubans seeking
to enter the United States, State Department press officer, Sondra McCarty said
she doubted it.

               September 8, 1980, Monday, Late City Final Edition

LOS ANGELES,ALMOST 200,RANKS NO.2 AMONG CITIES

BYLINE: By ROBERT LINDSEY

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1508 words

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 7


At the age of 199, it appears, Los Angeles has become No. 2.  This sprawling
city began a yearlong bicentennial celebration this weekend that will culminate
with the commemoration of the 200th anniversary of its founding by 44 immigrants
from Mexico on Sept. 4, 178l.

As the civic celebration was beginning, preliminary estimates from the 1980
Census were released indicating that Los Angeles was now the nation's second
most populous city, eclipsing Chicago, which had held that distinction since
1890 when it passed Philadelphia to become the ''Second City.''

Role of Mexican Immigrants

While few people dwelled on the matter, there was a pattern in the turn of
events: Los Angeles, a city founded by Mexicans, appeared to have become the
country's second largest city largely because of a renewed wave of immigration
from Mexico.

And as it began its bicentennial year, Los Angeles appeared to be on its way to
becoming the nation's first city where a majority of the population is made up
of immigrants from Latin America and Asia or descendants of earlier immigrants
from those regions of the world and Africa.

This city is still the Los Angeles of freeways, movie stars, earthquakes, palm
trees and smog, of experimental ways of life and unorthodox religious cults and
a seemingly omnipresent, benign sun.

Autos and Real Estate

It remains perhaps the quintessential American urban expression of the
automobile, a city that seems to have been experiencing a real estate boom
continuously since the first land developers and hucksters came from ''back
East'' a century ago and began to turn a sun-blessed semidesert into one of the
world's largest metropolitan regions by importing water from mountain ranges 300
miles away.

It is the economic center of a region containing more than 10 million people
that in the last decade has become the nation's major financial bridge to Asia,
a visibly thriving city whose downtown is currently experiencing a rejuvenation
involving more than $1 billion worth of new construction.

It is a cultural center that not only produces most of the world's movies and
prime-time television programming but, increasingly, exports original plays to
Broadway, has a world-class symphony orchestra whose musical director, Zubin
Mehta, was recruited by the New York Philharmonic, and is the setting for a
planned major museum of contemporary art that promises to be one of the most
ambitious museum projects in any American city in decades.

Annual Gathering of Migrants

Every summer, a 45-year-old southern California ritual recurs, when some of the
tens of thousands of migrants who moved west from Oklahoma, Texas, Iowa,
Nebraska and elsewhere in the 1930's gather at picnics to talk about old times.

But each year, there are fewer people at those picnics, because some of the
migrants have died and others have decided to move out of California to escape
the smog and congestion.

To fill their places, there is a new wave of migrants. Los Angeles is still
attracting people from other states, especially New York.  But more and more,
local officials say, the newcomers are from other countries.

''It's becoming a Hispanic city,'' said Charles Drescher, director of the city's
Community Analysis and Planning Division, which has estimated that the 1980
Census will show that non-Hispanic whites now make up 44 percent of the
population, as against 59 percent in 1970 and 72 percent in 1960.

But he said that the changes went beyond the tide of immigrants from Mexico and
other Latin-American countries who have been propelled northward by economic
deprivation and have changed the look and texture of life here.

He predicted that the census would also document a sizable influx of immigrants
from Taiwan, Korea, Vietnam, Cambodia and other thirdworld countries in the
1970's.  According to the local population researchers, it is this Latin and
Asian immigration, occurring in a decade when more than one million non-Hispanic
whites have left the city, that has allowed Los Angeles to challenge Chicago for
the position of the country's second largest city, after New York.

Although both cities are contesting the figures as too low, the preliminary
Census Bureau data indicate that Los Angeles now has about 152,000 more
residents than Chicago. The figures show Los Angeles with a population of
2,878,039, about 62,000 more than in 1970, and Chicago withh a population of
2,725,295, about 644,000 fewer than in 1970.

Breakdown of Population

The city's most recent estimates indicate that whites make up 44 percent of the
population; blacks, 21.5 percent; Hispanic residents 28 percent and Asians and
Pacific islanders about 7 percent.

The median age of the Hispanic residents is about 19, and the rate at which they
are increasing, through childbirth and immigration, has prompted some
researchers to predict that Latins could account for more than half of the
city's population by the end of this decade. By the year 2000, they say, the
Hispanic influx could make Los Angeles the nation's largest city. Hispanic
pupils already make up almost 40 percent of the student enrollment here.

The Spanish-speaking immigrants are becoming increasingly important economically
here, supporting not only retailing establishments but providing the labor for a
large garment industry, much of it operating in sweatshop conditions. The large
Latin population is also economically vital to the city's school system, whose
white population has plummeted in recent years.

The Latin residents have not yet translated their numbers into political
strength, but many people say they soon will.  ''It's only a matter of time -
it's already begun,'' Grace Montanez Davis, a Chicano, who is an aide to Mayor
Tom Bradley, a black, said recently in an interview.

Rivalry With New York

Although this is a city with a long history of self-promotion and civic
boosterism, the news that it appears to have passed Chicago in population is not
likely to bring much local applause. Many people here already believe that they
live in the Second City and have considered New York as their natural rival.

According to some observers, many Angelenos, as the people here call themselves,
have a kind of collective municipal inferiority complex. They say this is
especially true regarding New York City's image of supposedly superior cultural
riches and greater economic importance, in contrast with Los Angeles's
reputation as a kind of vast, shallow tinsel town - ''19 suburbs in search of a
city,'' as several generations of Eastern writers have depicted it.

The differences in reputations seems especially to trouble many of the New
Yorkers who have moved here. A study by the Security Pacific Bank last year
indicated that about 16 percent of this region's new residents in 1979 came from
New York State.

For many displaced New Yorkers, a move here results in a kind of love-hate
relationship involving the two cities, and they seem to be forever debating the
cities' relative merits. Many of them have been known to return to New York for
quick visits to confirm their decision to move here, or to import items, ranging
from Nedick's orange soda to New York pastrami, for comfort.

Neil Simon's Solution

Neil Simon, the playwright, moved here five years ago after tiring of New York's
problems but now divides his time between this city and Manhattan. Recently he
decided to try out his next play outside Los Angeles because of his
dissatisfaction with reviews in The Los Angeles Times.

Sandy Fox, a Brooklyn-born lawyer, holds a party each year at which 100 or so
former New Yorkers nostalgically play stickball and other games from their
childhood.

Reflecting on the dispute over the cities' respective cultural values, Gordon
Davidson, a former New Yorker who runs this city's respected Mark Taper Forum,
an innovative theater organization here, said:

''I'm bored with it. It's a silly argument. There's the problem of geographic
sprawl, but there is a lot of activity that's bubbling here in many areas in the
performing as well as the visual arts. The cultural situation in Los Angeles is
different than it is in the East. The East looked to, and benefited from, the
cultural heritage of Europe, but it's also been weighed down with it. Here we
can benefit from the things that occur on the Pacific rim and take advantage of
our Mexican and Hispanic influence.''

The bicentennial observance will include more than 150 community projects,
ranging from art shows to the commissioning of a ballet and plays that stress
the city's history. Angelenos are trying to use the event to enhance the city's
image. Admittedly inspired by the imagebuilding power of the ''I Love New York''
slogan, the bicentennial planners devised their own slogan: ''L.A.'s the
Place.''

Margo Albert, the wife of Eddie Albert, the actor, is co-chairman of the
celebration. ''This will be a fine opportunity to show that Los Angeles is a
great city instead of 'tinsel town,' and all that flaky stuff,'' she said.

WEST BERLIN PREPARING TO LIMIT JEWISH IMMIGRANTS

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 14, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 723 words

DATELINE: WEST BERLIN, Sept. 24


The West Berlin municipal authorities have taken steps to check the entry of
Jewish immigrants from the Soviet Union, ending a six-year period in which a
steady flow of Soviet Jews found a haven here.

The decision appears to have the support of Jewish leaders here who say their
community services are being overwhelmed by immigrants.  The new restrictions,
which are to be carried out this week, are designed to prevent Soviet Jews
allowed to emigrate to Israel from settling permanently in West Berlin. Since
1974, 2,600 Jews from the Soviet Union, many of them traveling on forged German
immigration papers and most originally bound for Israel, have found their way to
West Berlin.

Heinz Galinski, a Jewish leader in West Berlin, said he had been consulted and
was in full agreement with the administration's decision. ''We can no longer
cope with the stream of refugees,'' he said. ''We have taken more than our
share.''

Many Choose West Berlin

After Israel and the United States, he said West Berlin was the only place where
substantial numbers of Soviet Jews had found new homes.

Peter Ulrich, who is in charge of the city's department of internal affairs,
linked the restriction to the discovery some months ago of numerous cases in
which Jewish immigrants used false papers to claim refugee status or West German
nationality. ''These people had Israeli papers but they evidently found life
easier here,'' he said.

Mr. Galinski said that Soviet Jews with close family ties in the city would
still be allowed to settle here and eventually obtain full citizenship. He said
others, with Israeli nationality, would be considered aliens in the future and
would be barred from permanent settlement. He said they could apply for visas
and remain for periods of three to six months.

Some Face Deportation to Israel

Mr. Ulrich said authorities had investigated close to 1,000 recent immigrants
and had opened proceedings against 319, charging them with illegal entry. Twelve
Jews are in pretrial detention, he added, because evidence showed they had used
forged documents. Ten people were sentenced to prison terms ranging from two to
eight months.

The official said that under international law anyone found guilty of criminal
offenses could be deported, in this case to Israel, but Mr. Galinski said that
he had received assurances that all those now in West Berlin could stay in the
city.

''The authorities were generous and helpful in providing homes and jobs for the
new arrivals and in assisting us in our effort to integrate the immigrants,''
the Jewish official said, ''but the problems just tended to overwhelm a
community as small as ours.''

Berlin had a Jewish population of 175,000 before the Second World War, and the
flow of Jews from the Soviet Union was at first welcomed since it was adding to
a population made up mostly of older survivors. West Berlin's Jewish population
today is estimated at 6,000 to 7,000.

Language Is a Problem

Difficulties arose, according to Jewish residents here, because many of the new
arrivals spoke only Russian and had little or no knowledge of Jewish traditions
and religious life. ''Language classes were a predominant issue,'' he said,
''but almost as important and as difficult are our attempts to get the young
generation to take part in religious instruction, to learn Hebrew and to share
our customs and our faith.''

Jews from the Soviet Union's Baltic republics, where German language and
cultural influences prevailed before the war, had little trouble integrating,
officials said.

''I feel at home here,'' said a woman from Riga, who came to West Berlin three
years ago and is now a teacher at a municipal school.  ''My sons had some
language troubles at first, but now one studies at the city's free university
and the other one is at a teachers college,''.

But she said her situation appeared different from that of immigrants from other
parts of the Soviet Union, some of whom, as she put it, ''come only because they
want the good life and find conditions in Israel too harsh.''

Mr. Galinski acknowledged that the new restrictions appeared unpopular at first
sight. ''But to all those who shed crocodile's tears, I can only say where were
the big Jewish communities when the refugee stream began to flow? Let other
countries take their share.''
