JAILING OF CUBAN REFUGEES ASSAILED AS UNJUST PROCESS

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Page 6, Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 851 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26


Hundreds of the Cuban refugees tagged as hardened criminals by the Immigration
and Naturalization Service were locked up in Federal prisons shortly after their
arrival in this country because of such ''serious crimes'' in Cuba as killing a
cow without Government permission, according to lawyers who have examined their
cases.

And unless the cases are reviewed with greater understanding and discrimination,
the refugees now face the likelihood of being expelled or spending an indefinite
period in jail, an immigration service judge has cautioned.

In the course of expulsion hearings that the immigration service is conducting,
the judge, Theodore P. Jakaboski, and several lawyers for Cubans in the Federal
prison in Atlanta discovered that a significant number of the refugees were in
prison even though they had never committed a felony.

2,000 Cubans in U.S. Prisons

Some 2,000 Cubans in Federal prisons at Atlanta, Talladega, Ala., Leavenworth,
Kan., and McNeil Island, Wash., have been going through expulsion hearings since
President Carter's directive to the Justice Department on June 7 to move quickly
to expel refugees who had committed ''serious crimes'' in Cuba.

Immigration officials said that, of the 393 hearings completed, 388 involved
Cubans who had been officially excluded. Only five have not been ordered
expelled.

David W. Crosland, Acting Commissioner of the immigration service, said that
considerably more Cubans had initially been classified as criminals but that
reviews had diminished the number to about 2,000.  He said that he felt that due
process was being adhered to in the expulsion hearings.

The problem, according to Judge Jakaboski, is that many of the Cubans should not
be in prison in the first place.

Assessment by Judge

''A lot of these people aren't guilty of serious crimes,'' Judge Jakaboski said
in a telephone interview Wednesday. ''Some of them are petty criminals, but
there is no need to lock them up. There is no danger to society from them. I'd
say that 15 to 20 percent of the cases I dealt with have an asylum claim that
should be considered and 10 to 15 percent have valid claims to parole.''

Aliens can be excluded under immigration laws if they have ''committed a serious
nonpolitical crime prior to admission as a refugee.'' They can, however, claim
asylum in this country if return to their native land would lead to their
persecution because of race, religion, nationality, political opinion or
membership in a particular social group.

Judge Jakaboski, who held hearings in Atlanta for 10 days in August, said that,
of the 15 cases he had handled, he had returned four to the State Department for
reconsideration, granted asylum in one case and reserved judgment in two other
cases. In seven instances he ruled that the Cuban should be expelled from the
United States.

Language Problems

The judge said that the written statements of the Cuban's record were all done
in English, that the immigration service agents who had dealt with them on their
arrival frequently did not speak the idiomatic Spanish that the refugees used
and therefore did not communicate well, and that the statements freely
translated into English were not translated into Spanish and read back to the
refugees before they were asked to sign the statement.

A Cuban's criminal record is based on his or her own admission, said Judge
Jakaboski, adding that sophisticated criminals would not admit crimes.

Judge Jakaboski cited one of the cases he had referred back to the State
Department's Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs Department for consideration
as an example of the kind of Cubans who have been incarcerated.

The case involved a Cuban who was sentenced to 30 years in Cuba for stealing
fabric when he was 12 years old and stealing clothes when he was 16. Juvenile
crimes and offenses committed under the age of 18 are not admissible in
immigration law if five years have elapsed since their occurrence.

Lawyer's Experiences

Deborah S. Ebel, a lawyer for several of the Cubans in the Atlanta prison, said
that the problems with the Cubans' statements admitting crime were ''translation
problems,'' adding, ''There are an awful lot of translation problems.

''I had one case where the person had admitted to rape,'' she said. ''But, on
questioning, it turned out that at 14, he ran away with a girlfriend and set up
housekeeping. The girl's parents didn't like it, but it was more like eloping
than rape.''

Miss Ebel said that she and another lawyer had developed several hundred
questionnaires on the crimes that Cuban refugees in the Atlanta prison had
admitted.

Of the 312 admissions of crimes, she said, 47 percent were crimes of theft, with
the majority of these being ''small theft for sustenance.'' Crimes against
another person accounted for 11 percent. Eighteen percent of the crimes were
listed as anti-Castro political activity.

Miss Ebel said that 8 percent of the crimes were ''regulatory crimes, things
like killing your own cow without getting Government permission, or not having
balanced accounting books.''

IDEAS & TRENDS IN SUMMARY;
Havana Cuts;
Off Easy Exit;
by Margot Slade and Tom Ferrell

SECTION: Section 4; Page 8, Column 6; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 306 words


Without warning, the Cuban Government last week apparently stopped the boatlift
of refugees that has already brought 125,000 to the United States. According to
the Administration, first official word of the action came the Coast Guard,
which learned of it from boat captains forced to return from Cuba without
refugees.

There was speculation in Washington that Havana might have acted to counteract
negative feelings among Americans over the exodus.  The cutoff occurred as
United States immigration officials were involved in expulsion hearings for some
2,000 refugees, tagged as hardened criminals and awaiting disposition in Federal
prisons. Many, say lawyers examining their cases, had been imprisoned in Cuba
for inconsequential crimes.

Officials in charge of relocating the 10,000 or so Cubans still in camps may
take distant hope from two studies prepared for the Select Commission on
Immigration and Refugee Policy. These show that within 10 years, average
immigrant families start earning more than average families born in this country
and are not the burden on welfare systems they are sometimes perceived to be.
Immigrant families tend to have more working-age members, fewer children and a
heavier investment in education than native-born families.

Conducted by researchers at Yale University and the University of Illinois, the
studies may fuel the dispute as to whether immigrants are an asset to the
economy because they take unpopular jobs, or a drain because they take jobs from
those already here.

Last week, the Government began consolidating refugees from scattered camps at
Fort Chaffee, Ark. and announced it would open an old Army base in Puerto Rico
to house others.

               October 12, 1980, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

NEW JERSEYANS

SECTION: Section 11; New Jersey; Page 30, Column 5; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 757 words


AS Joan Morrison remembers the day in 1973, there they were - she and Charlotte
Fox Zabusky - standing outside the Morris County Courthouse. They were all
dressed up with no place to go after attending a naturalization ceremony.

So the two women retired to a nearby coffee shop and made plans then and there
to write a book about this nation of immigrants.  Called ''American Mosaic: The
Immigrant Experience in the Words of Those Who Lived It,'' the volume was
published recently by E.P.  Dutton.

In deciding to write the book, Mrs. Morrison, who lives in Morris Township, and
Mrs. Zabusky, who has since moved to Pittsburgh, started a more-difficult
journey than they had an anticipated.

''If we knew how much work it would be, I don't think we'd ever have started the
book,'' Mrs. Morrison says now.  But five years of researching and writing
produced the book, and the two women are now tasting the semi-celebrity,
semi-huckster life of authors helping to publicize their creation.

One recent Sunday, they starred in a program of drama and song in the auditorium
of the American Museum of Immigration at the Statue of Liberty. They have been
interviewed for the Voice of America and invited to speak at schools and
universities.

The book - in-their-own-words narratives by dozens of immigrants - stems from a
story that appeared in this section of The New York Times. It was about a
Christmas party held for a group of ''new Americans'' at the Neighborhood House
in Morristown. Mrs. Zabusky was in charge of the program, and Mrs. Morrison
wrote the story about it for the New Jersey Weekly.

One of the people mentioned in the story invited the two women to his
naturalization ceremony. It moved them emotionally - so much so, in fact, that
they decided to write ''American Mosaic.'' It tells the stories of some
otherwise anonymous Americans, and of some (like Alistair Cooke, for instance)
whose names are familiar.

There have been lots of books about immigrants. What is different about this
one?  ''It's probably the only one to deal with the human side,'' Mrs.  Morrison
said. ''Not statistics, not trends. People. We decided, as the title says, that
this nation is not a melting pot, but a mosaic.''

Writing is not an unfamiliar chore in the Morrison family. Mrs.  Morrison has
written for newspapers and magazines, and her husband, Robert, is an author of
science textbooks.

Another author, Leonard S. Silk, whose new book is ''The American
Establishment,'' has been appointed to the Board of Trustees at William Paterson
College in Wayne. Mr. Silk, a Montclair resident, was co-author of the book with
his son, Mark.

Father and son not only write about the Establishment, but they also work for
it. Mark Silk is a professor at Harvard, and Leonard Silk is economic columnist
for The New York Times.

Also joining the William Paterson board is Sol Hoffman of Teaneck, international
vice president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union. And, finally,
James A. Ware of South Plainfield, an employment and training-center supervisor
for the United States Department of Labor, has joined the adjunct sociology
faculty as a teacher of ''Sociology of Labor.''

The new ''community shaliach'' -liaison from Israel to the Jewish community of
Bergen County - is David Ben Asher, who is a colonel on leave from the Israel
Defense Force. He will live in Teaneck and have his office at the United Jewish
Community of Bergen County center, 111 Kinderkamack Road, River Edge.

Appointed provost of the 10,000-student Teaneck-Hackensack campus of Fairleigh
Dickinson University is Dr. Allan De Giulio of Ramsey.  ''It's a thrill to be
joining such a fine university,'' said Dr. De Giulio, who previously was
president of Harriman College in Harriman, N.Y.

The 1980 award of the Governmental Research Association for ''Most Distinguished
Research'' has been conferred on the Bureau of Government Research at Rutgers
University.

The award, presented at the association's annual conference in Austin, Tex.,
honored the 114-page report on ''School Budget Caps in New Jersey 1976-1980.''
The report was prepared by the Rutgers bureau's director, Dr. Ernest C. Reock
Jr.  Maurice Carroll

              October 16, 1980, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 28, Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 422 words

DATELINE: TUCSON, Ariz., Oct. 15


Manuel Hernandez Garcia, the Mexican laborer who says he was chained to a tree
without food or water for 24 hours on a ranch 35 miles east of Tucson, was
released from jail yesterday afternoon.

Mr. Hernandez, 20 years old, had been held in custody since Oct. 7 by the
Immigration and Naturalization Service pending a deportation hearing for lack of
proper documentation. But that hearing has been postponed until a case is
resolved against Walter M. Burris Jr., a rancher who allegedly chained Mr.
Hernandez to a tree on his property in a dispute over the theft of some tools.

Mr. Burris has been charged with unlawful imprisonment, aggravated assault and
kidnapping, and was himself released on his own recognizance last Thursday, the
day after he was arrested.

Mr. Hernandez is expected to testify Friday at a preliminary hearing for Mr.
Burris.

'Not Likely to Abscond'

Mr. Hernandez's release was arranged between Antonio D. Bustamante of Southern
Arizona Legal Aid Inc. and James G. Martin, assistant district director for
investigations of the Immigration and Naturalization Service in Phoenix.

Mr. Martin said today that he had permitted the release because Mr. Hernandez
was ''not likely to abscond.'' Max Torres, an officer with Youth Development
Inc., a crime prevention program in Tucson, has agreed to house Mr. Hernandez.
And Mr. Hernandez is expected to work at Mr. Torres's office until the Burris
case is completed.

Mr. Hernandez comes from the small village of Cuichata, Vera Cruz, 60 miles from
the Gulf of Mexico. A short man with Indian features, he first tried to enter
the United States on Aug. 20 near Nogales, Ariz., but was thwarted by the United
States Border Patrol. The next day he eluded capture and found employment doing
odd jobs at Mr.  Burris's ranch, where he says he was promised $7 a day plus
room and board.

On Oct. 6, according to the authorities, Mr. Burris accused Mr.  Hernandez of
stealing some tools, a charge that the Mexican denied.  Sheriff deputies report
that Mr. Burris then tied one end of a logging chain around a tree and locked
the other end around Mr.  Hernandez's neck. When Mr. Hernandez had not confessed
to the theft 24 hours later, the deputies said, Mr. Burris unchained him and Mr.
Hernandez hid in a closet in the bunkhouse he had been sleeping in.

A sheriff's deputy, reportedly alerted to the chaining by an anonymous phone
call to the Border Patrol office, rescued him. He had been held in the City of
South Tucson jail until his release yesterday.

REFUGEES SEIZE HOSPITAL BUILDING

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section B; Page 7, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 240 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20


Cuban refugees transferred here for psychiatric observation seized control of a
building at St.  Elizabeth's Hospital for six hours today before the authorities
quelled the disturbance.

A spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service said there were no
injuries in the incident, which came a day after a similar disturbance at the
hospital.

Twenty of the Cubans at St. Elizabeth's filed suit in Federal District Court
asking to be released. They contended that the confinement was ''dehumanizing
and stigmatizing.''

Officials said there were 92 Cubans in the building when the disturbance began
at 1:30 P.M.

I.N.S. Officers End Takeover

The Cubans remained in control until early evening, when about 100 uniformed
I.N.S. officers moved into the two-story brick building and ended the takeover.

David Crosland, the Acting Commissioner of the immigration service, said 19
inmates considered ''troublemakers'' were later taken to Andrews Air Force Base
for flights to other Federal institutions.

Seventeen men were being sent to the penitentiary in Springfield, Mo., and two
women were being flown to a prison in Lexington, Ky. The rest of the Cubans will
stay at St. Elizabeth's, Mr. Crosland said.

Don Ralbovski, a spokesman for the Public Health Service, said he did not know
what prompted the disturbance.

Selection of Jury Ends In Fourth Abscam Trial

A jury was selected yesterday for the fourth Abscam trial, in which the
defendants are a former investigator for the Immigration and Naturalization

The defendants are Alexander A. Alexandro Jr., 30 years old, of Commack, L.I.,
who left the Immigration and Naturalization Service after his indictment, and

secure permanent resident status in the United States for a foreigner.

bribery, bribe-receiving and conflict of interest.  Video and audio tapes may
play a key role in the trial, and under a procedural agreement between the
television networks and the court, any tapes introduced as evidence will be
available for broadcast within an hour.

AROUND THE NATION;
Haitians Win the Right To Hold Jobs in Florida

SECTION: Section A; Page 18, Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 169 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 21


As many as 20,000 Haitian refugees in south Florida today won the right to work
until a decision is reached on their individual claims for political asylum.

Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings approved the settlement of a class
action suit filed against the Government in July 1979 by the National Emergency
Civil Liberties Committee and the American Civil Liberties Union of Florida on
behalf of the National Council of Churches, the Haitian Refugee Center and a
number of Haitian refugees.

The suit challenged the Immigration and Naturalization Service's decision to
revoke the work authorizations of the Haitian refugees until their asylum claims
could be resolved. The Haitians asserted that the agency used a double standard
that favored Cuban refugees.

The immigration service has agreed to give work permits to Nicaraguan and
Haitian refugees who arrived in South Florida before June 20 this year and
reported by Aug. 1, 1980.

               October 28, 1980, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

IMMIGRATION BILLS AND THE LESSON OF THE HELSTOSKI CASECASE

SECTION: Section A; Page 38, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 577 words


To the Editor:

Your editorial on private immigration bills (Oct. 16) reiterates a misconception
of the Helstoski case which has contributed to the blasting of an outstanding,
12-year Congressional career and the denial to the people of the Ninth
Congressional District of New Jersey of the services of a dedicated public
figure.

It is true that the U.S. attorney withdrew the bribery prosecution after the
Supreme Court ruled that Helstoski's legislative acts (e.g., the introduction of
bills) could not be proved in court. What is overlooked, however, is that the
Supreme Court plainly permitted the attorney to try to prove that Helstoski had
taken money and had promised to perform legislative acts (the sort of proof
which is at the heart of the Abscam cases).

The Supreme Court was indubitably correct in its decision. If legislative acts
of members of Congress become the grist of Federal prosecutors, grand juries and
criminal-trial juries, the underlying concept of a free and independent
legislative body uncoerced by the executive or judicial branches of our
Government, is gravely threatened. On the other hand, the Court in Helstoski, as
it had done previously, emphasized that non-legislative acts of members of
Congress, e.g., taking bribes, were well within the ambit of the Federal
prosecutorial process.

Since it had been familiar law that legislative acts could not be proved, it is
obvious that the reiteration of that principle in Helstoski had nothing to do
with the U.S. attorney's decision to drop the bribery charges. The reason he did
so was that he finally realized that his case, shorn of impermissible evidence,
came to rest upon the testimony of two persons who had been caught in flagrant
violation of law and who bought their way out (freedom from prosecution in one
case, and a mild sentence in the other) by satisfying the ill-concealed desire
of the U.S. attorney to add Helstoski's scalp to his prosecutorial belt.

Against those two witnesses there would have been an outpouring of testimony
from constituents who over the years had been helped by an extraordinarily
devoted Congressman with never a hint of anything expected in return. The
Supreme Court's decision became an excuse, therefore, to drop what appeared to
be a losing prosecution that at the time seemed not to matter; Mr. Helstoski's
career had already been destroyed by the indictment, which had been extant for
more than three years.

The lesson of the Helstoski case, therefore, is not that private immigration
bills are bad. They provide healthy movement of the joints in what is otherwise
a rigid, impersonal and sometimes unjust immigration-law system. The lesson of
the Helstoski case is rather that Federal prosecutors, some of whom are bent on
the use of their offices for career development, can use their inordinate power
to destroy decent people.

Perhaps it has escaped the attention of The Times, although it is a matter of
record, that it was Henry Helstoski himself who caused the initiation of the
F.B.I. investigation which the U.S. attorney turned against him. Unfortunately,
in this post-Watergate era, any politician who is so much as charged with crime
is presumed guilty.

There is no easy remedy, but at least the media ought not exacerbate the
problem, as I am afraid you have done in your interpretation of the Helstoski
case in your editorial.
MORTON STAVIS, Newark, Oct. 16, 1980

The writer is Mr. Helstoski's attorney.

               October 28, 1980, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

DEFENDANT ONLY 'PLAYING ALONG' IN ABSCAM CASE, HE TELLS JURORS

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED

SECTION: Section A; Page 28, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 403 words


A Federal immigration investigator testified yesterday that rather than taking a
$2,000 bribe from Abscam undercover agents, he was ''playing'' along with their
immigration-fraud scheme because he thought they were organized-crime figures
and he had determined to investigate them.

''I was putting myself into a role of a rogue Federal agent to gain their
confidence and probe their organization,'' Alexander A.  Alexandro Jr., the
immigration investigator, said.

He gave this explanation in testifying in his own defense as his trial entered
its second week in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.  He and a co-defendant -
Alfred Carpentier, a Long Island businessman - face bribery and conspiracy
charges growing out of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Abscam operation to
uncover official corruption.

The trial is the fourth to result from the investigation, in which undercover
operators pretended they were wealthy Middle Easterners and their aides seeking
to buy favors in the United States. The three previous trials resulted in the
convictions of eight people, including Representatives Michael J. Myers of
Pennsylvania and John W. Jenrette Jr. of South Carolina.

Bribery Scheme Alleged

In the case of Mr. Alexandro, 31 years old, and Mr. Carpentier, 55, the Justice
Department charges that they engaged in a bribery scheme as part of an alleged
effort to obtain permanent resident status in the United States for a foreigner
''not entitled'' to it.

Mr. Alexandro is accused of having received the $2,000 as a down payment on a
$15,000 bribe. Mr. Carpentier is charged with conspiring with and ''aiding and
abetting'' him. Both have pleaded not guilty.

Under questioning yesterday by his attorney, Joel Winograd, Mr.  Alexandro
conceded having taken the $2,000 from two Abscam undercover men last year. But
he insisted, ''I was playing a role - I was trying to get on the inside of their
organization.''

Judge Mark A. Costantino dismissed an elderly juror and replaced her with an
alternate after Mr. Winograd complained that the woman had been sleeping through
much of yesterday's testimony. Before dismissing her, though, the judge
expressed sympathy for her problem of staying awake, indicating that he felt
that at least part of the trial was ''boring.''

              November 1, 1980, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

IMMIGRATION AIDE IS GUILTY IN ABSCAM CASE

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED

SECTION: Section 2; Page 28, Column 4; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 774 words


A Federal immigration investigator was found guilty last night of bribery,
conspiracy and conflict of interest in the fourth trial to grow out of the
Abscam investigation into official corruption.

His codefendant, a Long Island businessman, was found guilty of conspiracy and
aiding and abetting conflict of interest. But he was acquitted of a charge of
aiding and abetting bribery.

After three hours of deliberation, following a two-week trial, a jury in Federal
District Court in Brooklyn returned the verdicts against Alexander A. Alexandro
Jr., the investigator for the Immigration and Naturalization Service, and Alfred
Carpentier, the businessman.

Down Payment on a Bribe

They had been charged with engaging in a scheme to obtain permanent residence
status in the United States for a foreigner ''not entitled'' to it. Mr.
Alexandro had been accused of receiving $2,000 as a down payment on a $15,000
bribe from F.B.I. undercover operatives posing as representatives of wealthy
Middle Easterners seeking to buy favors in the United States.

Mr. Carpentier was charged with having conspired with and assisted Mr.
Alexandro.  As the verdict was announced at 10:20 P.M., Mr. Alexandro, a slender
31-year-old man in a vested brown suit, gazed at the jury without showing
emotion. So did the heavyset 55-year-old Mr.  Carpentier, who lives in East
Meadow. His family and two news reporters were the only spectators in the
downtown Brooklyn courtroom.

Mr. Alexandro, a resident of Commack, L.I., faces up to 15 years in prison and
Mr. Carpentier up to five years when they are sentenced within the next few
weeks by Judge Mark A. Costantino. Meanwhile they remain free in their own
recognizance.

Their lawyers said they would appeal.  Mr. Carpentier declined to comment after
the verdict. Mr. Alexandro said, ''Deep down inside my heart I know I'm not
guilty.'' Most of the jurors would not comment as they rushed from the
courthouse, but one said, ''The facts, we found it on the facts.''

Eight Abscam Convictions

The three previous trials based on the Federal Bureau of Investigation's
undercover investigation resulted in the convictions of eight people, including
Representatives Michael J. Myers of Pennsylvania and John W. Jenrette Jr. of
South Carolina. Among those scheduled to be tried on Abscam-related bribery
charges in the future are Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey and
Representatives John M. Murphy of New York and Frank Thompson Jr. of New Jersey.

According to John H. Jacobs, the prosecutor at the Alexandro-Carpentier trial,
the foreigner to be aided in the immigration-fraud scheme was an Irishman
supposedly acquainted with one of the bogus Arab sheiks who were at the heart of
the Abscam investigation. In fact, the Irishman, Thomas Foley, was a relative of
an F.B.I. agent.

The prosecution charged that among the methods envisioned for obtaining
residence status for Mr. Foley was ''procuring a woman for a temporary marriage
of convenience'' to him to establish his ''eligibility for permanent residence
because of a marriage to a United States citizen.''

Admitted Taking Money

The defendants denied the charges against them. Mr. Alexandro - who was the
first person arrested as a result of the Abscam investigation - conceded on the
witness stand that he had taken the $2,000 cash from the undercover men at a
hotel near Kennedy International Airport in Queens in August 1979. Indeed, the
F.B.I. surreptitiously videotaped the transaction, and the tape was played at
the trial.

But under questioning by his attorney, Joel Winograd, Mr. Alexandro testified
that he was ''playing'' along with the agents' immigration-fraud scheme because
he thought they were organizedcrime figures and he had set out to investigate
them.

''I was putting myself into a role of rogue Federal agent to gain their
confidence and probe their organization,'' he said.  Mr. Carpentier did not take
the stand, but his attorney, James A.  Pascarella, said his client was involved
in legitimate business dealings with the undercover men.

One of the undercover men, a convicted swindler named Melvin Weinberg, coached
Mr. Carpentier to say incriminating things, Mr.  Pascarella told the jury.

LAND OF IMMIGRANTS

SECTION: Section A; Page 14, Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 141 words


To the Editor:

On Sept. 9, an event unprecedented in American legal history took place in
California. The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals convened in San Francisco for
oral argument, with the judiciary headed by Herbert Y. Choy, an American of
Korean descent. Sitting alongside of him was Judge Shiro, of Japanese
extraction. The third member was Judge Tang, of Chinese origin. Thus, for the
first time in American life, a United States Circuit Court of Appeals sat with a
panel consisting of three judges of Asian descent. This speaks volumes for this
multifaceted country, in which essentially we are all immigrants.  JOSEPH
WINSTON New York, Oct. 31, 1980

120 CUBANS REACH U.S. AS AIRLIFT FROM HAVANA BEGINS

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 18, Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 403 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, Nov. 19


A planeload of 120 Cuban refugees arrived here today as an airlift of refugees
from Havana began.  The new arrivals were among 600 Cubans stranded at the port
of Mariel in September when Fidel Castro, Cuba's leader, abruptly halted a
five-month boatlift that had brought more than 125,000 Cubans to the United
States.

The chartered jet arrived early in the afternoon at Miami International Airport,
and the Cubans were qu ickly taken to a race track for immigration processing
and, in most cases, family reunions.Unlike most of the refugees in the boatlift,
the Cubans who arrived today had received United States visas in Hav ana. The
airlift is expected to take two weeks.

''There were 600 people sort of left on the beach when the boatlift ended,''
Wayne Smith, the head of the United States interests section in Havana, said in
a telephone interview. ''All of them were interviewed by the consular office and
immigration officers. They needed the normal criteria to qualify.''

Most of the 600 Cubans did qualify and will be flown to the United States, the
authorities said.  Myles Frechette, head of the State Department's Cuban desk in
Washington, said: ''We did this for humanitarian reasons. Hopefully all of the
people will be here in the next two weeks.''

However, the Federal Government is not paying for the airlift. Mr.  Frechette
said that getting the Cubans to the United States was the responsibility of
Cuban Americans, who must ch arter the aircraft.

The Church World Service is organizing the airlift, but the Coordinating
Committee of the Cuban Community is paying for the first flight, Roberto Perez,
a member of Church World Service, said.  The committee has collected about
$45,000 so far, Mr. Perez said.

No estimate of the airlift's cost was immediately available.  Mr. Frechette said
that the few Cubans who did not have relatives in the United States had been
granted permission to enter the country because of ''a well-founded fear of
persecution in Cuba.''

Mr. Smith said the United States interests section had granted other visas ''on
a very limited basis.'' He said that Cubans without families in this country had
little chance of receiving a visa.

Bahamas to Return 64 W ho Fled Haiti in Boat

NASSAU, the Bahamas, Nov. 23 (Reuters) - Bahamian officials said today that they
would send 64 refugees back to Haiti after the refugees recovered from a 39-day
ordeal at sea in a small boat trying to reach the United States.

chimney, has been taken into custody and will be returned to Haiti.

BRITISH DIRECTOR DENIED WORK PERMIT IN CANADA

BYLINE: By ANDREW H. MALCOLM, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Page 12, Column 5; Cultural Desk

LENGTH: 675 words

DATELINE: TORONTO, Nov. 28


Canadian immigration officials have denied a work permit to John Dexter, the
British director recently appointed to run the famed Stratford, Ontario,
Shakespeare Festival.

The surprise move, the latest in a series of controversies involving the
27-year-old festival, appeared to further endanger the future of Stratford,
which may soon see its 1981 season canceled.  Other current problems include
fast-approachi ng planning and publication deadlines for the new season as w ell
as a boycott by the Canadian Actors Equity Association, which is angered by the
festival board's failure to name a Canadian as artisti c director.

''It is my responsibility as minister,'' Immigration Minister Lloyd Axworthy
announced last night, ''to insure that Canadians get a reasonable chance at work
opportunities, and I have regretfully concluded that the festival board of
governors did not carry out a thorough and reasonable search for a Canadian
artistic director.'' As a result, he said, he was denying Mr. Dexter's permit
''at this time.''

Decision May Be Reviewed

Aides said the decision might be reviewed later if a thorough Canadian search
proved fruitless. But Mr. Axworthy's spokesman said, ''It's his view there is
someone qualified and willing.''

Robert Hicks, president of the board of governors of the festival and the center
of much of the controversy, said he was baffled by the decision. ''We're running
out of time,'' he said.

Dan MacDonald, an Actors Equity spokesman, said that the union was pleased with
the decision, but that the boycott remained in effect.  Fears were mounting for
the artistic future of the annual summerfall festival, which annually draws more
than 600,000 patrons to Stratford, a central Ontario town about 90 miles west of
Toronto.  Cancellation would also have serious economic implications for many
businesses in Stratford, where the theaters have created a multimillion-dollar
tourism industry.

The actors' boycott was called earlier this month after the Stratford board
suddenly ousted a four-member artistic directorate it had just installed to
replace another Briton, Robin Phillips, who announced his resignation over a
year ago. Mr. Phillips had become increasingly disturbed over the board's
apparent backing down on several commitments, including one to found a winter
operation in Toronto.

Cited Reason for Dismissals

The board dismissed the four -Peter Moss, Pam Brighton, Martha Henry and Urjo
Kareda - because, it said, they had failed to produce a financially viable plan
for the 1981 season.

But the abrupt dismissals and the appointment of Mr. Dexter, another foreigner
and former production head of New York's Metropolitan Opera, aroused a furor
within and without the arts community in Canada, where fervent nationalist
feelings have been growing in recent months. Historically, Britons have played a
prominent role in the Canadian arts. Currently they include Andrew Davis,
director of the Toronto Symphony, and Alexander Grant , artistic dire ctor of
the National Ballet of Canada.

The specter of foreign control and domination is an emotional one here these
days and has been stirred by the Trudeau Government's strong moves to force
increased Canadian control of certain industries, such as petroleum. Federal and
provincial governments, through significant grants of taxpayer dollars, play an
important role in the Canadian arts. More than 10 percent of Stratford's $6
million-plus budget comes from these governments.

In September, Peter Ustinov, starring in Stratford's production of ''King
Lear,'' threatened a lawsuit after the board had suddenly canceled the British
tour of the play, which was to open next week at London's Haymarket Theater.

2 IN BORDER PATROL SENTENCED FOR BEATINGS OF MEXICANS

BYLINE: By JOHN M. CREWDSON, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 21, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 465 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8


One Border Patrol agent was sentenced to a year in prison today and another drew
three years' probation for their part in the beatings of several Mexicans and at
least one American citizen at the Border Patrol's station near San Clemente,
Calif.

The agents, J. Gillespie Wood and Jose Martin Barker, were charged by a Federal
grand jury last July with multiple counts of deprivation of civil rights and
assaulting Federal officers. Mr. Wood pleaded guilty to the charges and Mr.
Barker was convicted by a Federal court jury in October.

The charges of assaulting a Federal officer arose after the Immigration and
Naturalization Service assigned two Mexican-American investigators to look into
allegations of frequent beatings by Border Patrol agents at San Clemente, about
60 miles north of San Diego.

The agents, Juan Espinal and Javier Dibene, dressed to resemble Mexican aliens,
were taken off a bus at an unspecified time before March of this year as the bus
passed through the patrol's San Clemente checkpoint on heavily traveled
Interstate 5. According to the Government's indictment, the agents were beaten
by Mr. Barker and Mr. Wood during questioning about their citizenship.

First Action of its Kind

The investigation marked the first time that the immigration service, the Border
Patrol's parent agency, had used its own agents in an undercover capacity to
ferret out internal wrongdoing.

A third border patrolman, Lester M. Fullen, who is alleged by the Government to
have observed the beatings and then lied about them before the grand jury, was
tried separately in November. The case ended in a mistrial, but Mr. Fullen is
scheduled to be retried next month.

According to the indictment, at least six Mexicans and a 16-yearold American
citizen also were beaten by Mr. Wood and Mr.  Barker. The allegations that
prompted the investigation came from the 16-yearold boy, who to stop the
beatings ''confessed'' to being a Mexican citizen and was subsequently sent back
to Mexico, according to the Justice Department.

Patrolman Barker, charged with having beaten one of the undercover investigators
with a metal chair, was sentenced to a year in Federal prison today by United
States District Judge Leland Nielsen in San Diego. Before pronouncing sentence,
Judge Nielsen said that a factor in his decisi on had been Mr. Barker's
continuing refusal at his trialto admit his role in the beatings.

Mr. Wood, a 17-year veteran of the Border P atrol and a supervisor at the San
Clemente checkpoint, was given a o ne-year suspended sentence, placed on
probation for three years and fined $1,000.

AROUND THE WORLD;
U.S. and Vietnam Agree On Immigration Program

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 4, Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 151 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8


The United States and Vietnam have reached agreement on a program that will
initially permit the immigration of up to 1,500 Vietnamese and their families to
the United States, the State Department said today.

The first departures from Vietnam, totaling about 250 people, are expected to
begin Thursday aboard a weekly Air France flight from Ho Chi Minh City, formerly
Saigon, to Bangkok, Thailand.

American officials said the Carter Administration, in selecting which Vietnamese
were eligible for entry into the United States, was giving priority to those
with relatives in the United States or those who were formerly employed by the
United States Government.

The State Department spokesman, John H. Trattner, said the program was
humanitarian in nature and was unrelated to the question of normalization of
relations between Washington and Hanoi.

               December 21, 1980, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

RUSSIAN IMMAGRANTS ESTABLISH NEW ENCLAVES IN CITY

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN

SECTION: Section 1; Part 2; Page 56, Column 3; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1062 words


When dawn breaks over Brooklyn's beaches and train after train rumbles up to the
Brighton Beach elevated stop, the subway station is a bit like Moscow's Metro -
fur-covered heads buried in the New Yorkbased Novoye Russkoye Slovo or Sovetsky
Sport, which is published in Moscow, grandmothers knitting and bragging about
their offspring.

A little later and a few blocks away, mixed in among several thousand other
students, 175 Russian teen-agers, many of them wearing the latest designer
jeans, enter the classrooms of Abraham Lincoln High School.

There in the Brighton Beach section, as in Manhattan's Washington Heights and
Forest Hills, Queens, the morning commuters and the high school students are
part of the most recent wave of Russian immigrants, nearly all of them Jews.

More than 30,000 immigrants have arrived in New York City from the Soviet Union
in the last eight years, and while many older Russians retain their Slavic
language and customs, nearly all the younger Russian immigrants are hurrying to
adopt the manners and habits of native New Yorkers. I'll make a brand-new start
of it in old

New York. If I can make it there, I'd make it anywhere. It's up to you, New
York, New York.  The band playing ''New York, New York''* one recent evening at
the Golden Palace, across the causeway from Brighton Beach on Coney Island, was
called the Five Russkys. But only the platters of white fish and red caviar -
''rybnoye assorti'' - and the half-empty bottles of vodka on the restaurant's
tables suggested that until recently, the owners, band and patrons had been no
closer to a New York nightclub than the cafes of Leningrad, Moscow or Kiev.

''Now we're Americans,'' said Vladimir Gincherman, one of three owners of the
Golden Palace. Grinning at his partners over glasses of champagne, he added,
''And our children will be Americans.''

The Russian students at Abraham Lincoln, occasionally sneaking puffs on a
forbidden cigarette, sit together in the school's lunchroom, speaking Russian
but not fending off American culture.

Discos and Cosmetics

''We go to discos on weekends,'' said Galina Vinokurova, a junior who came from
Odessa last year. Many of the Russian girls at the school stand out by their
devotion to American cosmetics. Generally, the more recent a girl's arrival, the
more she uses.

''It's a freedom to do what you want,'' one girl explained. ''In Russia there
isn't that much makeup. It's not really considered ladylike.''

Masha Englin came to the United States with her parents in 1974, two years after
the current wave of immigration from the Soviet Union began. ''I was the only
Russian in Forest Hills High School the year I began,'' she said.

Students like the 23-year-old Miss Englin, now an undergraduate at Columbia
University, represent the future to many Russian parents.  ''My son speaks
English much better than Russian,'' said Mr.  Gincherman, who began as a truck
driver six years ago. ''My job isn't to make him Russian. I want him to have a
good life in America. If I stay in Brooklyn, I will put him in private
schools.''

''I prepared myself to work hard,'' he added. ''Immediately we started selling
things - little trinkets, things from Russia. Little by little we learned to
speak English. We worked and we saved.''

Most Russians who come to New York leave the Soviet Union because they are
Jewish and say they were subject to discrimination there.  But many say they are
not religious and that they are not regarded as Jews by many Americans.

''We were Jewish in Russia,'' said Michael Varzar, another of the Golden
Palace's owners. ''Now in America we're not Jewish, we're Russian.''

Despite Americanization, many older Russians cling to their heritage. ''Business
is very good because Russians read a great deal,'' said Janny Orlikov, who runs
the Russian-language Black Sea Bookstore on Brighton Beach Avenue.

She shuffled the piles of Russian-language newspapers, some from Moscow, others
from New York City, on the counter before her.  ''Younger people don't read
Russian books,'' she said, ''but older people, those in their 40's and 50's,
certainly do. We read what we couldn't read about in Russia - about Stalin,
about Khrushchev.''

A New Television Station

Early next year, Mrs. Orlikov's husband, Yuri, will help open New York's first
Russian-language television station. But they both concede that the station's
programming will be aimed at older Russians.

''In five or six years, Russian kids will forget Russian,'' Mrs.  Orlikov said.
''You see how even I mix English in with my Russian.'' Last year 13,000 Russians
came to New York, according to Mark Handelman, an assistant director at the New
York Association of New Americans. Because the Soviet Union had limited
emigration, only 8,000 people had arrived here this year through Nov. 1.

Not all Russians here left the Soviet Union willingly. Pavel Litvinov says he
was expelled after laboring for four years in salt mines in Siberia, the penalty
he received for having demonstrated in Red Square against the Soviet invasion of
Czechoslovakia in 1968. Now teaching physics at the Hackley School in Tarrytown,
N.Y., Mr.  Litvinov considers himself one of the few hundred exiles among the
tens of thousands of immigrants.

In a gradual process, some of those Russians are beginning to leave their ethnic
neighborhoods. Miss Englin's parents, Artiom and Marina, moved across Queens
Boulevard to Rego Park, away from many of their compatriots.

''People would knock on our door at all hours - to taste food, to borrow sugar,
to get a recipe.'' Mrs. Englin said. ''It is like that in Russia, but here we
wanted some privacy.''

Mr. Gincherman, although saying that he generalizes too much about Russians in
New York, added: ''We want to go to Manhattan, we want to go to shows. We want
to be like everyone else.'' ---- *Copyright c 1977, United Artists Corporation.
All rights administered by Unart Music Corporation.

               December 28, 1980, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

NEW ADMINISTRATION AND CONGRESS FACE MAJOR IMMIGTRATION DECISIONS

BYLINE: By JOHN M. CREWDSON, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 1, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 4304 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


After years of relative inattention to the control of immigration, there are
signs that the incoming Congress, with encouragement from the Reagan
administration, may confront a difficult question: How wide open should the door
be through which millions of immigrants have stepped?

The impending debate, certain to be spirited and divisive, follows a year in
which nearly half the country's population growth has been attributable to legal
immigration and in which, by most estimates, illegal immigration has never been
greater.

Indeed, the 1970's may be remembered as the decade of the immigrant. In the last
10 years, the United States has absorbed more than four million immigrants and
refugees and perhaps twice that number of illegal aliens, more new residents
than in any decade in its history.  If current immigration and fertility rates
remain the same, the nation's population will double in 100 years.

'Not Sure Problems Are Soluble'

The immigration control system is in such disarray, many officials acknowledge,
that practically anyone who wishes to and who can afford the passage can come to
the United States, legally or illegally, and stay for months or years, if not
for good. Until now the prevailing attitude, in Congress and elsewhere, has
appeared to be fatalistic, typified by a Democratic Congressional aide who
remarked: ''I'm not sure the problems are soluble anyway. A lot of it is beyond
our control.''

But there are growing indications, in public opinion polls and in angry letters
from constituents, that many Americans, convinced that immigrants are taking
their jobs, draining the treasury and dividing cities into isolated and
increasingly hostile ethnic communities, are demanding a solution. One recent
poll by the Roper Organization showed that nine of 10 of those surveyed
supported an ''all-out effort'' to halt illegal immigration and that eight of 10
favored reducing the number of legal immigrants.

Senator Alan K. Simpson attributes this reaction to ''compassion fatigue,'' and
there can be no disputing that America in recent years has displayed an
abundance of compassion. In 1970, some 373,000 immigrants and refugees were
legally admitted to the United States. This year, counting 160,000 Cuban and
Haitian ''boat people'' who were not invited but who are being allowed to
remain, there will be more than 763,000, more than will be taken in by all other
countries combined.

''Somewhere along the line we're going to have to learn to say 'no,''' said
Senator Simpson, a Wyoming Republican. As head of the revitalized Senate
subcommittee on immigration, he said, his task will be to take the expected
legislative reforms from the Reagan White House and ''get the stuff up for a
vote.''

''The real issue,'' said the Senator, who reflects the conservative mood of the
incoming 97th Congress, ''and the one I intend to bring the focus back on, is
what is best for the existing human beings who are U.S. citizens. I don't hear
anybody saying, 'wait a minute, what about those of us who are here?'''

The reluctance of Congress to ask that question has been a source of
exasperation among those in the executive branch aware of the burgeoning
problem. ''When I was with the I.N.S.,'' Leonel Castillo, the former
Commissioner of Immigration, said recently, referring to the Immigration and
Naturalization Service, ''I realized that Congress likes what we have now.
Clearly, some people derive great benefit from the present situation.''

Though Mr. Castillo did not name them, the main beneficiaries appear to be
business interests that employ illegal aliens at low wages. Twice in recent
years business lobbyists have helped defeat in the Senate legislation forbidding
the employment of illegal aliens after it had been passed by the House of
Representatives.

And though there is a growing belief around the nation that, in a time of
continuing high unemployment, immigrants are taking jobs from American workers,
the real impetus for change, if it comes, will more likely be the long-awaited
final report of the Select Commission on Immigration and Refugee Policy, set up
last year to chart immigration policies for the rest of the century and beyond.

Among the 16 commissioners are four Cabinet members, four Senators, including
Mr. Simpson, four Representatives and four members at large, including the Rev.
Theodore M. Hesburgh, the panel's chairman, who is president of the University
of Notre Dame.

Earlier this month, the commission voted to recommend an amnesty for illegal
aliens in this country and passage of a Federal law prohibiting the employment
of workers without proper papers. The commission's logic appeared to be that the
situation was so hopeless that the practical solution was to start over by
making the illegal aliens now here citizens and removing incentives for others
to follow in their footsteps.

But sorting out citizens from uninvited visitors is difficult in a country whose
population is made up of so many ethnic strains, and the commission left what
some see as a crucial gap by failing to endorse a national ''work permit'' that
would help employers tell whom they could hire.

Stronger Enforcement Favored

The commission, now divided between conservatives and liberals on the work
permit question and other issues, will grow more conservative next month when it
is joined by a new Republican Attorney General and new Secretaries of State,
Health and Human Services, and Labor. Members say that votes on some key
recommendations may be reconsidered before being sent to Congress.

The Reagan administration, still in its transition phase, has not formulated a
detailed list of immigration reforms. But aides say that President-elect Ronald
Reagan has indicated his support for strengthened enforcement of the immigration
laws, combined with a program to permit more foreign workers into this country
on a temporary basis. The idea of temporary workers was rejected by the
commission but it is appealing to Mr. Simpson and other key Senators.

Though an amnesty proposal died in Congress after it was submitted by President
Carter more than three years ago, Congressional aides say the legislation was
badly managed by the White House and that there may be enough support for such a
plan in both the incoming Republican-controlled Senate and the House of
Representatives, which will have a Democratic majority but be more conservative.

As distasteful as the idea of an amnesty may be to Americans - a recent Gallup
Poll found that only 37 percent of those questioned supported such a plan - most
students of the problem are convinced that there is no practical alternative.

A mass roundup and deportation might be impracticable if not unconstitutional.
Senator Simpson, who said there ''may be close to 12 million'' illegal aliens
living in this country, double the highest estimate of the Carter
Administration, terms such a dragnet ''the greatest waste of effort and
resources'' imaginable.

Most authorities feel that to allow the aliens to retain their illegal status,
on the other hand, would be to perpetuate a permanent underclass subject to
abuse and exploitation from a host of sources, including alien smugglers who
force them into peonage, unscrupulous immigration officers who solicit bribes,
employers who demand kickbacks in return for jobs and landlords who gouge them
on rents.

And while illegal aliens pay the same Federal and state taxes as citizens,
numerous studies have shown that they are reluctant to take full advantage of
social services financed with their taxes.

Though the aliens may be willing to put up with hardships in return for economic
survival, Ray Marshall, the outgoing Secretary of Labor, has suggested that
their children will not have the same attitude and that ignoring the problem
''may result in another civil rights struggle in our nation in 10 or 15 years.''


Support for Amnesty Assessed

All these problems, and others, would be resolved by a general amnesty, and
Senator Simpson said he believed that ''the American people may buy it if they
see that we have an appropriate enforcement mechanism in place so that it isn't
going to happen again.'' But such a mechanism would depend largely on new
legislation prohibiting the employment of illegal aliens, and the debate over
the passage of such a law is certain to turn on the thorny question of whether
illegal aliens are displacing American workers.

No economist doubts that many illegal aliens perform unattractive, low-paying
jobs that would otherwise go begging, or that some laborintensive industries,
such as garment manufacturing, are now virtually dependent on them for survival.
But there are also those who argue that the presence of illegal workers keeps
wages and working conditions from improving to the point where they would be
attractive to Americans, and Secretary Marshall has asserted that without the
millions of ''undocumented workers'' now in this country the nation's
unemployment rate might be reduced to less than 4 percent.

Mr. Reagan's views on this question remain to be seen. But Henry Zuniga, a
campaign aide, said the President-elect had expressed the feeling ''that the
folks coming from Mexico for the most part are doing work that's necessary, that
they're not replacing U.S. citizens and that Mexico needs this kind of
assistance.''

Though a law forbidding the employment of illegal aliens is increasingly
attractive to many, critics argue that the United States is very nearly unable
to enforce existing immigration laws and that searching every place of business
in the country would require an army of police officers. Proponents reply that
while such a law might not stop all illegal immigrants and might not be
rigorously enforced with regard to restaurants and other small businesses, it
would enable the Justice Department to accuse large employers of a pattern of
employing illegals.

Whatever its ultimate intent, talk of an employment law inspires anger among
many Hispanic Americans, who fear that it would subject citizens with Spanish
surnames to inordinate and perhaps unconstitutional scrutiny by employers. ''If
they do have sanctions they better do it in a way that certain groups don't bear
the brunt of it,'' said Lupe Salinas, until recently a special assistant to
Attorney General Benjamin R. Civiletti. ''If they don't, they'll have every
Hispanic in the country up in arms.''

A crucial element in enforcing a Federal statute would be the sort of
Government-issued ''counterfeit-resistant'' work permit opposed by the select
commission. Senator Simpson dismissed fears of civil libertarians on the
commission that such a permit might become a ''national identity card,'' and
said he hoped the Congress would approve one. ''Enforcement can't work without
some kind of identification,'' he said.

Though the idea of temporary alien workers was also rejected by the select
commission, some of those who favor employer sanctions, among them many
rank-and-file immigration officers, argue that some provision ought to be made
for allowing such workers into the country on a controlled basis if a need
arose.

Mr. Reagan endorsed such an approach in a campaign speech last September in
which he suggested that aliens be given visas enabling them to work in this
country ''for whatever length of time they want to stay.'' According to Mr.
Zuniga, Mr. Reagan explained more recently ''that he's in favor of doing away
with the abuses of the undocumented worker, where people don't pay their wages
and these kinds of things.''

Resentment Over Bilingualism

The temporary-worker concept is strongly opposed, however, by much of organized
labor and by Hispanic rights groups. Other critics point to the experiences of
West Germany and France, which imported millions of ''guest workers'' from
southern Europe and then found it difficult to persuade them to leave.

Besides the question of competition for jobs, there is also growing grass-roots
concern that, unlike immigrants of the 19th and early 20th centuries, many of
the newest arrivals, particularly those who speak Spanish, are less inclined to
trade their primary cultures and languages for those of their adopted country.

The resentment that this occasions is most evident in the heated debate over
bilingualism in the schools and at the polling place, and over bilingual or, as
is true in Los Angeles, multilingual (English, Spanish and Japanese) signs and
notices in public places.

But the dismay is also more fundamental, as with the growing annoyance among
non-Spanish-speaking residents of Miami who find it difficult to communicate
with the Cubans who are rapidly supplanting blacks in service jobs there. The
same linguistic frustrations can be found to a lesser extent in New York City,
with its large Puerto Rican population, in Chicago, where half a million
Mexicans and Mexican-Americans now reside, and in polyglot Los Angeles, amid the
clamor of more than 80 languages and dialects.

Incidents of Violence

In some places, cultural disparities are giving rise to racial and ethnic
tensions that have occasionally erupted in violence. Last year, boats were set
afire and a man murdered after Texas shrimpers tangled with Vietnamese
fishermen. In the suburbs of Chicago, as in cities across the Southwest, gunfire
has erupted between Mexican-Americans and illegal Mexican aliens with whom they
compete for jobs and housing.

Several of those slain by blacks in last summer's rioting in Miami were Cubans,
and in Los Angeles, where aliens from Mexico and the Far East have taken over
formerly all-black neighborhoods, gangs of black, Hispanic and Asian youths
frequently battle each other. Most disturbing of all are the recent reports from
Texas that paramilitary units of the Ku Klux Klan are training their members to
hunt illegal aliens along the border.

A central element in the select commission's proposals, and one for which there
appears to be substantial support in Congress, is the appropriation of more
money, manpower and materiel for the immigration service, whose officials feel
their mounting problems have been largely ignored by successive administrations.

Keeping unwanted aliens from its shores has never been among the highest
priorities in a nation that thinks of itself as a land of immigrants, and
because citizens and lawmakers have instinctively recoiled from adopting such
measures as border fortifications and national identity cards the immigration
enforcement system that exists today was never intended to deal with anything
like the influx that confronts it.

8 Million Arrests Since '60

In 1960, only 70,000 illegal aliens were arrested in this country.  But there
have been eight million such arrests since then, including nearly a million this
year. Because the nation's defenses have not increased at an equal pace, the
United States now finds itself largely unable to insure the security of its
borders.

There are only about 350 Border Patrol agents on duty at any one time, most of
them concentrated across from the Mexican border cities of Tijuana and Juarez.
Only five agents are assigned to patrol 3,300 square miles of heavily traversed
southern Arizona desert. The Canadian border, fast becoming a favorite crossing
point for illegal aliens, is even more sparsely guarded.

In Los Angeles, where officials estimate that one resident in 10 is an illegal
alien, the immigration service is nearing total collapse and nowhere is the
situation much better. In a report issued last month, the General Accounting
Office declared that, once inside this country, an illegal alien ''has little
chance of being located and deported.'' In an increasingly troubled world the
United States is a most attractive sanctuary for those seeking political or
economic refuge, and as the overworked, underpaid employees of the immigration
service slowly sink beneath a sea of forms, permits, petitions, applications,
visas and other documents, the aliens continue to arrive in ever-larger numbers.

It is not altogether clear how a request for more funds will be received by a
Reagan administration committed to reducing the size of the Federal Government.
But with or without more money, reforming the immigration service, Mr. Civiletti
said, promises to be ''one of the most difficult issues that the new management
of the Department of Justice will have to deal with.''

Though there have been improvements in the agency's operations, the immigration
service continues to embrace what Representative Richardson Preyer of North
Carolina recently termed ''a woeful litany of problems.''

The problems are not all of the agency's own making. A large part of the
service's inability to stem the flow of illegal aliens has arisen from
restrictions, instituted this year to facilitate the counting of illegal aliens
during the census, that prevent officers from entering a residence or workplace
to look for aliens without a hard-to-obtain court order.

The restrictions have capped what has easily been the most trying year in the
agency's history. Besides the loss of personnel siphoned off to handle the
influx of Cuban refugees to Florida and the deportations of Iranian students
ordered by President Carter in retaliation for the seizure of the American
hostages in Teheran, the service has been hampered by gasoline shortages, by the
absence, for more than 15 months, of a permanent Immigration Commissioner and by
the refusal of the Carter Administration to budget more funds for enforcement.

Most immigration officials share the view of Joseph Howerton, director of the
agency's Los Angeles office, that ''there's nothing that couldn't be
accomplished with a blank check, except perhaps sealing the border.'' But Mr.
Civiletti has insisted that until the course of the nation's immigration policy
is decided, ''large budget increases for border enforcement personnel would be
premature.''

Shortcomings of 'Body Sensors'

No one knowledgeable about the problem, including David Crosland, the Acting
Commissioner of Immigration, favors an effort to seal the Mexican border. ''Law
enforcement alone is not the answer to the problem of illegal entry,'' Mr.
Crosland said the other day. ''You don't have to have an open border or a police
state. It's a question of how much control we need to have.''

Judging from past experience, however, it is far from clear that more personnel
and hardware represent a solution. A few years ago, at great cost, the
immigration agency salted parts of the border with a network of electronic
''body sensors,'' like those implanted by the Army along the demilitarized zone
in Vietnam, in hopes that they would detect the footsteps of illegal
border-crossers. When the sensors work at all, however, they are frequently
triggered by dogs and jackrabbits.

Nor are more personnel necessarily the answer. The real expense, some officials
say, is not in catching illegal aliens but in sending them home. The Government
is spending about $13 million a year to ''repatriate'' aliens from such distant
countries as Argentina and Hong Kong, but at a time when a one-way ticket abroad
can run to $1,000 or more there are far more aliens than funds to return them.
As a result, aliens under deportation orders are often simply given a letter
directing them to leave the country on their own.

Then, too, the agency is more than an innocent victim of bureaucratic
indifference. Among other things, the agency for years has limped along with
archaic handwritten record-keeping practices that afforded it virtually no idea
how many aliens, visitors, students, immigrants, businessmen or refugees were in
the country.

For years such shortcomings made little difference to anyone but those whose
files were routinely lost or destroyed. Then, in November 1979, President
Carter, reacting to the seizure of the American hostages in Teheran, ordered the
immigration service to deport Iranians who had entered this country to study and
then had dropped out of school.

The agency was forced to admit that it had no idea how many Iranian students
were in the country or who or where they were, provoking what Justice Department
aides said was an angry outburst from Griffin B. Bell, then Attorney General,
whom they described as ''stunned'' and ''shocked'' at what he subsequently
learned about the agency's jumbled operations.

Mr. Crosland, the agency's former general counsel and its acting commissioner
for over a year, said in an interview that he had ''tried to bring some sense of
professionalism'' to the agency, and perhaps his most important undertaking has
been bringing in management experts from the Interstate Commerce Commission to
reorganize the agency's operations.

In addition to working on the critical problems of computers for record keeping,
the study team has corrected problems with finances and purchasing practices and
strengthened internal audit procedures.  But officials now say it will be six or
seven years before the agency is fully computerized.

Tainted by Corruption

As if its other problems were not enough, the growing realization among many of
the immigration agency's 10,000 employees that their task is both impossible and
thankless has bred frustration that has resulted in a degree of brutality and
corruption unmatched by any other Federal law-enforcement agency.

Four Border Patrol agents, the first ever to face such charges, were convicted
this year of having physically abused illegal aliens, and more such trials are
pending. Mr. Crosland, a former civil rights lawyer, said that while efforts by
the agency to clean its own house had resulted in ''predictable kinds of morale
problems,'' he welcomed such prosecutions in hopes that ''people will think
twice before they push people around.''

Instances of corruption have also surfaced. In October, Representative Preyer, a
Democrat who heads the House Government Operations Committee, disclosed that a
number of immigration employees were ''under investigation for selling or
altering immigration documents.'' A few weeks later, an El Paso Border Patrol
agent was arrested after offering to sell a border-crossing card for $2,000, and
three weeks ago the immigration service announced that six employees of its New
York City office had been convicted of taking bribes to ''tamper'' with
immigration records.

There has been no permanent commissioner since Mr. Castillo resigned in October
1979, with the result that at a crucial time in its history the agency has been
somewhat adrift. A high-ranking Republican Congressional aide said that ''the
first order of business'' for the new administration would be ''to get somebody
in there that can turn that place around.''

That may not prove easy. A Justice Department aide acknowledged that ''the
position is a difficult one, very unattractive,'' and Mr.  Civiletti agreed that
there had not been ''hundreds of people seeking to become I.N.S. Commissioner.''

Whatever the quality of the new commissioner, and whatever new laws are enacted,
one thing remains certain: the aliens, especially those from Mexico and the
Caribbean, where the pressure to migrate increases by the day, will continue to
try to slip into the United States.

The reasons go well beyond the reach of Congress. More than half the work force
in Mexico is unemployed or underemployed, and demographers say that the
country's population of 68 million will nearly double by the year 2000. Though
the Mexican economy is growing by 8 percent a year, the benefits of growth are
more evident in the cities than in the impoverished countryside from which most
illegal aliens come.

The waiting list of Mexican citizens wishing to legally emigrate to the United
States contains about one million names, and it can take as long as 10 years to
get a visa. On the other hand, for a few hundred dollars a potential emigre can
arrange to be smuggled into the United States in a matter of days.

There are a few arguments for keeping things as they are, among them the
suggestion that the continuing northward flow of Mexico's poorest people
provides a ''safety valve'' against the possibility of a leftist revolution
there of the sort that recently occurred in Nicaragua.

Another theory holds that, to the extent that world resources are unevenly
distributed, exporting labor from a nation rich in human capital to a neighbor
blessed with natural and industrial wealth maximizes the benefits for both in
the long run. The debate in Congress may turn on whether, in the short run, the
United States owes more to the disadvantaged peoples of the world than to its
own.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                               The New York Times

               December 29, 1980, Monday, Late City Final Edition

CURB URGED FOR ALIENS IN U.S. SEEKING CITIZENSHIP

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 16, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 811 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28


David W. Crosland, Acting Commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization
Service, says that aliens in the United States who wish to become permanent
residents should be required to return to their home countries and apply from
those countries unless the aliens are closely related to American citizens.

Mr. Crosland said in an interview that such a requirement would not only reduce
the backlog of petitions pending before the immigration service but also would
discourage illegal aliens from working in this country while they applied for
permanent resident status.

Many aliens, he said, manipulate the immigration laws by entering the United
States as visitors or students, getting jobs and then staying here indefinitely.
In this way, he said, the aliens already here gain an unfair advantage over
their countrymen waiting in line at home for immigrant visas.

Permanent resident status is the first step toward citizenship.  Permanent
residents have most of the legal rights of citizens, but may not vote.  103,638
Aliens Applied

In 1978, the last year for which data are available, Mr. Crosland said, there
were 103,638 applications for permanent resident status from aliens, not
counting refugees. If, as Mr. Crosland proposed, only close relatives of United
States citizens were allowed to adjust their status, that would eliminate 53
percent of the applications. If close relatives of citizens and permanent
residents were eligible, Mr. Crosland said, the workload would be eased by 35
percent.

Mr. Crosland acknowledged in the interview Friday that his proposal would shift
a substantial burden from the immigration service to the State Department's
consular officers, who would presumably get more applications for immigrant
visas.

The immigration service handles applications from aliens in the United States,
who have extensive rights of appeal before immigration judges and in the Federal
courts. State Department employees review similar requests made through American
embassies and consulates abroad, and the decision of a consular officer, to
grant or refuse a visa, is usually final.

An alien who enters the United States with an immigrant visa has permanent
resident status and is eligible to become a citizen after five years of
continuous residence here.

Criticism of Proposal

Elizabeth J. Harper, a State Department official, said that Mr.  Crosland's
proposal would ''create unnecessary work for consular posts overseas'' and
''genuine hardship'' for the aliens involved.  Cornelius D. Scully, another
State Department official, said that the proposal would require ''bureaucratic
nonsense'' and would lead to ''great pressures from members of Congress to make
exceptions'' for particular aliens who were present in the United States.
Similar restrictions have not worked well in the past, he said.

In theory, aliens are subject to the same substantive requirements, whether they
apply for an immigrant visa from abroad or from within the United States.

But Verne Jervis, a spokesman for the immigration service, said that an alien
already here ''very definitely has an advantage'' because he can more easily
obtain a job, buy property, make investments and establish other interests in
this country that weigh in his favor.

Mr. Jervis said there were cases in which aliens used their presences here to
find American spouses, promptly obtained permanent resident status and then
dissolved the marriages. There is no quota limiting the number of aliens who can
become permanent residents through marriage to American citizens. But
immigration officials said that they would not grant permanent resident status
if they suspected that the marriage had been arranged for a fraudulent purpose.

The Select Commission on Immigration and Refugee Policy, a 16-member panel
created by Congress, may recommend some restriction such as that favored by Mr.
Crosland. The commission's staff suggested such a change, but at its last
meeting, the commission rejected the proposal by a vote of 6 to 5. Votes yet to
be cast by other commission members could change the result.

Before 1952, aliens generally had to leave the United States before they could
apply for permanent resident status. A 1952 law established a procedure under
which citizens of Eastern Hemisphere countries and some natives of the Western
Hemisphere could become permanent residents without first returning home.
Congress in 1965 prohibited Western Hemisphere natives from adjusting their
status and then removed the prohibition in 1976.

Israel Immigration Unit Curtails Vienna Efforts

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 6, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 298 words

DATELINE: TEL AVIV, Jan. 6


The official Israeli agency that handles the immigration of Soviet Jews to
Israel said today that it was curtailing its activities in Vienna because of a
dispute with the Austrian authorities.

The organization, the Jewish Agency, accused the Austrian Government of
violating a longstanding agreement giving the agency exclusive access to Soviet
Jews arriving in Vienna. It said that because the Austrians allowed other
organizations to get in touch with the Soviet emigrants, who had been traveling
with visas to Israel, many had been persuaded to go to countries other than
Israel.

The Jewish Agency said it was dropping its use of hostels in Vienna provided by
the Austrian authorities and moving the occupants to hotels. The agency's
representative in Vienna, Baruch Minkowitz, said the Ministry of Interior hung
signs in the hostel Tuesday referring Soviet emigrants wishing to go to
countries other than Israel to a room in the hostel to meet a representative of
the Austrian Red Cross.

The signs, in Russian, gave the addresses and telephone numbers of six
organizations that might help them. The groups included Rav Tov, a Hasidic
anti-Zionist organization in the United States; the World Council of Churches,
and the Tolstoy Foundation of anti-C@ommunist Russians.

In a statement issued in Jerusalem this afternoon, Aryeh Dulzin, chairman of the
Jewish Agency and the World Zionist Organization, said the Austrians had leased
the premises exclusively to the Jewish Agency.

The Austrian move appeared to be a response to Israeli actions to reduce the
rate, estimated to be as high as 85 percent, of emigrants who go to countries
other than Israel.
