                August 28, 1981, Friday, Late City Final Edition

GAINS FOR AMERICANS WHO WORK ABROAD

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON

SECTION: Section D; Page 1, Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1894 words


If there was ever a time to live and work abroad, it is now - at least the tax
experts say so. The new tax law will usher into effect on Jan. 1 some of the
most favorable provisions for taxing expatriates in 20 years.

Because the new law is expected to result in lower costs to companies with
employees working abroad, it is expected to lead to a spurt in overseas job
opportunities for Americans, in a dramatic reversal of the shrinkage of the last
few years.

''I have no doubt that there will be more hiring of Americans to work abroad,
both by American companies and by foreign employers,'' said Gilbert Dwyer, a
partner at Ward Howell International, an executive recruiting firm.

Beginning next year, Americans will be allowed to exclude from American income
taxes up to $75,000 of income earned abroad. That exclusion will rise by $5,000
a year until it reaches $95,000 in 1986. Expatriates may also be able to exclude
some of their foreign housing costs from American taxes, provided they meet
certain qualifications.

Varied Effects

How these changes will affect people now working overseas depends largely on
their individual circumstances, particularly on how their employers treat tax
payments now and on the taxes in the countries in which they work.

''As a general rule, the new law should offer a significant reduction in United
States taxes for many Americans overseas,'' said Robert H. Castles, director of
expatriate services at Arthur Young & Company, the accounting firm.

But, he and others noted, the many individuals whose employers already pay for
their higher tax costs will probably see little change. It has become the norm
among most major companies with employees abroad to pay not only the extra costs
of living abroad - such as housing and schooling and foreign taxes - but also
the taxes on the extra income these sums represent. In these cases, the
companies will benefit.

''From our employees' point of view, this bill is neither here nor there,'' said
George J. Clark, executive vice president at Citibank.  ''We have picked up the
tax burden, and will also pick up the benefit. The individual will not really be
affected.''

Even in such companies, however, individuals may find it worthwhile to examine
the new tax rules. For while the new provisions deal directly with foreign
earned income, they will indirectly affect other portions of people's tax bills.


Lower Investment Income Tax

For example, expatriates are likely to find their investment income taxed at
lower rates under the new law, but they may also find that they are barred from
putting money into tax-free Individual Retirement Accounts or from taking the
new marriage deduction, if they no longer have any earned income taxed in the
United States.  These are areas that tax experts hope will be clarified further
through regulations.

In any case, the lower cost of supporting an American abroad is expected to
translate into more jobs overseas being filled by Americans.

One tax executive at a major New York corporation who asked not to be identified
estimated that the current cost of supporting an American with a salary of
$30,000 a year in a foreign country was about $120,000, including salary,
housing, education, home leave and taxes. Taxes would amount to about $45,000,
he said.

''We anticipate that there will be a real increase in the number of United
States workers abroad,'' said Miles Bresee, manager of taxes at the Bechtel
Group, a San Francisco-based engineering and construction company with a sizable
overseas business.

''Not only will we be able to afford to put more American workers on our present
jobs, but we can be more competitive, and that should generate more new jobs.''

Some companies have already expressed an interest in sending more Americans
abroad, although such plans are not universal.

Whittaker Plans Increase

Joseph F. Alibrandi, president of the Whittaker Corporation of Los Angeles, for
example, has said that he plans to increase substantially the proportion of
Americans in his company's foreign work force under the more favorable tax
provisions. Currently, Americans constitute only about 10 or 15 percent of the
3,000 people Whittaker uses abroad in managing hospitals. The company hopes to
raise that figure to approximately half.

Citibank, too, expects to send more Americans abroad. ''Before, if we had a
Frenchman and an American who were equal in every way, we had to choose the
Frenchman for tax reasons,'' Mr. Clark said. ''Now that bias is removed. Over
time, we will have more Americans working abroad than we would have otherwise.''

But at the Chase Manhattan Bank, Walter Lamp, a vice president in the tax
department, cautioned, ''Taxes are only one of our costs of doing business. We
could now have room to put more people overseas, or we could make other
adjustments, such as becoming more competitive.''

American companies are not the only ones viewing American workers with new
interest. Mr. Dwyer, who specializes in recruiting for positions in the Middle
East, said that foreign employers - both business and government - were also
looking at the American labor market from a new perspective. One of his Saudi
Arabian clients has already expressed possible interest in hiring more
Americans, he said, as a result of the tax changes.

Complex List of Variables

For individuals who are working abroad or considering the possibility, the new
rules, which permit broad exclusions of income and housing costs from American
taxes, are in many ways easier than the provisions they are replacing. The old
law, effective since 1978, determined expatriate taxes by considering a long and
complex list of variables, including the country of residence, the size of
housing and schooling expenses, and the costs incurred in home leave.

To be eligible for the new foreign income exclusions, an individual must meet
one of two tests. The first calls for residence in a foreign country for one
full taxable year - a test that has not changed under the new law. (A person who
moves in the middle of a calendar year may - with permission - extend his tax
filing for the year until the residence test is met. The foreign income rules,
however, would apply only to the portion of the year spent abroad.)

The second test calls for being physically present in a country for 11 months
out of any 12-month period. The test in the old law required physical presence
in a foreign country for 17 out of 18 months.

People who meet the requirements of one of these tests may choose to protect
some of their foreign income from American taxes. Tax advisers caution, however,
that, while such exclusions are usually helpful, they are not best for everyone.

Each individual with income earned abroad may exclude up to $75,000 of that
income from American taxes next year. That figure will rise by $5,000 a year
until it reaches $95,000 in 1986. Income earned on investments, even foreign
investments, may not be excluded. However, because of the exclusion, many
expatriates will find their investment income being taxed at lower tax brackets.


Housing Cost Level Set

Expatriates may also be able to exclude or deduct housing costs over and above a
certain level, which Congress set equal to 16 percent of the salary of a United
States Government employee at the GS-14 Step 1 level. That means that next year,
individuals working abroad may shelter housing costs above $6,059. That figure
will rise as Government salaries increase.

However, tax experts say that the housing exclusion combined with the income
exclusion may not exceed an expatriate's foreign earned income. There is a fair
amount of confusion among tax experts on the circumstances when an employee
could or would take the housing benefit. Treasury Department regulations are
expected to clear up this area.

Despite the more favorable American tax policy, expatriates in certain countries
will still face foreign taxes. Those who are able to shelter all of their earned
income from American taxes may not credit any of their foreign taxes against
their American taxes. Those with earned incomes larger than the earned income
exclusion - $75,000 next year - will be allowed to credit some, but not all, of
that foreign tax against their American tax bill.

Regulations are still being written on exactly how that deduction will work. It
is expected, however, that it will be handled on some kind of proportionate
basis. An individual who earned $100,000 abroad, and excluded $75,000, would
still be required to pay American taxes on $25,000. Therefore, he would probably
be allowed to credit against his American taxes the portion of his foreign tax
bill attributable to that $25,000.

''The idea is to eliminate double taxation, not to create double benefits,''
said John R. Raedel, a partner at Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co. ''In cases where
a person is faced with foreign taxes higher than his American tax liability
would be, the expatriate is really in no better position tomorrow than
yesterday,'' Mr. Raedel said.

But, he cautioned people in countries where tax rates are higher than in the
United States: ''There is a limit on the amount of foreign taxes that you can
credit to your American taxes in any one year. It may not exceeed the American
tax you would owe on your income earned abroad. But you can carry the credit
back two years and forward five years to be used as a credit.''

So, for example, an employee who found his foreign salary subject to $50,000 in
taxes in the United States and $65,000 in his host country could take a $50,000
credit against his American taxes but could not take all $65,000, which would
have left the Treasury owing him $15,000. He could possibly take the remaining
$15,000 as a credit in the future.

Because of these rules on foreign taxes, it may sometimes pay for expatriates
not to use the exclusions that are available. Tax experts say some Americans
abroad may be better off being allowed to subtract all of their foreign taxes
from their American taxes and to carry the credits back and forward at will.
Once employees use the exclusions, if they then opt out, they may not use the
exclusions again for five years without special permission from the Treasury
Department.

''The decision not to elect the exclusions is probably atypical, but not so rare
that you should automatically ignore it,'' Mr. Raedel said.

And, Mr. Castles added: ''If you have to transfer from country to country,
particularly countries with different tax structures, you are going to find it
more difficult to plan the best tax results.  Under the new law, the emphasis
for expatriates has changed from dual country tax planning to foreign country
tax planning. Now it will pay for expatriates to concentrate on reducing their
foreign taxes.''
The New Tax Law: Eighth article of a series appearing periodically.

TYPE: series

                October 4, 1981, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

THE DOMESTIC POLICY STAFF IS DIFFERENT UNDER REAGAN

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

SECTION: Section 4; Page 2, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1132 words


WASHINGTON IF President Reagan has adhered more closely to his campaign promises
than other chief executives, the credit goes at least in part to the White
House's intellectual-in-residence, Martin C.  Anderson. As chief domestic policy
adviser, Mr. Anderson keeps an eye on emerging policies to insure that they
conform with Mr. Reagan's views.

Curiously, the conservative, 45-year-old economist is less visible now than he
was as issues adviser in the 1980 Presidential campaign.  Whenever possible, Mr.
Anderson seeks to orchestrate agreement among departments and agencies. As he
put it last week, he would prefer to present the President with a full list of
options, honestly stated, than to impose his own views on the final decisions.
Perhaps in consequence, he has not emerged as a leading public spokesman for the
Administration.

Mr. Ande rso n brings to his job a passionately held libertarian, free-market,
free-trade philosophy. He resisted efforts to protect the American auto industry
by setting quotas for imported Japanese cars. On immi gration issues, he tended
to oppose criminal penalties for employers hiring illegal aliens, on the ground
that they were an undesirable f orm of Government intervention in the
marketplace. He strongly supp orted the admission of guest workers from Mexico.
''If there is a Me xican citizen who wants to come to work in the United States
for a temporary period of time, pay taxes and stay out of trouble, I do n't see
anything wrong with that, especially if he learns the En glish language,'' Mr.
Anderson said.
An Understated Influence

Colleagues say that Mr. Anderson's self-effacing description of his current role
probably understates his influence. But it does reflect a reality. Mr. Reagan
has expressed himself so forcefully on so many issues for so long that his
policy analysts have less latitude for adventurous, creative thinking than did
President Carter's.

''We know where Reagan has been, what he's said, what the history is,'' Mr.
Anderson said. ''As long as the departments and agencies are moving in that
direction, excellent. We do not want to fight with them. It is very easy for the
White House staff to get into a position where you begin to compete with the
departments and agencies and you look at them as adversaries. That is the
dumbest thing in the world.'' He favors, he said, a kind of political
''jujitsu,'' using the staff of various agencies to do the work and analysis
necessary to achieve the President's policy objectives. His ''ideal form of
government,'' he added, ''is one that functions so efficiently and effortlessly
that you don't even know it exists.''

Mr. Anderson reports to Mr. Reagan through Edwin Meese 3d, the President's
counsellor, while his counterpart in the Carter Administration, Stuart E.
Eizenstat, reported to the President directly, and some members of Congress and
interest groups that put pressure on Mr. Eizenstat now focus their attention on
Mr. Meese.

But Mr. Anderson seems to feel comfortable with his role as intellectual
gatekeeper. A man who set out to be an engineer and never intended to be in
politics, he has had political experience, as research director for Richard
Nixon's Pres idential campaign in 1968, then became deputy to Arthur F. Burns w
hen Mr. Burns was counsellor to the President for domestic affa irs. In 1971, he
joined the Hoover Institution at Stanford University , the think tank from which
Mr. Reagan drew many aides and advisers . Mr. Anderson has been associated with
Mr. Reagan since 1975, has an easy relationship with him and sees the President
four or five times a week on business.

In his economic views, Mr. Anderson is neither a monetarist nor a doctrinaire
supply-sider. ''I don't consider myself to be in any of those schools,'' he
said, though he finds much to agree with in both.

Mr. Anderson presides over the formulation of policy on all domestic issues,
ranging from agriculture to the military draft to the Voting Rights Act to the
economy. But his specialty is welfare.  In a book so titled three years ago, he
drew a blueprint of Reagan Administration policy, saying that welfare payments
should go only to ''needy'' people, those who, through no fault of their own,
are unable to care for themselves or their families. The work, studded with
quotations from Voltaire, Machiavelli and John Stuart Mill, started with this
thesis: ''The 'war on poverty' that began in 1964 has been won. The growth of
jobs and income in the private economy, combined with an explosive increase in
Government spending for welfare and income transfer programs, has virtually
eliminated poverty in the United States.''

The budget for the fiscal year that began last week reflected that philosophy,
reducing Government benefits for millions of poor people who receive welfare,
food stamps, Medicaid and other social services.

The mechanism for setting such policies in the Reagan Administration consists of
five Cabinet councils in which selected Cabinet officers debate issues of common
concern - economic affairs, human services, food and agriculture, commerce and
trade, natural resources and the environment. Each council is staffed by
representatives of Mr. Anderson's office and the Office of Management and
Budget, of which his wife, Annelise Anderson, is an associate director. On a few
issues such as immigration, Mr. and Mrs. Anderson have pressed similar points of
view, reinforcing each other's arguments with a persistence that others find
difficult to resist.

The councils reflect Mr. Reagan's desire for Cabinet government and represent a
departure from Carter Administration practice. ''We tended to have inter-agency
groups only on an ad hoc basis, as necessary,'' Mr. Eizenstat has said. ''It was
not a permanent feature of our organizational structure.''

In the end, Mr. Anderson is not a political tactician or legislative strategist.
He is rather a theoretician who provides intellectual underpinnings for Mr.
Reaga n's positions, and one who isaware that so me members of his staff would
prefer to see the office take a more a ggressive role in developing and
promoting new programs.But that, he says, is not the mission the President wants
them to perform.

                 July 6, 1980, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

MORE GREEKS RETURN THAN EMIGRATE NOW

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 11, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 753 words

DATELINE: ATHENS, July 5


Since Odysseus roamed the world, Greeks have been reputed to be international
wanderers seeking better fortunes abroad than their poor homeland could offer.
For the last few years, however, they have been reversing the pattern and coming
home.

Statistics from the Ministry of Economic Coordination show not only that Greece
is no longer exporting its labor to the industrial centers of the West but also
that it is having to import migrant workers from third-world countries. The
exception is the United States, where Greeks have gone to stay.

''Since 1974 the rate of return has been larger than that of departure, a rare
development in terms of Greek social history,'' says Michael Papadakis of the
Ministry of Economic Coordination.  ''This is due as much to the slowdown in the
development pace and increased unemployment in the advanced Western countries
that received most of the Greek workers as to the growing needs of the Greek
employment market, which has needed more qualified workers.''

Quarter of Migrants Return

Greece has a population of nine million, and Foreign Ministry statistics show an
additional four million abroad, nearly three million of them in the United
States. More than three million of the total are classified as permanent
citizens of their host countries.  Of the 800,000 Greeks counted as migrant
workers, nearly a quarter have returned in the last six years.

The turning point was 1974, when for the first time since statistics began to be
compiled in 1850 more Greeks came home than emigrated - 24,476 compared with
24,448. While emigration reached a peak of 117,167 in 1965, with 12,000 to the
United States, it dropped to fewer than 20,000 in 1978.

As a consequence emigrants' remittances to their families here, which as of 1955
constituted the largest source of income, have since 1974 been exceeded by
shipping and then by tourism. In 1979 such remittances totaled $1.2 billion,
compared with $1.7 billion received from tourism and $1.5 billion from shipping.

Official statistics from the United States Embassy show that the number of Greek
emigrants to the United States has also dropped steadily, from a peak of 14,800
in 1969 to 3,500 in 1979. At the same time the repatriation rate from the United
States has remained low - 1,500 in 1969 and fewer than 1,000 in 1979, compared
with a high of 1,928 in 1976.

They Went to U.S. to Stay

''When Greeks migrated to Western Europe they went largely with the purpose of
working, making some money and then returning home,'' said Prof. Marios Raphel,
a Greek delegate at the Inter-European Migration Committee of the Council of
Europe. ''But when they went to the United States, they went to stay.''

American Embassy officials say migration to the United States is much greater
than statistics here show, since many migrate from intermediate countries or
originally go as students. They stay because their earnings are higher than in
Greece and because managerial and technological skills cannot be absorbed by the
Greek market.

Government officials say Greece is benefiting from the return of workers from
abroad, both from the availability of more skilled personnel for a developing
economy and from the transfer of savings, estimated to total several billion
dollars.

In the case of West Germany, where the number of migrant Greek workers and
family members has dropped from 400,000 to 280,000 in the last decade, the
desire to return has coincided with rising unemployment.

Greek Unemployment Low

Two factors in Greece facilitating the repatriation, which is taking place
without any visible reintegration problems, have been high growth rates and low
unemployment. Though both these healthy trends are yielding to the oil crisis,
the last decade saw average growth rates of 5 to 6 percent, double Western
Europe's, and only 2 percent unemployment.

Economic development and expectations have risen so fast that people no longer
want to do the menial and unskilled jobs they once would even emigrate to get.
Consequently, unskilled workers from third-world countries have been brought in,
especially for lowranking positions in the giant merchant fleet.

While three years ago such unskilled foreign migrants permanently resident in
Greece reached 40,000, the slowdown in development has led Greece to expel many,
so the total stands at 22,000. But the Greek fleet, which employs 168,000, still
has 15,000 places to fill, according to Anthony Chandris, president of the Greek
Shipowners Association.
